['What else was interesting in the passage?', '(80~km)~–~(20~km)}}{\\text{(40~min)~–~(10~min)}} \\\\\nm & = & \\frac{\\text{60~km}}{\\text{30~min}} \\\\\nm & = & {\\text{2}\\text{.0~km/min}\\text{.}} \\\\\n\\end{matrix}\\]$$']
['What is the equation for t?', 'The formula  $$\\(y = mx + b\\)$$  only applies to linear relationships, or ones that produce a straight line.']
['What kind of line is the quadratic relationship?', 'Another common type of line in physics is the quadratic relationship, which occurs when one of the variables is squared.']

['What is an example of a quadratic relationship in physics?', 'One quadratic relationship in physics is the relation between the speed of an object its centripetal acceleration, which is used to determine the force needed to keep an object moving in a circle.']
['What is another kind of relationship?', 'Another common relationship in physics is the inverse relationship, in which one variable decreases whenever the other variable increases.']
['What is an example of that?', 'An example in physics is Coulomb’s law.']
['What does that law say?', 'As the distance between two charged objects increases, the electrical force between the two charged objects decreases.']
['What is another inverse relationship?', 'Inverse proportionality, such the relation between x and y in the equation']
['What is a function with a special type of inverse relationship?', 'for some number k, is one particular kind of inverse relationship.']

['What type of inverse relationship is this?', 'A third commonly-seen relationship is the exponential relationship, in which a change in the independent variable produces a proportional change in the dependent variable.']
['What is the proportional change in the dependent variable?', 'As the value of the dependent variable gets larger, its rate of growth also increases.']
['What are some examples of exponential relationships?', 'For example, bacteria often reproduce at an exponential rate when grown under ideal conditions.']
['How is this example relevant?', 'As each generation passes, there are more and more bacteria to reproduce.']
['Why is this beneficial?', 'As a result, the growth rate of the bacterial population increases every generation.']
['What is a logarithmic scale?', 'Sometimes a variable can have a very large range of values.']
['What might a variable have a very large range of values?', 'This presents a problem when you’re trying to figure out the best scale to use for your graph’s axes.']
['What are the options for a logarithmic scale?', 'One option is to use a logarithmic (log) scale.']
['What is the value of each mark on a logarithmic scale?', 'In a logarithmic scale, the value each mark labels is the previous mark’s value multiplied by some constant.']
['What does it multiply by?', 'For a log base 10 scale, each mark labels a value that is 10 times the value of the mark before it.']
['What are the numbers on a base 10 logarithmic scale?', 'Therefore, a base 10 logarithmic scale would be numbered: 0, 10, 100, 1,000, etc.']

['What is the advantage of using logarithmic scales?', 'You can see how the logarithmic scale covers a much larger range of values than the corresponding linear scale, in which the marks would label the values 0, 10, 20, 30, and so on.']
['What is the first concept that you have a hard time explaining?', 'If you use a logarithmic scale on one axis of the graph and a linear scale on the other axis, you are using a semi-log plot.']
['What type of graphs do scientists use to measure the strength of earthquakes?', 'The Richter scale, which measures the strength of earthquakes, uses a semi-log plot.']

['How do you find the intensity level of an earthquake?', 'The degree of ground movement is plotted on a logarithmic scale against the assigned intensity level of the earthquake, which ranges linearly from 1-10 (Figure 1.29 (a)).']
['What type of plots do log-log charts make?', 'If a graph has both axes in a logarithmic scale, then it is referred to as a log-log plot.']

['What is the relationship between the wavelength and frequency of electromagnetic radiation such as light usually shown as?', 'The relationship between the wavelength and frequency of electromagnetic radiation such as light is usually shown as a log-log plot (Figure 1.29 (b)).']
['What other types of log-log plots are used?', 'Log-log plots are also commonly used to describe exponential functions, such as radioactive decay.']
['What is the definition of motion?', 'Our study of physics opens with kinematics—the study of motion without considering its causes.']
['What are the causes of motion?', 'Objects are in motion everywhere you look.']
['What does motion mean?', 'Everything from a tennis game to a space-probe flyby of the planet Neptune involves motion.']
['What happens when your heart is moving?', 'When you are resting, your heart moves blood through your veins.']
['What are some things that are always moving?', 'Even in inanimate objects, atoms are always moving.']
['What is the location of an object at any particular time called?', 'The location of an object at any particular time is its position.']
['What else is important about the definition of position?', 'More precisely, you need to specify its position relative to a convenient reference frame.']
['What is a reference frame?', 'Earth is often used as a reference frame, and we often describe the position of an object as it relates to stationary objects in that reference frame.']

['What other objects are stationary in reference frame?', 'For example, a rocket launch would be described in terms of the position of the rocket with respect to Earth as a whole, while a professor’s position could be described in terms of where she is in relation to the nearby white board.']
['What is another example of a reference frame?', 'In other cases, we use reference frames that are not stationary but are in motion relative to Earth.']
['Do all reference frames have to be earth based?', 'To describe the position of a person in an airplane, for example, we use the airplane, not Earth, as the reference frame.']
['What is another example of a symbiotic relationship?', '(See Figure 2.2.)']

['What are the other two factors in determining position?', "Thus, you can only know how fast and in what direction an object's position is changing against a background of something else that is either not moving or moving with a known speed and direction."]
['What is the coordinate system from which the positions of objects are described?', 'The reference frame is the coordinate system from which the positions of objects are described.']
['What are the four parts of a triangle?', 'Your classroom can be used as a reference frame.']
['What happens to the walls in your classroom?', 'In the classroom, the walls are not moving.']
['What happens to you as you walk?', 'Your motion as you walk to the door, can be measured against the stationary background of the classroom walls.']
['How can you tell if others are moving?', 'You can also tell if other things in the classroom are moving, such as your classmates entering the classroom or a book falling off a desk.']
['What direction do you think the book is moving?', 'You can also tell in what direction something is moving in the classroom.']
['What can you say about the teacher?', 'You might say, “The teacher is moving toward the door.”']
['What can you do to determine direction?', 'Your reference frame allows you to determine not only that something is moving but also the direction of motion.']
['What is motion?', 'You could also serve as a reference frame for others’ movement.']
['What does that mean?', 'If you remained seated as your classmates left the room, you would measure their movement away from your stationary location.']
['What can you say about the reference frame?', 'If you and your classmates left the room together, then your perspective of their motion would be change.']
['What would you do if you were the reference frame?', 'You, as the reference frame, would be moving in the same direction as your other moving classmates.']
['What can you tell me about the reference frame?', 'As you will learn in the Snap Lab, your description of motion can be quite different when viewed from different reference frames.']
['What can you tell me about the article?', 'As we study the motion of objects, we must first be able to describe the object’s position.']
['What is a good example of a good example?', 'Before your parent drives you to school, the car is sitting in your driveway.']
['What is the driveway used for?', 'Your driveway is the starting position for the car.']
['Why is that?', 'When you reach your high school, the car has changed position.']
['What is the new position of the school?', 'Its new position is your school.']
['What do physicists use variables to represent?', 'Physicists use variables to represent terms.']
['What is d used for?', 'We will use d to represent car’s position.']
['What is subscript used for?', 'We will use a subscript to differentiate between the initial position, d0, and the final position, df.']
['What else is important about variables?', 'In addition, vectors, which we will discuss later, will be in bold or will have an arrow above the variable.']
['What else can you tell me about variables?', 'Scalars will be italicized.']
['What can you tell me about Distance vs. Displacement?', "Now imagine driving from your house to a friend's house located several kilometers away."]
['How long does it take to drive to the store?', 'The distance an object moves is the length of the path between its initial position and its final position.']
['What does distance vs. displacement mean?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house depends on your path."]
['Do the equation of a line have to be straight?', 'As shown in Figure 2.5, distance is different from the length of a straight line between two points.']
['Why is this?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house is probably longer than the straight line between the two houses."]
['What is the difference between a position and a position?', 'We often want to be more precise when we talk about position.']
['What is the description of an object’s motion often includes more than just the distance it moves?', 'The description of an object’s motion often includes more than just the distance it moves.']
['What is an example of distance traveled?', 'For instance, if it is a five kilometer drive to school, the distance traveled is 5 kilometers.']
['How would you calculate the displacement of a car?', 'After dropping you off at school and driving back home, your parent will have traveled a total distance of 10 kilometers.']
['What will happen to the car and your parent after the drive?', 'The car and your parent will end up in the same starting position in space.']
['What is the net change in position of an object?', 'The net change in position of an object is its displacement, or  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{d}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What does the Greek letter delta mean?', 'The Greek letter delta,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\)$$, means change in.']
['What is the relation between distance and displacement?', 'If you are describing only your drive to school, then the distance traveled and the displacement are the same—5 kilometers.']
['How do distance and displacement differ?', 'When you are describing the entire round trip, distance and displacement are different.']
['What are the differences between distance and displacement?', 'When you describe distance, you only include the magnitude, the size or amount, of the distance traveled.']
['What do you include when describing displacement?', 'However, when you describe the displacement, you take into account both the magnitude of the change in position and the direction of movement.']

['What did you find most interesting about this?', 'In our previous example, the car travels a total of 10 kilometers, but it drives five of those kilometers forward toward school and five of those kilometers back in the opposite direction.']

['What is the result of adding the forward direction and the opposite direction?', 'If we ascribe the forward direction a positive (+) and the opposite direction a negative (–), then the two quantities will cancel each other out when added together.']

['What are the differences between displacement and distance?', 'A quantity, such as distance, that has magnitude (i.e., how big or how much) but does not take into account direction is called a scalar.']
['What is a quantity that has both magnitude and direction?', 'A quantity, such as displacement, that has both magnitude and direction is called a vector.']
['I have asked you the following questions: what are distance and displacement?', 'Hopefully you now understand the conceptual difference between distance and displacement.']
['Can you help me understand the meaning of these concepts?', 'Understanding concepts is half the battle in physics.']
['What is the other half of physics?', 'The other half is math.']
['What is the math of physics?', 'A stumbling block to new physics students is trying to wade through the math of physics while also trying to understand the associated concepts.']
['What is the result of this struggle?', 'This struggle may lead to misconceptions and answers that make no sense.']
['Can you explain this further?', 'Once the concept is mastered, the math is far less confusing.']
['What is the most important thing to understand about displacement?', 'So let’s review and see if we can make sense of displacement in terms of numbers and equations.']
['How can displacement be calculated?', "You can calculate an object's displacement by subtracting its original position, d0, from its final position df."]
['What does this mean?', 'In math terms that means']
['How do we determine these quantities?', 'To assign numbers and/or direction to these quantities, we need to define an axis with a positive and a negative direction.']

['In Figure 2.6, the axis is in a straight line with home at zero', 'We also need to define an origin, or O. In Figure 2.6, the axis is in a straight line with home at zero and school in the positive direction.']
['What is the positive direction?', 'If we left home and drove the opposite way from school, motion would have been in the negative direction.']
['What would you have assigned it?', 'We would have assigned it a negative value.']
['How are the two quantities related?', 'In the round-trip drive, df and d0 were both at zero kilometers.']
['What is the opposite of df?', 'In the one way trip to school, df was at 5 kilometers and d0 was at zero km.']
['How do we find out this distance?', 'So,  $$\\(\\Delta\\mathbf{d}\\)$$  was 5 kilometers.']
['What is the relationship between distance and displacement?', 'There is more to motion than distance and displacement.']
['What is involved in motion?', 'Questions such as, “How long does a foot race take?” and “What was the runner’s speed?” cannot be answered without an understanding of other concepts.']
['What other concepts will we look at in this section?', 'In this section we will look at time, speed, and velocity to expand our understanding of motion.']
['What is the description of how fast or slow an object moves called?', 'A description of how fast or slow an object moves is its speed.']
['What is speed used for?', 'Speed is the rate at which an object changes its location.']
['What does speed mean?', 'Like distance, speed is a scalar because it has a magnitude but not a direction.']
['What does speed depend on?', 'Because speed is a rate, it depends on the time interval of motion.']

['What is the difference between the end time and the beginning time?', 'You can calculate the elapsed time or the change in time,  $$\\(\\Delta t\\)$$, of motion as the difference between the ending time and the beginning time']
['What do you mean by average?', "When you describe an object's speed, you often describe the average over a time period."]
['What is the distance traveled divided by the time during which the motion occurs?', 'Average speed, vavg, is the distance traveled divided by the time during which the motion occurs.']
['What are the important things I need to know about this?', 'Suppose, for example, a car travels 150 kilometers in 3.2 hours.']
['What does the car travel at?', 'Its average speed for the trip is']
['What is an example of this in practice?', "A car's speed would likely increase and decrease many times over a 3.2 hour trip."]
['What is important to know about the distance/time formula?', 'Its speed at a specific instant in time, however, is its instantaneous speed.']
["What does a car's speedometer mean?", "A car's speedometer describes its instantaneous speed."]
['What is the vector version of speed?', 'The vector version of speed is velocity.']
['What does velocity describe?', 'Velocity describes the speed and direction of an object.']
['What does it describe?', 'As with speed, it is useful to describe either the average velocity over a time period or the velocity at a specific moment.']
['What is the average velocity of a moving object?', 'Average velocity is displacement divided by the time over which the displacement occurs.']
['What is a vector?', 'Velocity, like speed, has SI units of meters per second (m/s), but because it is a vector, you must also include a direction.']

['What else is interesting?', 'Furthermore, the variable v for velocity is bold because it is a vector, which is in contrast to the variable v for speed which is italicized because it is a scalar quantity.']
['What is the question that you have for your teacher?', 'Suppose a passenger moved toward the back of a plane with an average velocity of –4 m/s.']
['How did the passenger get to the back of the plane?', 'We cannot tell from the average velocity whether the passenger stopped momentarily or backed up before he got to the back of the plane.']
['What is the next step?', 'To get more details, we must consider smaller segments of the trip over smaller time intervals such as those shown in Figure 2.9.']
['What is the next step?', 'If you consider infinitesimally small intervals, you can define instantaneous velocity, which is the velocity at a specific instant in time.']
['Are there any other factors that affect instantaneous velocity?', 'Instantaneous velocity and average velocity are the same if the velocity is constant.']
['Is there anything else that you have to do?', 'Earlier, you have read that distance traveled can be different than the magnitude of displacement.']
['How does this relate to the speed?', 'In the same way, speed can be different than the magnitude of velocity.']
['What are some examples of a time limit?', 'For example, you drive to a store and return home in half an hour.']
['How would you calculate the distance between you and the store?', 'If your car’s odometer shows the total distance traveled was 6 km, then your average speed was 12 km/h.']
['How does this compare to your average velocity?', 'Your average velocity, however, was zero because your displacement for the round trip is zero.']
['Are there any other important things to know about the material?', 'A graph, like a picture, is worth a thousand words.']
['What can you tell me about the graph?', 'Graphs not only contain numerical information, they also reveal relationships between physical quantities.']
['What are you investigating in this section?', 'In this section, we will investigate kinematics by analyzing graphs of position over time.']
['What axes are perpendicular?', 'Graphs in this text have perpendicular axes, one horizontal and the other vertical.']

['What is the difference between horizontal and vertical?', 'When two physical quantities are plotted against each other, the horizontal axis is usually considered the independent variable, and the vertical axis is the dependent variable.']
['Are there any other important things to know?', 'In algebra, you would have referred to the horizontal axis as the x-axis and the vertical axis as the y-axis.']

['What are rise and run?', 'The rise is the change in position, (i.e., displacement) and the run is the change in time.']
['What is the formula for a relationship?', 'This relationship can also be written']

['What does the graph in Figure 2.13 show?', 'The graph in Figure 2.13 shows its motion as it is getting up to speed after starting at rest.']

['What happens when the equation of motion is expressed as a graph?', 'The graph of position versus time in Figure 2.13 is a curve rather than a straight line.']
['What happens when you graph velocity?', 'The slope of the curve becomes steeper as time progresses, showing that the velocity is increasing over time.']
['Does this tell us something about the instantaneous velocity?', 'The slope at any point on a position-versus-time graph is the instantaneous velocity at that point.']
['How is this found?', 'It is found by drawing a straight line tangent to the curve at the point of interest and taking the slope of this straight line.']
['What is an example of a tangent line?', 'Tangent lines are shown for two points in Figure 2.13.']
['What is the average velocity?', 'The average velocity is the net displacement divided by the time traveled.']
['What did we already study together?', 'Earlier, we examined graphs of position versus time.']
['What did we find out?', 'Now, we are going to build on that information as we look at graphs of velocity vs. time.']
['What is the rate of change of displacement?', 'Velocity is the rate of change of displacement.']
['What is the rate of change of velocity?', 'Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity; we will discuss acceleration more in another chapter.']
['How do the three concepts relate?', 'These concepts are all very interrelated.']
['What is the topic of this lesson?', 'Let’s return to our drive to school, and look at a graph of position versus time as shown in Figure 2.15.']
['What was the assumption that your parent drove to and from school?', 'We assumed for our original calculation that your parent drove with a constant velocity to and from school.']

['What was the factual assumption that the car could not have gone from rest to a constant velocity without speeding up?', 'We now know that the car could not have gone from rest to a constant velocity without speeding up.']
['What happened when we made the graph?', 'So the actual graph would be curved on either end, but let’s make the same approximation as we did then, anyway.']
['What can we learn about this graph?', 'Looking at this graph, and given what we learned, we can see that there are two distinct periods to the car’s motion—the way to school and the way back.']
['What is the average velocity of the car?', 'The average velocity for the drive to school is 0.5 km/minute.']
['How long did it take the car to drive back?', 'We can see that the average velocity for the drive back is –0.5 km/minute.']
['How do you compare the two graphs?', 'If we plot the data showing velocity versus time, we get another graph:']

['What are the three things that we can learn from that?', 'First, we can derive a v versus t graph from a d versus t graph.']
['What is important about the graph?', 'Second, if we have a straight-line position–time graph that is positively or negatively sloped, it will yield a horizontal velocity graph.']
['What is the second thing that you can learn from that graph?', 'There are a few other interesting things to note.']
['What are those other things that you could note?', 'Just as we could use a position vs. time graph to determine velocity, we can use a velocity vs. time graph to determine position.']
['What can you tell me about velocity and position?', 'We know that v = d/t.']

['What else do you know about the equation?', 'If we use a little algebra to re-arrange the equation, we see that d = v $$\\(\\times\\)$$ t. In Figure 2.16, we have velocity on the y-axis and time along the x-axis.']
['What happened before the motion?', 'Let’s take just the first half of the motion.']
['What was the total distance in metres that we found?', 'We get 0.5 km/minute  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10 minutes.']
['What are the units for minutes?', 'The units for minutes cancel each other, and we get 5 km, which is the displacement for the trip to school.']
['How long did it take to get to school?', 'If we calculate the same for the return trip, we get –5 km.']

['What did you do after you got to school?', 'If we add them together, we see that the net displacement for the whole trip is 0 km, which it should be because we started and ended at the same place.']
['What is the area under a velocity curve?', 'The area under a velocity curve represents the displacement.']
['Does the displacement curve tell us anything else about this?', 'The velocity curve also tells us whether the car is speeding up.']
['Is the car moving faster or slower?', 'In our earlier example, we stated that the velocity was constant.']
['Does the car need to speed up?', 'So, the car is not speeding up.']
["How can you tell that the car isn't speeding up?", 'Graphically, you can see that the slope of these two lines is 0.']
['Does the slope tell us that the car is speeding up, or accelerating?', 'This slope tells us that the car is not speeding up, or accelerating.']
['Does this answer your question?', 'We will do more with this information in a later chapter.']
['What are the two important parts of a graph?', 'For now, just remember that the area under the graph and the slope are the two important parts of the graph.']

['What else does this have to do with the linear equation?', 'Just like we could define a linear equation for the motion in a position vs. time graph, we can also define one for a velocity vs. time graph.']
['What is the slope equal to?', 'As we said, the slope equals the acceleration, a.']
['What is the y-intercept equal to?', 'And in this graph, the y-intercept is v0.']
['Does this explain the formula for the line?', 'Thus,  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = \\mathbf{v}_{0} + \\mathbf{a}t\\)$$ .']

['What is the difference between average acceleration and instantaneous acceleration?', 'Average acceleration is distinguished from instantaneous acceleration, which is acceleration at a specific instant in time.']
['What is the magnitude of acceleration over time?', 'The magnitude of acceleration is often not constant over time.']
['What is the reason for the acceleration of a moving object?', 'For example, runners in a race accelerate at a greater rate in the first second of a race than during the following seconds.']
['How do you calculate the average acceleration?', 'You do not need to know all the instantaneous accelerations at all times to calculate average acceleration.']

['Why not?', 'All you need to know is the change in velocity (i.e., the final velocity minus the initial velocity) and the change in time (i.e., the final time minus the initial time), as shown in the formula.']
['What is the result of the average acceleration?', 'Note that the average acceleration can be positive, negative, or zero.']
['What is the definition of negative acceleration?', 'A negative acceleration is simply an acceleration in the negative direction.']

['What is the direction of change in velocity?', 'Keep in mind that although acceleration points in the same direction as the change in velocity, it is not always in the direction of the velocity itself.']
['What is opposite to the direction of velocity?', 'When an object slows down, its acceleration is opposite to the direction of its velocity.']
['What is acceleration?', 'In everyday language, this is called deceleration; but in physics, it is acceleration—whose direction happens to be opposite that of the velocity.']
['What is a positive displacement?', 'For now, let us assume that motion to the right along the x-axis is positive and motion to the left is negative.']
['What are the examples of displacement?', 'Figure 3.2 shows a car with positive acceleration in (a) and negative acceleration in (b).']
['What is the definition of acceleration?', 'The arrows represent vectors showing both direction and magnitude of velocity and acceleration.']
['What are vector quantities?', 'Velocity and acceleration are both vector quantities.']
['What are vector quantities?', 'Recall that vectors have both magnitude and direction.']
['What is the difference between velocity and acceleration?', 'An object traveling at a constant velocity—therefore having no acceleration—does accelerate if it changes direction.']
['What causes a moving car to accelerate?', 'So, turning the steering wheel of a moving car makes the car accelerate because the velocity changes direction.']
['What is the equation for average acceleration?', 'Look back at the equation for average acceleration.']

['What are the values in the equation for average acceleration?', 'You can see that the calculation of average acceleration involves three values: change in time, (Δt); change in velocity, (Δv); and acceleration (a).']

['How is change in time stated in terms of the unit?', 'Change in time is often stated as a time interval, and change in velocity can often be calculated by subtracting the initial velocity from the final velocity.']
['What is the formula for determining average acceleration?', 'Average acceleration is then simply change in velocity divided by change in time.']
['What is important to know before we begin?', 'Before you begin calculating, be sure that all distances and times have been converted to meters and seconds.']

["What is the dimension of motion we're looking at?", 'We are only concerned with motion in one dimension.']
['What are the kinematic equations?', 'The kinematic equations apply to conditions of constant acceleration and show how these concepts are related.']
['What is constant acceleration?', 'Constant acceleration is acceleration that does not change over time.']
['What is the first kinematic equation?', 'The first kinematic equation relates displacement d, average velocity  $$\\(\\overline{v}\\)$$, and time t.']
['What is the relation between average velocity and displacement?', 'This equation says that average velocity is displacement per unit time.']
['What unit of time are we using to express the displacement?', 'We will express velocity in meters per second.']
['How can you see this relationship?', 'If we graph displacement versus time, as in Figure 3.6, the slope will be the velocity.']
['Is time the independent variable?', 'Whenever a rate, such as velocity, is represented graphically, time is usually taken to be the independent variable and is plotted along the x axis.']

['What kinematic equations describe motion with constant acceleration?', 'Now we come to our main focus of this chapter; namely, the kinematic equations that describe motion with constant acceleration.']

['What is the rate at which velocity increases?', 'In the third kinematic equation, acceleration is the rate at which velocity increases, so velocity at any point equals initial velocity plus acceleration multiplied by time']
['What is the third kinematic equation?', 'Note that this third kinematic equation does not have displacement in it.']
['Does this equation have a purpose?', 'Therefore, if you do not know the displacement and are not trying to solve for a displacement, this equation might be a good one to use.']
['What can we learn from this passage?', 'Note that, in reality, knowns and unknowns will vary.']
['What else can you tell me about the kinematic equation?', 'Sometimes you will want to rearrange a kinematic equation so that the knowns are the values on the axes and the unknown is the slope.']

['What is a problem-solving skill?', 'Problem-solving skills are essential to success in a science and life in general.']
['How can one acquire these skills?', 'The ability to apply broad physical principles, which are often represented by equations, to specific situations is a very powerful form of knowledge.']
['What is the power of this knowledge?', 'It is much more powerful than memorizing a list of facts.']

['What can memorizing facts help you with?', 'Analytical skills and problem-solving abilities can be applied to new situations, whereas a list of facts cannot be made long enough to contain every possible circumstance.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects in this text?', 'Essential analytical skills will be developed by solving problems in this text and will be useful for understanding physics and science in general throughout your life.']

['What is one step in solving a problem?', 'While no single step-by-step method works for every problem, the following general procedures facilitate problem solving and make the answers more meaningful.']
['What are other steps required to make a sandcastle?', 'A certain amount of creativity and insight are required as well.']
['What are the steps to determine the physical principles involved?', 'Examine the situation to determine which physical principles are involved.']
['What other steps can you think of that involve physical principles?', 'It is vital to draw a simple sketch at the outset.']
['How do you draw the sketch?', 'Decide which direction is positive and note that on your sketch.']
['What are the other steps you can think of?', 'Identify the knowns:']
['What is the information that is known?', 'Make a list of what information is given or can be inferred from the problem statement.']
['What can you do with the knowns?', 'Remember, not all given information will be in the form of a number with units in the problem.']
['What can you do with the knowns?', 'If something starts from rest, we know the initial velocity is zero.']
['What can you do with the knowns?', 'If something stops, we know the final velocity is zero.']
['What can you do with the knowns?', 'Identify the unknowns: Decide exactly what needs to be determined in the problem.']
['What can you do to solve the problem?', 'Find an equation or set of equations that can help you solve the problem.']
['What steps can you do after finding the equation?', 'Your list of knowns and unknowns can help here.']
['What can you do with this information?', 'For example, if time is not needed or not given, then the fifth kinematic equation, which does not include time, could be useful.']
['What can you do with the knowns?', 'Insert the knowns along with their units into the appropriate equation and obtain numerical solutions complete with units.']
['How do you write the solution?', 'This step produces the numerical answer; it also provides a check on units that can help you find errors.']
['What can you do with the units of the answer?', 'If the units of the answer are incorrect, then an error has been made.']
['What can you do with the equations?', 'Check the answer to see if it is reasonable:']
['How do you correct for the errors?', 'This final step is extremely important because the goal of physics is to accurately describe nature.']
['What does a reasonable answer look like?', 'To see if the answer is reasonable, check its magnitude, its sign, and its units.']
['What is the first step to problem solving?', 'Determine the knowns and unknowns.']
['What happens when you have identified the knowns and unknowns?', 'Find an equation that expresses the unknown in terms of the knowns.']
['What does finding an equation mean?', 'More than one unknown means more than one equation is needed.']
['What else happens at this point?', 'Solve the equation or equations.']
['What else happens when you calculate a percentage?', 'Be sure units and significant figures are correct.']
['What else happens at this point?', 'Check whether the answer is reasonable.']
['Why is the acceleration not uniform?', 'In many cases, acceleration is not uniform because the force acting on the accelerating object is not constant over time.']
['What situation has constant acceleration?', 'A situation that gives constant acceleration is the acceleration of falling objects.']

['What speed does an object falling at the ground have when air resistance is not a factor?', 'When air resistance is not a factor, all objects near Earth’s surface fall with an acceleration of about 9.80 m/s2.']
['What does air resistance have to do with this?', 'Although this value decreases slightly with increasing altitude, it may be assumed to be essentially constant.']
['What is the value of m/s2?', 'The value of 9.80 m/s2 is labeled g and is referred to as acceleration due to gravity.']

['What is the force that causes nonsupported objects to accelerate downward?', 'Gravity is the force that causes nonsupported objects to accelerate downward—or, more precisely, toward the center of Earth.']
['What does the weight of an object have to do with gravity?', 'The magnitude of this force is called the weight of the object and is given by mg where m is the mass of the object (in kg).']
['What is the value of g on other planets?', 'In places other than on Earth, such as the Moon or on other planets, g is not 9.80 m/s2, but takes on other values.']
['What did the negative sign mean?', 'When using g for the acceleration a in a kinematic equation, it is usually given a negative sign because the acceleration due to gravity is downward.']
['What is the cause of motion?', 'Force is the cause of motion, and motion draws our attention.']
['What is the most important reason to pay attention to motion?', 'Motion itself can be beautiful, such as a dolphin jumping out of the water, the flight of a bird, or the orbit of a satellite.']
['What is the study of motion called?', 'The study of motion is called kinematics, but kinematics describes only the way objects move—their velocity and their acceleration.']
['What is the study of the forces that affect the motion of moving objects and systems?', 'Dynamics considers the forces that affect the motion of moving objects and systems.']
['What is the foundation of dynamics?', 'Newton’s laws of motion are the foundation of dynamics.']
['What do these laws describe?', 'These laws describe the way objects speed up, slow down, stay in motion, and interact with other objects.']
['What are the laws about?', 'They are also universal laws: they apply everywhere on Earth as well as in space.']
['What is the difference between a force and a vector?', 'A force pushes or pulls an object.']
['What is the object being moved by a force?', 'The object being moved by a force could be an inanimate object, a table, or an animate object, a person.']
['What is pushing or pulling the object?', 'The pushing or pulling may be done by a person, or even the gravitational pull of Earth.']
['What do different magnitudes mean?', 'Forces have different magnitudes and directions; this means that some forces are stronger than others and can act in different directions.']
['What kind of force causes an object to move?', 'For example, a cannon exerts a strong force on the cannonball that is launched into the air.']
['What is an example of a strong force?', 'In contrast, a mosquito landing on your arm exerts only a small force on your arm.']
['What kind of forces are mentioned in the article?', 'When multiple forces act on an object, the forces combine.']
['What are the two terms used to describe the sum of the forces acting on an object?', 'Adding together all of the forces acting on an object gives the total force, or net force.']
['What is a force that acts on an object within a system from outside the system?', 'An external force is a force that acts on an object within the system from outside the system.']
['Why is this different?', 'This type of force is different than an internal force, which acts between two objects that are both within the system.']
['Are the two considered the same?', 'The net external force combines these two definitions; it is the total combined external force.']
['What else is this article about?', 'We discuss further details about net force, external force, and net external force in the coming sections.']
['What type of force is defined in the first section?', 'In mathematical terms, two forces acting in opposite directions have opposite signs (positive or negative).']
['What does the negative sign mean?', 'By convention, the negative sign is assigned to any movement to the left or downward.']

['What does opposite signs mean?', 'If two forces pushing in opposite directions are added together, the larger force will be somewhat canceled out by the smaller force pushing in the opposite direction.']

['What is the relationship between the two forces?', 'It is important to be consistent with your chosen coordinate system within a problem; for example, if negative values are assigned to the downward direction for velocity, then distance, force, and acceleration should also be designated as being negative in the downward direction.']
['What kind of force do they describe?', 'For our first example of force, consider an object hanging from a rope.']
['What does this example give us the opportunity to introduce?', 'This example gives us the opportunity to introduce a useful tool known as a free-body diagram.']
['What does a free-body diagram represent?', 'A free-body diagram represents the object being acted upon—that is, the free body—as a single point.']
['What is the form of this force?', 'Only the forces acting on the body (that is, external forces) are shown and are represented by vectors (which are drawn as arrows).']
['What are the only forces shown?', 'These forces are the only ones shown because only external forces acting on the body affect its motion.']
['How are the internal forces canceled out?', 'We can ignore any internal forces within the body because they cancel each other out, as explained in the section on Newton’s third law of motion.']
['What can we learn about forces from a free-body diagram?', 'Free-body diagrams are very useful for analyzing forces acting on an object.']

['What is the force of tension in the rope acting in the upward direction, opposite the force of gravity?', 'Figure 4.2 shows the force of tension in the rope acting in the upward direction, opposite the force of gravity.']

['What are the forces indicated in the free-body diagram by an arrow pointing up, representing tension, and another arrow pointing down, representing gravity?', 'The forces are indicated in the free-body diagram by an arrow pointing up, representing tension, and another arrow pointing down, representing gravity.']

['What is the relationship between the length of the arrows and the magnitude of the forces?', 'In a free-body diagram, the lengths of the arrows show the relative magnitude (or strength) of the forces.']
['What is the relationship between the vectors?', 'Because forces are vectors, they add just like other vectors.']
['How do the arrows relate to each other?', 'Notice that the two arrows have equal lengths in Figure 4.2, which means that the forces of tension and weight are of equal magnitude.']

['How does the length of the arrows relate to the force?', 'Because these forces of equal magnitude act in opposite directions, they are perfectly balanced, so they add together to give a net force of zero.']
['What is the primary force that is responsible for moving the ball from left to right?', 'Not all forces are as noticeable as when you push or pull on an object.']

["What is a force that can't be seen?", 'Some forces act without physical contact, such as the pull of a magnet (in the case of magnetic force) or the gravitational pull of Earth (in the case of gravitational force).']

['What is an example of a force?', 'In the next three sections discussing Newton’s laws of motion, we will learn about three specific types of forces: friction, the normal force, and the gravitational force.']
['What are free-body diagrams?', 'To analyze situations involving forces, we will create free-body diagrams to organize the framework of the mathematics for each individual situation.']
['What was the first law of motion?', 'Newton’s first law considered bodies at rest or bodies in motion at a constant velocity.']

['What is the other state of motion to consider?', 'The other state of motion to consider is when an object is moving with a changing velocity, which means a change in the speed and/or the direction of motion.']
['What is the second law of motion?', 'This type of motion is addressed by Newton’s second law of motion, which states how force causes changes in motion.']

['What does this law describe?', 'Newton’s second law of motion is used to calculate what happens in situations involving forces and motion, and it shows the mathematical relationship between force, mass, and acceleration.']
['What is the second law of thermodynamics?', 'Mathematically, the second law is most often written as']
['What is the relation that determines a formula?', 'where Fnet (or ∑F) is the net external force, m is the mass of the system, and a is the acceleration.']
['Is there anything else interesting?', 'Note that Fnet and ∑F are the same because the net external force is the sum of all the external forces acting on the system.']

['What is the first topic to be covered?', 'A change in motion is simply a change in velocity: the speed of an object can become slower or faster, the direction in which the object is moving can change, or both of these variables may change.']
['What does a change in velocity mean?', 'A change in velocity means, by definition, that an acceleration has occurred.']
['What causes a change in motion?', 'Newton’s first law says that only a nonzero net external force can cause a change in motion, so a net external force must cause an acceleration.']
['What happens if we speed up?', 'Note that acceleration can refer to slowing down or to speeding up.']

['What does acceleration mean?', 'Acceleration can also refer to a change in the direction of motion with no change in speed, because acceleration is the change in velocity divided by the time it takes for that change to occur, and velocity is defined by speed and direction.']
['What can you tell me about this?', 'From the equation $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\text{a},\\)$$ we see that force is directly proportional to both mass and acceleration, which makes sense.']
['What makes that so?', 'To accelerate two objects from rest to the same velocity, you would expect more force to be required to accelerate the more massive object.']

['Is it true that for two objects of the same mass, applying a greater force to one would accelerate it to a greater velocity?', 'Likewise, for two objects of the same mass, applying a greater force to one would accelerate it to a greater velocity.']
['What is the next question?', 'Now, let’s rearrange Newton’s second law to solve for acceleration.']
['What does the symbol mean?', 'This proportionality mathematically states what we just said in words: acceleration is directly proportional to the net external force.']
['What can you tell me about the relationships?', 'When two variables are directly proportional to each other, then if one variable doubles, the other variable must double.']
['What is the most important thing I should know about this?', 'Likewise, if one variable is reduced by half, the other variable must also be reduced by half.']
['What else can you tell me about the relationship between variables?', 'In general, when one variable is multiplied by a number, the other variable is also multiplied by the same number.']

['Does the proportionality make sense?', 'It seems reasonable that the acceleration of a system should be directly proportional to and in the same direction as the net external force acting on the system.']
['What is the relationship between force and acceleration?', 'An object experiences greater acceleration when acted on by a greater force.']
['What is inversely proportional?', 'Inversely proportional means that if one variable is multiplied by a number, the other variable must be divided by the same number.']
['Are there any other concepts that are inversely proportional?', 'Now, it also seems reasonable that acceleration should be inversely proportional to the mass of the system.']
['What does this mean?', 'In other words, the larger the mass (the inertia), the smaller the acceleration produced by a given force.']

['What is an example of this?', 'This relationship is illustrated in Figure 4.5, which shows that a given net external force applied to a basketball produces a much greater acceleration than when applied to a car.']
['What else do we need to know about the content?', 'Before putting Newton’s second law into action, it is important to consider units.']

['What units should we consider?', 'The equation $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a}\\)$$ is used to define the units of force in terms of the three basic units of mass, length, and time (recall that acceleration has units of length divided by time squared).']
['What is the SI unit of force called?', 'The SI unit of force is called the newton (abbreviated N) and is the force needed to accelerate a 1-kg system at the rate of 1 m/s2.']
['What is the first law of thermodynamics?', 'That is, because  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a},\\)$$  we have']

['What is the gravitational force?', 'One of the most important applications of Newton’s second law is to calculate weight (also known as the gravitational force), which is usually represented mathematically as W.']
['What does he describe as an acceleration?', 'When people talk about gravity, they don’t always realize that it is an acceleration.']
['When an object is dropped, it accelerates toward what?', 'When an object is dropped, it accelerates toward the center of Earth.']
['What is the net external force acting on an object?', 'Newton’s second law states that the net external force acting on an object is responsible for the acceleration of the object.']

['What is the net external force on a falling object?', 'If air resistance is negligible, the net external force on a falling object is only the gravitational force (i.e., the weight of the object).']
['What can be represented by a vector?', 'Weight can be represented by a vector because it has a direction.']
['What direction does gravity pull?', 'Down is defined as the direction in which gravity pulls, so weight is normally considered a downward force.']
['What is the equation for weight?', 'By using Newton’s second law, we can figure out the equation for weight.']
['What are some other problems you can see in the study material?', 'Consider an object with mass m falling toward Earth.']

['What happens to the object as it falls?', 'It experiences only the force of gravity (i.e., the gravitational force or weight), which is represented by W. Newton’s second law states that  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a}.\\)$$']
["Does Newton's second law apply in both cases?", 'Because the only force acting on the object is the gravitational force, we have  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = \\mathbf{W}.\\)$$']
['What does the acceleration of an object due to gravity equate to?', 'We know that the acceleration of an object due to gravity is g, so we have  $$\\(\\mathbf{a} = \\mathbf{g}.\\)$$']
['What does the acceleration of an object due to gravity equate to?', 'Substituting these two expressions into Newton’s second law gives']
['What is this equation for?', 'This is the equation for weight—the gravitational force on a mass m.']

["How does that relate to the Earth's gravity?", 'On Earth,  $$\\(\\mathbf{g} = 9.80\\text{~m/s}^{\\text{2}},\\)$$  so the weight (disregarding for now the direction of the weight) of a 1.0-kg object on Earth is']

['What direction does gravity act downward?', 'Recall that although gravity acts downward, it can be assigned a positive or negative value, depending on what the positive direction is in your chosen coordinate system.']
['Does this affect weight?', 'Be sure to take this into consideration when solving problems with weight.']
['Does this change if you move in any other direction?', 'When the downward direction is taken to be negative, as is often the case, acceleration due to gravity becomes g = −9.8 m/s2.']
['What is the relationship between weight and force?', 'When the net external force on an object is its weight, we say that it is in freefall.']
['What is the relationship between weight and force when an object is in freefall?', 'In this case, the only force acting on the object is the force of gravity.']

['Is freefall the same everywhere?', 'On the surface of Earth, when objects fall downward toward Earth, they are never truly in freefall because there is always some upward force due to air resistance that acts on the object (and there is also the buoyancy force of air, which is similar to the buoyancy force in water that keeps boats afloat).']
['What is the most important thing to know about the topic?', 'Gravity varies slightly over the surface of Earth, so the weight of an object depends very slightly on its location on Earth.']
['Do objects weigh less or more than they do in outer space?', 'Weight varies dramatically away from Earth’s surface.']
['How does the acceleration due to gravity vary?', 'On the moon, for example, the acceleration due to gravity is only 1.67 m/s2.']
['Does it make a difference if you are on the moon?', 'Because weight depends on the force of gravity, a 1.0-kg mass weighs 9.8 N on Earth and only about 1.7 N on the moon.']
['What is the difference between weight and mass?', 'It is important to remember that weight and mass are very different, although they are closely related.']

['What is the quantity of matter (how much stuff) in an object and does not vary, but weight is the gravitational force on an object and is proportional to the force of gravity?', 'Mass is the quantity of matter (how much stuff) in an object and does not vary, but weight is the gravitational force on an object and is proportional to the force of gravity.']

['Why do they have this difference?', 'It is easy to confuse the two, because our experience is confined to Earth, and the weight of an object is essentially the same no matter where you are on Earth.']

['Do mass and weight share a common vocabulary?', 'Adding to the confusion, the terms mass and weight are often used interchangeably in everyday language; for example, our medical records often show our weight in kilograms, but never in the correct unit of newtons.']

['What is one way to explain a force?', 'If you have ever stubbed your toe, you have noticed that although your toe initiates the impact, the surface that you stub it on exerts a force back on your toe.']

['What does this demonstrate?', 'Although the first thought that crosses your mind is probably “ouch, that hurt” rather than “this is a great example of Newton’s third law,” both statements are true.']

['What does it mean?', 'This is exactly what happens whenever one object exerts a force on another—each object experiences a force that is the same strength as the force acting on the other object but that acts in the opposite direction.']
['How is it important?', 'Everyday experiences, such as stubbing a toe or throwing a ball, are all perfect examples of Newton’s third law in action.']

['What does it say?', 'Newton’s third law of motion tells us that forces always occur in pairs, and one object cannot exert a force on another without experiencing the same strength force in return.']

['What happens in pairs?', 'We sometimes refer to these force pairs as action-reaction pairs, where the force exerted is the action, and the force experienced in return is the reaction (although which is which depends on your point of view).']
["What is the biggest thing we need to know about Newton's Third law?", 'Newton’s third law is useful for figuring out which forces are external to a system.']

['What is the importance of identifying external forces when setting up a problem?', 'Recall that identifying external forces is important when setting up a problem, because the external forces must be added together to find the net force.']
['What can we see Newton’s third law at work by looking at?', 'We can see Newton’s third law at work by looking at how people move about.']
['What can you tell me about the swimmer?', 'Consider a swimmer pushing off from the side of a pool, as illustrated in Figure 4.8.']
['What does she do after pushing off?', 'She pushes against the pool wall with her feet and accelerates in the direction opposite to her push.']
['How does the wall feel about this?', 'The wall has thus exerted on the swimmer a force of equal magnitude but in the direction opposite that of her push.']

["What is significant about the swimmer's force?", 'You might think that two forces of equal magnitude but that act in opposite directions would cancel, but they do not because they act on different systems.']
['What is our goal with this investigation?', 'In this case, there are two different systems that we could choose to investigate: the swimmer or the wall.']

['What is the swimmer?', 'If we choose the swimmer to be the system of interest, as in the figure, then  $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}\\)$$  is an external force on the swimmer and affects her motion.']
['Is she moving in a straight line?', 'Because acceleration is in the same direction as the net external force, the swimmer moves in the direction of  $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}.\\)$$']

['What is the swimmer?', 'Because the swimmer is our system (or object of interest) and not the wall, we do not need to consider the force $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{feet~on~wall}}\\)$$ because it originates from the swimmer rather than acting on the swimmer.']

['Do we have to consider it?', 'Therefore, $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{feet~on~wall}}\\)$$ does not directly affect the motion of the system and does not cancel $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}.\\)$$']
['What is her movement?', 'Note that the swimmer pushes in the direction opposite to the direction in which she wants to move.']
['What other examples of Newton’s third law can you give me?', 'Other examples of Newton’s third law are easy to find.']
['What can you give me one example of this law?', 'As a teacher paces in front of a whiteboard, he exerts a force backward on the floor.']
['What happens to the teacher in this case?', 'The floor exerts a reaction force in the forward direction on the teacher that causes him to accelerate forward.']
['What is the example of?', "Similarly, a car accelerates because the ground pushes forward on the car's wheels in reaction to the car's wheels pushing backward on the ground."]
['What are some examples of wheels pushing backward?', 'You can see evidence of the wheels pushing backward when tires spin on a gravel road and throw rocks backward.']
['What is one example of this law?', 'Another example is the force of a baseball as it makes contact with the bat.']
['What are some examples of how helicopters create lift?', 'Helicopters create lift by pushing air down, creating an upward reaction force.']
['How do birds fly?', 'Birds fly by exerting force on air in the direction opposite that in which they wish to fly.']
['Do wings make a difference?', 'For example, the wings of a bird force air downward and backward in order to get lift and move forward.']

['What are some examples of how an octopus moves?', 'An octopus propels itself forward in the water by ejecting water backward through a funnel in its body, which is similar to how a jet ski is propelled.']
['How does it work?', 'In these examples, the octopus or jet ski push the water backward, and the water, in turn, pushes the octopus or jet ski forward.']
['What are the three ways forces are classified?', 'Forces are classified and given names based on their source, how they are transmitted, or their effects.']
['What are some of the common types of forces?', 'In previous sections, we discussed the forces called push, weight, and friction.']
['What are some other types of forces?', 'In this section, applying Newton’s third law of motion will allow us to explore three more forces: the normal force, tension, and thrust.']

['What are some examples of two-dimensional and three-dimensional forces?', 'However, because we haven’t yet covered vectors in depth, we’ll only consider one-dimensional situations in this chapter.']
['What is a vector?', 'Another chapter will consider forces acting in two dimensions.']
['What is the gravitational force?', 'The gravitational force (or weight) acts on objects at all times and everywhere on Earth.']
['What is the force that causes a particle to move in a straight line?', 'The answer is the normal force.']

['What is the force that a surface applies to an object to support the weight of that object?', 'The normal force is the force that a surface applies to an object to support the weight of that object; it acts perpendicular to the surface upon which the object rests.']

['What is the net external force on an object when it is stationary?', 'If an object on a flat surface is not accelerating, the net external force is zero, and the normal force has the same magnitude as the weight of the system but acts in the opposite direction.']
['How is it written in equation form?', 'In equation form, we write that']
['What is the origin of the word tension?', 'The word tension comes from the Latin word meaning to stretch.']

['What is the force along the length of a flexible connector, such as a string, rope, chain, or cable?', 'Tension is the force along the length of a flexible connector, such as a string, rope, chain, or cable.']

['What are some examples of connectors?', 'Regardless of the type of connector attached to the object of interest, one must remember that the connector can only pull (or exert tension) in the direction parallel to its length.']
['What does tension do to the object?', 'Tension is a pull that acts parallel to the connector, and that acts in opposite directions at the two ends of the connector.']

['What is opposite directions at the two ends?', 'This is possible because a flexible connector is simply a long series of action-reaction forces, except at the two ends where outside objects provide one member of the action-reaction forces.']
['What is the tension in the rope?', 'Tension in the rope must equal the weight of the supported mass, as we can prove by using Newton’s second law.']
['What is the weight of the mass?', 'If the 5.00 kg mass in the figure is stationary, then its acceleration is zero, so $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = 0.\\)$$']
['What other forces act on the mass?', 'The only external forces acting on the mass are its weight W and the tension T supplied by the rope.']
['What is the net force?', 'Summing the external forces to find the net force, we obtain']
['What are the F and W signs?', 'where T and W are the magnitudes of the tension and weight, respectively, and their signs indicate direction, with up being positive.']
['What does it do?', 'By substituting mg for Fnet and rearranging the equation, the tension equals the weight of the supported mass, just as you would expect']
['What is another example of Newton’s third law in action?', 'Another example of Newton’s third law in action is thrust.']
['What happens as the rocket moves forward?', 'Rockets move forward by expelling gas backward at a high velocity.']

['Why does the rocket expell gas backward?', 'This means that the rocket exerts a large force backward on the gas in the rocket combustion chamber, and the gas, in turn, exerts a large force forward on the rocket in response.']
['What is the reaction force of a rocket?', 'This reaction force is called thrust.']
['What is a quantity that has magnitude and direction?', 'Recall that a vector is a quantity that has magnitude and direction.']
['What are some examples of vectors?', 'For example, displacement, velocity, acceleration, and force are all vectors.']
['What is the direction of a vector?', 'In one-dimensional or straight-line motion, the direction of a vector can be given simply by a plus or minus sign.']

['What are the terms for positive and negative motion?', 'Motion that is forward, to the right, or upward is usually considered to be positive (+); and motion that is backward, to the left, or downward is usually considered to be negative (−).']
['What do vectors describe?', 'In two dimensions, a vector describes motion in two perpendicular directions, such as vertical and horizontal.']
['What do the vectors refer to?', 'For vertical and horizontal motion, each vector is made up of vertical and horizontal components.']
['What does this mean?', 'In a one-dimensional problem, one of the components simply has a value of zero.']
['How are vectors applied?', 'For two-dimensional vectors, we work with vectors by using a frame of reference such as a coordinate system.']

['What is the method used to represent vectors?', 'Just as with one-dimensional vectors, we graphically represent vectors with an arrow having a length proportional to the vector’s magnitude and pointing in the direction that the vector points.']
['What is the graphical representation of a vector?', 'Figure 5.2 shows a graphical representation of a vector; the total displacement for a person walking in a city.']
['What does the graph show?', 'The person first walks nine blocks east and then five blocks north.']
['What was interesting about the graph?', 'Her total displacement does not match her path to her final destination.']
['What did you discover about the graph?', 'The displacement simply connects her starting point with her ending point using a straight line, which is the shortest distance.']
['What can you tell me about the graph?', 'We use the notation that a boldface symbol, such as D, stands for a vector.']

['What is the notation for the magnitude of a vector?', 'Its magnitude is represented by the symbol in italics, D, and its direction is given by an angle represented by the symbol $$\\(\\theta.\\)$$']
['Was there anything else interesting that you found?', 'Note that her displacement would be the same if she had begun by first walking five blocks north and then walking nine blocks east.']
['What is the head-to-tail method?', 'The head-to-tail method is a graphical way to add vectors.']
['What is the difference between the head and tail of a vector?', 'The tail of the vector is the starting point of the vector, and the head (or tip) of a vector is the pointed end of the arrow.']
['What is the head to tail method?', 'The following steps describe how to use the head-to-tail method for graphical vector addition.']
['What axis do we use to represent the vector?', 'Let the x-axis represent the east-west direction.']

['What is the name of the figure in 5.3?', 'Figure 5.3']

['What axis do we use to represent the vector?', 'Let the y-axis represent the north-south direction.']
["What does 'b' represent?", 'Draw an arrow to represent the second vector (five blocks to the north).']
['What is the formula for the second vector?', 'Place the tail of the second vector at the head of the first vector, as shown in Figure 5.4(b).']
['What is the figure 5.4?', 'Figure 5.4']
['What is 5.5 times?', 'A vertical vector is added.']
['What is the value of 5.6?', 'If there are more than two vectors, continue to add the vectors head-to-tail as described in step 2.']
['What is the value of 5.7?', 'In this example, we have only two vectors, so we have finished placing arrows tip to tail.']

['What is the figure 5.5?', 'Figure 5.5']

['What is the resultant of 5.7?', 'To find the direction of the resultant, use a protractor to measure the angle it makes with the reference direction (in this case, the x-axis).']

['What is the difference between vector addition and vector subtraction?', 'Vector subtraction is done in the same way as vector addition with one small change.']
['What do we do to get the change?', 'We add the first vector to the negative of the vector that needs to be subtracted.']
['What is the difference between a positive and negative vector?', 'A negative vector has the same magnitude as the original vector, but points in the opposite direction (as shown in Figure 5.6).']
['What does a negative vector have?', 'Subtracting the vector B from the vector A, which is written as A − B, is the same as A + (−B).']

['What is unique about vector subtraction?', 'This is true for scalars as well as vectors.']
