['What is the motion of an object thrown into the air called?', 'Projectile motion is the motion of an object thrown (projected) into the air.']
['What force is involved in launching an object?', 'After the initial force that launches the object, it only experiences the force of gravity.']
['What is the object called?', 'The object is called a projectile, and its path is called its trajectory.']
['What else is involved?', 'As an object travels through the air, it encounters a frictional force that slows its motion called air resistance.']

['Does air resistance have any effect on the trajectory of a rocket?', 'Air resistance does significantly alter trajectory motion, but due to the difficulty in calculation, it is ignored in introductory physics.']

['What are some important concepts in projectile motion?', 'The most important concept in projectile motion is that horizontal and vertical motions are independent, meaning that they don’t influence one another.']

['What is the difference between a cannonball in free fall and a cannonball launched horizontally in projectile motion?', 'Figure 5.27 compares a cannonball in free fall (in blue) to a cannonball launched horizontally in projectile motion (in red).']
['What can you tell me about the figure?', 'You can see that the cannonball in free fall falls at the same rate as the cannonball in projectile motion.']

['What is the significance of this information?', 'Keep in mind that if the cannon launched the ball with any vertical component to the velocity, the vertical displacements would not line up perfectly.']
['What do you think is the main point of this section?', 'Since vertical and horizontal motions are independent, we can analyze them separately, along perpendicular axes.']

['How do we calculate the velocity of a projectile?', 'To do this, we separate projectile motion into the two components of its motion, one along the horizontal axis and the other along the vertical.']
['What are the three sides of a right triangle?', 'We’ll call the horizontal axis the x-axis and the vertical axis the y-axis.']
['What are the components of the horizontal and vertical axes?', 'For notation, d is the total displacement, and x and y are its components along the horizontal and vertical axes.']
['What are the magnitudes of these vectors?', 'The magnitudes of these vectors are x and y, as illustrated in Figure 5.28.']
['What are the three parameters of projectile motion?', 'As usual, we use velocity, acceleration, and displacement to describe motion.']
['How do we find velocity?', 'We must also find the components of these variables along the x- and y-axes.']
['How do we find acceleration?', 'The components of acceleration are then very simple ay = –g = –9.80 m/s2.']
['What is positive displacement?', 'Note that this definition defines the upwards direction as positive.']
['What does ax =?', 'Because gravity is vertical, ax = 0.']
['How are the acceleration and displacement measured?', 'Both accelerations are constant, so we can use the kinematic equations.']
['What are the kinematic equations from a previous chapter?', 'For review, the kinematic equations from a previous chapter are summarized in Table 5.1.']
['How do you convert the velocity to the acceleration vector?', 'Separate the motion into horizontal and vertical components along the x- and y-axes.']

['Separate the speed of the object into its radians of motion along the x-', 'These axes are perpendicular, so  $$\\(A_{x} = A\\text{cos}\\theta\\)$$  and  $$\\(A_{y} = A\\text{sin}\\theta\\)$$ are used.']
['What is the magnitude of displacement along these axes?', 'The magnitudes of the displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{s}}\\)$$ along x- and y-axes are called $$\\(x\\)$$ and $$\\(y.\\)$$']

['What is the magnitude of velocity along these axes?', 'The magnitudes of the components of the velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ are $$\\(v_{x} = v\\cos\\theta\\)$$ and $$\\(v_{y} = v\\sin\\theta\\)$$, where $$\\(v\\)$$ is the magnitude of the velocity and $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is its direction.']
['What is the magnitude of acceleration along these axes?', 'Initial values are denoted with a subscript 0.']
['What happens after these radians are substracted?', 'Treat the motion as two independent one-dimensional motions, one horizontal and the other vertical.']

['What are the kinematic equations for horizontal and vertical motion?', 'The kinematic equations for horizontal and vertical motion take the following forms        $$\\[\\begin{array}{l}\n{\\text{Horizontal~Motion}(\\mathbf{a}_{x} = 0)} \\\\\n{x = x_{0} + v_{x}t} \\\\\n{v_{x} = v_{0x} = \\mathbf{\\text{v}}_{\\text{x}} = \\text{velocity~~is~a~constant.}} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$        Vertical motion (assuming positive is up $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{y} = - \\mathbf{g} = - 9.80\\text{~m/s}^{2}\\)$$ )        $$\\[\\begin{array}{rcl}\ny & = & {y_{0} + \\frac{1}{2}(v_{0y} + v_{y})t} \\\\\nv_{y} & = & {v_{0y} - \\mathbf{g}t} \\\\\ny & = & {y_{0} + v_{0y}t - \\frac{1}{2}\\mathbf{g}t^{2}} \\\\\nv_{y}^{2} & = & {v_{0y}^{2} - 2g(y - y_{0})} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$']
['What happens after the system has been locked?', 'Solve for the unknowns in the two separate motions (one horizontal and one vertical).']
['What is the value of t?', 'Note that the only common variable between the motions is time $$\\(t\\)$$ .']
['What is the solution to the problem?', 'The problem solving procedures here are the same as for one-dimensional kinematics.']
['Is the final solution the same?', 'Recombine the two motions to find the total displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{s}}\\)$$ and velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the analytical method of vector addition?', 'We can use the analytical method of vector addition, which uses $$\\(A = \\sqrt{A_{x}{}^{2} + A_{y}{}^{2}}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\theta = \\tan^{- 1}(A_{y}/A_{x})\\)$$ to find the magnitude and direction of the total displacement and velocity.']

['What is the direction of displacement?', '$$\\[\\begin{array}{l}\n\\text{Displacement} \\\\\n{\\mathbf{d} = \\sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}} \\\\\n{\\theta = \\tan^{- 1}(y/x)} \\\\\n\\text{Velocity} \\\\\n{\\mathbf{v} = \\sqrt{\\mathbf{v}_{x}^{2} + \\mathbf{v}_{y}^{2}}} \\\\\n{\\theta_{v} = \\tan^{- 1}(\\mathbf{v}_{y}/\\mathbf{v}_{x})} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$ $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is the direction of the displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{d}}\\)$$, and $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{v}}\\)$$ is the direction of the velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the method for analyzing two-dimensional projectile motion?', '(See Figure 5.29Figure 5.29 (a) We analyze two-dimensional projectile motion by breaking it into two independent one-dimensional motions along the vertical and horizontal axes.']
['What is the horizontal motion of a projectile?', '(b) The horizontal motion is simple, because \xa0ax=0\xa0ax=0\xa0ax=0 and \xa0vx\xa0vx\xa0vx is thus constant.']

['What happens to the vertical velocity as the object rises?', '(c) The velocity in the vertical direction begins to decrease as the object rises; at its highest point, the vertical velocity is zero.']

['What happens to the vertical velocity of an object as it falls towards the Earth?', 'As the object falls towards the Earth again, the vertical velocity increases again in magnitude but points in the opposite direction to the initial vertical velocity.']
['What is the y-motion?', '(d) The x- and y-motions are recombined to give the total velocity at any given point on the trajectory.']

['When we solve part (a) of the previous problem, the expression used to find $$', 'The expression we found for  $$\\(\\mathbf{y}\\)$$ while solving part (a) of the previous problem works for any projectile motion problem where air resistance is negligible.']
['What do we have to do to find the maximum height?', 'Call the maximum height  $$\\(\\mathbf{y} = h\\)$$; then,']
['What is this equation for?', 'This equation defines the maximum height of a projectile.']
['What is it based on?', 'The maximum height depends only on the vertical component of the initial velocity.']
['What is the first practice problem?', 'The fact that vertical and horizontal motions are independent of each other lets us predict the range of a projectile.']
['What is the horizontal distance R traveled by a projectile on level ground?', 'The range is the horizontal distance R traveled by a projectile on level ground, as illustrated in Figure 5.32.']
['What is the purpose of this discussion?', 'Throughout history, people have been interested in finding the range of projectiles for practical purposes, such as aiming cannons.']
['What is a problem you found on the practice problems?', 'Obviously, the greater the initial speed $$\\(v_{0}\\)$$, the greater the range, as shown in the figure above.']
['What else is true?', 'The initial angle $$\\(\\theta_{0}\\)$$ also has a dramatic effect on the range.']
['What else is true?', 'When air resistance is negligible, the range $$\\(R\\)$$ of a projectile on level ground is']
['what is it about?', 'where $$\\(v_{0}\\)$$ is the initial speed and $$\\(\\theta_{0}\\)$$ is the initial angle relative to the horizontal.']

['What are some important points about the range?', 'It is important to note that the range doesn’t apply to problems where the initial and final y position are different, or to cases where the object is launched perfectly horizontally.']
['What is a force that opposes motion?', 'Recall from the previous chapter that friction is a force that opposes motion, and is around us all the time.']
['What does friction cause?', 'Friction allows us to move, which you have discovered if you have ever tried to walk on ice.']
['What type of friction is this?', 'There are different types of friction—kinetic and static.']
['What is kinetic friction?', 'Kinetic friction acts on an object in motion, while static friction acts on an object or system at rest.']
['What is static friction?', 'The maximum static friction is usually greater than the kinetic friction between the objects.']
['What is static friction?', 'Imagine, for example, trying to slide a heavy crate across a concrete floor.']
['What happens if you push on a crate?', 'You may push harder and harder on the crate and not move it at all.']
['What is it doing?', 'This means that the static friction responds to what you do—it increases to be equal to and in the opposite direction of your push.']
['Is there anything you can do about it?', 'But if you finally push hard enough, the crate seems to slip suddenly and starts to move.']

['What is the difference between static and kinetic friction?', 'Once in motion, it is easier to keep it in motion than it was to get it started because the kinetic friction force is less than the static friction force.']

['What else do you need to know about static friction?', 'If you were to add mass to the crate, (for example, by placing a box on top of it) you would need to push even harder to get it started and also to keep it moving.']
['What do you need to know about the concrete?', 'If, on the other hand, you oiled the concrete you would find it easier to get the crate started and keep it going.']
['What is the figure that shows how friction occurs at the interface between two objects?', 'Figure 5.33 shows how friction occurs at the interface between two objects.']
['What is the difference between friction on a microscopic and microscopic level?', 'Magnifying these surfaces shows that they are rough on the microscopic level.']

['What happens when this is done?', 'So when you push to get an object moving (in this case, a crate), you must raise the object until it can skip along with just the tips of the surface hitting, break off the points, or do both.']
['What happens to the surfaces when pushed?', 'The harder the surfaces are pushed together (such as if another box is placed on the crate), the more force is needed to move them.']
['What is the magnitude of the frictional force?', 'The magnitude of the frictional force has two forms: one for static friction, the other for kinetic friction.']
['What is the difference between static friction and kinetic friction?', 'When there is no motion between the objects, the magnitude of static friction fs is']
['What is the coefficient of static friction?', 'where $$\\(\\mu_{\\text{s}}\\)$$ is the coefficient of static friction and N is the magnitude of the normal force.']
['What is the relationship among the three sides?', 'Recall that the normal force opposes the force of gravity and acts perpendicular to the surface in this example, but not always.']

['What does the equation mean?', 'Since the symbol $$\\(\\leq\\)$$ means less than or equal to, this equation says that static friction can have a maximum value of $$\\(\\mu_{\\text{s}}\\mathbf{N}.\\)$$']
['What is the minimum value of static friction?', 'That is,']
['What is static friction?', 'Static friction is a responsive force that increases to be equal and opposite to whatever force is exerted, up to its maximum limit.']
['What happens to the object when it exceeds its maximum limit?', 'Once the applied force exceeds fs(max), the object will move.']
['What is kinetic friction?', 'Once an object is moving, the magnitude of kinetic friction fk is given by']
['What causes friction to vary from surface to surface?', 'Friction varies from surface to surface because different substances are rougher than others.']
['What is the table 5.2 about?', 'Table 5.2 compares values of static and kinetic friction for different surfaces.']
['What is the coefficient of friction?', 'The coefficient of the friction depends on the two surfaces that are in contact.']

['What is the coefficient of kinetic friction?', 'Since the direction of friction is always opposite to the direction of motion, friction runs parallel to the surface between objects and perpendicular to the normal force.']

['Is there any other information in this section that is useful to you?', 'For example, if the crate you try to push (with a force parallel to the floor) has a mass of 100 kg, then the normal force would be equal to its weight']
['What is the right triangle?', 'perpendicular to the floor.']
['What do you have to do to get this?', 'If the coefficient of static friction is 0.45, you would have to exert a force parallel to the floor greater than']
['What did you do after that point?', 'to move the crate.']
['What happens to the crate after the motion?', 'Once there is motion, friction is less and the coefficient of kinetic friction might be 0.30, so that a force of only 290 N']
['How did this help?', 'would keep it moving at a constant speed.']
['What other results did they find?', 'If the floor were lubricated, both coefficients would be much smaller than they would be without lubrication.']
['What else did they find?', 'The coefficient of friction is unitless and is a number usually between 0 and 1.0.']

['What is the most important concept in our study material?', 'We discussed previously that when an object rests on a horizontal surface, there is a normal force supporting it equal in magnitude to its weight.']

['What does the text say about the normal force?', 'Up until now, we dealt only with normal force in one dimension, with gravity and normal force acting perpendicular to the surface in opposing directions (gravity downward, and normal force upward).']

['Why was that important?', 'Now that you have the skills to work with forces in two dimensions, we can explore what happens to weight and the normal force on a tilted surface such as an inclined plane.']
['What is the next part of the lesson?', 'For inclined plane problems, it is easier breaking down the forces into their components if we rotate the coordinate system, as illustrated in Figure 5.34.']
['What is the first step when setting up a problem?', 'The first step when setting up the problem is to break down the force of weight into components.']

['What is the force of gravity divided into when an object rests on an incline?', 'When an object rests on an incline that makes an angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ with the horizontal, the force of gravity acting on the object is divided into two components:']
['What are these two components?', 'A force acting perpendicular to the plane, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{\\bot}\\)$$, and a force acting parallel to the plane, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{||}\\)$$ .']

['What happens to the angular momentum of an object as it changes from vertical to horizontal?', 'The perpendicular force of weight, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{\\bot}\\)$$, is typically equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the normal force, $$\\(\\mathbf{N}.\\)$$']
['What happens after the object starts to accelerate?', 'The force acting parallel to the plane, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{||}\\)$$, causes the object to accelerate down the incline.']
['What happens after the object has accelerated down the incline?', 'The force of friction, $$\\(\\mathbf{f}\\)$$, opposes the motion of the object, so it acts upward along the plane.']
['What is important to be careful when resolving the weight of the object into components?', 'It is important to be careful when resolving the weight of the object into components.']
['Why is that?', 'If the angle of the incline is at an angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ to the horizontal, then the magnitudes of the weight components are']
['What is important to know about the equations?', 'Instead of memorizing these equations, it is helpful to be able to determine them from reason.']
['How do you determine the weight vectors?', 'To do this, draw the right triangle formed by the three weight vectors.']
['What other interesting things do you find?', 'Notice that the angle   of the incline is the same as the angle formed between $$\\(\\mathbf{w}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{\\bot}\\)$$ .']
['What are the angles of the tetrahedron?', 'Knowing this property, you can use trigonometry to determine the magnitude of the weight components']
['How many degrees of freedom is the plane incline?', 'Draw a sketch of the problem.']
['What are the angles of incidence of each object?', 'Identify known and unknown quantities, and identify the system of interest.']

['How are the forces acting on the objects?', 'Draw a free-body diagram (which is a sketch showing all of the forces acting on an object) with the coordinate system rotated at the same angle as the inclined plane.']
['Does the diagram show both vectors in parallel with each other?', 'Resolve the vectors into horizontal and vertical components and draw them on the free-body diagram.']
['Do you have the forces acting on the object?', 'Write Newton’s second law in the horizontal and vertical directions and add the forces acting on the object.']
['How does the equation of motion show the acceleration of the object?', 'If the object does not accelerate in a particular direction (for example, the x -direction) then Fnet x = 0.']
['Is the incline of the plane equal to 0?', 'If the object does accelerate in that direction, Fnet x = ma.']
['Do you know the value of m?', 'Check your answer.']
['What kind of example do we need to use?', 'Imagine a car parked against a wall.']
['What happens if a bulldozer pushes the car into the wall?', 'If a bulldozer pushes the car into the wall, the car will not move but it will noticeably change shape.']
["What is the car's shape after it was pushed into the wall?", 'A change in shape due to the application of a force is a deformation.']
['What kind of force causes deformation?', 'Even very small forces are known to cause some deformation.']
['What happens to the car when it is subjected to a small force?', 'For small deformations, two important things can happen.']
['What does the article say about this?', 'First, unlike the car and bulldozer example, the object returns to its original shape when the force is removed.']
['What else do we know about this?', 'Second, the size of the deformation is proportional to the force.']
['What is this known as?', 'This second property is known as Hooke’s law.']
['What is the equation of Hooke’s law?', 'In equation form, Hooke’s law is']

['what is it about?', 'where x is the amount of deformation (the change in length, for example) produced by the restoring force F, and k is a constant that depends on the shape and composition of the object.']

['What is the force that brings the object back to its equilibrium position?', 'The restoring force is the force that brings the object back to its equilibrium position; the minus sign is there because the restoring force acts in the direction opposite to the displacement.']
['What does it mean that the restoring force is proportional to the deformation x?', 'Note that the restoring force is proportional to the deformation x.']
['What is another name for deformation?', 'The deformation can also be thought of as a displacement from equilibrium.']
['What is displacement?', 'It is a change in position due to a force.']
['What would happen if there was no force?', 'In the absence of force, the object would rest at its equilibrium position.']
['What is related to the force constant k?', 'The force constant k is related to the stiffness of a system.']
['What is the relationship between the force constant and the stiffness of a system?', 'The larger the force constant, the stiffer the system.']
['What is more important to know about stiffness?', 'A stiffer system is more difficult to deform and requires a greater restoring force.']
['What is the unit of k?', 'The units of k are newtons per meter (N/m).']

['What is one of the most common uses of Hooke’s law?', 'One of the most common uses of Hooke’s law is solving problems involving springs and pendulums, which we will cover at the end of this section.']
['What do all of these things have in common?', 'They all oscillate.']
['What does the word "oscillate" mean?', 'That is, they move back and forth between two points, like the ruler illustrated in Figure 5.37.']
['What is involved in oscillations?', 'All oscillations involve force.']
['What can you tell me about the force?', 'For example, you push a child in a swing to get the motion started.']
['What does Newton’s first law mean?', 'Newton’s first law implies that an object oscillating back and forth is experiencing forces.']
['How do we know?', 'Without force, the object would move in a straight line at a constant speed rather than oscillate.']
['What kind of examples do you have for this?', 'Consider, for example, plucking a plastic ruler to the left as shown in Figure 5.38.']
['What kind of force?', 'The deformation of the ruler creates a force in the opposite direction, known as a restoring force.']
["What happens to the ruler after it's released?", 'Once released, the restoring force causes the ruler to move back toward its stable equilibrium position, where the net force on it is zero.']
['How does the ruler get there?', 'However, by the time the ruler gets there, it gains momentum and continues to move to the right, producing the opposite deformation.']
['What happens after that?', 'It is then forced to the left, back through equilibrium, and the process is repeated until it gradually loses all of its energy.']
['What is the simplest form of oscillation?', 'The simplest oscillations occur when the restoring force is directly proportional to displacement.']
['How do you know this?', 'Recall that Hooke’s law describes this situation with the equation F = −kx.']
['What else did you say?', 'Therefore, Hooke’s law describes and applies to the simplest case of oscillation, known as simple harmonic motion.']
['What is a simple example of a sustained note?', 'When you pluck a guitar string, the resulting sound has a steady tone and lasts a long time.']
['What happens to the string while it vibrates?', 'Each vibration of the string takes the same time as the previous one.']

['What is a motion that repeats itself at regular time intervals?', 'Periodic motion is a motion that repeats itself at regular time intervals, such as with an object bobbing up and down on a spring or a pendulum swinging back and forth.']
['What is the time to complete one oscillation?', 'The time to complete one oscillation (a complete cycle of motion) remains constant and is called the period T.']
['What is the units of time?', 'Its units are usually seconds.']
['What is the significance of frequency?', 'Frequency f is the number of oscillations per unit time.']
['What is the SI unit for frequency?', 'The SI unit for frequency is the hertz (Hz), defined as the number of oscillations per second.']
['What is the relationship between frequency and period?', 'The relationship between frequency and period is']
['What is the difference between frequency and period?', 'As you can see from the equation, frequency and period are different ways of expressing the same concept.']
['What do these terms mean?', 'For example, if you get a paycheck twice a month, you could say that the frequency of payment is two per month, or that the period between checks is half a month.']

['What is a definition of tangent function?', 'If there is no friction to slow it down, then an object in simple motion will oscillate forever with equal displacement on either side of the equilibrium position.']
['What is the equilibrium position?', 'The equilibrium position is where the object would naturally rest in the absence of force.']
['What is the maximum displacement from equilibrium called?', 'The maximum displacement from equilibrium is called the amplitude X.']
['Are displacement and amplitude the same?', 'The units for amplitude and displacement are the same, but depend on the type of oscillation.']
['What type of oscillation is the object on the spring?', 'For the object on the spring, shown in Figure 5.39, the units of amplitude and displacement are meters.']

['What are the only factors that affect the period and frequency of simple harmonic motion?', 'The mass m and the force constant k are the only factors that affect the period and frequency of simple harmonic motion.']
['How is the period of a simple harmonic oscillator determined?', 'The period of a simple harmonic oscillator is given by']

['What is the first step that you need to take before solving problems with springs and pendulums?', 'Before solving problems with springs and pendulums, it is important to first get an understanding of how a pendulum works.']
['What is an example of a simple pendulum?', 'Figure 5.40 provides a useful illustration of a simple pendulum.']
['What is an example of a pendulum?', 'Everyday examples of pendulums include old-fashioned clocks, a child’s swing, or the sinker on a fishing line.']

['What is the force acting on a pendulum?', 'For small displacements of less than 15 degrees, a pendulum experiences simple harmonic oscillation, meaning that its restoring force is directly proportional to its displacement.']
['What is a simple pendulum?', 'A pendulum in simple harmonic motion is called a simple pendulum.']
['What is the pendulum bob made of?', 'A pendulum has an object with a small mass, also known as the pendulum bob, which hangs from a light wire or string.']
['What is the equilibrium position for a pendulum?', 'The equilibrium position for a pendulum is where the angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is zero (that is, when the pendulum is hanging straight down).']
['What is the equilibrium position of a pendulum?', 'It makes sense that without any force applied, this is where the pendulum bob would rest.']
['What displacement of the pendulum bob is mentioned in the section?', 'The displacement of the pendulum bob is the arc length s.']
['What are the two components of the weight mg?', 'The weight mg has components mg cos $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ along the string and mg sin $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  tangent to the arc.']
['What happens to the string tension?', 'Tension in the string exactly cancels the component mg cos $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ parallel to the string.']
['What is left from the weight?', 'This leaves a net restoring force back toward the equilibrium position that runs tangent to the arc and equals −mg sin $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What is the relationship between the period of a simple pendulum and its length?', 'The only things that affect the period of a simple pendulum are its length and the acceleration due to gravity.']
['What other factors affect the period of a simple pendulum?', 'The period is completely independent of other factors, such as mass or amplitude.']
['Is there anything else important to know about T?', 'However, note that T does depend on g.']
['What does g represent?', 'This means that if we know the length of a pendulum, we can actually use it to measure gravity!']
['What will this lead to?', 'This will come in useful in Measuring Acceleration due to Gravity: The Period of a Pendulum.']
['What is the circular motion of an object about an axis of rotation?', 'Rotational motion is the circular motion of an object about an axis of rotation.']
['What else are we talking about?', 'We will discuss specifically circular motion and spin.']
['What is the definition of circular motion?', 'Circular motion is when an object moves in a circular path.']

['What are some examples of circular motion?', 'Examples of circular motion include a race car speeding around a circular curve, a toy attached to a string swinging in a circle around your head, or the circular loop-the-loop on a roller coaster.']

['What is the definition of spin?', 'Spin is rotation about an axis that goes through the center of mass of the object, such as Earth rotating on its axis, a wheel turning on its axle, the spin of a tornado on its path of destruction, or a figure skater spinning during a performance at the Olympics.']

['Do the two motions interfere with each other?', 'Sometimes, objects will be spinning while in circular motion, like the Earth spinning on its axis while revolving around the Sun, but we will focus on these two motions separately.']

['What is rotational motion?', 'When solving problems involving rotational motion, we use variables that are similar to linear variables (distance, velocity, acceleration, and force) but take into account the curvature or rotation of the motion.']

['What does the angle of rotation mean?', 'Here, we define the angle of rotation, which is the angular equivalence of distance; and angular velocity, which is the angular equivalence of linear velocity.']
['What is the distance traveled along a circular path called?', 'The arc length,  , is the distance traveled along a circular path.']
['What is the radius of curvature?', 'The radius of curvature, r, is the radius of the circular path.']
['What are the two examples of these concepts in this section?', 'Both are shown in Figure 6.3.']
['What are the angles for each of these points?', 'Consider a line from the center of the CD to its edge.']
["What is the line's angle of inclination?", 'In a given time, each pit (used to record information) on this line moves through the same angle.']
['What is the angle of rotation?', 'The angle of rotation is the amount of rotation and is the angular analog of distance.']
['What is the angular analog of distance?', 'The angle of rotation  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\theta\\)$$  is the arc length divided by the radius of curvature.']
['What is the unit used to measure the angle of rotation?', 'The angle of rotation is often measured by using a unit called the radian.']
['What is the radian defined as?', '(Radians are actually dimensionless, because a radian is defined as the ratio of two distances, radius and arc length.)']

['What is one complete rotation, where every point on the circle returns to its original position?', 'A revolution is one complete rotation, where every point on the circle returns to its original position.']

['How many radians does one revolution cover?', 'One revolution covers  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$  radians (or 360 degrees), and therefore has an angle of rotation of  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$  radians, and an arc length that is the same as the circumference of the circle.']
['Can you explain how radians and revolutions can be converted?', 'We can convert between radians, revolutions, and degrees using the relationship']
['How many revolutions does a revolution of the Earth take?', '1 revolution =  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$ rad = 360°.']
['How many radians are in 1 revolution?', 'See Table 6.1 for the conversion of degrees to radians for some common angles.']
['How do we find the distance that a ship travels?', 'We can answer this question by using the concept of angular velocity.']
['How is angular speed related to distance?', 'Consider first the angular speed  $$\\((\\omega)\\)$$  is the rate at which the angle of rotation changes.']
['What is the angular speed?', 'In equation form, the angular speed is']
['What is the tangent of an angle?', 'which means that an angular rotation  $$\\((\\Delta\\theta)\\)$$  occurs in a time,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$ .']
['What does the term angular speed mean?', 'If an object rotates through a greater angle of rotation in a given time, it has a greater angular speed.']
['What are the units for angular speed?', 'The units for angular speed are radians per second (rad/s).']
['What is the direction of the angular speed?', 'Now let’s consider the direction of the angular speed, which means we now must call it the angular velocity.']
['What direction of the angular velocity is along the axis of rotation?', 'The direction of the angular velocity is along the axis of rotation.']
['How did it relate to an object rotating clockwise?', 'For an object rotating clockwise, the angular velocity points away from you along the axis of rotation.']
['What does it relate to an object rotating counterclockwise?', 'For an object rotating counterclockwise, the angular velocity points toward you along the axis of rotation.']

['What is the instantaneous linear velocity of an object in rotational motion?', 'Angular velocity (ω) is the angular version of linear velocity v. Tangential velocity is the instantaneous linear velocity of an object in rotational motion.']

['What is the relationship between tangential velocity and angular velocity?', 'To get the precise relationship between angular velocity and tangential velocity, consider again a pit on the rotating CD.']
['What happens to the pit in the rotating CD?', 'This pit moves through an arc length  $$\\[(\\Delta s)\\]$$  in a short time  $$\\[(\\Delta t)\\]$$  so its tangential speed is']

['What did you discover in your investigation?', 'From the definition of the angle of rotation,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\theta = \\frac{\\text{Δ}s}{r}\\)$$, we see that  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s = r\\text{Δ}\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What else did you discover?', 'Substituting this into the expression for v gives']
['What does the equation mean?', 'The equation  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$  says that the tangential speed v is proportional to the distance r from the center of rotation.']

['What does that mean for a CD?', 'Consequently, tangential speed is greater for a point on the outer edge of the CD (with larger r) than for a point closer to the center of the CD (with smaller r).']
['Why is that?', 'This makes sense because a point farther out from the center has to cover a longer arc length in the same amount of time as a point closer to the center.']

['What is the difference between the case in which the tangential speed is equal and the case in which the angular speed is equal?', 'Note that both points will still have the same angular speed, regardless of their distance from the center of rotation.']
['What can you tell me about Figure 6.4?', 'See Figure 6.4.']
['1. What is the definition of a spherical object?', 'Now, consider another example: the tire of a moving car (see Figure 6.5).']
['How does this compare to the previous example?', 'The faster the tire spins, the faster the car moves—large  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  means large v because  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$ .']

['Does it matter which one of these is larger?', 'Similarly, a larger-radius tire rotating at the same angular velocity,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\omega}\\)$$, will produce a greater linear (tangential) velocity, v, for the car.']
['Why is this the case?', 'This is because a larger radius means a longer arc length must contact the road, so the car must move farther in the same amount of time.']
['What is linear velocity?', 'However, there are cases where linear velocity and tangential velocity are not equivalent, such as a car spinning its tires on ice.']
['What happens in this case?', 'In this case, the linear velocity will be less than the tangential velocity.']

['What is the arc length?', 'Due to the lack of friction under the tires of a car on ice, the arc length through which the tire treads move is greater than the linear distance through which the car moves.']
['What does this mean?', 'It’s similar to running on a treadmill or pedaling a stationary bike; you are literally going nowhere fast.']
['What is the previous section called?', 'In the previous section, we defined circular motion.']
['What is the simplest case of circular motion?', 'The simplest case of circular motion is uniform circular motion, where an object travels a circular path at a constant speed.']

['What happens when an object goes from one direction to another?', 'Note that, unlike speed, the linear velocity of an object in circular motion is constantly changing because it is always changing direction.']
['What is the difference between acceleration and deceleration?', 'We know from kinematics that acceleration is a change in velocity, either in magnitude or in direction or both.']
['What is constant velocity?', 'Therefore, an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always accelerating, even though the magnitude of its velocity is constant.']
['How does this affect everyday life?', 'You experience this acceleration yourself every time you ride in a car while it turns a corner.']
['What happens to you in the car when you turn?', 'If you hold the steering wheel steady during the turn and move at a constant speed, you are executing uniform circular motion.']
['What happens when the speed changes?', 'What you notice is a feeling of sliding (or being flung, depending on the speed) away from the center of the turn.']

['Is this a physical reaction?', 'This isn’t an actual force that is acting on you—it only happens because your body wants to continue moving in a straight line (as per Newton’s first law) whereas the car is turning off this straight-line path.']
['How does this feel to you?', 'Inside the car it appears as if you are forced away from the center of the turn.']
['What is the force called?', 'This fictitious force is known as the centrifugal force.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'The sharper the curve and the greater your speed, the more noticeable this effect becomes.']
['What do you find in Figure 6.7?', 'Figure 6.7 shows an object moving in a circular path at constant speed.']
['What does the figure show?', 'The direction of the instantaneous tangential velocity is shown at two points along the path.']
['What is the direction of the change in velocity in centripetal?', 'Acceleration is in the direction of the change in velocity; in this case it points roughly toward the center of rotation.']
['Is the center of rotation a point?', '(The center of rotation is at the center of the circular path).']

['Does the acceleration change as the object gets smaller?', 'If we imagine  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s\\)$$  becoming smaller and smaller, then the acceleration would point exactly toward the center of rotation, but this case is hard to draw.']

['What is the acceleration called when it is uniform circular motion?', 'We call the acceleration of an object moving in uniform circular motion the centripetal acceleration ac because centripetal means center seeking.']

['What does centripetal acceleration mean?', 'Now that we know that the direction of centripetal acceleration is toward the center of rotation, let’s discuss the magnitude of centripetal acceleration.']
['What is the magnitude of centripetal acceleration?', 'For an object traveling at speed v in a circular path with radius r, the magnitude of centripetal acceleration is']

['What is centripetal acceleration?', 'Centripetal acceleration is greater at high speeds and in sharp curves (smaller radius), as you may have noticed when driving a car, because the car actually pushes you toward the center of the turn.']
['What is significant about ac?', 'But it is a bit surprising that ac is proportional to the speed squared.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means, for example, that the acceleration is four times greater when you take a curve at 100 km/h than at 50 km/h.']
['What is the ac defined as?', 'We can also express ac in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity.']
['What is the magnitude of angular velocity?', 'Substituting  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$  into the equation above, we get  $$\\(a_{c} = \\frac{{(r\\omega)}^{2}}{r} = r\\omega^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What is the significance of this equation?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal acceleration in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity is']
['What is the governing equation for a centripetal acceleration?', 'Any force or combination of forces can cause a centripetal acceleration.']

['What is an example of a force?', 'Just a few examples are the tension in the rope on a tether ball, the force of Earth’s gravity on the Moon, the friction between a road and the tires of a car as it goes around a curve, or the normal force of a roller coaster track on the cart during a loop-the-loop.']
['What kind of force is this?', 'Any net force causing uniform circular motion is called a centripetal force.']
['What direction does a centripetal force point?', 'The direction of a centripetal force is toward the center of rotation, the same as for centripetal acceleration.']
['How does it cause acceleration?', 'According to Newton’s second law of motion, a net force causes the acceleration of mass according to Fnet = ma.']
['What is the acceleration of a uniform circular motion?', 'For uniform circular motion, the acceleration is centripetal acceleration: a = ac.']
['What is the magnitude of centripetal force, Fc?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal force, Fc, is  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\mathbf{a}_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']

['Why is the force constant?', 'By using the two different forms of the equation for the magnitude of centripetal acceleration,  $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{\\text{c}} = {v^{2}/r}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{c} = r\\omega^{2}\\)$$, we get two expressions involving the magnitude of the centripetal force Fc.']

['Are the expressions related to each other?', 'The first expression is in terms of tangential speed, the second is in terms of angular speed:  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\frac{v^{2}}{r}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = mr\\omega^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about the constant net external force?', 'Both forms of the equation depend on mass, velocity, and the radius of the circular path.']
['What is the force that causes a spinning object to turn?', 'You may use whichever expression for centripetal force is more convenient.']
['What else can you tell me about constant net external force?', 'Newton’s second law also states that the object will accelerate in the same direction as the net force.']

['What is the force that causes an object to accelerate towards the center of a circle?', 'By definition, the centripetal force is directed towards the center of rotation, so the object will also accelerate towards the center.']

['What is the other important point about constant net external force?', 'A straight line drawn from the circular path to the center of the circle will always be perpendicular to the tangential velocity.']
['What can you tell me about centripetal force?', 'Note that, if you solve the first expression for r, you get']

['What is the first thing you should know before we continue?', 'To get a feel for the typical magnitudes of centripetal acceleration, we’ll do a lab estimating the centripetal acceleration of a tennis racket and then, in our first Worked Example, compare the centripetal acceleration of a car rounding a curve to gravitational acceleration.']
["What are the next few things we'll be doing?", 'For the second Worked Example, we’ll calculate the force required to make a car round a curve.']
['What are some of the more important points?', 'In the section on uniform circular motion, we discussed motion in a circle at constant speed and, therefore, constant angular velocity.']
['How is it different from a constant velocity?', 'However, there are times when angular velocity is not constant—rotational motion can speed up, slow down, or reverse directions.']

['What are some examples of angular velocity?', 'Angular velocity is not constant when a spinning skater pulls in her arms, when a child pushes a merry-go-round to make it rotate, or when a CD slows to a halt when switched off.']
['What causes angular acceleration?', 'In all these cases, angular acceleration occurs because the angular velocity  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  changes.']
['What is an angular acceleration?', 'The faster the change occurs, the greater is the angular acceleration.']
['What is angular acceleration related to?', 'Angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is the rate of change of angular velocity.']

['What are the units of angular acceleration?', 'The units of angular acceleration are (rad/s)/s, or rad/s2.']
['What is positive acceleration?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  increases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is positive.']
['What is negative acceleration?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  decreases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is negative.']
['What else can you tell me about acceleration?', 'Keep in mind that, by convention, counterclockwise is the positive direction and clockwise is the negative direction.']

['What is negative acceleration?', 'Acceleration would be negative, for example, when an object that is rotating counterclockwise slows down.']
['What is positive acceleration?', 'It would be positive when an object that is rotating counterclockwise speeds up.']
['What do these equations mean?', 'These equations mean that the magnitudes of tangential acceleration and angular acceleration are directly proportional to each other.']
['How does this relate to other forces?', 'The greater the angular acceleration, the larger the change in tangential acceleration, and vice versa.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, consider riders in their pods on a Ferris wheel at rest.']

['Why would the riders have greater acceleration than the resting ones?', 'A Ferris wheel with greater angular acceleration will give the riders greater tangential acceleration because, as the Ferris wheel increases its rate of spinning, it also increases its tangential velocity.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'Note that the radius of the spinning object also matters.']
['What else does this mean?', 'For example, for a given angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$, a smaller Ferris wheel leads to a smaller tangential acceleration for the riders.']
['What are the rotational variables?', 'So far, we have defined three rotational variables:  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$.']

['What is an example of a rotational quantity?', 'For example, if a motorcycle wheel that starts at rest has a large angular acceleration for a fairly long time, it ends up spinning rapidly and rotates through many revolutions.']

['How does it rotate?', 'Putting this in terms of the variables, if the wheel’s angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is large for a long period of time t, then the final angular velocity  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  and angle of rotation  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  are large.']

['How does this apply to linear motion?', 'In the case of linear motion, if an object starts at rest and undergoes a large linear acceleration, then it has a large final velocity and will have traveled a large distance.']
['What is the kinematics of rotational motion?', 'The kinematics of rotational motion describes the relationships between the angle of rotation, angular velocity, angular acceleration, and time.']
['What is the difference between kinetics and dynamics?', 'It only describes motion—it does not include any forces or masses that may affect rotation (these are part of dynamics).']
['What does it look like?', 'Recall the kinematics equation for linear motion:  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = \\mathbf{v}_{0} + \\mathbf{a}t\\)$$  (constant a).']

['What is the relationship between angular acceleration and a constant?', 'As in linear kinematics, we assume a is constant, which means that angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is also a constant, because  $$\\(\\mathbf{a} = r\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$ .']

['What is torque?', 'If you have ever spun a bike wheel or pushed a merry-go-round, you know that force is needed to change angular velocity.']
['What is torque?', 'The farther the force is applied from the pivot point (or fulcrum), the greater the angular acceleration.']
['What is another example of a force acting on a medium?', 'For example, a door opens slowly if you push too close to its hinge, but opens easily if you push far from the hinges.']

['What is another example of angular acceleration?', 'Furthermore, we know that the more massive the door is, the more slowly it opens; this is because angular acceleration is inversely proportional to mass.']

['What is interesting about the relationships between force, mass, and acceleration from Newton’s second law of motion?', 'These relationships are very similar to the relationships between force, mass, and acceleration from Newton’s second law of motion.']

['Is there anything else that you want to know?', 'Since we have already covered the angular versions of distance, velocity and time, you may wonder what the angular version of force is, and how it relates to linear force.']

['What is the vector from the point of rotation (pivot point or fulcrum) to the location where force is applied?', 'The lever arm is the vector from the point of rotation (pivot point or fulcrum) to the location where force is applied.']
['What are the units for the magnitude of the lever arm?', 'Since the magnitude of the lever arm is a distance, its units are in meters, and torque has units of N⋅m.']
['What is the direction of the torque?', 'Torque is a vector quantity and has the same direction as the angular acceleration that it produces.']
['What is torque?', 'Applying a stronger torque will produce a greater angular acceleration.']
['What causes an object to accelerate?', 'For example, the harder the man pushes the merry-go-round in Figure 6.11, the faster it accelerates.']
['What causes the acceleration to be slower than it would otherwise?', 'Furthermore, the more massive the merry-go-round is, the slower it accelerates for the same torque.']

['What is the lever arm and leverage?', 'If the man wants to maximize the effect of his force on the merry-go-round, he should push as far from the center as possible to get the largest lever arm and, therefore, the greatest torque and angular acceleration.']
['What is torque?', 'Torque is also maximized when the force is applied perpendicular to the lever arm.']
['What are the linear and rotational forces?', 'Just as linear forces can balance to produce zero net force and no linear acceleration, the same is true of rotational motion.']

['What is the difference between rotational and linear force?', 'When two torques of equal magnitude act in opposing directions, there is no net torque and no angular acceleration, as you can see in the following video.']
['How do the two forces interact?', 'If zero net torque acts on a system spinning at a constant angular velocity, the system will continue to spin at the same angular velocity.']
['What kinds of orbits does Kepler describe?', 'Examples of orbits abound.']
['What kinds of objects are orbiting the Earth?', 'Hundreds of artificial satellites orbit Earth together with thousands of pieces of debris.']
['What is the moon’s orbit around Earth?', 'The moon’s orbit around Earth has intrigued humans from time immemorial.']
['What are the orbits of other objects?', 'The orbits of planets, asteroids, meteors, and comets around the sun are no less interesting.']

['How do the orbits of other objects compare?', 'If we look farther, we see almost unimaginable numbers of stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects orbiting one another and interacting through gravity.']
['What is the formula for the formula A = 1/2 + 2?', 'All these motions are governed by gravitational force.']

['What did Kepler say about the orbital motions of objects in our own solar system?', 'The orbital motions of objects in our own solar system are simple enough to describe with a few fairly simple laws.']
['What do the orbits of planets and moons satisfy?', 'The orbits of planets and moons satisfy the following two conditions:']
["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's laws?", 'The orbit of each planet around the sun is an ellipse with the sun at one focus.']
["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's second law?", 'Each planet moves so that an imaginary line drawn from the sun to the planet sweeps out equal areas in equal times.']

["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's third law?", 'The ratio of the squares of the periods of any two planets about the sun is equal to the ratio of the cubes of their average distances from the sun.']
['What are the descriptive laws named for?', 'These descriptive laws are named for the German astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571–1630).']

['What did Johannes Kepler devise?', 'He devised them after careful study (over some 20 years) of a large amount of meticulously recorded observations of planetary motion done by Tycho Brahe (1546–1601).']
['What was the study based on?', 'Such careful collection and detailed recording of methods and data are hallmarks of good science.']
['What are these data used for?', 'Data constitute the evidence from which new interpretations and meanings can be constructed.']
['What else is interesting in the article?', 'Let’s look closer at each of these laws.']
['What was the first law of motion?', 'The orbit of each planet about the sun is an ellipse with the sun at one focus, as shown in Figure 7.2.']
['What is the ellipse?', 'The planet’s closest approach to the sun is called perihelion and its farthest distance from the sun is called aphelion.']
['What is Kepler’s Third Law?', 'The ratio of the periods squared of any two planets around the sun is equal to the ratio of their average distances from the sun cubed.']
["What is true about Kepler's Third Law?", 'In equation form, this is']

['What else is constant?', 'The definition of an ellipse states that the sum of the distances  $$\\(\\overline{f_{1}m} + \\overline{mf_{2}}\\)$$  is also constant.']
['What else is constant?', 'These two facts taken together mean that the perimeter of triangle  $$\\(\\Delta f_{1}mf_{2}\\)$$  must also be constant.']
['What are the constants of the solar system?', 'Knowledge of these constants will help you determine positions and distances of objects in a system that includes one object orbiting another.']

['What is the second law of motion?', 'The second law says that the segments have equal area and that it takes equal time to sweep through each segment.']

['What does it mean to say that the time it takes to travel from A to B equals the time it takes to travel from C to D, and so forth?', 'That is, the time it takes to travel from A to B equals the time it takes to travel from C to D, and so forth.']
['What else did you learn about this?', 'Velocity v equals distance d divided by time t:  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = {d/t}\\)$$ .']
['What is it a constant for?', 'Then,  $$\\(t = {d/\\mathbf{v}}\\)$$, so distance divided by velocity is also a constant.']
['How does this relate to the Earth?', 'For example, if we know the average velocity of Earth on June 21 and December 21, we can compare the distance Earth travels on those days.']
['What is the degree of elongation of an elliptical orbit called?', 'The degree of elongation of an elliptical orbit is called its eccentricity (e).']
['How is eccentricity calculated?', 'Eccentricity is calculated by dividing the distance f from the center of an ellipse to one of the foci by half the long axis a.']
['What is the area of an ellipse?', 'The area of an ellipse is given by  $$\\(A = \\pi ab\\)$$, where b is half the short axis.']

['What is an example of calculating the area of the Earth in an orbit?', 'If you know the axes of Earth’s orbit and the area Earth sweeps out in a given period of time, you can calculate the fraction of the year that has elapsed.']

['What is the name of the scientist who discovered the gravitational force?', 'Sir Isaac Newton was the first scientist to precisely define the gravitational force, and to show that it could explain both falling bodies and astronomical motions.']
['What is a significant part of this document?', 'See Figure 7.7.']
['What did Newton discover?', 'But Newton was not the first to suspect that the same force caused both our weight and the motion of planets.']

['Who was the first one to believe that falling bodies and planetary motions had the same cause?', 'His forerunner, Galileo Galilei, had contended that falling bodies and planetary motions had the same cause.']
['What are some examples of this theory?', 'Some of Newton’s contemporaries, such as Robert Hooke, Christopher Wren, and Edmund Halley, had also made some progress toward understanding gravitation.']

['What was the first mathematical form?', 'But Newton was the first to propose an exact mathematical form and to use that form to show that the motion of heavenly bodies should be conic sections—circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.']
['What was the significance of this?', 'This theoretical prediction was a major triumph.']

['How did this form relate to the movement of bodies?', 'It had been known for some time that moons, planets, and comets follow such paths, but no one had been able to propose an explanation of the mechanism that caused them to follow these paths and not others.']
['What is the gravitational force?', 'The gravitational force is relatively simple.']
['What is the relationship between the masses involved and the distance between them?', 'It is always attractive, and it depends only on the masses involved and the distance between them.']

['What does this explain about objects and bodies?', 'Expressed in modern language, Newton’s universal law of gravitation states that every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force that is directed along a line joining them.']
['How does this force affect objects?', 'The force is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.']
['Is there anything else you would like to know about the gravitational force?', 'This attraction is illustrated by Figure 7.8.']

['What has it been measured to be?', 'It has been measured experimentally to be  $$\\(G = 6.673 \\times 10^{- 11}\\text{N} \\cdot \\text{m}^{\\text{2}}\\text{/kg}^{\\text{2}}\\)$$ .']
['What are the first three numbers in the equation G?', 'G is given above, Earth’s mass M is 5.97 × 1024 kg, and the radius r of Earth is 6.38 × 106 m.']
['What is the relation between G and M and r?', 'Putting these values into Newton’s universal law of gravitation gives']

['How does it effect the equation?', 'By substituting g for a in the equation for Newton’s second law of motion we get  $$\\(\\mathbf{F} = m\\mathbf{g}\\)$$ .']
['What is the result of the second law of motion?', 'Combining this with the equation for universal gravitation gives']

['What is mass?', 'Mass is the amount of matter in an object; weight is the force of attraction between the mass within two objects.']
['What causes weight to change?', 'Weight can change because g is different on every moon and planet.']
["What is an object's mass?", 'An object’s mass m does not change but its weight mg can.']

['Why can it be derived?', 'Applying Newton’s second law of motion to angular motion gives an expression for centripetal force, which can be equated to the expression for force in the universal gravitation equation.']
['Does it have any other properties?', 'This expression can be manipulated to produce the equation for Kepler’s third law.']
['Are there any other facts about it?', 'We saw earlier that the expression r3/T2 is a constant for satellites orbiting the same massive object.']

['Was this a popular discovery?', 'This discovery created a scientific and public sensation.']

['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is a vector and has the same direction as velocity v. Since mass is a scalar, when velocity is in a negative direction (i.e., opposite the direction of motion), the momentum will also be in a negative direction; and when velocity is in a positive direction, momentum will likewise be in a positive direction.']
['What SI unit for momentum is mentioned?', 'The SI unit for momentum is kg m/s.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is so important for understanding motion that it was called the quantity of motion by physicists such as Newton.']

['What else can you tell me about the material?', 'Recall our study of Newton’s second law of motion (Fnet = ma).']
['What is the second law of motion?', 'Newton actually stated his second law of motion in terms of momentum:']
['What is the relationship between momentum and the net external force?', 'The net external force equals the change in momentum of a system divided by the time over which it changes.']
['What is the difference between the final and initial values of momentum?', 'The change in momentum is the difference between the final and initial values of momentum.']
['What else do we know about impulse?', '$$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{F}}_{\\text{net}}\\text{Δ}t\\)$$is known as impulse and this equation is known as the impulse-momentum theorem.']

['What can it be used for?', 'When Newton’s second law is expressed in terms of momentum, it can be used for solving problems where mass varies, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{\\text{p}} = \\text{Δ}(m\\mathbf{\\text{v}})\\)$$ .']

['What does the conservation of momentum mean?', 'It is important we realize that momentum is conserved during collisions, explosions, and other events involving objects in motion.']
['What does it mean to conserve a quantity?', 'To say that a quantity is conserved means that it is constant throughout the event.']
['What does this mean?', 'In the case of conservation of momentum, the total momentum in the system remains the same before and after the collision.']
['What is conservation of momentum?', 'You may have noticed that momentum was not conserved in some of the examples previously presented in this chapter.']
['Where was momentum not conserved?', 'where forces acting on the objects produced large changes in momentum.']

["Why wasn't momentum conserved?", 'If the systems were expanded to include more objects, then momentum would in fact be conserved in those sample problems.']

['What can happen when momentum is conserved in larger systems?', 'It is always possible to find a larger system where momentum is conserved, even though momentum changes for individual objects within the system.']
['What causes a football player to bounce backward?', 'For example, if a football player runs into the goalpost in the end zone, a force will cause him to bounce backward.']
['What happens to the football player when he bounces back?', 'His momentum is obviously greatly changed, and considering only the football player, we would find that momentum is not conserved.']
['How much momentum is conserved in a system?', 'However, the system can be expanded to contain the entire Earth.']
['What happens to the Earth when it is hit by a football?', 'Surprisingly, Earth also recoils—conserving momentum—because of the force applied to it through the goalpost.']
['How large is the earth?', 'The effect on Earth is not noticeable because it is so much more massive than the player, but the effect is real.']

['What happens if the masses of two colliding objects are more similar than the masses of a football player and Earth?', 'Next, consider what happens if the masses of two colliding objects are more similar than the masses of a football player and Earth—in the example shown in Figure 8.4 of one car bumping into another.']

['How is the friction?', 'The only unbalanced force on each car is the force of the collision, assuming that the effects due to friction are negligible.']
['What happens to car m1 as a result of the collision?', 'Car m1 slows down as a result of the collision, losing some momentum, while car m2 speeds up and gains some momentum.']
['What happened after the collision?', 'If we choose the system to include both cars and assume that friction is negligible, then the momentum of the two-car system should remain constant.']
['How did the examples help?', 'Now we will prove that the total momentum of the two-car system does in fact remain constant, and is therefore conserved.']

['What is the last example?', 'The last example is less obvious.']

['What is the relationship between work and energy?', 'Work and energy are closely related.']

['What is the stored energy an object has as a result of its position above Earth’s surface (or another object in space)?', 'Gravitational potential energy is the stored energy an object has as a result of its position above Earth’s surface (or another object in space).']
['What do you find interesting about gravitational potential energy?', 'A roller coaster car at the top of a hill has gravitational potential energy.']
['What is one of the most important concepts in the document?', 'Let’s examine how doing work on an object changes the object’s energy.']

['What is the equation for the work we do on the rock?', 'The work we do on the rock equals the force we exert multiplied by the distance, d, that we lift the rock.']
['What is this formula equal to?', 'The work we do on the rock also equals the rock’s gain in gravitational potential energy, PEe.']
['What is the difference between kinetic and gravitational energies?', 'When we drop the rock the force of gravity causes the rock to fall, giving the rock kinetic energy.']

['What is an example of a gravitational force causing the rock to fall?', 'When work done on an object increases only its kinetic energy, then the net work equals the change in the value of the quantity $$\\(\\frac{1}{2}m\\mathbf{v}^{2}\\)$$ .']

['What is the example of a pulley?', 'Suppose the woman in Figure 9.3 lifting the TV with a pulley gets the TV to the fourth floor in two minutes, and the man carrying the TV up the stairs takes five minutes to arrive at the same place.']

['How does she know that?', 'However, the woman using the pulley has generated more power.']
['Why is this?', 'This is because she did the work in a shorter amount of time, so the denominator of the power formula, t, is smaller.']
["How do you know the man's force?", '(For simplicity’s sake, we will leave aside for now the fact that the man climbing the stairs has also done work on himself.)']

['What is the recitation?', 'Before proceeding, be sure you understand the distinctions among force, work, energy, and power.']
