['What other energy does the roller coaster have?', 'It is moving slowly, so it also has a small amount of kinetic energy.']
['Why does the car have potential energy?', 'As the car descends the first slope, its PE is converted to KE.']
['At what point does the car reach its lowest point?', 'At the low point much of the original PE has been transformed to KE, and speed is at a maximum.']
['How is the car able to maintain this speed?', 'As the car moves up the next slope, some of the KE is transformed back into PE and the car slows down.']
['What is the energy of a moving object?', 'On an actual roller coaster, there are many ups and downs, and each of these is accompanied by transitions between kinetic and potential energy.']
['What is the difference between friction and potential energy?', 'Assume that no energy is lost to friction.']
['What is the property of mechanical energy?', 'At any point in the ride, the total mechanical energy is the same, and it is equal to the energy the car had at the top of the first rise.']
['How does the energy have to stay the same?', 'This is a result of the law of conservation of energy, which says that, in a closed system, total energy is conserved—that is, it is constant.']
['How is this determined?', 'Using subscripts 1 and 2 to represent initial and final energy, this law is expressed as']
['What is the relationship between the three sides of a right-angled triangle?', 'Either side equals the total mechanical energy.']
['What is the phrase in a closed system?', 'The phrase in a closed system means we are assuming no energy is lost to the surroundings due to friction and air resistance.']
['What is a good assumption to make?', 'If we are making calculations on dense falling objects, this is a good assumption.']
['What are two other cases of the closed system assumption?', 'For the roller coaster, this assumption introduces some inaccuracy to the calculation.']
['What are simple machines?', 'Simple machines make work easier, but they do not decrease the amount of work you have to do.']
['Do they conserve energy?', 'Recall that in closed systems the total amount of energy is conserved.']

['Are there other factors involved with these machines?', 'Although it cannot change the amount of work you do, a simple machine can change the amount of force you must apply to an object, and the distance over which you apply the force.']
['What can be done with these machines?', 'In most cases, a simple machine is used to reduce the amount of force you must exert to do work.']

['Why must you exert force over a greater distance?', 'The down side is that you must exert the force over a greater distance, because the product of force and distance, fd, (which equals work) does not change.']
['What is the topic of our discussion?', 'Let’s examine how this works in practice.']

['What is one example of this in practice?', 'In Figure 9.8(a), the worker uses a type of lever to exert a small force over a large distance, while the pry bar pulls up on the nail with a large force over a small distance.']
['What is another example of this?', 'Figure 9.8(b) shows the how a lever works mathematically.']
['What is the force that lifts the load?', 'The effort force, applied at Fe, lifts the load (the resistance force) which is pushing down at Fr.']

['What is the next step in the process of determining the mechanical advantage of a lever?', 'The triangular pivot is called the fulcrum; the part of the lever between the fulcrum and Fe is the effort arm, Le; and the part to the left is the resistance arm, Lr. The mechanical advantage is a number that tells us how many times a simple machine multiplies the effort force.']

['What is the ideal mechanical advantage?', 'The ideal mechanical advantage, IMA, is the mechanical advantage of a perfect machine with no loss of useful work caused by friction between moving parts.']
['What is the equation for IMA?', 'The equation for IMA is shown in Figure 9.8(b).']
['What is this about?', 'Getting back to conservation of energy, for any simple machine, the work put into the machine, Wi, equals the work the machine puts out, Wo.']
['What happens with respect to a given machine?', 'Combining this with the information in the paragraphs above, we can write']
['What is a lever?', 'Some levers exert a large force to a short effort arm.']
['What happens when the resistance arm is short?', 'This results in a smaller force acting over a greater distance at the end of the resistance arm.']
['What type of levers do they make?', 'Examples of this type of lever are baseball bats, hammers, and golf clubs.']
['What is another example of a lever?', 'In another type of lever, the fulcrum is at the end of the lever and the load is in the middle, as in the design of a wheelbarrow.']
['What kind of simple machine is shown in Figure 9.9?', 'The simple machine shown in Figure 9.9 is called a wheel and axle.']
['What is a wheel and axle?', 'It is actually a form of lever.']
["What's different about the wheel and axle from a lever?", 'The difference is that the effort arm can rotate in a complete circle around the fulcrum, which is the center of the axle.']
['What are the forces acting on this wheel?', 'Force applied to the outside of the wheel causes a greater force to be applied to the rope that is wrapped around the axle.']
['What is the ideal mechanical advantage?', 'As shown in the figure, the ideal mechanical advantage is calculated by dividing the radius of the wheel by the radius of the axle.']
['What is an example of a wheel and axle?', 'Any crank-operated device is an example of a wheel and axle.']
['What is a simple machine?', 'An inclined plane and a wedge are two forms of the same simple machine.']
['What is a wedge?', 'A wedge is simply two inclined planes back to back.']
['What are the simple formulas for calculating the IMAs of these machines?', 'Figure 9.10 shows the simple formulas for calculating the IMAs of these machines.']
['What is an inclined plane?', 'All sloping, paved surfaces for walking or driving are inclined planes.']
['What are some examples of wedges?', 'Knives and axe heads are examples of wedges.']
['What is an example of a simple machine?', 'The screw shown in Figure 9.11 is actually a lever attached to a circular inclined plane.']
['What is an example of a screw?', 'Wood screws (of course) are also examples of screws.']
['What is an example of a lever?', 'The lever part of these screws is a screw driver.']
['What is the formula for IMA?', 'In the formula for IMA, the distance between screw threads is called pitch and has the symbol P.']
['What is the first figure in this section?', 'Figure 9.12 shows three different pulley systems.']
['What can you tell me about pulleys?', 'Of all simple machines, mechanical advantage is easiest to calculate for pulleys.']
['How do you calculate the load on a sling?', 'Simply count the number of ropes supporting the load.']
['What is the total distance over which a force is applied?', 'That is the IMA.']
['What happens to the force with more ropes?', 'Once again we have to exert force over a longer distance to multiply force.']
['Why do we have to exert force over a longer distance?', 'To raise a load 1 meter with a pulley system you have to pull N meters of rope.']
['What are some uses of pulley systems?', 'Pulley systems are often used to raise flags and window blinds and are part of the mechanism of construction cranes.']
['What is a complex machine?', 'A complex machine is a combination of two or more simple machines.']
['What type of machine is an example of a lever?', 'The wire cutters in Figure 9.13 combine two levers and two wedges.']
['What type of machines are included in bicycles?', 'Bicycles include wheel and axles, levers, screws, and pulleys.']
['What type of machines are included in cars?', 'Cars and other vehicles are combinations of many machines.']
['What are the IMA equations used for?', 'No simple or complex machines have the actual mechanical advantages calculated by the IMA equations.']
['What is the main reason complex machines have more mechanical advantages?', 'In real life, some of the applied work always ends up as wasted heat due to friction between moving parts.']
['What are the IMA equations?', 'Both the input work (Wi) and output work (Wo) are the result of a force, F, acting over a distance, d.']
['What is the highest efficiency of the simple machines?', 'Look back at the pictures of the simple machines and think about which would have the highest efficiency.']
['What else should you know about efficiency?', 'Efficiency is related to friction, and friction depends on the smoothness of surfaces and on the area of the surfaces in contact.']
['What is the theory of relativity?', 'Relativity is not new.']
['When did Galileo explain that motion is relative?', 'Way back around the year 1600, Galileo explained that motion is relative.']
['What does he mean?', 'Wherever you happen to be, it seems like you are at a fixed point and that everything moves with respect to you.']
['What about others?', 'Everyone else feels the same way.']
['Do you think it always has to be this way?', 'Motion is always measured with respect to a fixed point.']
['What is the fixed point of a fixed point?', 'This is called establishing a frame of reference.']
['Is it the same for everyone?', 'But the choice of the point is arbitrary, and all frames of reference are equally valid.']

['What is an example of relative motion?', 'A passenger in a moving car is not moving with respect to the driver, but they are both moving from the point of view of a person on the sidewalk waiting for a bus.']
['How fast are they moving?', 'They are moving even faster as seen by a person in a car coming toward them.']
['Do the car drivers have to respect any particular frame of reference?', 'It is all relative.']

['What is the discussion of relativity about?', 'Light is involved in the discussion of relativity because theories related to electromagnetism are inconsistent with Galileo’s and Newton’s explanation of relativity.']
['What was the controversy about?', 'The true nature of light was a hot topic of discussion and controversy in the late 19th century.']
['What did most people think?', 'At the time, it was not generally believed that light could travel across empty space.']
['Why did they think that?', 'It was known to travel as waves, and all other types of energy that propagated as waves needed to travel though a material medium.']
['What was said about the nature of light?', 'It was believed that space was filled with an invisible medium that light waves traveled through.']
['What was this imaginary material called?', 'This imaginary (as it turned out) material was called the ether (also spelled aether).']
['What else did people think about this material?', 'It was thought that everything moved through this mysterious fluid.']
['What did they think about this mysterious fluid?', 'In other words, ether was the one fixed frame of reference.']
['Did the Michelson–Morley experiment prove that?', 'The Michelson–Morley experiment proved it was not.']
['What were the names of some famous experiments?', 'In 1887, Albert Michelson and Edward Morley designed the interferometer shown in Figure 10.2 to measure the speed of Earth through the ether.']
['How does the interferometer work?', 'A light beam is split into two perpendicular paths and then recombined.']

['What else is done with the light beam?', 'Recombining the waves produces an inference pattern, with a bright fringe at the locations where the two waves arrive in phase; that is, with the crests of both waves arriving together and the troughs arriving together.']
['Are there any other patterns?', 'A dark fringe appears where the crest of one wave coincides with a trough of the other, so that the two cancel.']
['What does the cancellation represent?', 'If Earth is traveling through the ether as it orbits the sun, the peaks in one arm would take longer than in the other to reach the same location.']
['How is the interference pattern determined?', 'The places where the two waves arrive in phase would change, and the interference pattern would shift.']
['Why is this important?', 'But, using the interferometer, there was no shift seen!']

['What result led to two conclusions: that there is no ether and that the speed of light is the same regardless of the relative motion of source and observer?', 'This result led to two conclusions: that there is no ether and that the speed of light is the same regardless of the relative motion of source and observer.']
['What was the name of the experiment that was called the Michelson–Morley investigation?', 'The Michelson–Morley investigation has been called the most famous failed experiment in history.']
['What was the experiment that was intended to test?', 'To see what Michelson and Morley expected to find when they measured the speed of light in two directions, watch this animation.']

['Did they actually measure the speed of light in a particular direction?', 'In the video, two people swimming in a lake are represented as an analogy to light beams leaving Earth as it moves through the ether (if there were any ether).']
['What is the analogy for the swimmers?', 'The swimmers swim away from and back to a platform that is moving through the water.']
['What did the swimmers do in relation to the platform?', 'The swimmers swim in different directions with respect to the motion of the platform.']
['How did the swims work?', 'Even though they swim equal distances at the same speed, the motion of the platform causes them to arrive at different times.']
['What was the first two postulates of the theory of relativity?', 'A radical new theory was needed, and Albert Einstein, shown in Figure 10.3, was about to become everyone’s favorite genius.']
['What were the first two postulates about?', 'Einstein began with two simple postulates based on the two things we have discussed so far in this chapter.']
['What are the four postulates of physics?', 'The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames.']
['What is the speed of light in all inertial reference frames?', 'The speed of light is the same in all inertial reference frames and is not affected by the speed of its source.']
['What is the speed of light given the symbol c?', 'The speed of light is given the symbol c and is equal to exactly 299,792,458 m/s.']
['What else should I know about the speed of light?', 'This is the speed of light in vacuum; that is, in the absence of air.']
['How does it compare to other values?', 'For most purposes, we round this number off to  $$\\(3.00\\  \\times \\ 10^{8}\\text{~m/s}\\)$$']

['What is a reference frame where all objects follow Newton’s first law of motion?', 'The term inertial reference frame simply refers to a frame of reference where all objects follow Newton’s first law of motion:']
['What does the first law state?', 'Objects at rest remain at rest, and objects in motion remain in motion at a constant velocity in a straight line, unless acted upon by an external force.']
['What are some examples of inertial reference frames?', 'The inside of a car moving along a road at constant velocity and the inside of a stationary house are inertial reference frames.']
["What are some of the things that he's postulated?", 'Einstein’s postulates were carefully chosen, and they both seemed very likely to be true.']

['Was it easy to prove these things were true?', 'Einstein proceeded despite realizing that these two ideas taken together and applied to extreme conditions led to results that contradict Newtonian mechanics.']
['What did he do when the results contradicted Newtonian mechanics?', 'He just took the ball and ran with it.']
['What were the velocities in general?', 'In the traditional view, velocities are additive.']
['What is an example of adding velocities?', 'If you are running at 3 m/s and you throw a ball forward at a speed of 10 m/s, the ball should have a net speed of 13 m/s.']
['What does Einstein say about velocities?', 'However, according to relativity theory, the speed of a moving light source is not added to the speed of the emitted light.']

['What is the purpose of these postulates?', 'In addition, Einstein’s theory shows that if you were moving forward relative to Earth at nearly c (the speed of light) and could throw a ball forward at c, an observer at rest on the earth would not see the ball moving at nearly twice the speed of light.']
['What is the significance of these postulates?', 'This result conforms to both of Einstein’s postulates:']
['What else can you tell me about the postulates?', 'The speed of light has a fixed maximum and neither reference frame is privileged.']
["What is the first step to understanding Einstein's Postulates?", 'Consider how we measure elapsed time.']
['What are different methods for measuring elapsed time?', 'One method is to use the arrival of light from the event, such as observing a light turn green to start a drag race.']
['What is important about this method?', 'The timing will be more accurate if some sort of electronic detection is used, avoiding human reaction times and other complications.']
['What is the first of these questions?', 'Now suppose we use this method to measure the time interval between two flashes of light produced by flash lamps on a moving train.']
['How would this affect the distances?', '(See Figure 10.4)']
['What is the woman doing?', 'A woman (observer A) is seated in the center of a rail car, with two flash lamps at opposite sides equidistant from her.']
['What does the observer see?', 'Multiple light rays that are emitted from the flash lamps move towards observer A, as shown with arrows.']
['What are the arrows for?', 'A velocity vector arrow for the rail car is shown towards the right.']
['Who is standing on the platform?', 'A man (observer B) standing on the platform is facing the woman and also observes the flashes of light.']

['What are the postulates?', 'Observer A moves with the lamps on the rail car as the rail car moves towards the right of observer B. Observer B receives the light flashes simultaneously, and sees the bulbs as both having flashed at the same time.']
['What is the importance of this observation?', 'However, he sees observer A receive the flash from the right first.']
['What is the difference between the two lights?', 'Because the pulse from the right reaches her first, in her frame of reference she sees the bulbs as not having flashed simultaneously.']
['How does this postulate relate to time?', 'Here, a relative velocity between observers affects whether two events at well-separated locations are observed to be simultaneous.']
['What is the postulate of simultaneity?', 'Simultaneity, or whether different events occur at the same instant, depends on the frame of reference of the observer.']
['How does this relate to motion?', 'Remember that velocity equals distance divided by time, so t = d/v.']
['What else does this mean?', 'If velocity appears to be different, then duration of time appears to be different.']
['What is your first thought about the material?', 'This illustrates the power of clear thinking.']

['What did he say that illustrates the power of clear thinking?', 'We might have guessed incorrectly that, if light is emitted simultaneously, then two observers halfway between the sources would see the flashes simultaneously.']
['What did he say right?', 'But careful analysis shows this not to be the case.']
['What is the most important detail in the article for you?', 'Einstein was brilliant at this type of thought experiment (in German, Gedankenexperiment).']
['How did he think about the passage?', 'He very carefully considered how an observation is made and disregarded what might seem obvious.']
['What is the most important thing that this article taught?', 'The validity of thought experiments, of course, is determined by actual observation.']
['What evidence did Einstein have of his genius?', 'The genius of Einstein is evidenced by the fact that experiments have repeatedly confirmed his theory of relativity.']
['What experiments have confirmed it?', 'No experiments after that of Michelson and Morley were able to detect any ether medium.']

['What else did he find?', 'We will describe later how experiments also confirmed other predictions of special relativity, such as the distance between two objects and the time interval of two events being different for two observers moving with respect to each other.']
['What are the postulates about?', 'In summary: Two events are defined to be simultaneous if an observer measures them as occurring at the same time (such as by receiving light from the events).']
['What else do you want to know about this postulate?', 'Two events are not necessarily simultaneous to all observers.']

['What are the discrepancies between Newtonian mechanics and relativity theory?', 'The discrepancies between Newtonian mechanics and relativity theory illustrate an important point about how science advances.']
['What was the difference between Einstein’s theory and Newton’s?', 'Einstein’s theory did not replace Newton’s but rather extended it.']
['What is the reason a new theory must be developed?', 'It is not unusual that a new theory must be developed to account for new information.']
['What are some theories that make this happen?', 'In most cases, the new theory is built on the foundation of older theory.']
['What can be said about the theory?', 'It is rare that old theories are completely replaced.']

['What is the theory of special relativity?', 'In this chapter, you will learn about the theory of special relativity, but, as mentioned in the introduction, Einstein developed two relativity theories: special and general.']
['What is the main idea of the chapter?', 'Table 10.1 summarizes the differences between the two theories.']
['What kind of relativistic effects are involved?', 'Consideration of the measurement of elapsed time and simultaneity leads to an important relativistic effect.']

['What is the phenomenon of time passing more slowly for an observer who is moving relative to another observer?', 'Time dilation is the phenomenon of time passing more slowly for an observer who is moving relative to another observer.']
['What is a related concept?', 'For example, suppose an astronaut measures the time it takes for light to travel from the light source, cross her ship, bounce off a mirror, and return.']
['What does that tell us?', '(See Figure 10.5.)']
['What is a possible result for the astronaut?', 'Asking this question (another thought experiment) produces a profound result.']
['What is the profound result of the experiment?', 'We find that the elapsed time for a process depends on who is measuring it.']
['What is the relationship between time and distance?', 'In this case, the time measured by the astronaut is smaller than the time measured by the earth bound observer.']

['Why is the passage of time different for the two observers?', 'The passage of time is different for the two observers because the distance the light travels in the astronaut’s frame is smaller than in the earth bound frame.']
['What happens when we put the frames together?', 'Light travels at the same speed in each frame, and so it will take longer to travel the greater distance in the earth bound frame.']
['What was the main result of this equation?', 'Notice that when the velocity v is small compared to the speed of light c, then v/c becomes small, and $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$ becomes close to 1.']
['What happens when the velocity v is small?', 'When this happens, time measurements are the same in both frames of reference.']

['What is the most important aspect of the article?', 'Relativistic effects, meaning those that have to do with special relativity, usually become significant when speeds become comparable to the speed of light.']
['What is this used for?', 'This is seen to be the case for time dilation.']

['What is the relationship between these two speeds?', 'You may have seen science fiction movies in which space travelers return to Earth after a long trip to find that the planet and everyone on it has aged much more than they have.']

['What is this scenario based on?', 'This type of scenario is a based on a thought experiment, known as the twin paradox, which imagines a pair of twins, one of whom goes on a trip into space while the other stays home.']
['What happens after they return home?', 'When the space traveler returns, she finds her twin has aged much more than she.']
['What causes the paradox?', 'This happens because the traveling twin has been in two frames of reference, one leaving Earth and one returning.']

['What is the evidence of time dilation?', 'Time dilation has been confirmed by comparing the time recorded by an atomic clock sent into orbit to the time recorded by a clock that remained on Earth.']
['What is another interesting fact about the article?', 'GPS satellites must also be adjusted to compensate for time dilation in order to give accurate positioning.']
['What is the quickest way to find a formula for v?', 'If you look ahead, you might say you have about 10 km left to go.']
['Why does it say 10 km?', 'Another traveler might say the road ahead looks like it is about 15 km long.']
['Why do they disagree?', 'If you both measured the road, however, you would agree.']
['What happens if you change the speed of the car?', 'Traveling at everyday speeds, the distance you both measure would be the same.']
['What is the relativistic speed of light?', 'You will read in this section, however, that this is not true at relativistic speeds.']
['What are relativistic speeds?', 'Close to the speed of light, distances measured are not the same when measured by different observers moving with respect to one other.']
['What did everyone agree upon?', 'One thing all observers agree upon is their relative speed.']
['What is relative speed?', 'When one observer is traveling away from another, they both see the other receding at the same speed, regardless of whose frame of reference is chosen.']
['What is speed?', 'Remember that speed equals distance divided by time: v = d/t.']
['What is distance divided by time?', 'If the observers experience a difference in elapsed time, they must also observe a difference in distance traversed.']
['Why does this have to be true?', 'This is because the ratio d/t must be the same for both observers.']

['What is the shortening of distance experienced by an observer moving with respect to the points whose distance apart is measured called?', 'The shortening of distance experienced by an observer moving with respect to the points whose distance apart is measured is called length contraction.']

['What is the distance between two points measured in the reference frame where the observer and the points are at rest?', 'Proper length, L0, is the distance between two points measured in the reference frame where the observer and the points are at rest.']

['What is the definition of conserved momentum?', 'Momentum is conserved in classical mechanics whenever the net external force on a system is zero.']
['What is momentum conservation?', 'This makes momentum conservation a fundamental tool for analyzing collisions.']
['What is momentum used for?', 'We will see that momentum has the same importance in modern physics.']

['Why do we use this definition?', 'We use the mass of the object as measured at rest because we cannot determine its mass while it is moving.']

['What is the difference between the equations?', 'The difference is the m in $$\\(E_{0} = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Do we need to use it to find the value of m in the equation?', 'Here is a simple example:']
['What is a positron?', 'A positron is a type of antimatter that is just like an electron, except that it has a positive charge.']
['Why is this important?', 'When a positron and an electron collide, their masses are completely annihilated and converted to energy in the form of gamma rays.']
['What is the mass of a particle?', 'Because both particles have a rest mass of 9.11 × 10–31 kg, we multiply the mc2 term by 2.']
['What are gamma rays?', 'So the energy of the gamma rays is']
['e) How many kilograms is the distance between Earth and the Sun?', 'where we have the expression for the joule (J) in terms of its SI base units of kg, m, and s.']
['What is the main idea of this paragraph?', 'In general, the nuclei of stable isotopes have less mass then their constituent subatomic particles.']
['What is significant about the subatomic particles?', 'The energy equivalent of this difference is called the binding energy of the nucleus.']
['What causes the binding energy?', 'This energy is released during the formation of the isotope from its constituent particles because the product is more stable than the reactants.']
['What is the mass defect?', 'Expressed as mass, it is called the mass defect.']
['What is the mass defect of a helium nucleus?', 'For example, a helium nucleus is made of two neutrons and two protons and has a mass of 4.0003 atomic mass units (u).']
['What is the mass defect of a proton?', 'The sum of the masses of two protons and two neutrons is 4.0330 u.']
['What is the mass defect?', 'The mass defect then is 0.0327 u. Converted to kg, the mass defect is 5.0442 × 10–30 kg.']
['What other facts do you want to know about the mass defect?', 'Multiplying this mass times c2 gives a binding energy of 4.540 × 10–12 J.']
['How important is the mass defect for the human body?', 'This does not sound like much because it is only one atom.']
['What else should I know about the mass defect?', 'If you were to make one gram of helium out of neutrons and protons, it would release 683,000,000,000 J.']
['How much energy is released from a gram of helium?', 'By comparison, burning one gram of coal releases about 24 J.']
['What does the word temperature mean?', 'It’s one of those concepts so ingrained in our everyday lives that, although we know what it means intuitively, it can be hard to define.']
['What is the definition of temperature?', 'It is tempting to say that temperature measures heat, but this is not strictly true.']
['What is the transfer of energy due to a temperature difference called?', 'Heat is the transfer of energy due to a temperature difference.']
['What is temperature?', 'Temperature is defined in terms of the instrument we use to tell us how hot or cold an object is, based on a mechanism and scale invented by people.']
['What instrument do we use to tell us how hot or cold an object is?', 'Temperature is literally defined as what we measure on a thermometer.']
['What is the confusion between heat and temperature?', 'Heat is often confused with temperature.']
['How do people use the confusion to mean something?', 'For example, we may say that the heat was unbearable, when we actually mean that the temperature was high.']
['Why does this cause confusion?', 'This is because we are sensitive to the flow of energy by heat, rather than the temperature.']
['What is the SI unit of joule (J)?', 'Since heat, like work, transfers energy, it has the SI unit of joule (J).']
['How does the temperature change?', 'Atoms and molecules are constantly in motion, bouncing off one another in random directions.']
['What is the energy of motion?', 'Recall that kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and that it increases in proportion to velocity squared.']

['What is the energy associated with heat?', 'Without going into mathematical detail, we can say that thermal energy—the energy associated with heat—is the average kinetic energy of the particles (molecules or atoms) in a substance.']
['How is this related to temperature?', 'Faster moving molecules have greater kinetic energies, and so the substance has greater thermal energy, and thus a higher temperature.']
['What is the total internal energy of a system?', 'The total internal energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of its atoms and molecules.']
['What is the subcategory of internal energy?', 'Thermal energy is one of the subcategories of internal energy, as is chemical energy.']
['How do you determine temperature?', 'To measure temperature, some scale must be used as a standard of measurement.']
['What are three popular temperature scales?', 'The three most commonly used temperature scales are the Fahrenheit, Celsius, and Kelvin scales.']
['Are the Fahrenheit and Celsius scales the same?', 'Both the Fahrenheit scale and Celsius scale are relative temperature scales, meaning that they are made around a reference point.']

['What reference point does the Celsius scale use?', 'For example, the Celsius scale uses the freezing point of water as its reference point; all measurements are either lower than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a negative sign), or higher than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a positive sign).']
['What is the boiling point of water?', 'The boiling point of water is 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  for the Celsius scale, and its unit is the degree Celsius  (°C(°C(°C ).']
['What are some key aspects of the article?', 'On the Fahrenheit scale, the freezing point of water is at 32 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$, and the boiling point is at 212 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of temperature used in this scale?', 'The unit of temperature on this scale is the degree Fahrenheit  (°F(°F(°F ).']
['What is the Celsius scale?', 'Note that the difference in degrees between the freezing and boiling points is greater for the Fahrenheit scale than for the Celsius scale.']
['Does this have an impact on the meaning of temperature?', 'Therefore, a temperature difference of one degree Celsius is greater than a temperature difference of one degree Fahrenheit.']

['What else is interesting about this article?', 'Since 100 Celsius degrees span the same range as 180 Fahrenheit degrees, one degree on the Celsius scale is 1.8 times larger than one degree on the Fahrenheit scale (because  $$\\(\\frac{180}{100} = \\frac{9}{5} = 1.8\\)$$ ).']
['What is the use of this information?', 'This relationship can be used to convert between temperatures in Fahrenheit and Celsius (see Figure 11.2).']
['What is the Kelvin scale?', 'The Kelvin scale is the temperature scale that is commonly used in science because it is an absolute temperature scale.']
['What does the Kelvin scale mean?', 'This means that the theoretically lowest-possible temperature is assigned the value of zero.']

['What is zero degrees on the Kelvin scale known as?', 'Zero degrees on the Kelvin scale is known as absolute zero; it is theoretically the point at which there is no molecular motion to produce thermal energy.']
['What is the scale used for?', 'On the original Kelvin scale first created by Lord Kelvin, all temperatures have positive values, making it useful for scientific work.']
['What is the unit on the scale?', 'The official temperature unit on this scale is the kelvin, which is abbreviated as K.']
['What are some of the important points on the scale?', 'The freezing point of water is 273.15 K, and the boiling point of water is 373.15 K.']
['What is a factor in temperature?', 'Although absolute zero is possible in theory, it cannot be reached in practice.']

['What is the lowest temperature ever created and measured?', 'The lowest temperature ever created and measured during a laboratory experiment was  $$\\(1.0 \\times 10^{- 10}\\)$$  K, at Helsinki University of Technology in Finland.']

['What else can you tell me about the lowest temperature?', 'In comparison, the coldest recorded temperature for a place on Earth’s surface was 183 K (–89 \t°C), at Vostok, Antarctica, and the coldest known place (outside the lab) in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula, with a temperature of 1 K. Luckily, most of us humans will never have to experience such extremes.']

['What is something interesting you found?', 'While the Fahrenheit scale is still the most commonly used scale in the United States, the majority of the world uses Celsius, and scientists prefer Kelvin.']
['What are the differences between these two scales?', 'It’s often necessary to convert between these scales.']
['What was the result of this study?', 'For instance, if the TV meteorologist gave the local weather report in kelvins, there would likely be some confused viewers!']
['What else did you find out about this?', 'Table 11.1 gives the equations for conversion between the three temperature scales.']

['What happens when two objects at different temperatures are brought in contact with each other?', 'If two objects at different temperatures are brought in contact with each other, energy is transferred from the hotter object (that is, the object with the greater temperature) to the colder (lower temperature) object, until both objects are at the same temperature.']

['What is the effect on both objects when the temperatures are equal?', 'There is no net heat transfer once the temperatures are equal because the amount of heat transferred from one object to the other is the same as the amount of heat returned.']
['What are the major effects of heat transfer?', 'One of the major effects of heat transfer is temperature change: Heating increases the temperature while cooling decreases it.']

['What else can you tell me about heat transfers?', 'Experiments show that the heat transferred to or from a substance depends on three factors—the change in the substance’s temperature, the mass of the substance, and certain physical properties related to the phase of the substance.']
['What is the formula for $$[Q = mcDel]?', 'where m is the mass of the substance and ΔT is the change in its temperature, in units of Celsius or Kelvin.']
['What is the symbol c?', 'The symbol c stands for specific heat, and depends on the material and phase.']

['What is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of 1.00 kg of mass by 1.00 oC?', 'The specific heat is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of 1.00 kg of mass by 1.00 ºC.']

['Can you give me some more information about specific heat?', 'The specific heat c is a property of the substance; its SI unit is J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ K) or J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ).']
['What else does the formula mean?', 'The temperature change ( $$\\(\\Delta T\\)$$ ) is the same in units of kelvins and degrees Celsius (but not degrees Fahrenheit).']
['What is the relationship between specific heat and heat capacity?', 'Specific heat is closely related to the concept of heat capacity.']

['What is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$(text°C)$$?', 'Heat capacity is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ .']
['What is the equation of heat capacity?', 'In equation form, heat capacity C is  $$\\(C = mc\\)$$, where m is mass and c is specific heat.']
['What is the difference between specific heat and heat capacity?', 'Note that heat capacity is the same as specific heat, but without any dependence on mass.']

['Are there other significant differences between specific heat and heat capacity?', 'Consequently, two objects made up of the same material but with different masses will have different heat capacities.']
['How is this different from specific heat?', 'This is because the heat capacity is a property of an object, but specific heat is a property of any object made of the same material.']
['What is the title of our study material about?', 'Values of specific heat must be looked up in tables, because there is no simple way to calculate them.']
['What is the table called?', 'Table 11.2 gives the values of specific heat for a few substances as a handy reference.']

['What is this table used for?', 'We see from this table that the specific heat of water is five times that of glass, which means that it takes five times as much heat to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water than to raise the temperature of 1 kg of glass by the same number of degrees.']
['What causes heat transfer?', 'Whenever there is a temperature difference, heat transfer occurs.']
['How is heat transfer used?', 'Heat transfer may happen rapidly, such as through a cooking pan, or slowly, such as through the walls of an insulated cooler.']
['What are the three different heat transfer methods?', 'There are three different heat transfer methods: conduction, convection, and radiation.']
['How are all three methods interrelated?', 'At times, all three may happen simultaneously.']
['What other information do we need to know about this?', 'See Figure 11.3.']
['What is the process of heat transfer through direct physical contact called?', 'Conduction is heat transfer through direct physical contact.']
['What is a common example of conduction?', 'Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.']
['What can you tell me about conduction?', 'Sometimes, we try to control the conduction of heat to make ourselves more comfortable.']

['What is an example of a fabric that slows down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter?', 'Since the rate of heat transfer is different for different materials, we choose fabrics, such as a thick wool sweater, that slow down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter.']

['What is the difference between the living room carpet and the kitchen tile floor?', 'As you walk barefoot across the living room carpet, your feet feel relatively comfortable…until you step onto the kitchen’s tile floor.']
['What does this tell you?', 'This is explained by different rates of heat transfer:']
['Why does the tile floor feel colder?', 'The tile material removes heat from your skin at a greater rate than the carpeting, which makes it feel colder.']
['What does conduction mean?', 'Some materials simply conduct thermal energy faster than others.']

['What kinds of materials are good conductors?', 'In general, metals (like copper, aluminum, gold, and silver) are good heat conductors, whereas materials like wood, plastic, and rubber are poor heat conductors.']
['What is the first figure in the section?', 'Figure 11.4 shows particles (either atoms or molecules) in two bodies at different temperatures.']
['What is the difference in temperature between the two bodies?', 'The (average) kinetic energy of a particle in the hot body is higher than in the colder body.']
['Why does it have more kinetic energy?', 'If two particles collide, energy transfers from the particle with greater kinetic energy to the particle with less kinetic energy.']
['Does heat transfer?', 'When two bodies are in contact, many particle collisions occur, resulting in a net flux of heat from the higher-temperature body to the lower-temperature body.']
['How is the heat flux calculated?', 'The heat flux depends on the temperature difference  $$\\(\\Delta T = T_{\\text{hot}} - T_{\\text{cold}}\\)$$ .']
['Do you have any other important information about the section?', 'Therefore, you will get a more severe burn from boiling water than from hot tap water.']
['What is the process of heat transfer by the movement of a fluid called?', 'Convection is heat transfer by the movement of a fluid.']

['Where does this type of heat transfer happen?', 'This type of heat transfer happens, for example, in a pot boiling on the stove, or in thunderstorms, where hot air rises up to the base of the clouds.']
['What did you learn about conduction?', 'As the temperature of fluids increase, they expand and become less dense.']
['What did you do for an example?', 'For example, Figure 11.4 could represent the wall of a balloon with different temperature gases inside the balloon than outside in the environment.']

['What happens to the balloon when it is hot?', 'The hotter and thus faster moving gas particles inside the balloon strike the surface with more force than the cooler air outside, causing the balloon to expand.']
['What is the effect of buoyancy?', 'This decrease in density relative to its environment creates buoyancy (the tendency to rise).']
['What else did you learn about buoyancy?', 'Convection is driven by buoyancy—hot air rises because it is less dense than the surrounding air.']
['What are convection and radiation?', 'Sometimes, we control the temperature of our homes or ourselves by controlling air movement.']
['How do we control air movement?', 'Sealing leaks around doors with weather stripping keeps out the cold wind in winter.']
['What are some examples of air movement?', 'The house in Figure 11.5 and the pot of water on the stove in Figure 11.6 are both examples of convection and buoyancy by human design.']

['What are some natural examples of convection?', 'Ocean currents and large-scale atmospheric circulation transfer energy from one part of the globe to another, and are examples of natural convection.']
['What is the term for the transfer of heat?', 'Radiation is a form of heat transfer that occurs when electromagnetic radiation is emitted or absorbed.']

['What type of radiation is involved in this form of heat transfer?', 'Electromagnetic radiation includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared radiation, visible light, ultraviolet radiation, X-rays, and gamma rays, all of which have different wavelengths and amounts of energy (shorter wavelengths have higher frequency and more energy).']
['How is heat transferred?', 'You can feel the heat transfer from a fire and from the sun.']
['What is another example of heat transfer?', 'Similarly, you can sometimes tell that the oven is hot without touching its door or looking inside—it may just warm you as you walk by.']

['What are some other sources of heat transfer?', 'Another example is thermal radiation from the human body; people are constantly emitting infrared radiation, which is not visible to the human eye, but is felt as heat.']

['What is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required?', 'Radiation is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required, meaning that the heat doesn’t need to come into direct contact with or be transported by any matter.']
['Why is the space between Earth and the sun so cold?', 'The space between Earth and the sun is largely empty, without any possibility of heat transfer by convection or conduction.']
['What does the heat transfer?', 'Instead, heat is transferred by radiation, and Earth is warmed as it absorbs electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun.']
['What does radiation include?', 'All objects absorb and emit electromagnetic radiation (see Figure 11.7).']
['What else did you learn about radiation?', 'The rate of heat transfer by radiation depends mainly on the color of the object.']
['What color object is the most effective absorber and radiator?', 'Black is the most effective absorber and radiator, and white is the least effective.']
['What other things can you tell me about radiation?', 'People living in hot climates generally avoid wearing black clothing, for instance.']
['What else did you learn about radiation?', 'Similarly, black asphalt in a parking lot will be hotter than adjacent patches of grass on a summer day, because black absorbs better than green.']
['What is the opposite of green for radiation?', 'The reverse is also true—black radiates better than green.']
['What else are you learning about radiation?', 'On a clear summer night, the black asphalt will be colder than the green patch of grass, because black radiates energy faster than green.']
["What color object can't absorb radiation?", 'In contrast, white is a poor absorber and also a poor radiator.']
['What is the best way to describe the color of a white object?', 'A white object reflects nearly all radiation, like a mirror.']
['What has the course taught you so far?', 'So far, we have learned that adding thermal energy by heat increases the temperature of a substance.']
['What else did you learn in the lesson?', 'But surprisingly, there are situations where adding energy does not change the temperature of a substance at all!']
['What happens to the substance when it does not change temperature?', 'Instead, the additional thermal energy acts to loosen bonds between molecules or atoms and causes a phase change.']

['What is the energy called when it enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change in the system?', 'Because this energy enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change in the system, it is known as latent heat (latent means hidden).']
['What are the three phases of matter that you frequently encounter?', 'The three phases of matter that you frequently encounter are solid, liquid and gas (see Figure 11.8).']

['What is the difference between solid and liquid?', 'Solid has the least energetic state; atoms in solids are in close contact, with forces between them that allow the particles to vibrate but not change position with neighboring particles.']
['What can you tell me about the particles?', '(These forces can be thought of as springs that can be stretched or compressed, but not easily broken.)']
['What is the state of gas?', 'Gas has a more energetic state than liquid, in which particles are broken free of their bonds.']
['How is that related to distances?', 'Particles in gases are separated by distances that are large compared with the size of the particles.']
['What is the most energetic state of all?', 'The most energetic state of all is plasma.']
['What is plasma?', 'Although you may not have heard much about plasma, it is actually the most common state of matter in the universe—stars are made up of plasma, as is lightning.']
['What is the plasma state?', 'The plasma state is reached by heating a gas to the point where particles are pulled apart, separating the electrons from the rest of the particle.']

['What is an ionized gas that is a combination of the negatively charged free electrons and positively charged ions, known as plasma?', 'This produces an ionized gas that is a combination of the negatively charged free electrons and positively charged ions, known as plasma.']
['What is the melting point of a solid?', 'Energy is required to melt a solid because the bonds between the particles in the solid must be broken.']

['What is the temperature of melted solid?', 'Since the energy involved in a phase changes is used to break bonds, there is no increase in the kinetic energies of the particles, and therefore no rise in temperature.']
['What happens when you boil water?', 'Similarly, energy is needed to vaporize a liquid to overcome the attractive forces between particles in the liquid.']
['What is the temperature of an empty container?', 'There is no temperature change until a phase change is completed.']
['What is the temperature of soda?', 'The temperature of a cup of soda and ice that is initially at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  stays at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  until all of the ice has melted.']
['What happens when a liquid freezes?', 'In the reverse of these processes—freezing and condensation—energy is released from the latent heat (see Figure 11.9).']
['What is the value of q?', 'where  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  is the latent heat of fusion, and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  is the latent heat of vaporization.']
['What is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between solid and liquid?', 'The latent heat of fusion is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between solid and liquid.']
['What is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas?', 'The latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas.']

['What is the unit for $$(L_f)$$ and $$(L_v)$$?', '$$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  are coefficients that vary from substance to substance, depending on the strength of intermolecular forces, and both have standard units of J/kg.']
['What are some examples of heat transfer coefficient?', 'See Table 11.3 for values of  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  of different substances.']
['What is the best way to get there?', 'Let’s consider the example of adding heat to ice to examine its transitions through all three phases—solid to liquid to gas.']
['What is important about the phase diagram?', 'A phase diagram indicating the temperature changes of water as energy is added is shown in Figure 11.10.']

['What is the temperature of the ice?', 'The ice starts out at −20 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, and its temperature rises linearly, absorbing heat at a constant rate until it reaches 0 $$\\(\\text{°}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What happens when the ice melts?', 'Once at this temperature, the ice gradually melts, absorbing 334 kJ/kg.']
['What happens to the temperature while the ice melts?', 'The temperature remains constant at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  during this phase change.']
['Does the ice then go back to solid?', 'Once all the ice has melted, the temperature of the liquid water rises, absorbing heat at a new constant rate.']

['What happens to the water when it boils?', 'At 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, the water begins to boil and the temperature again remains constant while the water absorbs 2256 kJ/kg during this phase change.']
['What happens after the water boils?', 'When all the liquid has become steam, the temperature rises again at a constant rate.']
['What is vaporization?', 'We have seen that vaporization requires heat transfer to a substance from its surroundings.']
['What is condensation?', 'Condensation is the reverse process, where heat in transferred away from a substance to its surroundings.']
['Does condensation increase temperature?', 'This release of latent heat increases the temperature of the surroundings.']
['Can we remove heat from a vapor?', 'Energy must be removed from the condensing particles to make a vapor condense.']
['Is condensation always on cold surfaces?', 'This is why condensation occurs on cold surfaces: the heat transfers energy away from the warm vapor to the cold surface.']

['How does the energy get transferred?', 'The energy is exactly the same as that required to cause the phase change in the other direction, from liquid to vapor, and so it can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{v}\\)$$ .']
['Can you also calculate latent heat?', 'Latent heat is also released into the environment when a liquid freezes, and can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{f}\\)$$ .']

['When two objects are in contact with one another, what happens?', 'We learned in the previous chapter that when two objects (or systems) are in contact with one another, heat will transfer thermal energy from the object at higher temperature to the one at lower temperature until they both reach the same temperature.']
['What happens when they reach the same temperature?', 'The objects are then in thermal equilibrium, and no further temperature changes will occur if they are isolated from other systems.']
['Why do the systems interact and change?', 'The systems interact and change because their temperatures are different, and the changes stop once their temperatures are the same.']

['What is the basic meaning of thermal equilibrium?', 'Thermal equilibrium is established when two bodies are in thermal contact with each other—meaning heat transfer (i.e., the transfer of energy by heat) can occur between them.']
['What else can happen with thermal equilibrium?', 'If two systems cannot freely exchange energy, they will not reach thermal equilibrium.']

['What is an example of thermal equilibrium?', '(It is fortunate that empty space stands between Earth and the sun, because a state of thermal equilibrium with the sun would be too toasty for life on this planet!)']

['What is this theorem about?', 'If two systems, A and B, are in thermal equilibrium with each another, and B is in thermal equilibrium with a third system, C, then A is also in thermal equilibrium with C.']
['What is the relationship between temperature and energy?', 'This statement may seem obvious, because all three have the same temperature, but it is basic to thermodynamics.']
['What is the name of the theorem that states that the temperature of a liquid is constant?', 'It is called the zeroth law of thermodynamics.']

['Which law was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics but is so fundamental that scientists decided it should logically come first?', 'The explanation is that this law was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics but is so fundamental that scientists decided it should logically come first.']
['What is the zeroth law?', 'As an example of the zeroth law in action, consider newborn babies in neonatal intensive-care units in hospitals.']
['What kind of units are used to care for prematurely born or sick newborns?', 'Prematurely born or sick newborns are placed in special incubators.']
['What is special about the incubators?', 'These babies have very little covering while in the incubators, so to an observer, they look as though they may not be warm enough.']
['Why is that?', 'However, inside the incubator, the temperature of the air, the cot, and the baby are all the same—that is, they are in thermal equilibrium.']
['What happens in a thermal equilibrium?', 'The ambient temperature is just high enough to keep the baby safe and comfortable.']
['What are they studying next?', 'Before covering the first law of thermodynamics, it is first important to understand the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.']
['What is the definition of pressure?', 'Pressure, P, is defined as']
['What is pressure used for?', 'Pressure is defined for all states of matter but is particularly important when discussing fluids (such as air).']

['What is the word pressure used for?', 'You have probably heard the word pressure being used in relation to blood (high or low blood pressure) and in relation to the weather (high- and low-pressure weather systems).']
['What is pressure used for?', 'These are only two of many examples of pressures in fluids.']

['What is the relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas?', 'The relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas is given by the ideal gas law.']
['What is an ideal gas?', 'A gas is considered ideal at low pressure and fairly high temperature, and forces between its component particles can be ignored.']
['What does the ideal gas law state?', 'The ideal gas law states that']

['What is the relationship between P and V?', 'where P is the pressure of a gas, V is the volume it occupies, N is the number of particles (atoms or molecules) in the gas, and T is its absolute temperature.']
['What is the Boltzmann constant?', 'The constant k is called the Boltzmann constant and has the value  $$\\(k = 1.38 \\times 10^{-23}\\text{J/K}\\text{,}\\)$$']
['Can you tell me more about the ideal gas law?', 'For the purposes of this chapter, we will not go into calculations using the ideal gas law.']
['What is the best way to calculate the gas permeability?', 'Instead, it is important for us to notice from the equation that the following are true for a given mass of gas:']
['What is the inverse relationship between temperature and volume?', 'When volume is constant, pressure is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What is the inverse relationship between temperature and volume?', 'When temperature is constant, pressure is inversely proportional to volume.']
['What is the inverse relationship between volume and pressure?', 'When pressure is constant, volume is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What is the last point in the information for this unit?', 'This last point describes thermal expansion—the change in size or volume of a given mass with temperature.']
['What is it an effect of?', 'An increase in temperature means that there’s an increase in the kinetic energy of the individual atoms.']

['What is an effect of temperature?', 'Gases are especially affected by thermal expansion, although liquids expand to a lesser extent with similar increases in temperature, and even solids have minor expansions at higher temperatures.']
['What is another way that the information can be used?', 'This is why railroad tracks and bridges have expansion joints that allow them to freely expand and contract with temperature changes.']

['What is the relationship between pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas?', 'To get some idea of how pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas are related to one another, consider what happens when you pump air into a deflated tire.']

['What is the relationship between the temperature and pressure of air?', 'The tire’s volume first increases in direct proportion to the amount of air injected, without much increase in the tire pressure.']
['What is important to know about the walls of a tire?', 'Once the tire has expanded to nearly its full size, the walls limit volume expansion.']
['What happens after that?', 'If you continue to pump air into tire (which now has a nearly constant volume), the pressure increases with increasing temperature (see Figure 12.4).']
['What is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid?', 'Pressure–volume work is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid.']
['What are the conditions that produce Pressure–Volume Work?', 'Whenever there is a change in volume and external pressure remains constant, pressure–volume work is taking place.']
['What does compression do to the fluid?', 'During a compression, a decrease in volume increases the internal pressure of a system as work is done on the system.']
['What does expansion do to the fluid?', 'During an expansion (Figure 12.5), an increase in volume decreases the internal pressure of a system as the system does work.']
['What does the formula for pressure volume work mean?', 'Recall that the formula for work is  $$\\(W = Fd.\\)$$']
['What are the formulas for pressure and volume?', 'We can rearrange the definition of pressure,  $$\\(P = \\frac{F}{A},\\)$$  to get an expression for force in terms of pressure.']
['What is work?', 'Just as we say that work is force acting over a distance, for fluids, we can say that work is the pressure acting through the change in volume.']
['What does pressure mean in the context of work?', 'For pressure–volume work, pressure is analogous to force, and volume is analogous to distance in the traditional definition of work.']
['What is it about?', 'Heat (Q) and work (W) are the two ways to add or remove energy from a system.']
['What are the processes like?', 'The processes are very different.']
['What are they different for?', 'Heat is driven by temperature differences, while work involves a force exerted through a distance.']
['Do you think heat and work can produce identical results?', 'Nevertheless, heat and work can produce identical results.']
['What can they do?', 'For example, both can cause a temperature increase.']
['What is heat?', 'Heat transfers energy into a system, such as when the sun warms the air in a bicycle tire and increases the air’s temperature.']
['What can be done on the system, as when the bicyclist pumps air into the tire?', 'Similarly, work can be done on the system, as when the bicyclist pumps air into the tire.']
['Does that mean the temperature of the tire would be higher?', 'Once the temperature increase has occurred, it is impossible to tell whether it was caused by heat or work.']
['What is significant about heat and work?', 'Heat and work are both energy in transit—neither is stored as such in a system.']
['How do they affect the system?', 'However, both can change the internal energy, U, of a system.']

['What is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules called?', 'Internal energy is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules.']

['What else can you tell me about internal energy?', 'It can be divided into many subcategories, such as thermal and chemical energy, and depends only on the state of a system (that is, P, V, and T), not on how the energy enters or leaves the system.']
['What is the first law of thermodynamics?', 'In order to understand the relationship between heat, work, and internal energy, we use the first law of thermodynamics.']

['What does the first law of thermodynamics mean?', 'The first law of thermodynamics applies the conservation of energy principle to systems where heat and work are the methods of transferring energy into and out of the systems.']
['What can it be used to describe?', 'It can also be used to describe how energy transferred by heat is converted and transferred again by work.']

['What does the first law of thermodynamics state?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy of a closed system equals the net heat transfer into the system minus the net work done by the system.']
['What is the equation for the first law of thermodynamics?', 'In equation form, the first law of thermodynamics is']
['What is this about?', 'Here,  $$\\(\\Delta U\\)$$ is the change in internal energy, U, of the system.']
['What is the net heat transferred into the system?', 'As shown in Figure 12.6, Q is the net heat transferred into the system—that is, Q is the sum of all heat transfers into and out of the system.']
['What is the net work done by the system?', 'W is the net work done by the system—that is, W is the sum of all work done on or by the system.']
['What is the convention for Q and W?', 'By convention, if Q is positive, then there is a net heat transfer into the system; if W is positive, then there is net work done by the system.']
['What is the difference between positive Q and positive W?', 'So positive Q adds energy to the system by heat, and positive W takes energy from the system by work.']
['What is internal energy?', 'Note that if heat transfers more energy into the system than that which is done by work, the difference is stored as internal energy.']
['What is the difference between entropy and kinetic energy?', 'Recall from the chapter introduction that it is not even theoretically possible for engines to be 100 percent efficient.']
['How is that possible?', 'This phenomenon is explained by the second law of thermodynamics, which relies on a concept known as entropy.']
['What is entropy?', 'Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.']
['What does entropy describe?', 'Entropy also describes how much energy is not available to do work.']
['How does entropy affect the energy of a system?', "The more disordered a system and higher the entropy, the less of a system's energy is available to do work."]
['What is one important fact that you learned in your reading?', 'Although all forms of energy can be used to do work, it is not possible to use the entire available energy for work.']

['What does this mean?', 'Consequently, not all energy transferred by heat can be converted into work, and some of it is lost in the form of waste heat—that is, heat that does not go toward doing work.']
['What is important in thermodynamics?', 'The unavailability of energy is important in thermodynamics; in fact, the field originated from efforts to convert heat to work, as is done by engines.']
['How does Q interact with temperature?', 'Q is positive for energy transferred into the system by heat and negative for energy transferred out of the system by heat.']
['What is entropy expressed in units of?', 'In SI, entropy is expressed in units of joules per kelvin (J/K).']

['What is the most important thing to remember about this section?', 'If temperature changes during the process, then it is usually a good approximation (for small changes in temperature) to take T to be the average temperature in order to avoid trickier math (calculus).']

['Have you ever heard someone say something like, "There is no way to know if"?', 'If so, you have been on the receiving end of a practical joke and, in the process, learned a valuable lesson about the nature of the universe as described by the second law of thermodynamics.']
['What is 52 pickup and why did they make this joke?', 'In the game of 52 pickup, the prankster tosses an entire deck of playing cards onto the floor, and you get to pick them up.']

['How do you know if the cards are still alive?', 'In the process of picking up the cards, you may have noticed that the amount of work required to restore the cards to an orderly state in the deck is much greater than the amount of work required to toss the cards and create the disorder.']

['What is the second law of thermodynamics?', 'The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any spontaneous process; it never decreases.']
['Why is that?', 'An important implication of this law is that heat transfers energy spontaneously from higher- to lower-temperature objects, but never spontaneously in the reverse direction.']
['Why is that?', 'This is because entropy increases for heat transfer of energy from hot to cold (Figure 12.9).']
['Is there any other important information?', 'Because the change in entropy is Q/T, there is a larger change in  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$  at lower temperatures (smaller T).']

['Is there anything else important?', 'The decrease in entropy of the hot (larger T) object is therefore less than the increase in entropy of the cold (smaller T) object, producing an overall increase in entropy for the system.']

['What is the result of a process that transfers heat from a cooler object to a hotter object?', 'Another way of thinking about this is that it is impossible for any process to have, as its sole result, heat transferring energy from a cooler to a hotter object.']
['Why is it impossible to transfer energy from colder to hotter?', 'Heat cannot transfer energy spontaneously from colder to hotter, because the entropy of the overall system would decrease.']

['How does this theory apply to water?', 'Suppose we mix equal masses of water that are originally at two different temperatures, say  $$\\(\\text{20}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{40}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']
['What will happen when the two temperatures are combined?', 'The result will be water at an intermediate temperature of  $$\\(\\text{30}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']
['What is the result of this process?', 'Three outcomes have resulted: entropy has increased, some energy has become unavailable to do work, and the system has become less orderly.']
['How is this relevant to the passage?', 'Let us think about each of these results.']

['What is the effect of mixing two bodies of water?', 'Mixing the two bodies of water has the same effect as the heat transfer of energy from the higher-temperature substance to the lower-temperature substance.']

['What happens when two liquids are mixed?', 'The mixing decreases the entropy of the hotter water but increases the entropy of the colder water by a greater amount, producing an overall increase in entropy.']
['What are two aspects of the second law?', 'Second, once the two masses of water are mixed, there is no more temperature difference left to drive energy transfer by heat and therefore to do work.']
['What happens when the temperature difference is gone?', 'The energy is still in the water, but it is now unavailable to do work.']
['Why is it harder to combine things?', 'Third, the mixture is less orderly, or to use another term, less structured.']

['How is that beneficial?', 'Rather than having two masses at different temperatures and with different distributions of molecular speeds, we now have a single mass with a broad distribution of molecular speeds, the average of which yields an intermediate temperature.']

['What are three things the second law of thermodynamics talks about?', 'These three results—entropy, unavailability of energy, and disorder—not only are related but are, in fact, essentially equivalent.']

['What is related to the three results?', 'Heat transfer of energy from hot to cold is related to the tendency in nature for systems to become disordered and for less energy to be available for use as work.']
['What does this law tell us?', 'A cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter.']
['Does the second law tell us anything else?', 'Nor does a hot, stationary automobile ever spontaneously cool off and start moving.']
['What are some examples of the second law?', 'Another example is the expansion of a puff of gas introduced into one corner of a vacuum chamber.']
['What happens to the gas when it is introduced into the corner?', 'The gas expands to fill the chamber, but it never regroups on its own in the corner.']
['How does the gas never regroup?', 'The random motion of the gas molecules could take them all back to the corner, but this is never observed to happen (Figure 12.10).']
['What did you have to say about heat?', "We've explained that heat never transfers energy spontaneously from a colder to a hotter object."]
['What is the problem with spontaneously?', 'The key word here is spontaneously.']
['What is the energy transfer from a colder to hotter object called?', 'If we do work on a system, it is possible to transfer energy by heat from a colder to hotter object.']
['What is the next topic?', "We'll learn more about this in the next section, covering refrigerators as one of the applications of the laws of thermodynamics."]

['What is the second law of thermodynamics about?', 'Sometimes people misunderstand the second law of thermodynamics, thinking that based on this law, it is impossible for entropy to decrease at any particular location.']

['What do you mean by entropy of one part of the universe can decrease, as long as the total change in entropy of the universe increases?', 'But, it actually is possible for the entropy of one part of the universe to decrease, as long as the total change in entropy of the universe increases.']
['What is an equation for a trig function?', 'In equation form, we can write this as']
['What is the equation describing?', 'Energy transfer is necessary.']
['How can you decrease entropy in the real world?', 'If you pick up marbles that are scattered about the room and put them into a cup, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']
['What is an example of work that decreases entropy?', 'If you gather iron ore from the ground and convert it into steel and build a bridge, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']
['What is the entropy of local systems on Earth?', 'Energy coming from the sun can decrease the entropy of local systems on Earth—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{syst}}\\)$$  is negative.']

['What happens when the entropy of the rest of the universe increases by a greater amount?', 'But the overall entropy of the rest of the universe increases by a greater amount—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{envir}}\\)$$  is positive and greater in magnitude.']
['What does this mean?', 'In the case of the iron ore, although you made the system of the bridge and steel more structured, you did so at the expense of the universe.']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'Altogether, the entropy of the universe is increased by the disorder created by digging up the ore and converting it to steel.']
['Do we have any other explanation?', 'Therefore,']

['What is the relationship among the two sides of a right-angled triangle according to Py?', 'Every time a plant stores some solar energy in the form of chemical potential energy, or an updraft of warm air lifts a soaring bird, Earth experiences local decreases in entropy as it uses part of the energy transfer from the sun into deep space to do work.']
['What is the result of a decrease in entropy?', 'There is a large total increase in entropy resulting from this massive energy transfer.']
['What is the result of the energy transfer by heat?', 'A small part of this energy transfer by heat is stored in structured systems on Earth, resulting in much smaller, local decreases in entropy.']
['What is entropy related to?', 'Entropy is related not only to the unavailability of energy to do work; it is also a measure of disorder.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about the passage?', 'For example, in the case of a melting block of ice, a highly structured and orderly system of water molecules changes into a disorderly liquid, in which molecules have no fixed positions (Figure 12.11).']
['What is the result of this change in entropy?', "There is a large increase in entropy for this process, as we'll see in the following worked example."]
['What does a heat engine do?', 'A heat engine does exactly this—it makes use of the properties of thermodynamics to transform heat into work.']
['What are some examples of heat engines?', 'Gasoline and diesel engines, jet engines, and steam turbines that generate electricity are all examples of heat engines.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Figure 12.13 illustrates one of the ways in which heat transfers energy to do work.']
['What is the way in which heat transfers energy to do work?', 'Fuel combustion releases chemical energy that heat transfers throughout the gas in a cylinder.']
['What else is happening in the cylinder?', 'This increases the gas temperature, which in turn increases the pressure of the gas and, therefore, the force it exerts on a movable piston.']
['What happens with the gas?', 'The gas does work on the outside world, as this force moves the piston through some distance.']
['What happens after the piston moves?', 'Thus, heat transfer of energy to the gas in the cylinder results in work being done.']
['What are the piston and rod in a reciprocating engine?', 'To repeat this process, the piston needs to be returned to its starting point.']

['What happens at the starting point?', 'Heat now transfers energy from the gas to the surroundings, so that the gas’s pressure decreases, and a force is exerted by the surroundings to push the piston back through some distance.']
['What does a cyclical process bring a system back to?', 'A cyclical process brings a system, such as the gas in a cylinder, back to its original state at the end of every cycle.']
['Do all heat engines use cyclical processes?', 'All heat engines use cyclical processes.']
['What do they use heat for?', 'Heat engines do work by using part of the energy transferred by heat from some source.']

['How does it work?', 'As shown in Figure 12.14, heat transfers energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, from the high-temperature object (or hot reservoir), whereas heat transfers unused energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, into the low-temperature object (or cold reservoir), and the work done by the engine is W.']
['What is a reservoir?', 'In physics, a reservoir is defined as an infinitely large mass that can take in or put out an unlimited amount of heat, depending upon the needs of the system.']
['What is the temperature of the hot reservoir?', 'The temperature of the hot reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{h}}\\text{,}\\)$$  and the temperature of the cold reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the process of bringing the system back to its original condition at the end of every cycle?', 'As noted, a cyclical process brings the system back to its original condition at the end of every cycle.']
['What happens at the end of every cycle?', 'Such a system’s internal energy, U, is the same at the beginning and end of every cycle—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta U = 0\\)$$ .']

['What is the formula for determining internal energy?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that  $$\\(\\Delta U = Q - W\\text{,}\\)$$  where Q is the net heat transfer during the cycle, and W is the net work done by the system.']
