['What about light from most sources vibrates in all directions perpendicular to propagation?', 'Light from most sources vibrates in all directions perpendicular to propagation.']
['What can you tell me about the polarized field?', 'Light with an electric field that vibrates in only one direction is called polarized.']
['What is a diagram of polarized light?', 'A diagram of polarized light would look like Figure 15.2.']
['What is a polarizing filter?', 'Polarized glasses are an example of a polarizing filter.']
['What is the difference between polarized and non-polarized glasses?', 'These glasses absorb most of the horizontal light waves and transmit the vertical waves.']
['Why do they absorb the horizontal waves?', 'This cuts down glare, which is caused by horizontal waves.']
['How do polarizing filters work?', 'Figure 15.10 shows how waves traveling along a rope can be used as a model of how a polarizing filter works.']
['What is a vertically polarized wave?', 'The oscillations in one rope are in a vertical plane and are said to be vertically polarized.']
['What is horizontally polarized?', 'Those in the other rope are in a horizontal plane and are horizontally polarized.']
['What happens with a horizontally polarized wave?', 'If a vertical slit is placed on the first rope, the waves pass through.']
['What happens with a vertical slit?', 'However, a vertical slit blocks the horizontally polarized waves.']
['What are the Rope Models?', 'For EM waves, the direction of the electric field oscillation is analogous to the disturbances on the ropes.']
['Which types of electromagnetic wave behavior can light have?', 'Light can also be polarized by reflection.']
['What happens to polarized light?', 'Most of the light reflected from water, glass, or any highly reflective surface is polarized horizontally.']
['What can you learn from this information?', 'Figure 15.11 shows the effect of a polarizing lens on light reflected from the surface of water.']
['What is the relationship among these angles?', 'We can use the speed of light, c, to carry out several simple but interesting calculations.']
['What is a simple calculation?', 'If we know the distance to a celestial object, we can calculate how long it takes its light to reach us.']
['What does this calculation tell you?', 'Of course, we can also make the reverse calculation if we know the time it takes for the light to travel to us.']
['What happens when you know the time it takes?', 'For an object at a very great distance from Earth, it takes many years for its light to reach us.']
['What does this tell us?', 'This means that we are looking at the object as it existed in the distant past.']
['What can this tell us about the object?', 'The object may, in fact, no longer exist.']
['How are light years measured?', 'Very large distances in the universe are measured in light years.']

['How do you calculate a light year?', 'One light year is the distance that light travels in one year, which is  $$\\(9.46\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ kilometers or $$\\(5.88\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ miles (…and 1012 is a trillion!).']
['What is the rate at which light is radiated from a source called?', 'The rate at which light is radiated from a source is called luminous flux, P, and it is measured in lumens (lm).']
['What is another important aspect of the article?', 'Energy-saving light bulbs, which provide more luminous flux for a given use of electricity, are now available.']
['What are the different types of light bulbs available?', 'One of these bulbs is called a compact fluorescent lamp; another is an LED (light-emitting diode) bulb.']

['Why should we use energy-saving light bulbs?', 'If you wanted to replace an old incandescent bulb with an energy saving bulb, you would want the new bulb to have the same brightness as the old one.']
['How can you tell which bulb has the same brightness?', 'To compare bulbs accurately, you would need to compare the lumens each one puts out.']
['What other information about wattage is important?', 'Comparing wattage—that is, the electric power used—would be misleading.']
['How can we know how many lumens a bulb produces?', 'Both wattage and lumens are stated on the packaging.']
['What is the luminous flux of a bulb?', 'The luminous flux of a bulb might be 2,000 lm.']
['What does it account for?', 'That accounts for all the light radiated in all directions.']
['What do we really need to know?', 'However, what we really need to know is how much light falls on an object, such as a book, at a specific distance.']
['How are lumens and lux related?', 'The number of lumens per square meter is called illuminance, and is given in units of lux (lx).']
['How is luminous flux determined?', 'Picture a light bulb in the middle of a sphere with a 1-m radius.']
['How large is the sphere?', 'The total surface of the sphere equals 4πr2 m2.']
['What does that tell us about illuminance?', 'The illuminance is now only one-fourth as great, because the r2 term in the denominator is 4 instead of 1.']
['What does Figure 15.12 show us about illuminance?', 'Figure 15.12 shows how illuminance decreases with the inverse square of the distance.']
['What is the third way light can travel from a source to another location?', 'There are three ways, as shown in Figure 16.2, in which light can travel from a source to another location.']
['What are the three ways energy can come to Earth?', 'It can come directly from the source through empty space, such as from the Sun to Earth.']
['What else is important?', 'Light can travel to an object through various media, such as air and glass.']
['How does light travel through these things?', 'Light can also arrive at an object after being reflected, such as by a mirror.']
['What happens to light in all these cases?', 'In all these cases, light is modeled as traveling in a straight line, called a ray.']

['What does light do when it meets certain things?', 'Light may change direction when it encounters the surface of a different material (such as a mirror) or when it passes from one material to another (such as when passing from air into glass).']
['What happens to the light after it changes direction?', 'It then continues in a straight line—that is, as a ray.']
['What does the word ray come from?', 'The word ray comes from mathematics.']
['What does it mean to be a line that originates from some point?', 'Here it means a straight line that originates from some point.']
['What other interesting information did you find?', 'It is acceptable to visualize light rays as laser rays (or even science fiction depictions of ray guns).']

['What is the first thing you learned about light?', 'Because light moves in straight lines, that is, as rays, and changes directions when it interacts with matter, it can be described through geometry and trigonometry.']
['What is the name of this part of optics, described by straight lines and angles?', 'This part of optics, described by straight lines and angles, is therefore called geometric optics.']

['What are the two laws that govern how light changes direction when it interacts with matter?', 'There are two laws that govern how light changes direction when it interacts with matter: the law of reflection, for situations in which light bounces off matter; and the law of refraction, for situations in which light passes through matter.']
['What is the next major point?', 'In this section, we consider the geometric optics of reflection.']
['What do we see when we look into a mirror?', 'Whenever we look into a mirror or squint at sunlight glinting from a lake, we are seeing a reflection.']
['What is the law of reflection?', 'The law of reflection states:']
['What does it state?', 'The angle of reflection,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{r}}\\)$$, equals the angle of incidence,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{i}}\\)$$.']
['What is the law of reflection?', 'This law governs the behavior of all waves when they interact with a smooth surface, and therefore describe the behavior of light waves as well.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The reflection of light is simplified when light is treated as a ray.']

['How is this done?', 'This concept is illustrated in Figure 16.3, which also shows how the angles are measured relative to the line perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray strikes it.']
['What is that line called?', 'This perpendicular line is also called the normal line, or just the normal.']
['What is light reflected in this way called?', 'Light reflected in this way is referred to as specular (from the Latin word for mirror: speculum).']
['What are characteristics of mirrors?', 'We expect to see reflections from smooth surfaces, but Figure 16.4, illustrates how a rough surface reflects light.']

['What happens when you have rough surfaces?', 'Because the light is reflected from different parts of the surface at different angles, the rays go in many different directions, so the reflected light is diffused.']
['What can diffused light be used for?', 'Diffused light allows you to read a printed page from almost any angle because some of the rays go in different directions.']
['What other objects have rough surfaces and can be seen from many angles?', 'Many objects, such as people, clothing, leaves, and walls, have rough surfaces and can be seen from many angles.']
['What are the characteristics of a mirror?', 'A mirror, on the other hand, has a smooth surface and reflects light at specific angles.']
['What kind of object are you looking at in your mirror?', 'When we see ourselves in a mirror, it appears that our image is actually behind the mirror.']
['What can you tell me about the mirror?', 'We see the light coming from a direction determined by the law of reflection.']
['What are the angles in between?', 'The angles are such that our image is exactly the same distance behind the mirror, di, as the distance we stand away from the mirror, do.']

['What can you tell me about mirror images?', 'Although these mirror images make objects appear to be where they cannot be (such as behind a solid wall), the images are not figments of our imagination.']
['What else is significant about the mirrors?', 'Mirror images can be photographed and videotaped by instruments and look just as they do to our eyes, which are themselves optical instruments.']
['What is an image in a mirror?', 'An image in a mirror is said to be a virtual image, as opposed to a real image.']
['What is the difference between a real and virtual image?', 'A virtual image is formed when light rays appear to diverge from a point without actually doing so.']
['What does Figure 16.5 help illustrate?', 'Figure 16.5 helps illustrate how a flat mirror forms an image.']
['What does the figure show?', 'Two rays are shown emerging from the same point, striking the mirror, and reflecting into the observer’s eye.']
['What happens when the rays diverge slightly?', 'The rays can diverge slightly, and both still enter the eye.']
['What else do we know about a flat mirror?', 'If the rays are extrapolated backward, they seem to originate from a common point behind the mirror, allowing us to locate the image.']
['What else do we know about a flat mirror?', 'The paths of the reflected rays into the eye are the same as if they had come directly from that point behind the mirror.']

['What can we say about a flat mirror?', 'Using the law of reflection—the angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence—we can see that the image and object are the same distance from the mirror.']
['What are the two different images?', 'This is a virtual image, as defined earlier.']
['What are some characteristics of mirrors?', 'Some mirrors are curved instead of flat.']
['What happens if there is a curve in the mirror?', 'A mirror that curves inward is called a concave mirror, whereas one that curves outward is called a convex mirror.']
['What can you find on the internet?', 'Pick up a well-polished metal spoon and you can see an example of each type of curvature.']
['What do you think of that?', 'The side of the spoon that holds the food is a concave mirror; the back of the spoon is a convex mirror.']
['What is the best explanation of this?', 'Observe your image on both sides of the spoon.']
['What can ray diagrams be used to find?', 'Ray diagrams can be used to find the point where reflected rays converge or appear to converge, or the point from which rays appear to diverge.']
['Where do ray diagrams start?', 'This is called the focal point, F.']

['What is F?', 'The distance from F to the mirror along the central axis (the line perpendicular to the center of the mirror’s surface) is called the focal length, f. Figure 16.9 shows the focal points of concave and convex mirrors.']
['What type of mirrors are these?', 'Images formed by a concave mirror vary, depending on which side of the focal point the object is placed.']

['What can the mirror be used for?', 'For any object placed on the far side of the focal point with respect to the mirror, the rays converge in front of the mirror to form a real image, which can be projected onto a surface, such as a screen or sheet of paper']
['What else did you learn?', 'However, for an object located inside the focal point with respect to the concave mirror, the image is virtual.']
['What is an image that appears behind a convex mirror?', 'For a convex mirror the image is always virtual—that is, it appears to be behind the mirror.']
['What else did you learn?', 'The ray diagrams in Figure 16.10 show how to determine the nature of the image formed by concave and convex mirrors.']
['What kind of mirrors are used in the world?', 'You should be able to notice everyday applications of curved mirrors.']
['What are some examples of security mirrors?', 'One common example is the use of security mirrors in stores, as shown in Figure 16.11.']
['What part of the telescope is used to reflect light?', 'Some telescopes also use curved mirrors and no lenses (except in the eyepieces) both to magnify images and to change the path of light.']
['Which telescope shows the best image?', 'Figure 16.12 shows a Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope.']
['What is the Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope used for?', 'This design uses a spherical primary concave mirror and a convex secondary mirror.']
['How does the image appear on the focal plane?', 'The image is projected onto the focal plane by light passing through the perforated primary mirror.']

['What is the effective focal length of a telescope?', 'The effective focal length of such a telescope is the focal length of the primary mirror multiplied by the magnification of the secondary mirror.']
['What is the result of a telescope with a focal length of f/l = f/s?', 'The result is a telescope with a focal length much greater than the length of the telescope itself.']

['What is the property of a parabolic mirror?', 'A parabolic concave mirror has the very useful property that all light from a distant source, on reflection by the mirror surface, is directed to the focal point.']

['What is the other property of a light source placed at the focal point?', 'Likewise, a light source placed at the focal point directs all the light it emits in parallel lines away from the mirror.']
['What is Parabolic Mirror used for?', 'This case is illustrated by the ray diagram in Figure 16.13.']
['What is the light source in a car headlight, for example, located at?', 'The light source in a car headlight, for example, is located at the focal point of a parabolic mirror.']

['What else does Table 16.1 contain?', 'Parabolic mirrors are also used to collect sunlight and direct it to a focal point, where it is transformed into heat, which in turn can be used to generate electricity.']
['What is another application of parabolic mirrors?', 'This application is shown in Figure 16.14.']

['What are the equations for curved mirrors?', 'Curved mirrors and the images they create involve a fairly small number of variables: the mirror’s radius of curvature, R; the focal length, f; the distances of the object and image from the mirror, do and di, respectively; and the heights of the object and image, ho and hi, respectively.']
['What signs do the variables have?', 'The signs of these values indicate whether the image is inverted, erect (upright), real, or virtual.']
['What are the equations that relate these variables and apply them to everyday problems?', 'We now look at the equations that relate these variables and apply them to everyday problems.']
['What are the implications of this equation?', 'This equation can be rearranged several ways.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, it may be written to solve for focal length.']
['What is the ratio of the size of the image, hi, to the size of the object, ho?', 'Magnification, m, is the ratio of the size of the image, hi, to the size of the object, ho.']
['What is the value of m?', 'The value of m can be calculated in two ways.']
['What is the Pythagorean theorem?', 'This relationship can be written to solve for any of the variables involved.']
['What is an example of a variable involved in this relationship?', 'For example, the height of the image is given by']
['What is the simplest equation?', 'We saved the simplest equation for last.']
['What is the simplest equation for the radius of curvature of a curved mirror?', 'The radius of curvature of a curved mirror, R, is simply twice the focal length.']

['What information can we get from the algebraic sign?', 'A negative di indicates a virtual image; a positive value indicates a real image A negative hi indicates an inverted image; a positive value indicates an erect image']
['What other information can we get from the algebraic sign?', 'For concave mirrors, f is positive; for convex mirrors, f is negative']
['What is the law of refraction?', 'You may have noticed some odd optical phenomena when looking into a fish tank.']
['What are these odd optical phenomena?', 'For example, you may see the same fish appear to be in two different places (Figure 16.16).']

['How do you know that it is in two different places?', 'This is because light coming to you from the fish changes direction when it leaves the tank and, in this case, light rays traveling along two different paths both reach our eyes.']

['What is the changing of a light ray’s direction called when it passes a boundary between materials of different composition, or between layers in single material where there are changes in temperature and density?', 'The changing of a light ray’s direction (loosely called bending) when it passes a boundary between materials of different composition, or between layers in single material where there are changes in temperature and density, is called refraction.']
['What does the law of refraction do?', 'Refraction is responsible for a tremendous range of optical phenomena, from the action of lenses to voice transmission through optical fibers.']
['Why does light bend when it moves in a particular direction?', 'It is because light changes speed when going from one material to another.']
['What is light waves?', 'This behavior is typical of all waves and is especially easy to apply to light because light waves have very small wavelengths, and so they can be treated as rays.']
['What else should we know before we study the law of refraction?', 'Before we study the law of refraction, it is useful to discuss the speed of light and how it varies between different media.']
['What happened to the speed of light in 1879?', 'The speed of light is now known to great precision.']

['What is the value of the speed of light in a vacuum?', 'In fact, the speed of light in a vacuum, c, is so important, and is so precisely known, that it is accepted as one of the basic physical quantities, and has the fixed value']

['what is the approximate value of 3.00 $$(times)$$ 108 m/s used whenever three-digit precision is sufficient?', 'where the approximate value of 3.00  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  108 m/s is used whenever three-digit precision is sufficient.']
['What does this tell me?', 'The speed of light through matter is less than it is in a vacuum, because light interacts with atoms in a material.']
['How does this work?', 'The speed of light depends strongly on the type of material, given that its interaction with different atoms, crystal lattices, and other substructures varies.']
['What can we learn from this information?', 'We define the index of refraction, n, of a material to be']
['What is $$[n = fraccv,]?', 'where v is the observed speed of light in the material.']

['What is the index of refraction?', 'Because the speed of light is always less than c in matter and equals c only in a vacuum, the index of refraction (plural: indices of refraction) is always greater than or equal to one.']

['What is the analogy for and a description of how a ray of light changes direction when it passes from one medium to another?', 'Figure 16.17 provides an analogy for and a description of how a ray of light changes direction when it passes from one medium to another.']
['How are the angles measured?', 'As in the previous section, the angles are measured relative to a perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray crosses it.']
['What is the analogy for the change in direction of the light ray?', 'The change in direction of the light ray depends on how the speed of light changes.']
['What is the relation between speed and direction?', 'The change in the speed of light is related to the indices of refraction of the media involved.']
['What is the relation between indices of refraction and direction?', 'In the situations shown in Figure 16.17, medium 2 has a greater index of refraction than medium 1.']
['What does this mean?', 'This difference in index of refraction means that the speed of light is less in medium 2 than in medium 1.']
['What is the analogy?', 'Note that, in Figure 16.17(a), the path of the ray moves closer to the perpendicular when the ray slows down.']
['Is that correct?', 'Conversely, in Figure 16.17(b), the path of the ray moves away from the perpendicular when the ray speeds up.']
['Is the path reversible?', 'The path is exactly reversible.']
['What is the difference between a lawn mower and a lawn?', 'In both cases, you can imagine what happens by thinking about pushing a lawn mower from a footpath onto grass, and vice versa.']
['Why is that?', 'Going from the footpath to grass, the right front wheel is slowed and pulled to the side as shown.']
['What is the change in direction for light when it goes from a fast medium to a slow one?', 'This is the same change in direction for light when it goes from a fast medium to a slow one.']
["What is the correct way to describe the mower's motion?", 'When going from the grass to the footpath, the left front wheel moves faster than the others, and the mower changes direction as shown.']
['Is that correct?', 'This, too, is the same change in direction as light going from slow to fast.']
['What is the relationship between incident angle and speed?', 'The amount that a light ray changes direction depends both on the incident angle and the amount that the speed changes.']

['What is the effect of speed change on light?', 'For a ray at a given incident angle, a large change in speed causes a large change in direction, and thus a large change in the angle of refraction.']

['What is the exact mathematical relationship between incident angle and speed change?', 'The exact mathematical relationship is the law of refraction, or Snell’s law, which is stated in equation form as']

['How is this used in science?', 'Here, n1 and n2 are the indices of refraction for media 1 and 2, respectively, and θ1 and θ2 are the angles between the rays and the perpendicular in the respective media 1 and 2, as shown in Figure 16.17.']
['What are the two types of rays called?', 'The incoming ray is called the incident ray and the outgoing ray is called the refracted ray.']
['What are the associated angles called?', 'The associated angles are called the angle of incidence and the angle of refraction.']
['Are there any other aspects about this that you want to know?', 'Later, we apply Snell’s law to some practical situations.']
['What is the spreading of white light into the wavelengths of which it is composed?', 'Dispersion is defined as the spreading of white light into the wavelengths of which it is composed.']
['Why does light spread?', 'This happens because the index of refraction varies slightly with wavelength.']
['What can dispersion do?', 'Figure 16.18 shows how a prism disperses white light into the colors of the rainbow.']
['What is the relationship between refraction and reflection?', 'Rainbows are produced by a combination of refraction and reflection.']
['How does light pass through water?', 'Light enters a drop of water and is reflected from the back of the drop, as shown in Figure 16.19.']
['What is the relationship between refraction and reflection?', 'The light is refracted both as it enters and as it leaves the drop.']
['What happens during refraction?', 'Because the index of refraction of water varies with wavelength, the light is dispersed and a rainbow is observed.']
['Why does a mirror reflect less than 90 percent of light?', 'A good-quality mirror reflects more than 90 percent of the light that falls on it; the mirror absorbs the rest.']
['Why does the mirror reflect light?', 'But, it would be useful to have a mirror that reflects all the light that falls on it.']
['Can we have total reflection using an aspect of refraction?', 'Interestingly, we can produce total reflection using an aspect of refraction.']

['What happens when a ray of light strikes the surface between two materials?', 'Consider what happens when a ray of light strikes the surface between two materials, such as is shown in Figure 16.20(a).']
['What happens when light strikes the surface between two materials?', 'Part of the light crosses the boundary and is refracted; the rest is reflected.']
['What is an example of refraction?', 'If, as shown in the figure, the index of refraction for the second medium is less than the first, the ray bends away from the perpendicular.']

['What happens when light enters a window?', 'Because n1 > n2, the angle of refraction is greater than the angle of incidence—that is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ > $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$ .']
['What is the difference between light entering the window and light leaving the window?', 'Now, imagine what happens as the incident angle is increased.']
["The incident angle increases because it is greater than the ray's normal.", 'This causes  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$  to increase as well.']
['How does this effect the light?', 'The largest the angle of refraction,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$, can be is 90°, as shown in Figure 16.20(b).']

['What is the critical angle for a combination of two materials?', 'The critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, for a combination of two materials is defined to be the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, which produces an angle of refraction of 90°.']
['What does the article say?', 'That is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  is the incident angle for which  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ = 90°.']

['What is the critical angle?', 'If the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, is greater than the critical angle, as shown in Figure 16.20(c), then all the light is reflected back into medium 1, a condition called total internal reflection.']
['What is the relationship between angles and indices of refraction?', 'Recall that Snell’s law states the relationship between angles and indices of refraction.']

['What is the first question I want to ask you?', 'When the incident angle equals the critical angle ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$= $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$), the angle of refraction is 90° ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$= 90°).']
['What happens next?', 'Noting that sin 90° = 1, Snell’s law in this case becomes']

['What is total internal reflection?', 'Total internal reflection occurs for any incident angle greater than the critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, and it can only occur when the second medium has an index of refraction less than the first.']

['What happens if the incident angle is smaller than this?', 'Note that the previous equation is written for a light ray that travels in medium 1 and reflects from medium 2, as shown in Figure 16.20.']
['What are some of the important applications of total internal reflection?', 'There are several important applications of total internal reflection.']
['What can it explain about diamonds?', 'Total internal reflection, coupled with a large index of refraction, explains why diamonds sparkle more than other materials.']

['What other interesting facts about this material?', 'The critical angle for a diamond-to-air surface is only 24.4°; so, when light enters a diamond, it has trouble getting back out (Figure 16.21).']
['How does the light do this?', 'Although light freely enters the diamond at different angles, it can exit only if it makes an angle less than 24.4° with the normal to a given surface.']
['How are diamonds used?', 'Facets on diamonds are specifically intended to make this unlikely, so that the light can exit only in certain places.']

['What else does this have to do with sparkle?', 'Diamonds with very few impurities are very clear, so the light makes many internal reflections and is concentrated at the few places it can exit—hence the sparkle.']
['What is it about?', 'A light ray that strikes an object that consists of two mutually perpendicular reflecting surfaces is reflected back exactly parallel to the direction from which it came.']
['What is true about parallel reflection?', 'This parallel reflection is true whenever the reflecting surfaces are perpendicular, and it is independent of the angle of incidence.']
['What is an example of this?', 'Such an object is called a corner reflector because the light bounces from its inside corner.']

['What kind of objects are there?', 'Many inexpensive reflector buttons on bicycles, cars, and warning signs have corner reflectors designed to return light in the direction from which it originates.']
['What else do you know about the material?', 'Corner reflectors are perfectly efficient when the conditions for total internal reflection are satisfied.']
['What is the most common critical angle?', 'With common materials, it is easy to obtain a critical angle that is less than 45°.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'One use of these perfect mirrors is in binoculars, as shown in Figure 16.22.']
['What is another application of periscopes?', 'Another application is for periscopes used in submarines.']
['What is the most important information I should know for this assignment?', 'Fiber optics are one common application of total internal reflection.']

['What is the term for the transmission of light down fibers of plastic or glass?', 'In communications, fiber optics are used to transmit telephone, internet, and cable TV signals, and they use the transmission of light down fibers of plastic or glass.']

['What happens when light enters the fiber?', 'Because the fibers are thin, light entering one is likely to strike the inside surface at an angle greater than the critical angle and, thus, be totally reflected (Figure 16.23).']

['What is the design of the fiber optics?', 'The index of refraction outside the fiber must be smaller than inside, a condition that is satisfied easily by coating the outside of the fiber with a material that has an appropriate refractive index.']
['Do the coatings have to be on both sides of the fiber?', 'In fact, most fibers have a varying refractive index to allow more light to be guided along the fiber through total internal reflection.']
['What is reflected along the fiber?', 'Rays are reflected around corners as shown in the figure, making the fibers into tiny light pipes.']
['What are lenses used for?', 'Lenses are found in a huge array of optical instruments, ranging from a simple magnifying glass to the eye to a camera’s zoom lens.']
['What can be told about the law of refraction?', 'In this section, we use the law of refraction to explore the properties of lenses and how they form images.']
['What is one important fact you need to know about this topic?', 'Some of what we learned in the earlier discussion of curved mirrors also applies to the study of lenses.']

['What is the difference between the mirror and lens characteristics?', 'Concave, convex, focal point F, and focal length f have the same meanings as before, except each measurement is made from the center of the lens instead of the surface of the mirror.']

['What is the explanation for the convex lens shown in Figure 16.25?', 'The convex lens shown in Figure 16.25 has been shaped so that all light rays that enter it parallel to its central axis cross one another at a single point on the opposite side of the lens.']
['How does the central axis help with the measurement?', 'The central axis, or axis, is defined to be a line normal to the lens at its center.']
['What happens when a lens of this type is used?', 'Such a lens is called a converging lens because of the converging effect it has on light rays.']

['What is the expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens to illustrate?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.25 to illustrate how the ray changes direction both as it enters and as it leaves the lens.']

['What happens when you look through it?', 'Because the index of refraction of the lens is greater than that of air, the ray moves toward the perpendicular as it enters and away from the perpendicular as it leaves.']
['Is that correct?', '(This is in accordance with the law of refraction.)']
['How is that reflected?', 'As a result of the shape of the lens, light is thus bent toward the axis at both surfaces.']
['What are the other characteristics of lenses?', 'Note that rays from a light source placed at the focal point of a converging lens emerge parallel from the other side of the lens.']
['What does a converging lens do?', 'You may have heard of the trick of using a converging lens to focus rays of sunlight to a point.']
['What is the purpose of a laser?', 'Such a concentration of light energy can produce enough heat to ignite paper.']

['What is the effect of a concave lens on rays of light that enter it parallel to its axis?', 'Figure 16.26 shows a concave lens and the effect it has on rays of light that enter it parallel to its axis (the path taken by ray 2 in the figure is the axis of the lens).']
['What causes the light rays to bend away (diverge) from its axis?', 'The concave lens is a diverging lens because it causes the light rays to bend away (diverge) from its axis.']

['What is the focal point of the diverging lens?', 'In this case, the lens has been shaped so all light rays entering it parallel to its axis appear to originate from the same point, F, defined to be the focal point of a diverging lens.']
['What is the focal length of a lens?', 'The distance from the center of the lens to the focal point is again called the focal length, or “ƒ,” of the lens.']
['How can you find the focal length of a lens?', 'Note that the focal length of a diverging lens is defined to be negative.']

['What else happened in this section?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.26 to illustrate how the shape of the lens, together with the law of refraction, causes the ray to follow its particular path and diverge.']
['What is one of the characteristics of a lens?', 'The power, P, of a lens is very easy to calculate.']
['How does it work?', 'It is simply the reciprocal of the focal length, expressed in meters']
['What is the unit of power determined by?', 'The units of power are diopters, D, which are expressed in reciprocal meters.']
['What other information did you find interesting in the article?', 'If the focal length is negative, as it is for the diverging lens in Figure 16.26, then the power is also negative.']
['What is an example of image formation?', 'In some circumstances, a lens forms an image at an obvious location, such as when a movie projector casts an image onto a screen.']
['What is the image location of a movie projector?', 'In other cases, the image location is less obvious.']
['What is image formation?', 'We use ray tracing for thin lenses to illustrate how they form images, and we develop equations to describe the image-formation quantitatively.']
['What are the rules for ray tracing?', 'These are the rules for ray tracing:']
['What happens to a ray passing through the center of a converging lens?', 'Consider an object some distance away from a converging lens, as shown in Figure 16.27.']
['How can you determine the location of an image?', 'To find the location and size of the image formed, we trace the paths of select light rays originating from one point on the object.']
['What is the originating point of the arrow?', 'In this example, the originating point is the top of a woman’s head.']
['How many rays do you need to trace?', 'Figure 16.27 shows three rays from the top of the object that can be traced using the ray-tracing rules just listed.']
['What will happen after tracing these rays?', 'Rays leave this point traveling in many directions, but we concentrate on only a few, which have paths that are easy to trace.']
['What do we determine from these rays?', 'The first ray is one that enters the lens parallel to its axis and passes through the focal point on the other side (rule 1).']
['What is the other ray?', 'The second ray passes through the center of the lens without changing direction (rule 3).']
['What happens to the third ray?', 'The third ray passes through the nearer focal point on its way into the lens and leaves the lens parallel to its axis (rule 4).']
['What is the final result of the image?', 'The image of the top of the person’s head is located at this point.']
['How many points do you need to trace?', 'Rays from another point on the object, such as the belt buckle, also cross at another common point, forming a complete image, as shown.']
['What happened after tracing these rays?', 'Although three rays are traced in Figure 16.27, only two are necessary to locate the image.']
['What is the best way to trace these rays?', 'It is best to trace rays for which there are simple ray-tracing rules.']
['What is the application of ray tracing to other situations?', 'Before applying ray tracing to other situations, let us consider the example shown in Figure 16.27 in more detail.']
['What is the image formed in Figure 16.27 about?', 'The image formed in Figure 16.27 is a real image—meaning, it can be projected.']

['What is the process of light rays from one point on an object actually crossing at the location of the image and can be projected onto a screen, a piece of film, or the retina of an eye?', 'That is, light rays from one point on the object actually cross at the location of the image and can be projected onto a screen, a piece of film, or the retina of an eye.']
['What is the object distance, do?', 'In Figure 16.27, the object distance, do, is greater than f.']
['What is the next step in the topic?', 'Now we consider a ray diagram for a convex lens where do< f, and another diagram for a concave lens.']
['What does case 1 mean?', 'The examples in Figure 16.27 and Figure 16.28 represent the three possible cases—case 1, case 2, and case 3—summarized in Table 16.3.']
['What does the table mean?', 'In the table, m is magnification; the other symbols have the same meaning as they did for curved mirrors.']
['What are the equations for image formation by lenses?', 'Image formation by lenses can also be calculated from simple equations.']
['What are the equations used to calculate the radians of the Sun?', 'We learn how these calculations are carried out near the end of this section.']
['What are some common applications of lenses?', 'Some common applications of lenses with which we are all familiar are magnifying glasses, eyeglasses, cameras, microscopes, and telescopes.']
['Do we need to look at other applications of lenses?', 'We take a look at the latter two examples, which are the most complex.']
['What is an example of a telescope without lens?', 'We have already seen the design of a telescope that uses only mirrors in Figure 16.12.']
['What is an example of a telescope with two lenses?', 'Figure 16.29 shows the design of a telescope that uses two lenses.']
['What is an example of a telescope with three lenses?', 'Part (a) of the figure shows the design of the telescope used by Galileo.']
['Why is this more advantageous?', 'It produces an upright image, which is more convenient for many applications.']
['What is the arrangement of lenses used in many astronomical telescopes?', 'Part (b) shows an arrangement of lenses used in many astronomical telescopes.']
['What is the advantage of this design?', 'This design produces an inverted image, which is less of a problem when viewing celestial objects.']
["What are the four figures we're working with?", 'Figure 16.30 shows the path of light through a typical microscope.']
['What was the first microscope used for?', 'Microscopes were first developed during the early 1600s by eyeglass makers in the Netherlands and Denmark.']
['What is the simplest compound microscope constructed from?', 'The simplest compound microscope is constructed from two convex lenses, as shown schematically in Figure 16.30.']
['What is the first lens in a telescope?', 'The first lens is called the objective lens; it has typical magnification values from 5 $$\\(\\times\\)$$  to 100 $$\\(\\times\\)$$ .']
['What are the objectives in a microscope?', 'In standard microscopes, the objectives are mounted such that when you switch between them, the sample remains in focus.']
['What is the term for a group of objectives arranged in a particular way?', 'Objectives arranged in this way are described as parfocal.']
['What is the second lens called?', 'The second lens, the eyepiece, also referred to as the ocular, has several lenses that slide inside a cylindrical barrel.']
['How does the eyepiece help focus?', 'The focusing ability is provided by the movement of both the objective lens and the eyepiece.']
['What do the two lenses do?', 'The purpose of a microscope is to magnify small objects, and both lenses contribute to the final magnification.']

['What is the difference between the two lenses?', 'In addition, the final enlarged image is produced in a location far enough from the observer to be viewed easily because the eye cannot focus on objects or images that are too close.']
['What is an example of this physics in practice?', 'Real lenses behave somewhat differently from how they are modeled using rays diagrams or the thin-lens equations.']
['What happens to real lenses in practice?', 'Real lenses produce aberrations.']
['What is an aberration?', 'An aberration is a distortion in an image.']
['What causes aberrations?', 'There are a variety of aberrations that result from lens size, material, thickness, and the position of the object.']
['What are the different kinds of aberrations?', 'One common type of aberration is chromatic aberration, which is related to color.']

['What is the relationship between color and aberrations?', 'Because the index of refraction of lenses depends on color, or wavelength, images are produced at different places and with different magnifications for different colors.']
['What is the difference between mirrors and lenses?', 'The law of reflection is independent of wavelength, so mirrors do not have this problem.']
['What is another advantage for the use of mirrors in optical systems such as telescopes?', 'This result is another advantage for the use of mirrors in optical systems such as telescopes.']
['What is the most important thing you learned in this lesson?', 'Figure 16.31(a) shows chromatic aberration for a single convex lens, and its partial correction with a two-lens system.']

['What happens to violet light in a lens?', 'The index of refraction of the lens increases with decreasing wavelength, so violet rays are refracted more than red rays, and are thus focused closer to the lens.']
['What is the problem with the diverging lens?', 'The diverging lens corrects this in part, although it is usually not possible to do so completely.']
['What are some things to be aware of in regards to the converging lens?', 'Lenses made of different materials and with different dispersions may be used.']

['What are some examples of the lenses?', 'For example, an achromatic doublet consisting of a converging lens made of crown glass in contact with a diverging lens made of flint glass can reduce chromatic aberration dramatically (Figure 16.31(b)).']
['What does the eye do?', 'The eye is perhaps the most interesting of all optical instruments.']
['What is most interesting about the eye?', 'It is remarkable in how it forms images and in the richness of detail and color they eye can detect.']
['What can it do?', 'However, our eyes commonly need some correction to reach what is called normal vision, but should be called ideal vision instead.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Image formation by our eyes and common vision correction are easy to analyze using geometric optics.']
['What is the anatomy of the eye?', 'Figure 16.32 shows the basic anatomy of the eye.']
['What is the most important part of the eye?', 'The cornea and lens form a system that, to a good approximation, acts as a single thin lens.']
["What is the eye's job?", 'For clear vision, a real image must be projected onto the light-sensitive retina, which lies at a fixed distance from the lens.']
['What does the lens of the eye do?', 'The lens of the eye adjusts its power to produce an image on the retina for objects at different distances.']
['How does the eye adjust for distances?', 'The center of the image falls on the fovea, which has the greatest density of light receptors and the greatest acuity (sharpness) in the visual field.']
['What is the blind spot?', 'There are no receptors at the place where the optic nerve meets the eye, which is called the blind spot.']
['What is the reason for that?', 'An image falling on this spot cannot be seen.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'The variable opening (or pupil) of the eye along with chemical adaptation allows the eye to detect light intensities from the lowest observable to 1010 times greater (without damage).']
['How did they do that?', 'Ten orders of magnitude is an incredible range of detection.']
['What are some of the functions of the eyes?', 'Our eyes perform a vast number of functions, such as sense direction, movement, sophisticated colors, and distance.']
['What part of the eye processes visual information?', 'Processing of visual nerve impulses begins with interconnections in the retina and continues in the brain.']
["What is the eye's communication with the brain?", 'The optic nerve conveys signals received by the eye to the brain.']
['What kind of indices do lenses have?', 'Refractive indices are crucial to image formation using lenses.']
['What does a table show?', 'Table 16.4 shows refractive indices relevant to the eye.']
['What is the bending of rays called?', 'The biggest change in the refractive index—and the one that causes the greatest bending of rays—occurs at the cornea rather than the lens.']
['What is the ray diagram in Figure 16.33?', 'The ray diagram in Figure 16.33 shows image formation by the cornea and lens of the eye.']
["What determines the rays' bend?", 'The rays bend according to the refractive indices provided in Table 16.4.']
['What is the reason rays bend?', 'The cornea provides about two-thirds of the magnification of the eye because the speed of light changes considerably while traveling from air into the cornea.']
['What does the lens provide?', 'The lens provides the remaining magnification needed to produce an image on the retina.']

['What are the layers of the lens?', 'The cornea and lens can be treated as a single thin lens, although the light rays pass through several layers of material (such as the cornea, aqueous humor, several layers in the lens, and vitreous humor), changing direction at each interface.']
['What is the image formed like?', 'The image formed is much like the one produced by a single convex lens.']
['What was the case 1 image?', 'This result is a case 1 image.']
['What is the image upside down?', 'Images formed in the eye are inverted, but the brain inverts them once more to make them seem upright.']
['What is the basic principle of physics?', 'As noted, the image must fall precisely on the retina to produce clear vision—that is, the image distance, di, must equal the lens-to-retina distance.']
['What is di equal to?', 'Because the lens-to-retina distance does not change, di must be the same for objects at all distances.']
['What are the other basic principles?', 'The eye manages to vary the distance by varying the power (and focal length) of the lens to accommodate for objects at various distances.']
['How do they regulate the lens power?', 'In Figure 16.33, you can see the small ciliary muscles above and below the lens that change the shape of the lens and, thus, the focal length.']
['What is vision correction?', 'The need for some type of vision correction is very common.']
['What is the most common vision defect?', 'Common vision defects are easy to understand, and some are simple to correct.']
['What are common vision defects?', 'Figure 16.34 illustrates two common vision defects.']

['What is the inability to see distant objects clearly while close objects are in focus?', 'Nearsightedness, or myopia, is the inability to see distant objects clearly while close objects are in focus.']
['What causes nearsightedness?', 'The nearsighted eye overconverges the nearly parallel rays from a distant object, and the rays cross in front of the retina.']
['What does this do to the image?', 'More divergent rays from a close object are converged on the retina, producing a clear image.']

['What is the inability to see close objects clearly whereas distant objects may be in focus?', 'Farsightedness, or hyperopia, is the inability to see close objects clearly whereas distant objects may be in focus.']
['What causes farsightedness?', 'A farsighted eye does not converge rays from a close object sufficiently to make the rays meet on the retina.']
['What does this do to the image?', 'Less divergent rays from a distant object can be converged for a clear image.']

['What can you tell me about nearsightedness?', 'Because the nearsighted eye overconverges light rays, the correction for nearsightedness involves placing a diverging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does the diverging lens do?', 'This lens reduces the power of an eye that has too short a focal length (Figure 16.35(a)).']
['What can you tell me about farsightedness?', 'Because the farsighted eye underconverges light rays, the correction for farsightedness is to place a converging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does the converging lens do?', 'This lens increases the power of an eye that has too long a focal length (Figure 16.35(b)).']
