['What is the relationship between diffraction and interference?', 'We know that visible light is the type of electromagnetic wave to which our eyes responds.']
['What does light obey?', 'As we have seen previously, light obeys the equation']

['What else did you learn?', 'where  $$\\(c = 3.00\\  \\times \\ 10^{8}\\)$$  m/s is the speed of light in vacuum, f is the frequency of the electromagnetic wave in Hz (or s–1), and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is its wavelength in m.']
['What is the range of wavelengths?', 'The range of visible wavelengths is approximately 380 to 750 nm.']
['What does light do?', 'As is true for all waves, light travels in straight lines and acts like a ray when it interacts with objects several times as large as its wavelength.']
['Does light follow any patterns?', 'However, when it interacts with smaller objects, it displays its wave characteristics prominently.']
['What is interference?', 'Interference is the identifying behavior of a wave.']
['What can be seen in Figure 17.2?', 'In Figure 17.2, both the ray and wave characteristics of light can be seen.']
['What is the ray behavior?', 'The laser beam emitted by the observatory represents ray behavior, as it travels in a straight line.']
['What are the wave characteristics?', 'Passing a pure, one-wavelength beam through vertical slits with a width close to the wavelength of the beam reveals the wave character of light.']

['Are there other things in this figure?', 'Here we see the beam spreading out horizontally into a pattern of bright and dark regions that are caused by systematic constructive and destructive interference.']
['What is interference?', 'As it is characteristic of wave behavior, interference is observed for water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['What is the principle of interference?', 'That interference is a characteristic of energy propagation by waves is demonstrated more convincingly by water waves.']
['What is an example of water waves?', 'Figure 17.3 shows water waves passing through gaps between some rocks.']
['What causes interference?', 'You can easily see that the gaps are similar in width to the wavelength of the waves and that this causes an interference pattern as the waves pass beyond the gaps.']
['what is interference pattern?', 'A cross-section across the waves in the foreground would show the crests and troughs characteristic of an interference pattern.']
['Light has what kind of wave properties?', 'Light has wave characteristics in various media as well as in a vacuum.']

['What do the wave properties do when light goes from a vacuum to some medium, such as water?', 'When light goes from a vacuum to some medium, such as water, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency, f, remains the same.']
['How do the wave properties change?', 'The speed of light in a medium is  $$\\(v = c/n\\)$$, where n is its index of refraction.']
['What else can you tell me about the wave properties?', 'If you divide both sides of the equation  $$\\(c = f\\lambda\\)$$  by n, you get  $$\\(c/n = v = f\\lambda/n\\)$$ .']
['What is the wavelength in a medium?', 'Therefore,  $$\\(v = f\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, where  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$  is the wavelength in a medium, and']
['What did you find interesting?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength in vacuum and n is the medium’s index of refraction.']
['What does this mean?', 'It follows that the wavelength of light is smaller in any medium than it is in vacuum.']

['What happens to the wavelengths when they are smaller?', 'In water, for example, which has n = 1.333, the range of visible wavelengths is (380 nm)/1.333 to (760 nm)/1.333, or  $$\\(\\lambda_{n} =\\)$$ 285–570 nm.']
['What are other interesting things about this paragraph?', 'Although wavelengths change while traveling from one medium to another, colors do not, since colors are associated with frequency.']
['What is the main point of the passage?', 'The Dutch scientist Christiaan Huygens (1629–1695) developed a useful technique for determining in detail how and where waves propagate.']

['How did Huygens determine in detail how and where waves propagate?', 'He used wavefronts, which are the points on a wave’s surface that share the same, constant phase (such as all the points that make up the crest of a water wave).']
['How do wavefronts propagate?', 'Huygens’s principle states, “Every point on a wavefront is a source of wavelets that spread out in the forward direction at the same speed as the wave itself.']
['What happens when wavelets spread?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to all of the wavelets.”']
['What does the figure 17.4 show?', 'Figure 17.4 shows how Huygens’s principle is applied.']
['What is the long edge that moves in a wave?', 'A wavefront is the long edge that moves; for example, the crest or the trough.']
['What happens at each point on the wavefront?', 'Each point on the wavefront emits a semicircular wave that moves at the propagation speed v.']
['What does the vector tell us about how the wavefront will be developed?', 'These are drawn later at a time, t, so that they have moved a distance  $$\\(s = vt\\)$$ .']
['What is the new wavefront?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to the wavelets and is where the wave is located at time t.']
['Do other types of waves work the same way as Huygens’s principle?', 'Huygens’s principle works for all types of waves, including water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['What will the principle be useful for?', 'It will be useful not only in describing how light waves propagate, but also in how they interfere.']

['What is the problem we studied?', 'For light, you expect to see a sharp shadow of the doorway on the floor of the room, and you expect no light to bend around corners into other parts of the room.']

['What is another example of how the human senses can affect perception?', 'When sound passes through a door, you hear it everywhere in the room and, thus, you understand that sound spreads out when passing through such an opening.']
["What are some examples of light's non-standard behavior?", 'The answer is that the wavelengths that make up the light are very short, so that the light acts like a ray.']
['Are there any other examples of light being distorted?', 'Sound has wavelengths on the order of the size of the door, and so it bends around corners.']
['What is the topic of the passage?', 'If light passes through smaller openings, often called slits, you can use Huygens’s principle to show that light bends as sound does (see Figure 17.5).']
['What is the bending of a wave around the edges of an opening or an obstacle called?', 'The bending of a wave around the edges of an opening or an obstacle is called diffraction.']
['What is a wave characteristic that occurs for all types of waves?', 'Diffraction is a wave characteristic that occurs for all types of waves.']
['What is evidence that a phenomenon is produced by waves?', 'If diffraction is observed for a phenomenon, it is evidence that the phenomenon is produced by waves.']

['What is an example of light having the properties of a wave?', 'Thus, the horizontal diffraction of the laser beam after it passes through slits in Figure 17.2 is evidence that light has the properties of a wave.']
['What is the first argument that he used to support his position?', 'The fact that Huygens’s principle worked was not considered enough evidence to prove that light is a wave.']
['Why was he considered unpopular?', 'People were also reluctant to accept light’s wave nature because it contradicted the ideas of Isaac Newton, who was still held in high esteem.']

['What was the name of the physicist who did the double slit experiment?', 'The acceptance of the wave character of light came after 1801, when the English physicist and physician Thomas Young (1773–1829) did his now-classic double-slit experiment (see Figure 17.7).']
['What other important things should you know about waves?', 'When light passes through narrow slits, it is diffracted into semicircular waves, as shown in Figure 17.8 (a).']
['What is the difference between constructive interference and destructive interference?', 'Pure constructive interference occurs where the waves line up crest to crest or trough to trough.']
['What happens when there is destructive interference?', 'Pure destructive interference occurs where they line up crest to trough.']
['What can you observe when light is being diffracted?', 'The light must fall on a screen and be scattered into our eyes for the pattern to be visible.']
['What is the analogous pattern for water waves?', 'An analogous pattern for water waves is shown in Figure 17.8 (b).']
['What can you observe while looking through the slits?', 'Note that regions of constructive and destructive interference move out from the slits at well-defined angles to the original beam.']
['Are there any other things of note?', 'Those angles depend on wavelength and the distance between the slits, as you will see below.']

['What is this article about?', 'The fact that the wavelength of light of one color, or monochromatic light, can be calculated from its two-slit diffraction pattern in Young’s experiments supports the conclusion that light has wave properties.']
['What is an example of a calculation involved in this article?', 'To understand the basis of such calculations, consider how two waves travel from the slits to the screen.']
['What else is relevant to this?', 'Each slit is a different distance from a given point on the screen.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus different numbers of wavelengths fit into each path.']

['What happens when these waves arrive at different times?', 'Waves start out from the slits in phase (crest to crest), but they will end up out of phase (crest to trough) at the screen if the paths differ in length by half a wavelength, interfering destructively.']
['What happens if the paths differ by a whole wavelength?', 'If the paths differ by a whole wavelength, then the waves arrive in phase (crest to crest) at the screen, interfering constructively.']

['How can destructive interference be modeled?', 'More generally, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any half-integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\frac{1}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{3}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{5}{2}\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then destructive interference occurs.']

['What is the difference between constructive and destructive interference?', 'Similarly, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\lambda,\\ 2\\lambda,\\ 3\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then constructive interference occurs.']
['What are some other interesting facts about this study material?', 'Figure 17.9 shows how to determine the path-length difference for waves traveling from two slits to a common point on a screen.']

['What else is mentioned about this measurement?', 'If the screen is a large distance away compared with the distance between the slits, then the angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  between the path and a line from the slits perpendicular to the screen (see the figure) is nearly the same for each path.']

['Is there anything else interesting about the measurement?', 'That approximation and simple trigonometry show the length difference,  $$\\(\\Delta L\\)$$, to be  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$, where d is the distance between the slits,']
['What is the order of the interference?', 'The number m is the order of the interference.']
['What order does it have?', 'For example, m = 4 is fourth-order interference.']
['What does this show?', 'Light passing through a single slit forms a diffraction pattern somewhat different from that formed by double slits.']
['What is different about a single slit?', 'Figure 17.11 shows a single-slit diffraction pattern.']
['What does it show?', 'Note that the central maximum is larger than those on either side, and that the intensity decreases rapidly on either side.']
['What is the analysis of single-slit diffraction illustrated in?', 'The analysis of single-slit diffraction is illustrated in Figure 17.12.']
['What else is there to read?', 'Assuming the screen is very far away compared with the size of the slit, rays heading toward a common destination are nearly parallel.']
['What else is in this material?', 'That approximation allows a series of trigonometric operations that result in the equations for the minima produced by destructive interference.']
['What do you learn from this information?', 'When rays travel straight ahead, they remain in phase and a central maximum is obtained.']

['What else did you learn?', 'However, when rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the original direction of the beam, each ray travels a different distance to the screen, and they can arrive in or out of phase.']

['What else happened during this process?', 'Thus, a ray from the center travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther than the ray from the top edge of the slit, they arrive out of phase, and they interfere destructively.']

['Did anything else interesting happen during this test?', 'Similarly, for every ray between the top and the center of the slit, there is a ray between the center and the bottom of the slit that travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther to the common point on the screen, and so interferes destructively.']
['What did you learn next?', 'Symmetrically, there will be another minimum at the same angle below the direct ray.']

['What is the equation used to determine constructive interference?', 'To calculate the positions of constructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be an integral multiple, m, of the wavelength.']
['What is the number associated with this equation?', '$$\\(\\lambda\\)$$']

['What is the function of the slits?', 'where d is the distance between the slits and  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between a line from the slits to the maximum and a line perpendicular to the barrier in which the slits are located.']
['What is the next section of this paper?', 'To calculate the positions of destructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be a half-integral multiple of the wavelength:']
['When was Albert Einstein first aware of photons and excited atoms?', 'In 1917, Albert Einstein was thinking about photons and excited atoms.']
['What did he consider?', 'He considered an atom excited by a certain amount of energy and what would happen if that atom were hit by a photon with the same amount of energy.']
['Did he find anything interesting about this concept?', 'He suggested that the atom would emit a photon with that amount of energy, and it would be accompanied by the original photon.']
['What could those photons do?', 'Those photons could go on to hit other excited atoms, and soon you would have a stream of in-phase photons.']
['What is a stream of in-phase photons called?', 'Such a light stream is said to be coherent.']
['What did the scientific community do with his idea?', 'Some four decades later, Einstein’s idea found application in a process called, light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.']
['What was the alphabet?', 'Take the first letters of all the words (except by and “of”) and write them in order.']
['What is the last word in the passage?', 'You get the word laser (see Figure 17.2 (a)), which is the name of the device that produces such a beam of light.']
['What are some of the characteristics of laser beams?', 'Laser beams are directional, very intense, and narrow (only about 0.5 mm in diameter).']
['What are the properties of laser beams?', 'These properties lead to a number of applications in industry and medicine.']
['What are some examples of how they are used?', 'The following are just a few examples:']
['What chapter was this in?', 'This chapter began with a picture of a compact disc (see Figure 17.1).']
['What was the picture of?', 'Those audio and data-storage devices began replacing cassette tapes during the 1990s.']
['How do CDs work?', 'CDs are read by interpreting variations in reflections of a laser beam from the surface.']
['Do any other things need lasers?', 'Some barcode scanners use a laser beam.']
['What are some uses of lasers?', 'Lasers are used in industry to cut steel and other metals.']
['What are some other uses of lasers?', 'Lasers are bounced off reflectors that astronauts left on the Moon.']

['What can be used to make precise calculations of the Earth-Moon distance?', 'The time it takes for the light to make the round trip can be used to make precise calculations of the Earth-Moon distance.']
['What can you tell me about laser beams?', 'Laser beams are used to produce holograms.']
['What is the name of the image that is three-dimensional?', 'The name hologram means entire picture (from the Greek holo-, as in holistic), because the image is three-dimensional.']
['What is the difference between a two dimensional image and a three dimensional image?', 'A viewer can move around the image and see it from different perspectives.']
['Why is this different than traditional photography?', 'Holograms take advantage of the wave properties of light, as opposed to traditional photography which is based on geometric optics.']
['What is the process of creating a holographic image?', 'A holographic image is produced by constructive and destructive interference of a split laser beam.']
['What are some of the advantages of using a laser as a surgical tool?', 'One of the advantages of using a laser as a surgical tool is that it is accompanied by very little bleeding.']
['What is the most common use of laser eye surgery?', 'Laser eye surgery has improved the vision of many people, without the need for corrective lenses.']
['What is the purpose of a laser beam?', 'A laser beam is used to change the shape of the lens of the eye, thus changing its focal length.']
['What happens if you pass light through a large number of evenly-spaced parallel slits?', 'An interesting thing happens if you pass light through a large number of evenly-spaced parallel slits.']
['What is that arrangement of slits called?', 'Such an arrangement of slits is called a diffraction grating.']
['What happens to light when it is split into two parts?', 'An interference pattern is created that is very similar to the one formed by double-slit diffraction (see Figure 17.8 and Figure 17.9).']
['How was this grating made?', 'A diffraction grating can be manufactured by scratching glass with a sharp tool to form a number of precisely positioned parallel lines, which act like slits.']

['What are other applications of this?', 'Diffraction gratings work both for transmission of light, as in Figure 17.13, and for reflection of light, as on the butterfly wings or the Australian opal shown in Figure 17.14, or the CD pictured in the opening illustration of this chapter.']
['What are they used for?', 'In addition to their use as novelty items, diffraction gratings are commonly used for spectroscopic dispersion and analysis of light.']
['How do you analyze the light?', 'What makes them particularly useful is the fact that they form a sharper pattern than do double slits.']
['What is the sharper pattern?', 'That is, their bright regions are narrower and brighter, while their dark regions are darker.']
['What is the sharper pattern?', 'Figure 17.15 shows idealized graphs demonstrating the sharper pattern.']
['What are some examples of natural diffraction gratings?', 'Natural diffraction gratings occur in the feathers of certain birds.']

['What do these gratings do?', 'Tiny, fingerlike structures in regular patterns act as reflection gratings, producing constructive interference that gives the feathers colors not solely due to their pigmentation.']
['What is the effect of a rainbow on a white object?', 'The effect is called iridescence.']

['What are diffraction gratings?', 'Diffraction gratings are key components of monochromators—devices that separate the various wavelengths of incoming light and allow a beam with only a specific wavelength to pass through.']
['What are monochromators used for?', 'Monochromators are used, for example, in optical imaging of particular wavelengths from biological or medical samples.']

['How do they help analyze a sample?', 'A diffraction grating can be chosen to specifically analyze a wavelength of light emitted by molecules in diseased cells in a biopsy sample, or to help excite strategic molecules in the sample with a selected frequency of light.']
['What are some other uses for monochromators?', 'Another important use is in optical fiber technologies where fibers are designed to provide optimum performance at specific wavelengths.']
['What wavelengths are used in optical fiber technologies?', 'A range of diffraction gratings is available for selecting specific wavelengths for such use.']
['What is one of the applications of wavelengths?', 'Diffraction gratings are used in spectroscopes to separate a light source into its component wavelengths.']
['What is another application of wavelengths?', 'When a material is heated to incandescence, it gives off wavelengths of light characteristic of the chemical makeup of the material.']
['How can the chemical makeup of a material be determined?', 'A pure substance will produce a spectrum that is unique, thus allowing identification of the substance.']
['What is another application of wavelengths?', 'Spectroscopes are also used to measure wavelengths both shorter and longer than visible light.']
['What is noteworthy about wavelengths?', 'Such instruments have become especially useful to astronomers and chemists.']
['What is Figure 17.18?', 'Figure 17.18 shows a diagram of a spectroscope.']
['What is light?', 'Light diffracts as it moves through space, bending around obstacles and interfering constructively and destructively.']
['What does diffraction mean?', 'While diffraction allows light to be used as a spectroscopic tool, it also limits the detail we can obtain in images.']
['What is an example of a wave-based application?', 'Figure 17.19 (a) shows the effect of passing light through a small circular aperture.']
['What was the effect of the light?', 'Instead of a bright spot with sharp edges, a spot with a fuzzy edge surrounded by circles of light is obtained.']
['What is the pattern caused by diffraction similar to that produced by a single slit?', 'This pattern is caused by diffraction similar to that produced by a single slit.']
['What was the result of their experiment?', 'Light from different parts of the circular aperture interferes constructively and destructively.']
['What are the effects of that interference?', 'The effect is most noticeable when the aperture is small, but the effect is there for large apertures, too.']
['What is figure 17.19 (b)?', 'Figure 17.19 (b) shows the diffraction pattern produced by two point light sources that are close to one another.']

['What does it show that there are two light sources rather than one?', 'The pattern is similar to that for a single point source, and it is just barely possible to tell that there are two light sources rather than one.']
['Why would it be hard to tell?', 'If they are closer together, as in Figure 17.19 (c), you cannot distinguish them, thus limiting the detail, or resolution, you can obtain.']
['What does this limit do?', 'That limit is an inescapable consequence of the wave nature of light.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'There are many situations in which diffraction limits the resolution.']
['Why does it limit the resolution?', 'The acuity of vision is limited because light passes through the pupil, the circular aperture of the eye.']

['What are some examples of the limitation of resolution?', 'Be aware that the diffraction-like spreading of light is due to the limited diameter of a light beam, not the interaction with an aperture.']

['What is an example of this?', 'Thus light passing through a lens with a diameter of D shows the diffraction effect and spreads, blurring the image, just as light passing through an aperture of diameter D does.']
['What can diffraction limit?', 'Diffraction limits the resolution of any system having a lens or mirror.']
['What else does diffraction limit?', 'Telescopes are also limited by diffraction, because of the finite diameter, D, of their primary mirror.']
['What is the chapter about?', 'Early in the chapter, it was mentioned that when light passes from one medium to another, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency remains constant.']
['What is the equation for diffraction?', 'The equation']

['what are we studying?', 'shows how to the wavelength in a given medium,  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, is related to the wavelength in a vacuum,  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$, and the refractive index, n, of the medium.']
['What is the equation useful for?', 'The equation is useful for calculating the change in wavelength of a monochromatic laser beam in various media.']
['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'The analysis of a diffraction grating is very similar to that for a double slit.']

['What is the difference between a double slit and a single slit?', 'As you know from the discussion of double slits in Young’s double-slit experiment, light is diffracted by, and spreads out after passing through, each slit.']
['What else do you want to know?', 'Rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the incident direction.']
['What can you tell me about rays?', 'Each ray travels a different distance to a common point on a screen far away.']

['What do the rays start in phase, and they can be in or out of phase when they reach a screen, depending on the difference in the path lengths traveled?', 'The rays start in phase, and they can be in or out of phase when they reach a screen, depending on the difference in the path lengths traveled.']
['Why is that?', 'Each ray travels a distance that differs by  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  from that of its neighbor, where d is the distance between slits.']

['What happens when the rays arrive in phase?', 'If  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  equals an integral number of wavelengths, the rays all arrive in phase, and constructive interference (a maximum) is obtained.']
['What is the condition necessary to obtain constructive interference for a diffraction grating?', 'Thus, the condition necessary to obtain constructive interference for a diffraction grating is']

['What is the formula for the maximum intensity of light?', 'where d is the distance between slits in the grating,  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength of the light, and m is the order of the maximum.']
['What is the equation for the two slits separated by d?', 'Note that this is exactly the same equation as for two slits separated by d.']
['How is this different?', 'However, the slits are usually closer in diffraction gratings than in double slits, producing fewer maxima at larger angles.']

['What is the definition of diffraction?', 'To answer that question, consider the diffraction pattern for a circular aperture, which, similar to the diffraction pattern of light passing through a slit, has a central maximum that is wider and brighter than the maxima surrounding it (see Figure 17.19 (a)).']

['What is the diameter of a circular aperture?', 'It can be shown that, for a circular aperture of diameter D, the first minimum in the diffraction pattern occurs at  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, provided that the aperture is large compared with the wavelength of light, which is the case for most optical instruments.']

['Who developed the diffraction limit to resolution based on diffraction?', 'The accepted criterion for determining the diffraction limit to resolution based on diffraction was developed by Lord Rayleigh in the 19th century.']

['What determines the diffraction limit?', 'The Rayleigh criterion for the diffraction limit to resolution states that two images are just resolvable when the center of the diffraction pattern of one is directly over the first minimum of the diffraction pattern of the other.']
['What is the definition of maximum brightness?', 'See Figure 17.20 (b).']

['What are the angles of the first minimum?', 'The first minimum is at an angle of  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, so that two point objects are just resolvable if they are separated by the angle']

['What does the ta represent?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength of the light (or other electromagnetic radiation) and D is the diameter of the aperture, lens, mirror, etc., with which the two objects are observed.']
['What is the unit of measurement for radians?', 'In the expression above,  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  has units of radians.']
["What does the phrase 'electric charge' mean?", 'You may know someone who has an electric personality, which usually means that other people are attracted to this person.']
['What does it mean to be attracted to someone?', 'This saying is based on electric charge, which is a property of matter that causes objects to attract or repel each other.']
['What are the two types of electric charge?', 'Electric charge comes in two varieties, which we call positive and negative.']
['What are the differences between like and unlike charges?', 'Like charges repel each other, and unlike charges attract each other.']
['Do two positive charges repel each other?', 'Thus, two positive charges repel each other, as do two negative charges.']
['What do a positive charge and a negative charge attract each other?', 'A positive charge and a negative charge attract each other.']

['What does it mean when various materials are rubbed together in controlled ways?', 'When various materials are rubbed together in controlled ways, certain combinations of materials always result in a net charge of one type on one material and a net charge of the opposite type on the other material.']
['What type of charge does it have?', 'By convention, we call one type of charge positive and the other type negative.']
['What are some examples of a positive and negative charge?', 'For example, when glass is rubbed with silk, the glass becomes positively charged and the silk negatively charged.']
['What happens when glass and silk are rubbed together?', 'Because the glass and silk have opposite charges, they attract one another like clothes that have rubbed together in a dryer.']
['Can two glass rods rubbed with silk in this manner repel one another?', 'Two glass rods rubbed with silk in this manner will repel one another, because each rod has positive charge on it.']
['Do two silk cloths rubbed in this manner repel each other?', 'Similarly, two silk cloths rubbed in this manner will repel each other, because both cloths have negative charge.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Figure 18.2 shows how these simple materials can be used to explore the nature of the force between charges.']
['Why did scientists investigate the two types of charges?', 'It took scientists a long time to discover what lay behind these two types of charges.']

['What is the origin of the word electric?', 'The word electric itself comes from the Greek word elektron for amber, because the ancient Greeks noticed that amber, when rubbed by fur, attracts dry straw.']

['What did William Gilbert propose?', 'Almost 2,000 years later, the English physicist William Gilbert proposed a model that explained the effect of electric charge as being due to a mysterious electrical fluid that would pass from one object to another.']

['What happened to his model?', 'This model was debated for several hundred years, but it was finally put to rest in 1897 by the work of the English physicist J. J. Thomson and French physicist Jean Perrin.']

['What did Thomson and Perrin study?', 'Along with many others, Thomson and Perrin were studying the mysterious cathode rays that were known at the time to consist of particles smaller than the smallest atom.']
['What did Perrin show?', 'Perrin showed that cathode rays actually carried negative electrical charge.']

['Why did Thomson believe his work?', 'Later, Thomson’s work led him to declare, “I can see no escape from the conclusion that [cathode rays] are charges of negative electricity carried by particles of matter.”']

['What is the article about?', 'It took several years of further experiments to confirm Thomson’s interpretation of the experiments, but science had in fact discovered the particle that carries the fundamental unit of negative electrical charge.']
['What is that particle called?', 'We now know this particle as the electron.']

['Did they tell us anything else about this topic?', 'Atoms, however, were known to be electrically neutral, which means that they carry the same amount of positive and negative charge, so their net charge is zero.']
['Why do electrons have a negative charge?', 'Because electrons are negative, some other part of the atom must contain positive charge.']

['What did Thomas put forth?', 'Thomson put forth what is called the plum pudding model, in which he described atoms as being made of thousands of electrons swimming around in a nebulous mass of positive charge, as shown by the left-side image of Figure 18.3.']

['What did his student believe about this theory?', 'His student, Ernest Rutherford, originally believed that this model was correct and used it (along with other models) to try to understand the results of his experiments bombarding gold foils with alpha particles (i.e., helium atoms stripped of their electrons).']
['Did the results confirm Thomson’s model?', 'The results, however, did not confirm Thomson’s model but rather destroyed it!']

['What did Rutherford find?', 'Rutherford found that most of the space occupied by the gold atoms was actually empty and that almost all of the matter of each atom was concentrated into a tiny, extremely dense nucleus, as shown by the right-side image of Figure 18.3.']
['What was the atomic nucleus later found to contain?', 'The atomic nucleus was later found to contain particles called protons, each of which carries a unit of positive electric charge.']
['What are the fundamental particles that carry electric charge?', 'Protons and electrons are thus the fundamental particles that carry electric charge.']
['What is the charge of a proton?', 'Each proton carries one unit of positive charge, and each electron carries one unit of negative charge.']

['What is the opposite of the charge carried by a proton?', 'To the best precision that modern technology can provide, the charge carried by a proton is exactly the opposite of that carried by an electron.']

['What is the SI unit for electric charge?', 'The SI unit for electric charge is the coulomb (abbreviated as “C”), which is named after the French physicist Charles Augustin de Coulomb, who studied the force between charged objects.']
['What is the SI unit of electric charge?', 'The proton carries  $$\\(+ 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C.}\\)$$  and the electron carries  $$\\(-1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C,}\\)$$ .']
['What is the formula for +1.00 C?', 'The number n of protons required to make +1.00 C is']
['What is the formula for electric charge?', 'The same number of electrons is required to make −1.00 C of electric charge.']
['What is the unit of charge?', 'The fundamental unit of charge is often represented as e.']
['What is the charge on a proton?', 'Thus, the charge on a proton is e, and the charge on an electron is −e.']
['What is the equation of charge?', 'Mathematically,  $$\\(e = + 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What happens to the total charge of a system?', 'Because the fundamental positive and negative units of charge are carried on protons and electrons, we would expect that the total charge cannot change in any system that we define.']
['What is the relationship between charge and its conservation?', 'In other words, although we might be able to move charge around, we cannot create or destroy it.']
['Is this true?', 'This should be true provided that we do not create or destroy protons or electrons in our system.']

['Do they make it impossible to conserve charge?', 'In the twentieth century, however, scientists learned how to create and destroy electrons and protons, but they found that charge is still conserved.']
['What is the status of this idea?', 'Many experiments and solid theoretical arguments have elevated this idea to the status of a law.']
['What is the law about electrical charge?', 'The law of conservation of charge says that electrical charge cannot be created or destroyed.']
['What is the law of conservation of charge?', 'The law of conservation of charge is very useful.']
['What does the law of conservation of energy tell us?', 'It tells us that the net charge in a system is the same before and after any interaction within the system.']
['What is the most important thing to remember?', 'Of course, we must ensure that no external charge enters the system during the interaction and that no internal charge leaves the system.']
['What is the mathematical expression for conservation of charge?', 'Mathematically, conservation of charge can be expressed as']
['What is the difference between conductors and insulators?', 'Materials can be classified depending on whether they allow charge to move.']
['What is the most important information you can provide?', 'If charge can easily move through a material, such as metals, then these materials are called conductors.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that charge can be conducted (i.e., move) through the material rather easily.']
["What can't charge move through?", 'If charge cannot move through a material, such as rubber, then this material is called an insulator.']
['What are most materials?', 'Most materials are insulators.']
['What makes most materials insulators?', 'Their atoms and molecules hold on more tightly to their electrons, so it is difficult for electrons to move between atoms.']
['Why is it difficult to do this?', 'However, it is not impossible.']
['What is possible to force electrons to do?', 'With enough energy, it is possible to force electrons to move through an insulator.']
['What is the danger of this?', 'However, the insulator is often physically destroyed in the process.']
['How are metals different from other materials?', 'In metals, the outer electrons are loosely bound to their atoms, so not much energy is required to make electrons move through metal.']
['What are some examples of metals that are good conductors?', 'Such metals as copper, silver, and aluminum are good conductors.']
['What are some examples of materials that are used to insulate?', 'Insulating materials include plastics, glass, ceramics, and wood.']
['What does this mean?', 'The conductivity of some materials is intermediate between conductors and insulators.']
['What are the materials that are used to make semiconductors?', 'These are called semiconductors.']

['How can they be made conductive?', 'They can be made conductive under the right conditions, which can involve temperature, the purity of the material, and the force applied to push electrons through them.']
['What can you do with semiconductors?', 'Because we can control whether semiconductors are conductors or insulators, these materials are used extensively in computer chips.']
['What is the most commonly used semiconductor?', 'The most commonly used semiconductor is silicon.']
['What is in the next section?', 'Figure 18.8 shows various materials arranged according to their ability to conduct electrons.']
['What happens if charges are like?', 'Because like charges repel each other, they will push against each other until they are as far apart as they can get.']
['Does a conductor allow the charge to move?', 'Because the charge can move in a conductor, it moves to the outer surfaces of the object.']
['What happens to the charge on the sphere?', 'Figure 18.9(a) shows schematically how an excess negative charge spreads itself evenly over the outer surface of a metal sphere.']
['When electrons move through a material, what happens to the electrons?', 'The electrons still repel each other, but they are not able to move, because the material is an insulator.']
['What happens to the excess charge when it is not distributed over the object?', 'Thus, the excess charge stays put and does not distribute itself over the object.']
['What is the best way to show this?', 'Figure 18.9(b) shows this situation.']
['What is considered neutral?', 'Most objects we deal with are electrically neutral, which means that they have the same amount of positive and negative charge.']
['What is a neutral object considered?', 'However, transferring negative charge from one object to another is fairly easy to do.']
['What happens when negative charge is transferred from one object to another?', 'When negative charge is transferred from one object to another, an excess of positive charge is left behind.']
['What is the positive charge carried by?', 'The positive charge is carried by the proton, which is stuck firmly in the nucleus of atoms, and the atoms are stuck in place in solid materials.']
['What makes electrons easier to transfer?', 'Electrons, which carry the negative charge, are much easier to remove from their atoms or molecules and can therefore be transferred more easily.']
['What is it that causes electric charge to transfer?', 'Electric charge can be transferred in several manners.']
['What is the contact method?', 'One of the simplest ways to transfer charge is charging by contact, in which the surfaces of two objects made of different materials are placed in close contact.']

['When two materials are separated, what happens to the electrons?', 'If one of the materials holds electrons more tightly than the other, then it takes some electrons with it when the materials are separated.']
['What can happen if the materials are rubbed together?', 'Rubbing two surfaces together increases the transfer of electrons, because it creates a closer contact between the materials.']
['What does the rubbing do?', 'It also serves to present fresh material with a full supply of electrons to the other material.']
['How does this apply to the human body?', 'Thus, when you walk across a carpet on a dry day, your shoes rub against the carpet, and some electrons are removed from the carpet by your shoes.']
['What happens to the shoes when this occurs?', 'The result is that you have an excess of negative charge on your shoes.']
['How does the excess of charge transfer?', 'When you then touch a doorknob, some of your excess of electrons transfer to the neutral doorknob, creating a small spark.']
['What is the second way to transfer electric charge?', 'Touching the doorknob with your hand demonstrates a second way to transfer electric charge, which is charging by conduction.']
['How does it work?', 'This transfer happens because like charges repel, and so the excess electrons that you picked up from the carpet want to be as far away from each other as possible.']
['What do they do after they get there?', 'Some of them move to the doorknob, where they will distribute themselves over the outer surface of the metal.']
['What other types of transfer are discussed?', 'Another example of charging by conduction is shown in the top row of Figure 18.10.']

['What is the top row of figure 18.10?', 'A metal sphere with 100 excess electrons touches a metal sphere with 50 excess electrons, so 25 electrons from the first sphere transfer to the second sphere.']
['What does this do?', 'Each sphere finishes with 75 excess electrons.']
['What other questions do we have?', 'The same reasoning applies to the transfer of positive charge.']

['What are the differences between positive and negative charge?', 'However, because positive charge essentially cannot move in solids, it is transferred by moving negative charge in the opposite direction.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, consider the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']
['Why is that the case?', 'The first metal sphere has 100 excess protons and touches a metal sphere with 50 excess protons, so the second sphere transfers 25 electrons to the first sphere.']
['What happens as a result of that?', 'These 25 extra electrons will electrically cancel 25 protons so that the first metal sphere is left with 75 excess protons.']
['What is the final result of that?', 'This is shown in the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']
['What else does this illustrate?', 'The second metal sphere lost 25 electrons so it has 25 more excess protons, for a total of 75 excess protons.']
['What is the end result of the experiment?', 'The end result is the same if we consider that the first ball transferred a net positive charge equal to that of 25 protons to the first ball.']

['What is the main idea of Transfer and Separation of Charge?', 'In this discussion, you may wonder how the excess electrons originally got from your shoes to your hand to create the spark when you touched the doorknob.']
['What happens when you touch your shoes to your hands?', 'The answer is that no electrons actually traveled from your shoes to your hands.']

['What happened after the electrons traveled to your hands?', 'Instead, because like charges repel each other, the excess electrons on your shoe simply pushed away some of the electrons in your feet.']
['What happens when you walk on a wet floor?', 'The electrons thus dislodged from your feet moved up into your leg and in turn pushed away some electrons in your leg.']
['What happens after this?', 'This process continued through your whole body until a distribution of excess electrons covered the extremities of your body.']

['What is the end result of this discussion?', 'Thus your head, your hands, the tip of your nose, and so forth all received their doses of excess electrons that had been pushed out of their normal positions.']

['What was the result of electrons being pushed out of your feet by the excess electrons on your shoes?', 'All this was the result of electrons being pushed out of your feet by the excess electrons on your shoes.']
['What is this type of charge separation called?', 'This type of charge separation is called polarization.']

['Can this revert?', 'As soon as the excess electrons leave your shoes (by rubbing off onto the floor or being carried away in humid air), the distribution of electrons in your body returns to normal.']
['What is this reverting?', 'Every part of your body is again electrically neutral (i.e., zero excess charge).']
['What is the phenomenon of polarization?', 'The phenomenon of polarization is seen in Figure 18.1.']
['Why is the child polarized?', 'The child has accumulated excess positive charge by sliding on the slide.']
['What is it a result of?', 'This excess charge repels itself and so becomes distributed over the extremities of the child’s body, notably in his hair.']
['What happens to the hair when it is tangled?', 'As a result, the hair stands on end, because the excess negative charge on each strand repels the excess positive charge on neighboring strands.']
['What can polarization be used for?', 'Polarization can be used to charge objects.']
['What is a good example of polarization?', 'Consider the two metallic spheres shown in Figure 18.11.']
['What is the relation between the two metal spheres?', 'The spheres are electrically neutral, so they carry the same amounts of positive and negative charge.']

['What do you find interesting about this discussion?', 'In the top picture (Figure 18.11(a)), the two spheres are touching, and the positive and negative charge is evenly distributed over the two spheres.']

['What is a way to separate the positive and negative charge?', 'We then approach a glass rod that carries an excess positive charge, which can be done by rubbing the glass rod with silk, as shown in Figure 18.11(b).']

['How does the negative charge leave the sphere?', 'Because opposite charges attract each other, the negative charge is attracted to the glass rod, leaving an excess positive charge on the opposite side of the right sphere.']

['What is an example of charging by induction, whereby a charge is created by approaching a charged object with a second object to create an unbalanced charge in the second object?', 'This is an example of charging by induction, whereby a charge is created by approaching a charged object with a second object to create an unbalanced charge in the second object.']
['What happens to the excess charge?', 'If we then separate the two spheres, as shown in Figure 18.11(c), the excess charge is stuck on each sphere.']
['What happens to the two spheres?', 'The left sphere now has an excess negative charge, and the right sphere has an excess positive charge.']
['How does the opposite charge move?', 'Finally, in the bottom picture, the rod is removed, and the opposite charges attract each other, so they move as close together as they can get.']

['What happened in the 17th century?', 'More than 100 years before Thomson and Rutherford discovered the fundamental particles that carry positive and negative electric charges, the French scientist Charles-Augustin de Coulomb mathematically described the force between charged objects.']
['What did de Coulomb do?', 'Doing so required careful measurements of forces between charged spheres, for which he built an ingenious device called a torsion balance.']
['What is a waveguide?', 'This device, shown in Figure 18.15, contains an insulating rod that is hanging by a thread inside a glass-walled enclosure.']
['What is inside the enclosure?', 'At one end of the rod is the metallic sphere A.']

["What was Coulomb's third ball?", 'When no charge is on this sphere, it touches sphere B. Coulomb would touch the spheres with a third metallic ball (shown at the bottom of the diagram) that was charged.']

['What would happen if the spheres were placed together?', 'An unknown amount of charge would distribute evenly between spheres A and B, which would then repel each other, because like charges repel.']
['What would the rod do then?', 'This force would cause sphere A to rotate away from sphere B, thus twisting the wire until the torsion in the wire balanced the electrical force.']
['What did Coulomb do after this?', 'Coulomb then turned the knob at the top, which allowed him to rotate the thread, thus bringing sphere A closer to sphere B.']
['What did he find?', 'He found that bringing sphere A twice as close to sphere B required increasing the torsion by a factor of four.']
['What was this test used for?', 'Bringing the sphere three times closer required a ninefold increase in the torsion.']
['How did he use this data?', 'From this type of measurement, he deduced that the electrical force between the spheres was inversely proportional to the distance squared between the spheres.']
['How did he describe this force?', 'In other words,']
['How is the charge distributed between the spheres?', 'An electrical charge distributes itself equally between two conducting spheres of the same size.']
['What did Coulomb find out?', 'Knowing this allowed Coulomb to divide an unknown charge in half.']
['How does he do this?', 'Repeating this process would produce a sphere with one quarter of the initial charge, and so on.']
['How did he test this?', 'Using this technique, he measured the force between spheres A and B when they were charged with different amounts of charge.']
['How was this done?', 'These measurements led him to deduce that the force was proportional to the charge on each sphere, or']

['What is the equation used to describe the electrostatic force between charged objects?', 'This equation is known as Coulomb’s law, and it describes the electrostatic force between charged objects.']
['What is the constant of proportionality?', 'The constant of proportionality k is called Coulomb’s constant.']
['What is the value of k?', 'In SI units, the constant k has the value  $$\\(k = 8.99\\  \\times \\ 10^{9}\\text{N} \\cdot \\text{m}^{\\text{2}}\\text{/C}^{\\text{2.}}\\)$$']
['What is the direction of force?', 'The direction of the force is along the line joining the centers of the two objects.']
["How does Coulomb's law work?", 'If the two charges are of opposite signs, Coulomb’s law gives a negative result.']
['How does this help us understand the force between particles?', 'This means that the force between the particles is attractive.']
['How does this help us understand the force between molecules?', 'If the two charges have the same signs, Coulomb’s law gives a positive result.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that the force between the particles is repulsive.']
['What are the opposite signs of positive?', 'For example, if both  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are negative or if both are positive, the force between them is repulsive.']
['What does this mean for the force between molecules?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(a).']

['What are the opposite signs of negative?', 'If  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is a negative charge and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is a positive charge (or vice versa), then the charges are different, so the force between them is attractive.']
['What does this mean for the force between molecules?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(b).']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'Note that Coulomb’s law applies only to charged objects that are not moving with respect to each other.']
['What is this law about?', 'The law says that the force is proportional to the amount of charge on each object and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the objects.']
['What else did you learn?', 'If we double the charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$, for instance, then the force is doubled.']
['How does the force change as distance increases?', 'If we double the distance between the objects, then the force between them decreases by a factor of  $$\\(2^{2} = 4\\)$$ .']

['How does this law apply to anything else?', 'Although Coulomb’s law is true in general, it is easiest to apply to spherical objects or to objects that are much smaller than the distance between the objects (in which case, the objects can be approximated as spheres).']
['What is an example of an inverse-square law?', 'Coulomb’s law is an example of an inverse-square law, which means the force depends on the square of the denominator.']
['What other inverse-square laws are there?', 'Another inverse-square law is Newton’s law of universal gravitation, which is  $$\\(F = {{Gm_{1}m_{2}}/r^{2}}\\)$$ .']

['What difference between these two laws?', 'Although these laws are similar, they differ in two important respects: (i) The gravitational constant G is much, much smaller than k ( $$\\(G = 6.67\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 11}\\text{m}^{3}\\text{/kg} \\cdot \\text{s}^{2}\\)$$ ); and (ii) only one type of mass exists, whereas two types of electric charge exist.']

['What are the two different properties of mass?', 'These two differences explain why gravity is so much weaker than the electrostatic force and why gravity is only attractive, whereas the electrostatic force can be attractive or repulsive.']
['What is the most important part of this study material for you?', 'Finally, note that Coulomb measured the distance between the spheres from the centers of each sphere.']
['How did he determine the radius of one sphere?', 'He did not explain this assumption in his original papers, but it turns out to be valid.']
['What is this assumption about?', 'From outside a uniform spherical distribution of charge, it can be treated as if all the charge were located at the center of the sphere.']

['What can you tell me about the force field?', 'You may have heard of a force field in science fiction movies, where such fields apply forces at particular positions in space to keep a villain trapped or to protect a spaceship from enemy fire.']
['What are other applications of force fields?', 'The concept of a field is very useful in physics, although it differs somewhat from what you see in movies.']

['What is a way of conceptualizing and mapping the force that surrounds any object and acts on another object at a distance without apparent physical connection?', 'A field is a way of conceptualizing and mapping the force that surrounds any object and acts on another object at a distance without apparent physical connection.']

['What is a field of energy?', 'For example, the gravitational field surrounding Earth and all other masses represents the gravitational force that would be experienced if another mass were placed at a given point within the field.']
['Who proposed the concept of an electric field?', 'Michael Faraday, an English physicist of the nineteenth century, proposed the concept of an electric field.']

['What is an electric field used for?', 'If you know the electric field, then you can easily calculate the force (magnitude and direction) applied to any electric charge that you place in the field.']
['What is an electric field generated by?', 'An electric field is generated by electric charge and tells us the force per unit charge at all locations in space around a charge distribution.']

['What does it tell us about the charge distribution?', 'The charge distribution could be a single point charge; a distribution of charge over, say, a flat plate; or a more complex distribution of charge.']
['What is an electric field?', 'The electric field extends into space around the charge distribution.']
['What is an electric field?', 'Now consider placing a test charge in the field.']

['What is a positive electric charge whose charge is so small that it does not significantly disturb the charges that create the electric field?', 'A test charge is a positive electric charge whose charge is so small that it does not significantly disturb the charges that create the electric field.']
['What is the test charge?', 'The electric field exerts a force on the test charge in a given direction.']
['What is the force exerted?', 'The force exerted is proportional to the charge of the test charge.']
['What is the force proportional to?', 'For example, if we double the charge of the test charge, the force exerted on it doubles.']
['What does it tell you?', 'Mathematically, saying that electric field is the force per unit charge is written as']
['What is the relationship between E and F?', 'where we are considering only electric forces.']

['How is the force on the positive test charge related to the electric field?', 'Note that the electric field is a vector field that points in the same direction as the force on the positive test charge.']
['What are the units of electric field?', 'The units of electric field are N/C.']
['What does the F represent?', 'where the absolute value is used, because we only consider the magnitude of the force.']
['What is the magnitude of the electric field?', 'The magnitude of the electric field is then']
['What does this equation represent?', 'This equation gives the magnitude of the electric field created by a point charge Q.']
['What is the distance from a point charge?', 'The distance r in the denominator is the distance from the point charge, Q, or from the center of a spherical charge, to the point of interest.']
['What is the reactivity of a field?', 'If the test charge is removed from the electric field, the electric field still exists.']
['How can you create a three-dimensional map of the electric field?', 'To create a three-dimensional map of the electric field, imagine placing the test charge in various locations in the field.']

['How do you calculate the electric field?', 'At each location, measure the force on the charge, and use the vector equation  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{E} = {\\overset{\\rightarrow}{F}/q_{\\text{test}}}\\)$$  to calculate the electric field.']
['What happens to the vector when you place the test charge?', 'Draw an arrow at each point where you place the test charge to represent the strength and the direction of the electric field.']
['What is the length of the arrows?', 'The length of the arrows should be proportional to the strength of the electric field.']
['What happens if you join the arrows?', 'If you join together these arrows, you obtain lines.']

['What is the figure that shows an image of the three-dimensional electric field created by a positive charge?', 'Figure 18.17 shows an image of the three-dimensional electric field created by a positive charge.']
['What is this chapter about?', 'Just drawing the electric field lines in a plane that slices through the charge gives the two-dimensional electric-field maps shown in Figure 18.18.']
['Are there two directions for the electric field?', 'On the left is the electric field created by a positive charge, and on the right is the electric field created by a negative charge.']
['What is the problem with the electric field lines?', 'Notice that the electric field lines point away from the positive charge and toward the negative charge.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus, a positive test charge placed in the electric field of the positive charge will be repelled.']
['Why is that?', 'This is consistent with Coulomb’s law, which says that like charges repel each other.']
['What is the next thing you will need to do?', 'If we place the positive charge in the electric field of the negative charge, the positive charge is attracted to the negative charge.']
['What is the opposite of positive test charges?', 'The opposite is true for negative test charges.']
['What happens to the electric field lines?', 'Thus, the direction of the electric field lines is consistent with what we find by using Coulomb’s law.']
['What does the equation $(E = k|Q|/r2) tell us?', 'The equation  $$\\(E = {{k|Q|}/r^{2}}\\)$$  says that the electric field gets stronger as we approach the charge that generates it.']
['What does this mean?', 'For example, at 2 cm from the charge Q (r = 2 cm), the electric field is four times stronger than at 4 cm from the charge (r = 4 cm).']
['What do we see in Figure 18.17 and Figure 18.18?', 'Looking at Figure 18.17 and Figure 18.18 again, we see that the electric field lines become denser as we approach the charge that generates it.']
['What does this mean?', 'In fact, the density of the electric field lines is proportional to the strength of the electric field!']
['What are some of the interesting things you learned from studying it?', 'Electric-field maps can be made for several charges or for more complicated charge distributions.']
['What else did you learn?', 'The electric field due to multiple charges may be found by adding together the electric field from each individual charge.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about this information?', 'Because this sum can only be a single number, we know that only a single electric-field line can go through any given point.']
['How do you explain this?', 'In other words, electric-field lines cannot cross each other.']
['What is the most important information in the figure?', 'Figure 18.19(a) shows a two-dimensional map of the electric field generated by a charge of +q and a nearby charge of −q.']
['How is this important?', 'The three-dimensional version of this map is obtained by rotating this map about the axis that goes through both charges.']
['What is another important information?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would experience a force in the direction of the field lines at its location.']
['What would happen if a metal was placed in a negative charge?', 'It would thus be repelled from the positive charge and attracted to the negative charge.']
['What is the electric field generated by two charges of q?', 'Figure 18.19(b) shows the electric field generated by two charges of −q.']
['How is this different from the other two figures?', 'Note how the field lines tend to repel each other and do not overlap.']
['What is interesting about the figure?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would be attracted to both charges.']

['What else is significant about the figure?', 'If you are far from these two charges, where far means much farther than the distance between the charges, the electric field looks like the electric field from a single charge of −2q.']

['What is the basic structure of energy in space?', 'As you learned in studying gravity, a mass in a gravitational field has potential energy, which means it has the potential to accelerate and thereby increase its kinetic energy.']
['What happens to objects with kinetic energy?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What is an example of using kinetic energy to do work?', 'For example, imagine you want to use a stone to pound a nail into a piece of wood.']

['What happens to the potential energy of the stone when it is lifted high above the nail?', 'You first lift the stone high above the nail, which increases the potential energy of the stone-Earth system—because Earth is so large, it does not move, so we usually shorten this by saying simply that the potential energy of the stone increases.']
['How does gravity interact with potential energy?', 'When you drop the stone, gravity converts the potential energy into kinetic energy.']
['What happens when the kinetic energy is used to do work?', 'When the stone hits the nail, it does work by pounding the nail into the wood.']

['What is the work that a mass can potentially do by virtue of its position in a gravitational field?', 'The gravitational potential energy is the work that a mass can potentially do by virtue of its position in a gravitational field.']

['What can you tell me about potential energy?', 'Potential energy is a very useful concept, because it can be used with conservation of energy to calculate the motion of masses in a gravitational field.']

['What is the difference between electric potential energy and gravitational potential energy?', 'Electric potential energy works much the same way, but it is based on the electric field instead of the gravitational field.']
['What is an electric field?', 'By virtue of its position in an electric field, a charge has an electric potential energy.']

['How does it convert to kinetic energy?', 'If the charge is free to move, the force due to the electric field causes it to accelerate, so its potential energy is converted to kinetic energy, just like a mass that falls in a gravitational field.']
['Can this energy be used to do work?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']

['What is the energy that a charge can do by virtue of its position in an electric field?', 'The electric potential energy is the work that a charge can do by virtue of its position in an electric field.']
['What are some key terms in Section Key Terms?', 'The analogy between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy is depicted in Figure 18.21.']
['What is depicted in figure 18.21?', "On the left, the ball-Earth system gains gravitational potential energy when the ball is higher in Earth's gravitational field."]
['How do those two systems compare?', 'On the right, the two-charge system gains electric potential energy when the positive charge is farther from the negative charge.']
['What are the key terms in the passage?', 'Let’s use the symbol  $$\\(U_{G}\\)$$  to denote gravitational potential energy.']
['How does this change?', 'When a mass falls in a gravitational field, its gravitational potential energy decreases.']

['What does conservation of energy tell us?', 'Conservation of energy tells us that the work done by the gravitational field to make the mass accelerate must equal the loss of potential energy of the mass.']
['What is work done by gravitational field?', 'If we use the symbol  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{gravity}}\\)$$  to denote this work, then']

['What is the formula for this problem?', 'where F is the force due to gravity, and  $$\\(y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  and  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  are the initial and final positions of the ball, respectively.']
['What is the negative sign for?', 'The negative sign is because gravity points down, which we consider to be the negative direction.']
['What does F = mg mean?', 'For the constant gravitational field near Earth’s surface,  $$\\(F = mg\\)$$ .']
['What does the formula for energy mean?', 'The change in gravitational potential energy of the mass is']

['What do you mean by F left(F - y_text)?', 'Note that  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}} - y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  is just the negative of the height h from which the mass falls, so we usually just write  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{']
['What does F mean?', 'G}} = - mgh\\)$$ .']
['What is the final question?', 'We now apply the same reasoning to a charge in an electric field to find the electric potential energy.']

['What is the change in electric potential energy?', 'The change  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}}\\)$$  in electric potential energy is the work done by the electric field to move a charge q from an initial position  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to a final position  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  ( $$\\(- \\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}}\\)$$ ).']

['What is the work done by the field?', 'The definition of work does not change, except that now the work is done by the electric field:  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}} = F(x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}})\\)$$ .']

['What is the force applied to the charge by the electric field?', 'For a charge that falls through a constant electric field E, the force applied to the charge by the electric field is  $$\\(F = qE\\)$$ .']
['What is the change in electric potential energy of the charge?', 'The change in electric potential energy of the charge is thus']
['What is this analogy compared to?', 'Figure 18.22 shows how this analogy would work if we were close to Earth’s surface, where gravity is constant.']
['What is in the top image?', 'The top image shows a charge accelerating due to a constant electric field.']
['What else can you tell me about the bottom image?', 'Likewise, the round mass in the bottom image accelerates due to a constant gravitation field.']
['What happens to the particle after it accelerates?', 'In both cases, the potential energy of the particle decreases, and its kinetic energy increases.']

['What is important to know about this equation?', 'If the electric field is not constant, then the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$  is not valid, and deriving the electric potential energy becomes more involved.']

['What is an example of how this equation can be involved?', 'For example, consider the electric potential energy of an assembly of two point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  of the same sign that are initially very far apart.']
['What are the initial positions of the two charges?', 'We start by placing charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  at the origin of our coordinate system.']
['How does this charge move?', 'This takes no electrical energy, because there is no electric field at the origin (because charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is very far away).']
['What happens next?', 'We then bring charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  in from very far away to a distance r from the center of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$ .']
['What is the energy of the electric field of charge?', 'This requires some effort, because the electric field of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  applies a repulsive force on charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$ .']
['What happens to the energy?', 'The energy it takes to assemble these two charges can be recuperated if we let them fly apart again.']
['How can this be done?', 'Thus, the charges have potential energy when they are a distance r apart.']

['What is the electric potential energy of a pair of point charges $$(q_1)$$ and $$(q_2)$$ a distance r apart?', 'It turns out that the electric potential energy of a pair of point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  a distance r apart is']

['What is the main idea of this section?', 'To recap, if charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are free to move, they can accumulate kinetic energy by flying apart, and this kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What else are you learning about in this section?', 'The maximum amount of work the two charges can do (if they fly infinitely far from each other) is given by the equation above.']
['What is the potential energy of a charged pair of atoms?', 'Notice that if the two charges have opposite signs, then the potential energy is negative.']
['What does the negative potential energy mean?', 'This means that the charges have more potential to do work when they are far apart than when they are at a distance r apart.']
['Why is that?', 'This makes sense: Opposite charges attract, so the charges can gain more kinetic energy if they attract each other from far away than if they start at only a short distance apart.']
['What else is a fact about this situation?', 'Thus, they have more potential to do work when they are far apart.']
['Are there any other interesting things about this situation?', 'Figure 18.23 summarizes how the electric potential energy depends on charge and separation.']

['What is it about?', 'Recall that to find the force applied by a fixed charge Q on any arbitrary test charge q, it was convenient to define the electric field, which is the force per unit charge applied by Q on any test charge that we place in its electric field.']
['What else is it about?', 'The same Strategy is used here with electric potential energy:']
['What did we study?', 'We now define the electric potential V, which is the electric potential energy per unit charge.']
['What is the electric potential called?', 'Normally, the electric potential is simply called the potential or voltage.']
['What are the units for the potential?', 'The units for the potential are J/C, which are given the name volt (V) after the Italian physicist Alessandro Volta (1745–1827).']

['How is the electric potential a distance r from a point charge $$(q_1)$$ measured?', 'From the equation  $$\\(U_{\\text{E}} = {{kq_{1}q_{2}}/r}\\)$$, the electric potential a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is']

['What is the equation for the energy required per unit charge to bring a charge from infinity to a distance r from a point charge?', 'This equation gives the energy required per unit charge to bring a charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  from infinity to a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['How is this represented in the passage?', 'Mathematically, this is written as']
