['What are the relevant details?', '\\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = r} - \\left. \\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = \\infty}\\text{.}\\]$$']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py?', 'Note that this equation actually represents a difference in electric potential.']

['What is the electric potential difference?', 'However, because the second term is zero, it is normally not written, and we speak of the electric potential instead of the electric potential difference, or we just say the potential difference, or voltage).']

['What is the electric potential energy per unit charge between two points not infinitely far apart?', 'Below, when we consider the electric potential energy per unit charge between two points not infinitely far apart, we speak of electric potential difference explicitly.']

['What are the other variables that could influence potential difference?', 'Just remember that electric potential and electric potential difference are really the same thing; the former is used just when the electric potential energy is zero in either the initial or final charge configuration.']
['What is the text about?', 'Now consider the electric potential near a group of charges q1, q2, and q3, as drawn in Figure 18.24.']
['How is the electric potential derived?', 'The electric potential is derived by considering the electric field.']

['Why does the electric potential add together?', 'Electric fields follow the principle of superposition and can be simply added together, so the electric potential from different charges also add together.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Thus, the electric potential of a point near a group of charges is']
['What is the function that the field vector ta,tt and tr are?', 'Now let’s consider the electric potential in a uniform electric field.']

['How is the potential determined?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$, we see that the potential difference in going from  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  in a uniform electric field E is']

['What are some examples of a positive charge in a region with high potential?', 'Notice that a positive charge in a region with high potential will experience a force pushing it toward regions of lower potential.']
['What is potential?', 'In this sense, potential is like pressure for fluids.']
['How so?', 'Imagine a pipe containing fluid, with the fluid at one end of the pipe under high pressure and the fluid at the other end of the pipe under low pressure.']
['What happens to the fluid?', 'If nothing prevents the fluid from flowing, it will flow from the high-pressure end to the low-pressure end.']
['What happens to a positive charge that is free to move?', 'Likewise, a positive charge that is free to move will move from a region with high potential to a region with lower potential.']
['What are the current values of these two capacitors?', 'Consider again the X-ray tube discussed in the previous sample problem.']
['What is an example of what is happening in the current?', 'A single positive charge produces an electric field that points away from it, as in Figure 18.17.']
['What is the field like?', 'This field is not uniform, because the space between the lines increases as you move away from the charge.']
['What happens when you combine two charges?', 'However, if we combine a positive and a negative charge, we obtain the electric field shown in Figure 18.19(a).']
['Are the electric field lines equally spaced?', 'Notice that, between the charges, the electric field lines are more equally spaced.']
['What is the current through the capacitor?', 'Now the region between the lines of charge contains a fairly uniform electric field.']

["I'm just waiting for you to explain your understanding of the polarization.", 'We can extend this idea even further and into two dimensions by placing two metallic plates face to face and charging one with positive charge and the other with an equal magnitude of negative charge.']
['How can we do this?', 'This can be done by connecting one plate to the positive terminal of a battery and the other plate to the negative terminal, as shown in Figure 18.28.']
['What can we infer from this?', 'The electric field between these charged plates will be extremely uniform.']
['What is the difference between plates and plates?', 'Let’s think about the work required to charge these plates.']
['What are some advantages of using a capacitor?', 'Before the plates are connected to the battery, they are neutral—that is, they have zero net charge.']

['How does the capacitor charge?', 'Placing the first positive charge on the left plate and the first negative charge on the right plate requires very little work, because the plates are neutral, so no opposing charges are present.']
['When the capacitor is charged, what happens to the plates?', 'Now consider placing a second positive charge on the left plate and a second negative charge on the right plate.']
['What are some factors in charge transfer?', 'Because the first two charges repel the new arrivals, a force must be applied to the two new charges over a distance to put them on the plates.']
['What is the definition of work?', 'This is the definition of work, which means that, compared with the first pair, more work is required to put the second pair of charges on the plates.']
['What other facts about work are important?', 'To place the third positive and negative charges on the plates requires yet more work, and so on.']
['What else should we know about work?', 'The battery!']
["What is the battery's job in this scenario?", 'Its chemical potential energy is converted into the work required to separate the positive and negative charges.']
['What is the difference between a battery and capacitor?', 'Although the battery does work, this work remains within the battery-plate system.']

['What is the relation between energy and conservation of energy?', 'Therefore, conservation of energy tells us that, if the potential energy of the battery decreases to separate charges, the energy of another part of the system must increase by the same amount.']
['What happens when the energy is stored in the battery?', 'In fact, the energy from the battery is stored in the electric field between the plates.']
['What is the analogy to a raise hammer?', 'This idea is analogous to considering that the potential energy of a raised hammer is stored in Earth’s gravitational field.']
['What happens if the gravitational field disappears?', 'If the gravitational field were to disappear, the hammer would have no potential energy.']
['What happens if the electric field disappears?', 'Likewise, if no electric field existed between the plates, no energy would be stored between them.']
['What will I need to know to make a battery?', 'If we now disconnect the plates from the battery, they will hold the energy.']
['How will they store the energy?', 'We could connect the plates to a lightbulb, for example, and the lightbulb would light up until this energy was used up.']
['What are the plates used for?', 'These plates thus have the capacity to store energy.']
['What can happen as a result?', 'For this reason, an arrangement such as this is called a capacitor.']

['What is an arrangement of objects that, by virtue of their geometry, can store energy an electric field?', 'A capacitor is an arrangement of objects that, by virtue of their geometry, can store energy an electric field.']
['Are there any diagrams in the document that help you learn?', 'Various real capacitors are shown in Figure 18.29.']
['What is the common design of a capacitor?', 'They are usually made from conducting plates or sheets that are separated by an insulating material.']
['What other designs are there?', 'They can be flat or rolled up or have other geometries.']

['What is the relationship between C and Q and V?', 'where Q is the magnitude of the charge on each capacitor plate, and V is the potential difference in going from the negative plate to the positive plate.']
['How can you figure this out?', 'This means that both Q and V are always positive, so the capacitance is always positive.']

['What is the unit of capacitance?', 'We can see from the equation for capacitance that the units of capacitance are C/V, which are called farads (F) after the nineteenth-century English physicist Michael Faraday.']

['What can you tell me about the content?', 'The equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes sense: A parallel-plate capacitor (like the one shown in Figure 18.28) the size of a football field could hold a lot of charge without requiring too much work per unit charge to push the charge into the capacitor.']
['How is this calculated?', 'Thus, Q would be large, and V would be small, so the capacitance C would be very large.']

['What about smaller capacitors?', 'Squeezing the same charge into a capacitor the size of a fingernail would require much more work, so V would be very large, and the capacitance would be much smaller.']
['What is one important fact about this material?', 'Although the equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes it seem that capacitance depends on voltage, in fact it does not.']

['What is the fact that capacitance depends on voltage?', 'For a given capacitor, the ratio of the charge stored in the capacitor to the voltage difference between the plates of the capacitor always remains the same.']
['What determines the capacitance of a capacitor?', 'Capacitance is determined by the geometry of the capacitor and the materials that it is made from.']

['Why does it say this?', 'Before working through some sample problems, let’s look at what happens if we put an insulating material between the plates of a capacitor that has been charged and then disconnected from the charging battery, as illustrated in Figure 18.30.']

['What happens after we remove the insulating material?', 'Because the material is insulating, the charge cannot move through it from one plate to the other, so the charge Q on the capacitor does not change.']

['What happens when we put the insulating material in?', 'An electric field exists between the plates of a charged capacitor, so the insulating material becomes polarized, as shown in the lower part of the figure.']
['What is this referred to as?', 'An electrically insulating material that becomes polarized in an electric field is called a dielectric.']

['What is the negative charge in the molecules in the material?', 'Figure 18.30 shows that the negative charge in the molecules in the material shifts to the left, toward the positive charge of the capacitor.']
['What causes the electrons to shift?', 'This shift is due to the electric field, which applies a force to the left on the electrons in the molecules of the dielectric.']
['What happens to the right sides of the molecules?', 'The right sides of the molecules are now missing a bit of negative charge, so their net charge is positive.']
['What are dielectrics?', 'All electrically insulating materials are dielectrics, but some are better dielectrics than others.']
['What are they better at than a dielectric?', 'A good dielectric is one whose molecules allow their electrons to shift strongly in an electric field.']

['What does an electric field do?', 'In other words, an electric field pulls their electrons a fair bit away from their atom, but they do not escape completely from their atom (which is why they are insulators).']
['What does figure 18.31 show?', 'Figure 18.31 shows a macroscopic view of a dielectric in a charged capacitor.']

['How does the view of a dielectric effect the electric field?', 'Notice that the electric-field lines in the capacitor with the dielectric are spaced farther apart than the electric-field lines in the capacitor with no dielectric.']

['How does this affect the field?', 'This means that the electric field in the dielectric is weaker, so it stores less electrical potential energy than the electric field in the capacitor with no dielectric.']
['What is special about dielectrics?', 'In fact, the molecules in the dielectric act like tiny springs, and the energy in the electric field goes into stretching these springs.']

['What else does the energy do?', 'With the electric field thus weakened, the voltage difference between the two sides of the capacitor is smaller, so it becomes easier to put more charge on the capacitor.']
['Why is that important?', 'Placing a dielectric in a capacitor before charging it therefore allows more charge and potential energy to be stored in the capacitor.']

['What does the dielectric constant have to do with capacitors?', 'Because  $$\\(\\kappa\\)$$  is greater than 1 for dielectrics, the capacitance increases when a dielectric is placed between the capacitor plates.']
['What is the dielectric constant of a material?', 'The dielectric constant of several materials is shown in Table 18.1.']

['What do they mean by alternating current?', 'Just as water flows from high to low elevation, electrons that are free to move will travel from a place with low potential to a place with high potential.']
['What is the difference between a battery and an electrical current?', 'A battery has two terminals that are at different potentials.']
['How does the current flow?', 'If the terminals are connected by a conducting wire, an electric current (charges) will flow, as shown in Figure 19.2.']

['When electrons move from the low-potential terminal of the battery (the negative end) through the wire and enter the high-potential terminal of the battery (the positive end), what is the current like?', 'Electrons will then move from the low-potential terminal of the battery (the negative end) through the wire and enter the high-potential terminal of the battery (the positive end).']
['What is the rate at which electric charge moves?', 'Electric current is the rate at which electric charge moves.']

['Do currents matter?', 'A large current, such as that used to start a truck engine, moves a large amount very quickly, whereas a small current, such as that used to operate a hand-held calculator, moves a small amount of charge more slowly.']

['Do we use that same approach for electric current?', 'As shown in Figure 19.3, electric current is very similar.']
['How do we count those charges?', 'We count the number of electrical charges that flow past a section of a conductor; in this case, a wire.']

['What was the problem you were studying?', 'Assume each particle q in Figure 19.3 carries a charge  $$\\(q = 1\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$, in which case the total charge shown would be  $$\\(\\Delta Q = 5q = 5\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$ .']
['What are the charges moving past the area?', 'If these charges move past the area A in a time  $$\\(\\Delta t = 1\\;\\text{ns}\\)$$, then the current would be']
['How does it work in an ionic compound?', 'Note that we assigned a positive charge to the charges in Figure 19.3.']
['What are the negative charges in a wire?', 'Normally, negative charges—electrons—are the mobile charge in wires, as indicated in Figure 19.2.']
['What are the positive charges in solids?', 'Positive charges are normally stuck in place in solids and cannot move freely.']

['How do we define conventional current?', 'However, because a positive current moving to the right is the same as a negative current of equal magnitude moving to the left, as shown in Figure 19.4, we define conventional current to flow in the direction that a positive charge would flow if it could move.']
['What is the current composed of?', 'Thus, unless otherwise specified, an electric current is assumed to be composed of positive charges.']
['What is the unit of electric charge?', 'Also note that one Coulomb is a significant amount of electric charge, so 5 A is a very large current.']
['What is the current you will see in everyday life?', 'Most often you will see current on the order of milliamperes (mA).']

['What are the other types of current?', 'Depending on the situation, positive charges, negative charges, or both may move.']
['What is important about electrons?', 'In metal wires, as we have seen, current is carried by electrons, so the negative charges move.']
['What is important about ions?', 'In ionic solutions, such as salt water, both positively charged and negatively charged ions move.']
['What does current do in nerve cells?', 'This is also true in nerve cells.']
['Are there any other types of current?', 'Pure positive currents are relatively rare but do occur.']
['Who is Franklin?', 'History credits American politician and scientist Benjamin Franklin with describing current as the direction that positive charges flow through a wire.']
['What was his theory about electrons?', 'He named the type of charge associated with electrons negative long before they were known to carry current in so many situations.']
['What type of obstacles do electrons encounter as they move?', 'As electrons move through a metal wire, they encounter obstacles such as other electrons, atoms, impurities, etc.']
['What happens to the electrons as they encounter obstacles?', 'The electrons scatter from these obstacles, as depicted in Figure 19.5.']
['What happens with each interaction?', 'Normally, the electrons lose energy with each interaction.']
['What is the energy loss caused by?', 'To keep the electrons moving thus requires a force, which is supplied by an electric field.']
['What is the electric field in a wire?', 'The electric field in a wire points from the end of the wire at the higher potential to the end of the wire at the lower potential.']
['What do electrons carry?', 'Electrons, carrying a negative charge, move on average (or drift) in the direction opposite the electric field, as shown in Figure 19.5.']
['How does this help me understand the subject?', 'So far, we have discussed current that moves constantly in a single direction.']
['What does this mean?', 'This is called direct current, because the electric charge flows in only one direction.']
['What is this referred to as?', 'Direct current is often called DC current.']

['What is the most important concept presented in this document?', 'Many sources of electrical power, such as the hydroelectric dam shown at the beginning of this chapter, produce alternating current, in which the current direction alternates back and forth.']
['What is the term for an electrical current that is alternately flowing?', 'Alternating current is often called AC current.']
['What does AC current follow?', 'Alternating current moves back and forth at regular time intervals, as shown in Figure 19.6.']
['What happens if there is no source of AC current?', 'The alternating current that comes from a normal wall socket does not suddenly switch directions.']
['What causes it to switch?', 'Rather, it increases smoothly up to a maximum current and then smoothly decreases back to zero.']
['What happens after the current drops to zero?', 'It then grows again, but in the opposite direction until it has reached the same maximum value.']
['What happens after the maximum value?', 'After that, it decreases smoothly back to zero, and the cycle starts over again.']
['What type of devices use AC?', 'Devices that use AC include vacuum cleaners, fans, power tools, hair dryers, and countless others.']
['What do these devices obtain when you plug them into a wall socket?', 'These devices obtain the power they require when you plug them into a wall socket.']
['What happens when you plug the devices into the socket?', 'The wall socket is connected to the power grid that provides an alternating potential (AC potential).']
['What does AC potential do to the devices?', 'When your device is plugged in, the AC potential pushes charges back and forth in the circuit of the device, creating an alternating current.']
['What type of power does the computer use?', 'Many devices, however, use DC, such as computers, cell phones, flashlights, and cars.']
['What is the DC potential?', 'One source of DC is a battery, which provides a constant potential (DC potential) between its terminals.']
['What can the battery do?', 'With your device connected to a battery, the DC potential pushes charge in one direction through the circuit of your device, creating a DC current.']
['What is another way to produce DC current?', 'Another way to produce DC current is by using a transformer, which converts AC potential to DC potential.']
['What do you use the transformer for?', 'Small transformers that you can plug into a wall socket are used to charge up your laptop, cell phone, or other electronic device.']
['What is a transformer that transforms AC voltage into DC voltage?', 'People generally call this a charger or a battery, but it is a transformer that transforms AC voltage into DC voltage.']

['What else did you learn about the power source?', 'The next time someone asks to borrow your laptop charger, tell them that you don’t have a laptop charger, but that they may borrow your converter.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'As mentioned previously, electrical current in a wire is in many ways similar to water flowing through a pipe.']
['What is the water current like?', 'The water current that can flow through a pipe is affected by obstacles in the pipe, such as clogs and narrow sections in the pipe.']
['What would these obstacles do to the water current?', 'These obstacles slow down the flow of current through the pipe.']

['What can slow down electrical current in a wire?', 'Similarly, electrical current in a wire can be slowed down by many factors, including impurities in the metal of the wire or collisions between the charges in the material.']
['What are the factors that create a resistance to the electrical current?', 'These factors create a resistance to the electrical current.']
['What is resistance?', 'Resistance is a description of how much a wire or other electrical component opposes the flow of charge through it.']

['Who found that current through a conductor is proportional to the voltage drop across a current-carrying conductor?', 'In the 19th century, the German physicist Georg Simon Ohm (1787–1854) found experimentally that current through a conductor is proportional to the voltage drop across a current-carrying conductor.']
['What is the relationship between voltage and resistance?', 'This relationship is called Ohm’s law.']
['How does it relate to the current?', 'It can be viewed as a cause-and-effect relationship, with voltage being the cause and the current being the effect.']
['What is the name of the law?', 'Ohm’s law is an empirical law like that for friction, which means that it is an experimentally observed phenomenon.']
['What are the units of resistance?', 'The units of resistance are volts per ampere, or V/A.']
['What is the symbol for V/A?', 'We call a V/A an ohm, which is represented by the uppercase Greek letter omega ( $$\\(\\text{Ω}\\)$$ ).']
["What does Ohm's law have to do with electricity?", 'Thus,']
['What is Ohm’s law?', 'Ohm’s law holds for most materials and at common temperatures.']
['What happens when the temperature is too low?', 'At very low temperatures, resistance may drop to zero (superconductivity).']
['What happens when the temperature is too high?', 'At very high temperatures, the thermal motion of atoms in the material inhibits the flow of electrons, increasing the resistance.']
['Are all substances considered to be Ohmic?', 'The many substances for which Ohm’s law holds are called ohmic.']
['What type of conductors are Ohmic?', 'Ohmic materials include good conductors like copper, aluminum, and silver, and some poor conductors under certain circumstances.']
["What else is significant about Ohm's law?", 'The resistance of ohmic materials remains essentially the same for a wide range of voltage and current.']
['What is your first question?', 'Now that we understand the concept of electric current, let’s see what we can do with it.']
['What do you mean by modern lifestyle?', 'As you are no doubt aware, the modern lifestyle relies heavily on electrical devices.']
['What do electrical devices contain?', 'These devices contain ingenious electric circuits, which are complete, closed pathways through which electric current flows.']
['What is an electric circuit?', 'Returning to our water analogy, an electric circuit is to electric charge like a network of pipes is to water:']

['What does the electric circuit do?', 'The electric circuit guides electric charge from one point to the next, running the charge through various devices along the way to extract work or information.']
['What type of circuits are used in power systems?', 'Electric circuits are made from many materials and cover a huge range of sizes, as shown in Figure 19.8.']

['Are there any specific types of circuits mentioned in the passage?', 'Computers and cell phones contain electric circuits whose features can be as small as roughly a billionth of a meter (a nanometer, or  $$\\(10^{-9}\\text{m}\\)$$ ).']

['What are the pathways that guide the current in these devices made of?', 'The pathways that guide the current in these devices are made by ultraprecise chemical treatments of silicon or other semiconductors.']
['Are there other types of circuits mentioned in the passage?', 'Large power systems, on the other hand, contain electric circuits whose features are on the scale of meters.']
['What is the reason for the large features?', 'These systems carry such large electric currents that their physical dimensions must be relatively large.']
['What kind of pathways do these circuits consist of?', 'The pathways that form electric circuits are made from a conducting material, normally a metal in macroscopic circuits.']

['What kinds of objects can be connected through these pathways?', 'For example, copper wires inside your school building form the electrical circuits that power lighting, projectors, screens, speakers, etc.']
['What kind of representations do we use to represent these circuits?', 'To represent an electric circuit, we draw circuit diagrams.']
['What do we use to represent the elements in the circuit?', 'We use lines and symbols to represent the elements in the circuit.']

['What are some of the symbols we will use?', 'There are many different symbols that scientists and engineers use in circuit diagrams, but we will focus on four main symbols: the wire, the battery or voltage source, resistors, and the ground.']
['What do the thin black lines in the electric circuit diagram represent?', 'The thin black lines in the electric circuit diagram represent the pathway that the electric charge must follow.']
['What do the black lines mean?', 'These pathways are assumed to be perfect conductors, so electric charge can move along these pathways without losing any energy.']
['What does perfect conductor mean?', 'In reality, the wires in circuits are not perfect, but they come close enough for our purposes.']
['What is the main topic of this section?', 'The zigzag element labeled R is a resistor, which is a circuit element that provides a known resistance.']
['What does the R stand for?', 'Macroscopic resistors are often color coded to indicate their resistance, as shown in Figure 19.10.']

['What is the red element in Figure 19.9?', 'The red element in Figure 19.9 is a battery, with its positive and negative terminals indicated; the longer line represents the positive terminal of the battery, and the shorter line represents the negative terminal.']
['What color is the battery icon?', 'Note that the battery icon is not always colored red; this is done in Figure 19.9 just to make it easy to identify.']

['What does the element labeled ground on the lower left of the circuit indicate?', 'Finally, the element labeled ground on the lower left of the circuit indicates that the circuit is connected to Earth, which is a large, essentially neutral object containing an infinite amount of charge.']
['What is ground connected to?', 'Among other things, the ground determines the potential of the negative terminal of the battery.']
['What is the potential of the ground?', 'Normally, the potential of the ground is defined to be zero:  $$\\(V_{\\text{ground}} \\equiv 0\\)$$ .']
['How does zero affect the lower wire?', 'This means that the entire lower wire in Figure 19.10 is at a voltage of zero volts.']
['What is the electric current in Figure 19.9?', 'The electric current in Figure 19.9 is indicted by the blue line labeled I.']
['What is the direction of the arrow on?', 'The arrow indicates the direction in which positive charge would flow in this circuit.']

['What direction does the negative charge flow in metals?', 'Recall that, in metals, electrons are mobile charge carriers, so negative charges actually flow in the opposite direction around this circuit (i.e., counterclockwise).']
['What is the difference between a current and a voltage?', 'However, we draw the current to show the direction in which positive charge would move.']
['What can you tell me about Figure 19.9?', 'On the right side of Figure 19.9 is an analogous water circuit.']
['Why is this analogous?', 'Water at a higher pressure leaves the top of the pump, which is like charges leaving the positive terminal of the battery.']
['How does the water flow?', 'The water travels through the pipe, like the charges traveling through the wire.']
['What happens to the water as it goes through the sand filter?', 'Next, the water goes through a sand filter, which heats up as the water squeezes through.']
['What happens after the filter?', 'This step is like the charges going through the resistor.']
['What happens during the pass?', 'When charges flow through a resistor, they do work to heat up the resistor.']
['What happens after the resistor?', 'After flowing through the sand filter, the water has converted its potential energy into heat, so it is at a lower pressure.']
['What is the voltage of the charges exiting the resistor?', 'Likewise, the charges exiting the resistor have converted their potential energy into heat, so they are at a lower voltage.']
['What is significant about voltage?', 'Recall that voltage is just potential energy per charge.']
['Is there more?', 'Thus, water pressure is analogous to electric potential energy (i.e., voltage).']

['What else does this tell me?', 'Coming back to the water circuit again, we see that the water returns to the bottom of the pump, which is like the charge returning to the negative terminal of the battery.']
['What is the water pump used for?', 'The water pump uses a source of energy to pump the water back up to a high pressure again, giving it the pressure required to go through the circuit once more.']
['Why does it use energy?', 'The water pump is like the battery, which uses chemical energy to increase the voltage of the charge up to the level of the positive terminal.']
['What is the potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery?', 'The potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery is the voltage rating of the battery.']
['What is the voltage of the upper pipe?', 'This voltage is like water pressure in the upper pipe.']

['What causes electric charge to flow toward a lower voltage?', 'Just like a higher pressure forces water to move toward a lower pressure, a higher voltage forces electric charge to flow toward a lower voltage.']
['What is a pump used for?', 'The pump takes water at low pressure and does work on it, ejecting water at a higher pressure.']
['What happens to a battery?', 'Likewise, a battery takes charge at a low voltage, does work on it, and ejects charge at a higher voltage.']
['What is the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9?', 'Note that the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9 is the same throughout the circuit.']

['Is it always the same current?', 'In other words, if we measured the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time at any point in the circuit, we would get the same answer no matter where in the circuit we measured.']
['Does that mean that the water always flows at the same speed?', 'The same is true of the electrical circuit in the same figure.']
['What else is true about the electric circuit?', 'The electric current is the same at all points in this circuit, including inside the battery and in the resistor.']
['Are there any other interesting things that are true about the current in the electric circuit?', 'The electric current neither speeds up in the wires nor slows down in the resistor.']
['Can current in an electric circuit cause voltage to drop?', 'This would create points where too much or too little charge would be bunched up.']
['What else is true about current in the electric circuit?', 'Thus, the current is the same at all points in the circuit shown in Figure 19.9.']

['What is the difference between electric and water circuits?', 'Although the current is the same everywhere in both the electric and water circuits, the voltage or water pressure changes as you move through the circuits.']
['What happens to the voltage?', 'In the water circuit, the water pressure at the pump outlet stays the same until the water goes through the sand filter, assuming no energy loss in the pipe.']

['What is the voltage in the electrical circuit the same at all points in a given wire?', 'Likewise, the voltage in the electrical circuit is the same at all points in a given wire, because we have assumed that the wires are perfect conductors.']

['Why are the wires perfect conductors?', 'Thus, as indicated by the constant red color of the upper wire in Figure 19.11, the voltage throughout this wire is constant at  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['Where does the voltage go next?', 'The voltage then drops as you go through the resistor, but once you reach the blue wire, the voltage stays at its new level of  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  all the way to the negative terminal of the battery (i.e., the blue terminal of the battery).']
['What is an example of a voltage increase?', 'If we go from the blue wire through the battery to the red wire, the voltage increases from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$ to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['How do resistors help increase the voltage?', 'Likewise, if we go from the blue wire up through the resistor to the red wire, the voltage also goes from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']
['What do we use resistors for?', 'Thus, using']

['How are you going to calculate the voltage in a resistor?', 'Note that  $$\\(V_{\\text{resistor}}\\)$$  is measured from the bottom of the resistor to the top, meaning that the top of the resistor is at a higher voltage than the bottom of the resistor.']
['What is the direction of current flow in a resistor?', 'Thus, current flows from the top of the resistor or higher voltage to the bottom of the resistor or lower voltage.']
['What other important information is included in this paper?', 'Other possible circuit elements include capacitors and switches.']
['How are capacitors and switches connected?', 'These are drawn as shown on the left side of Figure 19.12.']
['What is a switch?', 'A switch is a device that opens and closes the circuit, like a light switch.']
['How are switches analogous to a light switch?', 'It is analogous to a valve in a water circuit, as shown on the right side of Figure 19.12.']
['What happens with the switch closed?', 'With the switch open, no current passes through the circuit.']
['What happens with the switch closed?', 'With the switch closed, it becomes part of the wire, so the current passes through it with no loss of voltage.']
['What are the names of the capacitors?', 'The capacitor is labeled C on the left of Figure 19.12.']
['What are capacitors like in the electrical circuit?', 'A capacitor in an electrical circuit is analogous to a flexible membrane in a water circuit.']

['What is a current?', 'When the switch is closed in the circuit of Figure 19.12, the battery forces electrical current to flow toward the capacitor, charging the upper capacitor plate with positive charge.']
['What happens to the voltage as it builds up?', 'As this happens, the voltage across the capacitor plates increases.']
['What happens to the current when the membrane is broken?', 'This is like the membrane in the water circuit:']
['What happens to the membrane?', 'When the valve is opened, the pump forces water to flow toward the membrane, making it stretch to store the excess water.']
['What happens to the water when it is pushed against the membrane?', 'As this happens, the pressure behind the membrane increases.']
['What can we do with this information?', 'Now if we open the switch, the capacitor holds the voltage between its plates because the charges have nowhere to go.']

['What happens to the charges after they hit the plates?', 'Likewise, if we close the valve, the water has nowhere to go and the membrane maintains the water pressure in the pipe between itself and the valve.']

['What is the most important concept from this text?', 'If the switch is closed for a long time in the electric circuit or if the valve is open for a long time in the water circuit, the current will eventually stop flowing because the capacitor or the membrane will have become completely charged.']
['What happens when it is completely charged?', 'Each circuit is now in the steady state, which means that its characteristics do not change over time.']

['What is the steady state characterized by?', 'In this case, the steady state is characterized by zero current, and this does not change as long as the switch or valve remains in the same position.']
['How is zero current different than a steady state?', 'In the steady state, no electrical current passes through the capacitor, and no water current passes through the membrane.']
['What is the voltage between the plates?', 'The voltage difference between the capacitor plates will be the same as the battery voltage.']
['What is the pressure behind the membrane?', 'In the water circuit, the pressure behind the membrane will be the same as the pressure created by the pump.']

['What does the circuit in Figure 19.12 show?', 'Although the circuit in Figure 19.12 may seem a bit pointless because all that happens when the switch is closed is that the capacitor charges up, it does show the capacitor’s ability to store charge.']
['What does a capacitor do?', 'Thus, the capacitor serves as a reservoir for charge.']
['How can this be beneficial?', 'This property of capacitors is used in circuits in many ways.']
['What are some applications of capacitors?', 'For example, capacitors are used to power circuits while batteries are being charged.']
['What can capacitors do?', 'In addition, capacitors can serve as filters.']
['What are the main functions of filters?', 'To understand this, let’s go back to the water analogy.']
['What is the source of water?', 'Suppose you have a water hose and are watering your garden.']
['What happens when your friend kinks the hose?', 'Your friend thinks he’s funny, and kinks the hose.']
['What happens to you if the hose is kinked?', 'While the hose is kinked, you experience no water flow.']
['Why does he kink the hose?', 'When he lets go, the water starts flowing again.']
['What happens if he does this really fast?', 'If he does this really fast, you experience water-no water-water-no water, and that’s really no way to water your garden.']
['What does this mean for you?', 'Now imagine that the hose is filling up a big bucket, and you are watering from the bottom of the bucket.']

['What happens next?', 'As long as you had water in your bucket to begin with and your friend doesn’t kink the water hose for too long, you would be able to water your garden without the interruptions.']
['What does your friend do with the water hose?', 'Your friend kinking the water hose is filtered by the big bucket’s supply of water, so it does not impact your ability to water the garden.']
['What else do you know about this analogy?', 'We can think of the interruptions in the current (be it water or electrical current) as noise.']
['What does the capacitor do?', 'Capacitors act in an analogous way as the water bucket to help filter out the noise.']
['What else do you know about capacitors?', 'Capacitors have so many uses that it is very rare to find an electronic circuit that does not include some capacitors.']
['What happened next?', 'Now that we have a basic idea of how electrical circuits work, let’s see what happens in circuits with more than one circuit element.']
['What did we look at in this section?', 'In this section, we look at resistors in series.']

['What else is important about resistors in series?', 'Components connected in series are connected one after the other in the same branch of a circuit, such as the resistors connected in series on the left side of Figure 19.14.']
['How is it related to arithmetic?', 'We will now try to find a single resistance that is equivalent to the three resistors in series on the left side of Figure 19.14.']
['What is an equivalent resistor?', 'An equivalent resistor is a resistor that has the same resistance as the combined resistance of a set of other resistors.']
['What does this mean?', 'In other words, the same current will flow through the left and right circuits in Figure 19.14 if we use the equivalent resistor in the right circuit.']

["what is Ohm's law?", 'According to Ohm’s law, the voltage drop V across a resistor when a current flows through it is  $$\\(V = IR\\)$$  where I is the current in amperes (A) and R is the resistance in ohms ( $$\\(\\Omega\\)$$ ).']
['what is voltage drop?', 'Another way to think of this is that V is the voltage necessary to make a current I flow through a resistance R. Applying']

['what is voltage drop?', 'Ohm’s law to each resistor on the left circuit of Figure 19.14, we find that the voltage drop across  $$\\(R_{1}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{1} = IR_{1}\\)$$, that across  $$\\(R_{2}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{2} = IR_{2}\\)$$, and that across  $$\\(R_{3}\\)$$  is  $$\\(V_{3} = IR_{3}\\)$$ .']

['What else did you learn about parallel resistors?', 'Resistors are in parallel when both ends of each resistor are connected directly together.']

['What is the equivalent resistance of the parallel resistors?', 'Therefore, the equivalent resistance must be less than the smallest resistance of the parallel resistors.']

['How does Ohm’s law help with the calculation of current?', 'Ohm’s law tells us that the current flowing through a circuit depends on the resistance of the circuit and the voltage across the circuit.']
['What is the formula for the current?', 'But to know the current, we must first know the equivalent resistance.']

['What is the most common way people use power?', 'Power is associated by many people with electricity.']
['What is the most important thing we use power for?', 'Every day, we use electric power to run our modern appliances.']
['What is the most common way we get power?', 'Electric power transmission lines are visible examples of electricity providing power.']
['What does electric power do for us?', 'We also use electric power to start our cars, to run our computers, or to light our homes.']

['What is the rate at which energy of any type is transferred?', 'Power is the rate at which energy of any type is transferred; electric power is the rate at which electric energy is transferred in a circuit.']
['What is the most important information I should know about power?', 'In this section, we’ll learn not only what this means, but also what factors determine electric power.']
['What does watt mean?', 'To get started, let’s think of light bulbs, which are often characterized in terms of their power ratings in watts.']

['How do they compare?', 'Although both operate at the same voltage, the 60-W bulb emits more light intensity than the 25-W bulb.']

['What tells us that something other than voltage determines the power output of an electric circuit?', 'This tells us that something other than voltage determines the power output of an electric circuit.']

['What are some things you learned from the section on resistors?', 'Incandescent light bulbs, such as the two shown in Figure 19.20, are essentially resistors that heat up when current flows through them and they get so hot that they emit visible and invisible light.']
['How can you tell which is better?', 'Thus the two light bulbs in the photo can be considered as two different resistors.']

['What do you learn about current and voltage?', 'In a simple circuit such as a light bulb with a voltage applied to it, the resistance determines the current by Ohm’s law, so we can see that current as well as voltage must determine the power.']
['What is the formula for power?', 'The formula for power may be found by dimensional analysis.']

['What does the equation tell us about electric power?', 'Thus, equation above tells us that electric power is voltage times current, or']

['Are there other ways of describing electric power?', 'Note that only resistance (not capacitance or anything else), current, and voltage enter into the expressions for electric power.']
['What determines how much power a circuit dissipates?', 'This means that the physical characteristic of a circuit that determines how much power it dissipates is its resistance.']
['What do capacitors do?', 'Any capacitors in the circuit do not dissipate electric power—on the contrary, capacitors either store electric energy or release electric energy back to the circuit.']

['When was the study material created?', 'People have been aware of magnets and magnetism for thousands of years.']

['What are the earliest records of magnets?', 'The earliest records date back to ancient times, particularly in the region of Asia Minor called Magnesia—the name of this region is the source of words like magnet.']
['What is Magnesia?', 'Magnetic rocks found in Magnesia, which is now part of western Turkey, stimulated interest during ancient times.']

['Did magnets create problems?', 'When humans first discovered magnetic rocks, they likely found that certain parts of these rocks attracted bits of iron or other magnetic rocks more strongly than other parts.']
['What are the areas of the magnet called?', 'These areas are called the poles of a magnet.']

['What is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material?', 'A magnetic pole is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material, such as iron.']
['Are there any other examples of magnetism?', 'For example, the poles of the bar magnet shown in Figure 20.2 are where the paper clips are concentrated.']

['What is the most important thing you learned from the article?', 'If a bar magnet is suspended so that it rotates freely, one pole of the magnet will always turn toward the north, with the opposite pole facing south.']
['What did they discover by testing the magnets?', 'This discovery led to the compass, which is simply a small, elongated magnet mounted so that it can rotate freely.']
['What were some examples of compass designs?', 'An example of a compass is shown Figure 20.3.']
['What are the two poles of a magnet called?', 'The pole of the magnet that orients northward is called the north pole, and the opposite pole of the magnet is called the south pole.']

['What is the most important information about magnets?', 'The discovery that one particular pole of a magnet orients northward, whereas the other pole orients southward allowed people to identify the north and south poles of any magnet.']
["What is magnets' greatest influence on everyday life?", 'It was then noticed that the north poles of two different magnets repel each other, and likewise for the south poles.']
['Are there any exceptions to this rule?', 'Conversely, the north pole of one magnet attracts the south pole of other magnets.']
['What is the analogy?', 'This situation is analogous to that of electric charge, where like charges repel and unlike charges attract.']
['How is this analogous to magnets?', 'In magnets, we simply replace charge with pole: Like poles repel and unlike poles attract.']
['What is the force between magnets dependent on?', 'This is summarized in Figure 20.4, which shows how the force between magnets depends on their relative orientation.']
['What is the name of the pole of a magnet that orients northward?', 'Consider again the fact that the pole of a magnet that orients northward is called the north pole of the magnet.']
['What does the opposite pole do?', 'If unlike poles attract, then the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic North Pole must be a magnetic south pole!']
['How does this apply to magnets?', 'Likewise, the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic South Pole must be a magnetic north pole.']

['What figure describes this situation?', 'This situation is depicted in Figure 20.5, in which Earth is represented as containing a giant internal bar magnet with its magnetic south pole at the geographic North Pole and vice versa.']

['What are some important things to know about magnetism?', 'If we were to somehow suspend a giant bar magnet in space near Earth, then the north pole of the space magnet would be attracted to the south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['What happens with a compass needle?', 'This is in essence what happens with a compass needle:']
['What does this do?', 'Its magnetic north pole is attracted to the magnet south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['Was this material a textbook or online?', 'The answer is no:']
['What are the two poles of a bar magnet?', 'Each half of the bar magnet has a north pole and a south pole.']
['What else do you know about the poles?', 'You can even continue cutting each piece of the bar magnet in half, and you will always obtain a new, smaller magnet with two opposite poles.']

['What is the most important part of the article?', 'As shown in Figure 20.6, you can continue this process down to the atomic scale, and you will find that even the smallest particles that behave as magnets have two opposite poles.']

['What is the most important discovery in the article?', 'In fact, no experiment has ever found any object with a single magnetic pole, from the smallest subatomic particle such as electrons to the largest objects in the universe such as stars.']
['What is the most important thing that you learned?', 'Because magnets always have two poles, they are referred to as magnetic dipoles—di means two.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Below, we will see that magnetic dipoles have properties that are analogous to electric dipoles.']
['What materials exhibit strong magnetic effects?', 'Only certain materials, such as iron, cobalt, nickel, and gadolinium, exhibit strong magnetic effects.']
['What is the name of the materials that are magnetic?', 'Such materials are called ferromagnetic, after the Latin word ferrum for iron.']
['What is the difference between strong magnetization and weak magnetization?', 'Other materials exhibit weak magnetic effects, which are detectable only with sensitive instruments.']

['What else is important to know about magnets?', 'Not only do ferromagnetic materials respond strongly to magnets—the way iron is attracted to magnets—but they can also be magnetized themselves—that is, they can be induced to be magnetic or made into permanent magnets (Figure 20.7).']

['What is a material that retains its magnetic behavior for a long time?', 'A permanent magnet is simply a material that retains its magnetic behavior for a long time, even when exposed to demagnetizing influences.']

['What is magnetization?', 'When a magnet is brought near a previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material, it causes local magnetization of the material with unlike poles closest, as in the right side of Figure 20.7.']
['What causes an attractive force?', 'This causes an attractive force, which is why unmagnetized iron is attracted to a magnet.']
['What happens on a microscopic scale?', 'What happens on a microscopic scale is illustrated in Figure 7(a).']
['What do domains do?', 'Regions within the material called domains act like small bar magnets.']
['What happens in the domains?', 'Within domains, the magnetic poles of individual atoms are aligned.']
['What does the atom do?', 'Each atom acts like a tiny bar magnet.']
['What are the domains?', 'Domains are small and randomly oriented in an unmagnetized ferromagnetic object.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about this section?', 'In response to an external magnetic field, the domains may grow to millimeter size, aligning themselves, as shown in Figure 7(b).']
['What can be done to make this permanent?', 'This induced magnetization can be made permanent if the material is heated and then cooled, or simply tapped in the presence of other magnets.']
['What is magnetization?', 'Conversely, a permanent magnet can be demagnetized by hard blows or by heating it in the absence of another magnet.']
['What is the result of increased thermal motion at higher temperature?', 'Increased thermal motion at higher temperature can disrupt and randomize the orientation and size of the domains.']

['What is the temperature at which a ferromagnetic material cannot be magnetized?', 'There is a well-defined temperature for ferromagnetic materials, which is called the Curie temperature, above which they cannot be magnetized.']
['What is the Curie temperature for iron?', 'The Curie temperature for iron is 1,043 K (770 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ), which is well above room temperature.']
['Does it matter what metal is used?', 'There are several elements and alloys that have Curie temperatures much lower than room temperature and are ferromagnetic only below those temperatures.']
['What is magnetic fields?', 'We have thus seen that forces can be applied between magnets and between magnets and ferromagnetic materials without any contact between the objects.']
['What is reminiscent of electric forces?', 'This is reminiscent of electric forces, which also act over distances.']

['What is the concept of electric fields?', 'Electric forces are described using the concept of the electric field, which is a force field around electric charges that describes the force on any other charge placed in the field.']
['What is the concept of magnetic fields?', 'Likewise, a magnet creates a magnetic field around it that describes the force exerted on other magnets placed in the field.']

['What do magnetic field lines represent?', 'As with electric fields, the pictorial representation of magnetic field lines is very useful for visualizing the strength and direction of the magnetic field.']

['What is the direction of magnetic field lines defined to be?', 'As shown in Figure 20.9, the direction of magnetic field lines is defined to be the direction in which the north pole of a compass needle points.']

['What is the direction of a compass needle when placed near a magnet?', 'If you place a compass near the north pole of a magnet, the north pole of the compass needle will be repelled and point away from the magnet.']
['Can you tell me what happens when the north pole of a magnet is repelled?', 'Thus, the magnetic field lines point away from the north pole of a magnet and toward its south pole.']
['What is one way magnetic fields can be mapped out?', 'Magnetic field lines can be mapped out using a small compass.']

['How is the compass used to map out magnetic fields?', 'The compass is moved from point to point around a magnet, and at each point, a short line is drawn in the direction of the needle, as shown in Figure 20.10.']
['How are the lines joined?', 'Joining the lines together then reveals the path of the magnetic field line.']
['What can be used to visualize magnetic field lines?', 'Another way to visualize magnetic field lines is to sprinkle iron filings around a magnet.']
['What will happen to the magnetic field lines?', 'The filings will orient themselves along the magnetic field lines, forming a pattern such as that shown on the right in Figure 20.10.']

['What is the relationship between magnetic fields and electric field lines?', 'When two magnets are brought close together, the magnetic field lines are perturbed, just as happens for electric field lines when two electric charges are brought together.']

['What happens when two magnets are brought close together?', 'Bringing two north poles together—or two south poles—will cause a repulsion, and the magnetic field lines will bend away from each other.']
['What is the result of this?', 'This is shown in Figure 20.11, which shows the magnetic field lines created by the two closely separated north poles of a bar magnet.']
['What happens if the poles touch?', 'When opposite poles of two magnets are brought together, the magnetic field lines join together and become denser between the poles.']
['How does this compare to the separation?', 'This situation is shown in Figure 20.11.']
['What kind of field is stronger where the lines are denser?', 'Like the electric field, the magnetic field is stronger where the lines are denser.']

['What is the density of the magnetic field between the two north poles in Figure 20.11?', 'Thus, between the two north poles in Figure 20.11, the magnetic field is very weak because the density of the magnetic field is almost zero.']
['What happens in that area?', 'A compass placed at that point would essentially spin freely if we ignore Earth’s magnetic field.']

['How does that change the field?', 'Conversely, the magnetic field lines between the north and south poles in Figure 20.11 are very dense, indicating that the magnetic field is very strong in this region.']
['What happens in that region?', 'A compass placed here would quickly align with the magnetic field and point toward the south pole on the right.']
['What is a magnetic field?', 'Note that magnets are not the only things that make magnetic fields.']
['Did any currents cause magnetic fields?', 'Early in the nineteenth century, people discovered that electrical currents cause magnetic effects.']

['Who discovered that a compass needle was deflected by a current-carrying wire?', 'The first significant observation was by the Danish scientist Hans Christian Oersted (1777–1851), who found that a compass needle was deflected by a current-carrying wire.']
['Did they make a discovery about that?', 'This was the first significant evidence that the movement of electric charges had any connection with magnets.']
['What is an electromagnet?', 'An electromagnet is a device that uses electric current to make a magnetic field.']
['What are the temporary induced magnets called?', 'These temporarily induced magnets are called electromagnets.']

['What are some uses of electromagnets?', 'Electromagnets are employed for everything from a wrecking yard crane that lifts scrapped cars to controlling the beam of a 90-km-circumference particle accelerator to the magnets in medical-imaging machines (see Figure 20.12).']
['What is the field created by an electric current in a long straight wire?', 'The magnetic field created by an electric current in a long straight wire is shown in Figure 20.13.']
['What happens when the current flows through a wire?', 'The magnetic field lines form concentric circles around the wire.']
['What can you tell me about magnetic fields?', 'The direction of the magnetic field can be determined using the right-hand rule.']
['What is the right-hand rule?', 'This rule shows up in several places in the study of electricity and magnetism.']

['What does the right-hand rule say?', 'Applied to a straight current-carrying wire, the right-hand rule says that, with your right thumb pointed in the direction of the current, the magnetic field will be in the direction in which your right fingers curl, as shown in Figure 20.13.']
['Does the right-hand rule say anything else?', 'If the wire is very long compared to the distance r from the wire, the strength B of the magnetic field is given by']
['What is the function B_[straighttextwire of this magnetic field?', '$$\\[B_{\\text{straight}\\text{wire}} = \\frac{\\mu_{0}']
['What is the function I?', 'I}{2\\pi r}\\]$$']
['What is the formula to find a magnetic field according to this paper?', 'where I is the current in the wire in amperes.']
['What is the SI unit for magnetic field?', 'The SI unit for magnetic field is the tesla (T).']

['What is the symbol $(mu_0)$$ —read “mu-zero”—is a constant called the “permeability of free space” and is given by?', 'The symbol  $$\\(\\mu_{0}\\)$$ —read “mu-zero”—is a constant called the “permeability of free space” and is given by']
['What happened after the cylinder was removed?', 'Now imagine winding a wire around a cylinder with the cylinder then removed.']
['What happens when you combine two wires?', 'The result is a wire coil, as shown in Figure 20.14.']
['What does it do?', 'This is called a solenoid.']
['What is the direction of the magnetic field produced by a solenoid?', 'To find the direction of the magnetic field produced by a solenoid, apply the right-hand rule to several points on the coil.']

['What should you be able to convince yourself that, inside the coil, the magnetic field points from left to right?', 'You should be able to convince yourself that, inside the coil, the magnetic field points from left to right.']
['How is that accomplished?', 'In fact, another application of the right-hand rule is to curl your right-hand fingers around the coil in the direction in which the current flows.']
['Does the magnet move?', 'Your right thumb then points in the direction of the magnetic field inside the coil: left to right in this case.']
['What are the individual loops of wire inside a solenoid?', 'Each loop of wire contributes to the magnetic field inside the solenoid.']
['What happens when the magnetic field lines are drawn from a loop of wire outside?', 'Because the magnetic field lines must form closed loops, the field lines close the loop outside the solenoid.']
['What is the result of the magnetic field lines inside the solenoid?', 'The magnetic field lines are much denser inside the solenoid than outside the solenoid.']
['What is the result of this?', 'The resulting magnetic field looks very much like that of a bar magnet, as shown in Figure 20.15.']

['How do you find the direction of the force?', 'The direction of the force may be found by using another version of the right-hand rule: First, we join the tails of the velocity vector and a magnetic field vector, as shown in step 1 of Figure 20.16.']

['How does the right-hand rule calculate?', 'We then curl our right fingers from  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\)$$, as indicated in step (2) of Figure 20.16.']
['What happens when you use the right-hand rule?', 'The direction in which the right thumb points is the direction of the force.']
['What is the direction of the force on the page?', 'For the charge in Figure 20.16, we find that the force is directed into the page.']

['What is the difference between a magnetic field and a current?', 'Instead of a single charge moving through a magnetic field, consider now a steady current I moving through a straight wire.']
['What does an electric current involve?', 'An electric current involves charges that move.']

['What is this equation for?', 'This equation gives the force on a straight current-carrying wire of length  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a magnetic field of strength B.']
['What is the angle $(theta)$$?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the current vector and the magnetic field vector.']
