['What does the equation mean?', 'The direction of the force is determined in the same way as for a single charge.']
['What else is important?', 'Curl your right fingers from the vector for I to the vector for B, and your right thumb will point in the direction of the force on the wire.']
['What else should I know about the equation?', 'For the wire shown in Figure 20.19, the force is directed into the page.']
['What else should we do?', 'Throughout this section, you may have noticed the symmetries between magnetic effects and electric effects.']
['What are the effects of electromagnetism?', 'These effects all fall under the umbrella of electromagnetism, which is the study of electric and magnetic phenomena.']
['How do electric charges produce electric fields?', 'We have seen that electric charges produce electric fields, and moving electric charges produce magnetic fields.']
['What do moving magnetic dipoles produce?', 'A magnetic dipole produces a magnetic field, and, as we will see in the next section, moving magnetic dipoles produce an electric field.']
['What is the relationship between electricity and magnetism?', 'Thus, electricity and magnetism are two intimately related and symmetric phenomena.']

['What is the relationship between current, voltage, and field?', 'As we learned previously, a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field experiences a force—recall  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$ .']

['What is the most common application of magnetic force on current-carrying wires?', 'Electric motors, which convert electrical energy into mechanical energy, are the most common application of magnetic force on current-carrying wires.']
['What do motors consist of?', 'Motors consist of loops of wire in a magnetic field.']
['How do the loops move?', 'When current is passed through the loops, the magnetic field exerts a torque on the loops, which rotates a shaft.']
['What is the result of the rotation of the electric motor?', 'Electrical energy is converted to mechanical work in the process.']
['What is the schematic drawing of an electric motor?', 'Figure 20.23 shows a schematic drawing of an electric motor.']

['What is the most important concept in this section?', 'Let us examine the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23 to find the torques produced about the axis of the vertical shaft—this will lead to a useful equation for the torque on the loop.']
['What are some of the other concepts?', 'We take the magnetic field to be uniform over the rectangular loop, which has width w and height  $$\\(\\ell\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in the figure.']
['How do we determine the force on each segment of the loop?', 'First, consider the force on the top segment of the loop.']
['How do we determine the direction of the force?', 'To determine the direction of the force, we use the right-hand rule.']
['What is the right-hand rule?', 'The current goes from left to right into the page, and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page.']
['What does the right hand rule say?', 'Curl your right fingers from the current vector to the magnetic field vector and your right thumb points down.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus, the force on the top segment is downward, which produces no torque on the shaft.']

['What happened next?', 'Repeating this analysis for the bottom segment—neglect the small gap where the lead wires go out—shows that the force on the bottom segment is upward, again producing no torque on the shaft.']
['Using a small box and a ruler, draw the vertical segment of the loop.', 'Consider now the left vertical segment of the loop.']

['Does the left vertical segment of the loop exert the same force as the right vertical segment?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, we find that the force exerted on this segment is perpendicular to the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.23.']
['What is the force that produces a torque on the shaft?', 'This force produces a torque on the shaft.']

['What is the torque on the shaft?', 'Repeating this analysis on the right vertical segment of the loop shows that the force on this segment is in the direction opposite that of the force on the left segment, thereby producing an equal torque on the shaft.']
['How is the total torque on the shaft related to the left vertical segment of the loop?', 'The total torque on the shaft is thus twice the toque on one of the vertical segments of the loop.']
['What did you find interesting about the material?', 'To find the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins, consider Figure 20.24, which shows a view of the wire loop from above.']

['How do you find the torque?', 'Recall that torque is defined as  $$\\(\\tau = rF\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  where F is the applied force, r is the distance from the pivot to where the force is applied, and θ is the angle between r and F.']
['What is the most important aspect of this?', 'Notice that, as the loop spins, the current in the vertical loop segments is always perpendicular to the magnetic field.']
['What else is significant in the article?', 'Thus, the equation  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives the magnitude of the force on each vertical segment as  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\text{.}\\)$$']
['How did you calculate the torque?', 'The distance r from the shaft to where this force is applied is w/2, so the torque created by this force is']
['What was the relation between rotational and circular motions?', 'If we have a multiple loop with N turns, we get N times the torque of a single loop.']
['What is the calculation for this?', 'Using the fact that the area of the loop is  $$\\(A = w\\ell\\text{;}\\)$$  the expression for the torque becomes']
['What is the NIAB?', 'This is the torque on a current-carrying loop in a uniform magnetic field.']
['What does it tell us?', 'This equation can be shown to be valid for a loop of any shape.']
['What did you learn?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\tau = NIAB\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  we see that the torque is zero when  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What happened after that?', 'As the wire loop rotates, the torque increases to a maximum positive torque of  $$\\(w\\ell B\\)$$  when  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What happens next?', 'The torque then decreases back to zero as the wire loop rotates to  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$  From  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\theta = 360{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{,}\\)$$  the torque is negative.']
['What happens to the torque?', 'Thus, the torque changes sign every half turn, so the wire loop will oscillate back and forth.']

['What happens if we run the motor in reverse?', 'Consider now what happens if we run the motor in reverse; that is, we attach a handle to the shaft and mechanically force the coil to rotate within the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.26.']

['What is the force?', 'As per the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ —where  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the vectors  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\text{—charges}\\)$$  in the wires of the loop experience a magnetic force because they are moving in a magnetic field.']
['What does the right-hand rule tell us?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, where we curl our fingers from vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']

['What do we find when we look at the top and bottom segments of a conductor?', 'B}\\)$$, we find that charges in the top and bottom segments feel a force perpendicular to the wire, which does not cause a current.']

['Why is there no current?', 'However, charges in the vertical wires experience forces parallel to the wire, causing a current to flow through the wire and through an external circuit if one is connected.']
['What is an external circuit?', 'A device such as this that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is called a generator.']
['Is there a way to find the total current flowing in the circuit?', 'Because current is induced only in the side wires, we can find the induced emf by only considering these wires.']

['How can we get the voltage in the coil?', 'As explained in Induced Current in a Wire, motional emf in a straight wire moving at velocity v through a magnetic field B is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\text{,}\\)$$  where the velocity is perpendicular to the magnetic field.']

['Are the current and voltage related in some way?', 'In the generator, the velocity makes an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  with B (see Figure 20.27), so the velocity component perpendicular to B is  $$\\(v\\sin\\theta\\text{.}\\)$$']

['Do we need to calculate the emf for each wire individually?', 'Thus, in this case, the emf induced on each vertical wire segment is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  and they are in the same direction.']
['Do we need to add the emfs for the other wires?', 'The total emf around the loop is then']
['What is the problem with the expression?', 'Although this expression is valid, it does not give the emf as a function of time.']
['What else does this mean?', 'To find how the emf evolves in time, we assume that the coil is rotated at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What else do we need to know?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is related to the angular velocity by  $$\\(\\theta = \\omega t\\text{,}\\)$$  so that']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py?', 'Recall that tangential velocity v is related to angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  by  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Is there any other interesting information in this section?', 'Here,  $$\\(r = {w/2}\\)$$, so that  $$\\(v = \\left( {w\\operatorname{/2}} \\right)\\omega\\)$$  and']

['What is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity $$(omega)$$ in a uniform magnetic field B?', 'is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  in a uniform magnetic field B.']
['What is the maximum (peak) emf?', 'Figure 20.28 shows a generator connected to a light bulb and a graph of the emf vs. time.']

['What was the result of the generator being connected to the light bulb?', 'Note that the emf oscillates from a positive maximum of  $$\\(E_{0}\\)$$  to a negative maximum of  $$\\({-E}_{0}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What other information can you give me about the positive and negative maximum?', 'In between, the emf goes through zero, which means that zero current flows through the light bulb at these times.']
['Why does the light bulb flicker on and off?', 'Thus, the light bulb actually flickers on and off at a frequency of 2f, because there are two zero crossings per period.']
['What is the frequency of alternating current?', 'In the United States, the frequency of alternating current is 60 Hz, so the lights flicker on and off at a frequency of 120 Hz.']
['What is the flicker rate of the lights?', 'This is faster than the refresh rate of the human eye, so you don’t notice the flicker of the lights.']
['What else do you know about light bulbs?', 'Also, other factors prevent various different types of light bulbs from switching on and off so fast, so the light output is smoothed out a bit.']
['In what way did the model help?', 'In real life, electric generators look a lot different than the figures in this section, but the principles are the same.']

['What is the source of mechanical energy that turns the coil?', 'The source of mechanical energy that turns the coil can be falling water—hydropower—steam produced by the burning of fossil fuels, or the kinetic energy of wind.']

['What is the name of the machine that uses steam to generate electricity?', 'Figure 20.29 shows a cutaway view of a steam turbine; steam moves over the blades connected to the shaft, which rotates the coil within the generator.']
['What is an example of magnetic induction?', 'Another very useful and common device that exploits magnetic induction is called a transformer.']

['What does a transformer do?', 'Transformers do what their name implies—they transform voltages from one value to another; the term voltage is used rather than emf because transformers have internal resistance.']

['What are other examples of transformers?', 'For example, many cell phones, laptops, video games, power tools, and small appliances have a transformer built into their plug-in unit that changes 120 V or 240 V AC into whatever voltage the device uses.']
['What are some examples of transformers?', 'Figure 20.30 shows two different transformers.']
['What are the wire coils visible in each device?', 'Notice the wire coils that are visible in each device.']
['What are the coils for?', 'The purpose of these coils is explained below.']

['What is the maximum (peak) emf of a laminated-coil transformer?', 'Figure 20.31 shows a laminated-coil transformer, which is based on Faraday’s law of induction and is very similar in construction to the apparatus Faraday used to demonstrate that magnetic fields can generate electric currents.']
['What are the two wire coils called?', 'The two wire coils are called the primary and secondary coils.']

['What happens when the input voltage is applied across the primary coil?', 'In normal use, the input voltage is applied across the primary coil, and the secondary produces the transformed output voltage.']

['What is the iron core used for?', 'Not only does the iron core trap the magnetic field created by the primary coil, but also its magnetization increases the field strength, which is analogous to how a dielectric increases the electric field strength in a capacitor.']
['What is the output voltage?', 'Since the input voltage is AC, a time-varying magnetic flux is sent through the secondary coil, inducing an AC output voltage.']

['What is the maximum (peak) emf?', 'For the transformer shown in Figure 20.31, the output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  from the secondary coil depends almost entirely on the input voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  across the primary coil and the number of loops in the primary and secondary coils.']
['What else can you tell me about Faraday’s law?', 'Faraday’s law of induction for the secondary coil gives its induced output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  to be']

['What is the formula for the magnetic flux density of a secondary coil?', 'where  $$\\(N_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  is the number of loops in the secondary coil and  $$\\({\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}\\)$$  is the rate of change of magnetic flux.']

['What is the output voltage?', 'The output voltage equals the induced emf  $$\\(\\text{(}V_{\\text{S}} = E_{\\text{S}}\\text{),}\\)$$  provided coil resistance is small—a reasonable assumption for transformers.']

['What happens to the magnetic flux as it rotates?', 'The cross-sectional area of the coils is the same on each side, as is the magnetic field strength, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ/Δ}t\\)$$  is the same on each side.']
['What happens to the input voltage?', 'The input primary voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  is also related to changing flux by']
['What is the transformer equation?', 'This is known as the transformer equation.']

['How does a transformer work?', 'It simply states that the ratio of the secondary voltage to the primary voltage in a transformer equals the ratio of the number of loops in secondary coil to the number of loops in the primary coil.']

['What are transformers used for?', 'Transformers are widely used in the electric power industry to increase voltages—called step-up transformers—before long-distance transmission via high-voltage wires.']
['What are other uses of transformers?', 'They are also used to decrease voltages—called step-down transformers—to deliver power to homes and businesses.']

['What is the most common way to generate power?', 'The overwhelming majority of electric power is generated by using magnetic induction, whereby a wire coil or copper disk is rotated in a magnetic field.']
['What is the primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk?', 'The primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk can be provided by a variety of means.']
['What is a secondary energy source?', 'Hydroelectric power plants use the kinetic energy of water to drive electric generators.']
['What are other secondary energy sources?', 'Coal or nuclear power plants create steam to drive steam turbines that turn the coils.']
['What are other primary energy sources?', 'Other sources of primary energy include wind, tides, or waves on water.']

['What is the process of transferring electrical power from the source to the consumer?', 'Once power is generated, it must be transmitted to the consumer, which often means transmitting power over hundreds of kilometers.']
['How is power transmitted?', 'To do this, the voltage of the power plant is increased by a step-up transformer, that is stepped up, and the current decreases proportionally because']
['What is this theorem about?', 'The lower current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  in the transmission wires reduces the Joule losses, which is heating of the wire due to a current flow.']
['What is this heating caused by?', 'This heating is caused by the small, but nonzero, resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{wire}}\\)$$  of the transmission wires.']
['What is the significance of this?', 'The power lost to the environment through this heat is']
['I am interested in how the loss of power is proportional to the current squared in the', 'which is proportional to the current squared in the transmission wire.']

['What is the reason for the transmitted current to be as small as possible?', 'This is why the transmitted current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  must be as small as possible and, consequently, the voltage must be large to transmit the power  $$\\(P_{\\text{transmitted}}\\text{⋅}\\)$$']
['What are some important facts about transmission voltage?', 'Voltages ranging from 120 to 700 kV are used for transmitting power over long distances.']
['What is the typical voltage at the exit of the power station?', 'The voltage is stepped up at the exit of the power station by a step-up transformer, as shown in Figure 20.32.']

['What is the voltage of the power lines that are used to deliver electricity to a population or industrial center?', 'Once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center, the voltage is stepped down at a substation to between 5 and 30 kV.']
['What happens after the voltage is stepped down?', 'Finally, at individual homes or businesses, the power is stepped down again to 120, 240, or 480 V.']
['What is a transformer designed based on Faradays law of induction?', 'Each step-up and step-down transformation is done with a transformer designed based on Faradays law of induction.']
["What is the name of the person who's law of induction was used to create electricity?", 'We’ve come a long way since Queen Elizabeth asked Faraday what possible use could be made of electricity.']
['What is the current current?', 'In the preceding section, we learned that a current creates a magnetic field.']
['What does this mean?', 'If nature is symmetrical, then perhaps a magnetic field can create a current.']

['How did this happen?', 'In 1831, some 12 years after the discovery that an electric current generates a magnetic field, English scientist Michael Faraday (1791–1862) and American scientist Joseph Henry (1797–1878) independently demonstrated that magnetic fields can produce currents.']

['What is the basic process of generating currents with magnetic fields called?', 'The basic process of generating currents with magnetic fields is called induction; this process is also called magnetic induction to distinguish it from charging by induction, which uses the electrostatic Coulomb force.']
['What is noteworthy about Changing magnetic fields?', 'When Faraday discovered what is now called Faraday’s law of induction, Queen Victoria asked him what possible use was electricity.']
['What was his response to the question?', '“Madam,” he replied, “What good is a baby?”']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Today, currents induced by magnetic fields are essential to our technological society.']

['What kind of technology is involved in the electric generator?', 'The electric generator—found in everything from automobiles to bicycles to nuclear power plants—uses magnetism to generate electric current.']

['What other devices do this?', 'Other devices that use magnetism to induce currents include pickup coils in electric guitars, transformers of every size, certain microphones, airport security gates, and damping mechanisms on sensitive chemical balances.']

['What is one of the topics we are studying today?', 'One experiment Faraday did to demonstrate magnetic induction was to move a bar magnet through a wire coil and measure the resulting electric current through the wire.']
['What was the experiment performed on?', 'A schematic of this experiment is shown in Figure 20.33.']
['What did the scientist find during this experiment?', 'He found that current is induced only when the magnet moves with respect to the coil.']
['What does that mean?', 'When the magnet is motionless with respect to the coil, no current is induced in the coil, as in Figure 20.33.']

['What happens when you move the magnet in the opposite direction?', 'In addition, moving the magnet in the opposite direction (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) or reversing the poles of the magnet (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) results in a current in the opposite direction.']
['What is Induced Electromotive Force?', 'If a current is induced in the coil, Faraday reasoned that there must be what he called an electromotive force pushing the charges through the coil.']
['What does this mean?', 'This interpretation turned out to be incorrect; instead, the external source doing the work of moving the magnet adds energy to the charges in the coil.']
['What is the energy added per unit charge?', 'The energy added per unit charge has units of volts, so the electromotive force is actually a potential.']
['What was the name of the force that he called an electromotive force?', 'Unfortunately, the name electromotive force stuck and with it the potential for confusing it with a real force.']

['What does the term electromotive force mean now?', 'For this reason, we avoid the term electromotive force and just use the abbreviation emf, which has the mathematical symbol  $$\\(\\varepsilon\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What is the rate at which energy is drawn from a source per unit current flowing through a circuit?', 'The emf may be defined as the rate at which energy is drawn from a source per unit current flowing through a circuit.']

['What is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit?', 'Thus, emf is the energy per unit charge added by a source, which contrasts with voltage, which is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit.']

['To determine the induced emf, what is the best way to determine the induced emf?', 'To understand why an emf is generated in a coil due to a moving magnet, consider Figure 20.34, which shows a bar magnet moving downward with respect to a wire loop.']
['What was the left hand image of?', 'Initially, seven magnetic field lines are going through the loop (see left-hand image).']

['What is the right hand image of?', 'Because the magnet is moving away from the coil, only five magnetic field lines are going through the loop after a short time  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  (see right-hand image).']
['What is the result of this experiment?', 'Thus, when a change occurs in the number of magnetic field lines going through the area defined by the wire loop, an emf is induced in the wire loop.']
['How is this derived?', 'Experiments such as this show that the induced emf is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic field.']
['What else did you mention?', 'Mathematically, we express this as']
['What is the purpose of this theory?', 'Note that magnetic field lines that lie in the plane of the wire loop do not actually pass through the loop, as shown by the left-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['How does the figure explain this?', 'In this figure, the arrow coming out of the loop is a vector whose magnitude is the area of the loop and whose direction is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.']

['What is the other figure?', 'In Figure 20.35, as the loop is rotated from  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$ to  $$\\({\\theta = 0{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}}\\text{,}\\)$$  the contribution of the magnetic field lines to the emf increases.']

['What does this do?', 'Thus, what is important in generating an emf in the wire loop is the component of the magnetic field that is perpendicular to the plane of the loop, which is  $$\\({B\\cos\\theta}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is this analogous to?', 'This is analogous to a sail in the wind.']
['How can a conducting loop be used to generate electricity?', 'Think of the conducting loop as the sail and the magnetic field as the wind.']

["Do you think this helps you understand the'sail in the wind' analogy?", 'To maximize the force of the wind on the sail, the sail is oriented so that its surface vector points in the same direction as the winds, as in the right-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['What happens when the sail is orientated differently?', 'When the sail is aligned so that its surface vector is perpendicular to the wind, as in the left-most loop in Figure 20.35, then the wind exerts no force on the sail.']
['What kind of field lines?', 'Another way to reduce the number of magnetic field lines that go through the conducting loop in Figure 20.35 is not to move the magnet but to make the loop smaller.']
['What happens when you make the loop smaller?', 'Experiments show that changing the area of a conducting loop in a stable magnetic field induces an emf in the loop.']
['What does the emf do?', 'Thus, the emf produced in a conducting loop is proportional to the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area']
['What is the formula for the magnetic field of a loop?', 'where  $$\\(B\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is the perpendicular magnetic field and A is the area of the loop.']
['What is an example of the product?', 'The product  $$\\(BA\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is very important.']

['What is the function of the product?', 'It is proportional to the number of magnetic field lines that pass perpendicularly through a surface of area A. Going back to our sail analogy, it would be proportional to the force of the wind on the sail.']
['What is the total amount of energy in a magnetic field?', 'It is called the magnetic flux and is represented by  $$\\(\\text{Φ}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of magnetic flux?', 'The unit of magnetic flux is the weber (Wb), which is magnetic field per unit area, or T/m2.']
['What is the Weber also?', 'The weber is also a volt second (Vs).']
['What is one important fact in the document?', 'Finally, for a coil made from N loops, the emf is N times stronger than for a single loop.']
['What is the emf induced by a changing magnetic field in a coil of N loops?', 'Thus, the emf induced by a changing magnetic field in a coil of N loops is']

['Where does this proportionality begin?', 'The last question to answer before we can change the proportionality into an equation is “In what direction does the current flow?” The Russian scientist Heinrich Lenz (1804–1865) explained that the current flows in the direction that creates a magnetic field that tries to keep the flux constant in the loop.']
['What is this proportionality used for?', 'For example, consider again Figure 20.34.']
['What happens to the current loops?', 'The motion of the bar magnet causes the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines that go through the loop to decrease.']
['Why does this happen?', 'Therefore, an emf is generated in the loop that drives a current in the direction that creates more upward-pointing magnetic field lines.']
['What direction does the current flow in?', 'By using the right-hand rule, we see that this current must flow in the direction shown in the figure.']

['Why does it try to keep the flux constant in the loop?', 'To express the fact that the induced emf acts to counter the change in the magnetic flux through a wire loop, a minus sign is introduced into the proportionality  $$\\(\\varepsilon \\propto {{\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}}\\text{.}\\)$$, which gives Faraday’s law of induction.']
['What is Lenz’s law?', 'Lenz’s law is very important.']
['What is the illustration of?', 'To better understand it, consider Figure 20.36, which shows a magnet moving with respect to a wire coil and the direction of the resulting current in the coil.']

['What happens when the north pole of the magnet approaches the coil?', 'In the top row, the north pole of the magnet approaches the coil, so the magnetic field lines from the magnet point toward the coil.']

['What else happens with Lenz’s law?', 'Thus, the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}} = B_{\\text{mag}}\\left( \\hat{x} \\right)\\)$$  pointing to the right increases in the coil.']

['Does it change in any other direction?', 'According to Lenz’s law, the emf produced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}} = B_{\\text{coil}}\\left( {- \\hat{x}} \\right)\\)$$  inside the coil pointing to the left.']
['What is the other important fact regarding Lenz’s law?', 'This will counter the increase in magnetic flux pointing to the right.']

['What else is interesting?', 'To see which way the current must flow, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil,}}\\)$$  and the current will flow in the direction indicated by curling your right fingers.']
['Are the images helpful?', 'This is shown by the image of the right hand in the top row of Figure 20.36.']
['Does this have an impact on the current flow?', 'Thus, the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(a).']
['What is the most significant thing I should know about this document?', 'In Figure 4(b), the direction in which the magnet moves is reversed.']
['What is the relation between field and direction?', 'In the coil, the right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  due to the moving magnet decreases.']

['What will happen if there is no direction?', 'Lenz’s law says that, to counter this decrease, the emf will drive a current that creates an additional right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}}\\)$$  in the coil.']

['Can you give me some examples of how to use a magnet?', 'Again, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field, and the current will flow in the direction indicate by curling your right fingers (Figure 4(b)).']
['What is the next step?', 'Finally, in Figure 4(c), the magnet is reversed so that the south pole is nearest the coil.']
['What happened then?', 'Now the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  points toward the magnet instead of toward the coil.']
['What is the other interesting thing about this part?', 'As the magnet approaches the coil, it causes the left-pointing magnetic field in the coil to increase.']

['What law tells us that the emf induced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field pointing to the right?', 'Lenz’s law tells us that the emf induced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field pointing to the right.']
['What will happen if the field is pointing to the right?', 'This will counter the increasing magnetic flux pointing to the left due to the magnet.']

['What is a rule that shows that the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(c)?', 'Using the right-hand rule again, as indicated in the figure, shows that the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(c).']
['What is the first thing you tell me about Blackbodies?', 'Our first story of curious significance begins with a T-shirt.']

['What color shirt would you wear on a hot day?', 'You are likely aware that wearing a tight black T-shirt outside on a hot day provides a significantly less comfortable experience than wearing a white shirt.']
['What does the black shirt have to do with the story?', 'Black shirts, as well as all other black objects, will absorb and re-emit a significantly greater amount of radiation from the sun.']
['How does this relate to what?', 'This shirt is a good approximation of what is called a blackbody.']
['What is a blackbody?', 'A perfect blackbody is one that absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy that is incident upon it.']
['What is a blackbody used for?', 'Imagine wearing a tight shirt that did this!']
['What did you study in your class?', 'This phenomenon is often modeled with quite a different scenario.']
['What did you study?', 'Imagine carving a small hole in an oven that can be heated to very high temperatures.']

['What happens if there is light around the hole?', 'As the temperature of this container gets hotter and hotter, the radiation out of this dark hole would increase as well, re-emitting all energy provided it by the increased temperature.']
['What happens to the hole as the temperature is increased?', 'The hole may even begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased.']
['What colors will it glow in as the temperature is increased?', 'Like a burner on your stove, the hole would glow red, then orange, then blue, as the temperature is increased.']
['What happens after a certain point?', 'In time, the hole would continue to glow but the light would be invisible to our eyes.']
['What does this container look like?', 'This container is a good model of a perfect blackbody.']

['What is the analysis of blackbodies that led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century?', 'It is the analysis of blackbodies that led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century.']
['What is one example of how you will study Blackbodies?', 'Take a moment to carefully examine Figure 21.2.']
['What will happen to the figure?', 'The more time you spend interpreting this figure, the closer you will be to understanding quantum physics!']
['What is the name of the figure in that chapter?', 'Figure 21.2 is a plot of radiation intensity against radiated wavelength.']
['What does this graph show?', 'In other words, it shows how the intensity of radiated light changes when a blackbody is heated to a particular temperature.']
['How did you figure this out?', 'It may help to just follow the bottom-most red line labeled 3,000 K, red hot.']
['What does the graph show?', 'The graph shows that when a blackbody acquires a temperature of 3,000 K, it radiates energy across the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What wavelength is it most intensely emitted at?', 'However, the energy is most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm.']
['What is the wavelength of 1000 nm?', 'This is in the infrared portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What other information can you provide?', 'While a body at this temperature would appear red-hot to our eyes, it would truly appear ‘infrared-hot’ if we were able to see the entire spectrum.']
['When the temperature of the gas is constant, radiated energy stays constant.', 'As temperature increases, the total amount of energy radiated increases.']
['What can we do in Figure 21.2 to visualize this?', 'This is shown by examining the area underneath each line.']
['What is the difference between red lines and blue lines?', 'Regardless of temperature, all red lines on the graph undergo a consistent pattern.']

['What is the intensity of electromagnetic radiation at one particular wavelength?', 'While electromagnetic radiation is emitted throughout the spectrum, the intensity of this radiation peaks at one particular wavelength.']
['What is the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity?', 'As the temperature changes, the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity changes.']
['What temperature is the highest heat of radiation at?', 'At 4,000 K, the radiation is most intense in the yellow-green portion of the spectrum.']

['At what temperature would the blackbody be white hot?', 'At 6,000 K, the blackbody would radiate white hot, due to intense radiation throughout the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What is significant about Figure 21.2?', 'Remember that white light is the emission of all visible colors simultaneously.']
['What color light is emitted?', 'As the temperature increases, the frequency of light providing the greatest intensity increases as well.']
['Does this mean that frequency is increasing?', 'Recall the equation  $$\\(v = f\\lambda.\\)$$']
['What happens to wavelength?', 'Because the speed of light is constant, frequency and wavelength are inversely related.']
['What can we infer from this?', 'This is verified by the leftward movement of the three red lines as temperature is increased.']

['What is the most important thing scientists do in science?', 'While in science it is important to categorize observations, theorizing as to why the observations exist is crucial to scientific advancement.']
['What are two theories that helped move scientific research forward?', 'It is questions like these that drove significant research at the turn of the twentieth century.']
['What was the question that Max Planck set in motion?', 'And within the context of these questions, Max Planck discovered something of tremendous importance.']

["What was the prevailing theory about Planck's revolution?", 'The prevailing theory at the time of Max Planck’s discovery was that intensity and frequency were related by the equation  $$\\(I = \\frac{2kT}{\\lambda^{2}}.\\)$$']

['What does this equation infer?', 'This equation, derived from classical physics and using wave phenomena, infers that as wavelength increases, the intensity of energy provided will decrease with an inverse-squared relationship.']
['What happens if the ratio of distance to wavelength is constant?', 'This relationship is graphed in Figure 21.3 and shows a troubling trend.']
['What was a troubling trend?', 'For starters, it should be apparent that the graph from this equation does not match the blackbody graphs found experimentally.']
['What does this graph reveal?', 'Additionally, it shows that for an object of any temperature, there should be an infinite amount of energy quickly emitted in the shortest wavelengths.']
['What should be done when theory and experimental results clash?', 'When theory and experimental results clash, it is important to re-evaluate both models.']
['What was the name of the theory that was found?', 'The disconnect between theory and reality was termed the ultraviolet catastrophe.']

["What was the Planck's Revolution?", 'Due to concerns over the ultraviolet catastrophe, Max Planck began to question whether another factor impacted the relationship between intensity and wavelength.']

['What factor, he posited, should affect the probability that short wavelength light would be emitted?', 'This factor, he posited, should affect the probability that short wavelength light would be emitted.']

['What would happen if the probability of short wavelength light were reduced?', 'Should this factor reduce the probability of short wavelength light, it would cause the radiance curve to not progress infinitely as in the classical theory, but would instead cause the curve to precipitate back downward as is shown in the 5,000 K, 4,000 K, and 3,000 K temperature lines of the graph in Figure 21.3.']

['What else is significant about the factor?', 'Planck noted that this factor, whatever it may be, must also be dependent on temperature, as the intensity decreases at lower and lower wavelengths as the temperature increases.']

['How did this change the view of physics?', 'The determination of this probability factor was a groundbreaking discovery in physics, yielding insight not just into light but also into energy and matter itself.']
['What was the consequence of this discovery?', 'It would be the basis for Planck’s 1918 Nobel Prize in Physics and would result in the transition of physics from classical to modern understanding.']
['What did Planck construct in an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor?', 'In an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor, Max Planck constructed a new theory.']

['What theory created the branch of physics called quantum mechanics?', 'This theory, which created the branch of physics called quantum mechanics, speculated that the energy radiated by the blackbody could exist only in specific numerical, or quantum, states.']

['How was this theory calculated?', 'This theory is described by the equation  $$\\(E = nhf,\\)$$  where n is any nonnegative integer (0, 1, 2, 3, …) and h is Planck’s constant, given by  $$\\(h = 6.626\\  \\times \\ 10^{-34}\\text']
['Is there a formula for the probabilities of these things?', '{J} \\cdot \\text{s},\\)$$  and f is frequency.']
["What is Planck's equation?", 'Through this equation, Planck’s probability factor can be more clearly understood.']
['What are the three ways light quantized?', 'Each frequency of light provides a specific quantized amount of energy.']

['What is the structure of the spectrum?', 'Low frequency light, associated with longer wavelengths would provide a smaller amount of energy, while high frequency light, associated with shorter wavelengths, would provide a larger amount of energy.']
['How is this a relationship?', 'For specified temperatures with specific total energies, it makes sense that more low frequency light would be radiated than high frequency light.']
['What is the relationship between the two?', 'To a degree, the relationship is like pouring coins through a funnel.']
['What is the analogy for the funnel?', 'More of the smaller pennies would be able to pass through the funnel than the larger quarters.']
['Why does this matter?', 'In other words, because the value of the coin is somewhat related to the size of the coin, the probability of a quarter passing through the funnel is reduced!']
['What would an increase in temperature signify?', 'Furthermore, an increase in temperature would signify the presence of higher energy.']
['What is the ultimate conclusion?', 'As a result, the greater amount of total blackbody energy would allow for more of the high frequency, short wavelength, energies to be radiated.']
['How does this affect the blackbody curve?', 'This permits the peak of the blackbody curve to drift leftward as the temperature increases, as it does from the 3,000 K to 4,000 K to 5,000 K values.']
['What is the next question?', 'Furthering our coin analogy, consider a wider funnel.']
['What would the wider funnel do?', 'This funnel would permit more quarters to pass through and allow for a reduction in concern about the probability factor.']

['What is the interplay between the predicted classical model and the quantum probability that creates the curve depicted in Figure 21.3?', 'In summary, it is the interplay between the predicted classical model and the quantum probability that creates the curve depicted in Figure 21.3.']
['What is the highest frequency?', 'Just as quarters have a higher currency denomination than pennies, higher frequencies come with larger amounts of energy.']

['Does anything else tie this to currency denomination?', 'However, just as the probability of a quarter passing through a fixed diameter funnel is reduced, so is the probability of a high frequency light existing in a fixed temperature object.']
['How does this help?', 'As is often the case in physics, it is the balancing of multiple incredible ideas that finally allows for better understanding.']
['What is the process of quantization?', 'It may be helpful at this point to further consider the idea of quantum states.']

['What are physical entities that are quantized?', 'Atoms, molecules, and fundamental electron and proton charges are all examples of physical entities that are quantized—that is, they appear only in certain discrete values and do not have every conceivable value.']
['What is a revolutionary concept?', 'On the macroscopic scale, this is not a revolutionary concept.']
['What are some examples of quantum states?', 'A standing wave on a string allows only particular harmonics described by integers.']

['Can you explain how quantum states are used in practical applications?', 'Going up and down a hill using discrete stair steps causes your potential energy to take on discrete values as you move from step to step.']
['What other examples do you have?', 'Furthermore, we cannot have a fraction of an atom, or part of an electron’s charge, or 14.33 cents.']
['What is the difference between a substructure and a whole?', 'Rather, everything is built of integral multiples of these substructures.']
['What did it mean?', 'That said, to discover quantum states within a phenomenon that science had always considered continuous would certainly be surprising.']

['Who discovered that energy was quantized on a small scale as well?', 'When Max Planck was able to use quantization to correctly describe the experimentally known shape of the blackbody spectrum, it was the first indication that energy was quantized on a small scale as well.']

['What was the discovery?', 'This discovery earned Planck the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918 and was such a revolutionary departure from classical physics that Planck himself was reluctant to accept his own idea.']

['What was the general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization greatly enhanced by?', 'The general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization was greatly enhanced by Einstein’s explanation of the photoelectric effect (discussed in the next section), which took energy quantization a step further.']
['What does the photoelectric effect do?', 'When light strikes certain materials, it can eject electrons from them.']
['What is the name of the effect that light (photo) produces electricity?', 'This is called the photoelectric effect, meaning that light (photo) produces electricity.']

['What are some other applications of the photoelectric effect?', 'One common use of the photoelectric effect is in light meters, such as those that adjust the automatic iris in various types of cameras.']
['What other uses are there?', 'Another use is in solar cells, as you probably have in your calculator or have seen on a rooftop or a roadside sign.']
['What do photovoltaic cells do?', 'These make use of the photoelectric effect to convert light into electricity for running different devices.']

['What are the Revolutionary Properties of the Photoelectric Effect?', 'When Max Planck theorized that energy was quantized in a blackbody radiator, it is unlikely that he would have recognized just how revolutionary his idea was.']

['Why did he say that?', 'Using tools similar to the light meter in Figure 21.5, it would take a scientist of Albert Einstein’s stature to fully discover the implications of Max Planck’s radical concept.']

['What is the Revolutionary Properties of the photoelectric effect?', 'Through careful observations of the photoelectric effect, Albert Einstein realized that there were several characteristics that could be explained only if EM radiation is itself quantized.']

['What was his explanation of the characteristics of the universe?', 'While these characteristics will be explained a bit later in this section, you can already begin to appreciate why Einstein’s idea is very important.']
['What does quantized mean?', 'It means that the apparently continuous stream of energy in an EM wave is actually not a continuous stream at all.']
['What is the EM wave composed of?', 'In fact, the EM wave itself is actually composed of tiny quantum packets of energy called photons.']
['What is E = hf?', 'where E is the energy of a photon of frequency f and h is Planck’s constant.']

["What is Planck's constant?", 'A beam from a flashlight, which to this point had been considered a wave, instead could now be viewed as a series of photons, each providing a specific amount of energy see Figure 21.6.']
['What is the light beam made of?', 'Furthermore, the amount of energy within each individual photon is based upon its individual frequency, as dictated by  $$\\(E = hf.\\)$$']

['How does the frequency determine the energy of photons?', 'As a result, the total amount of energy provided by the beam could now be viewed as the sum of all frequency-dependent photon energies added together.']

['Which of the following is not a type of variable?', 'Just as with Planck’s blackbody radiation, Einstein’s concept of the photon could take hold in the scientific community only if it could succeed where classical physics failed.']
['What was the photoelectric effect?', 'The photoelectric effect would be a key to demonstrating Einstein’s brilliance.']
['What type of property do we need to consider?', 'Consider the following five properties of the photoelectric effect.']

['What are these properties consistent with?', 'All of these properties are consistent with the idea that individual photons of EM radiation are absorbed by individual electrons in a material, with the electron gaining the photon’s energy.']
['What do these properties have in common?', 'Some of these properties are inconsistent with the idea that EM radiation is a simple wave.']

['Are there other properties that are important for the photoelectric effect?', 'For simplicity, let us consider what happens with monochromatic EM radiation in which all photons have the same energy hf.']
['What is the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface?', 'If we vary the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface, we find the following:']

['What can you tell me about the effect of frequency on the EM radiation?', 'For a given material, there is a threshold frequency f0 for the EM radiation below which no electrons are ejected, regardless of intensity.']
['What does the photon model explain?', 'Using the photon model, the explanation for this is clear.']
['What is the interaction between photons and electrons?', 'Individual photons interact with individual electrons.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'Thus if the energy of an individual photon is too low to break an electron away, no electrons will be ejected.']
['What is mentioned in the passage?', 'However, if EM radiation were a simple wave, sufficient energy could be obtained simply by increasing the intensity.']
['What happens when EM radiation falls on a material?', 'Once EM radiation falls on a material, electrons are ejected without delay.']

['What happens when an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron?', 'As soon as an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron, the electron is ejected.']

['What is required for sufficient energy to be deposited at the metal surface in order to eject an electron?', 'If the EM radiation were a simple wave, several minutes would be required for sufficient energy to be deposited at the metal surface in order to eject an electron.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'The number of electrons ejected per unit time is proportional to the intensity of the EM radiation and to no other characteristic.']
['What is the photon model?', 'High-intensity EM radiation consists of large numbers of photons per unit area, with all photons having the same characteristic energy, hf.']
['What is the result of increased photons per unit area?', 'The increased number of photons per unit area results in an increased number of electrons per unit area ejected.']
['What is the energy of ejected electrons?', 'If we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons, we find the following:']
['What is mentioned next?', 'The maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons is independent of the intensity of the EM radiation.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'Instead, as noted in point 3 above, increased intensity results in more electrons of the same energy being ejected.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'If EM radiation were a simple wave, a higher intensity could transfer more energy, and higher-energy electrons would be ejected.']

['What is the kinetic energy KE of an ejected electron equals the photon energy minus the binding energy BE of the electron in the specific material?', 'The kinetic energy KE of an ejected electron equals the photon energy minus the binding energy BE of the electron in the specific material.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'An individual photon can give all of its energy to an electron.']
['What is the photon’s energy used for?', 'The photon’s energy is partly used to break the electron away from the material.']
['What is the remainder of the energy?', 'The remainder goes into the ejected electron’s kinetic energy.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'In equation form, this is given by']

['What is the equation for the kinetic energy of the ejected electron?', 'where  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  is the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electron,  $$\\(hf\\)$$  is the photon’s energy, and BE is the binding energy of the electron to the particular material.']
['What does it tell us?', 'This equation explains the properties of the photoelectric effect quantitatively and demonstrates that BE is the minimum amount of energy necessary to eject an electron.']
['What is significant about this equation?', 'If the energy supplied is less than BE, the electron cannot be ejected.']
['What else did you learn about this equation?', 'The binding energy can also be written as  $$\\(BE = hf_{0},\\)$$  where  $$\\(f_{0}\\)$$  is the threshold frequency for the particular material.']
['What else was significant about this equation?', 'Figure 21.8 shows a graph of maximum  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  versus the frequency of incident EM radiation falling on a particular material.']
['What is the photoelectric effect?', 'While Einstein’s understanding of the photoelectric effect was a transformative discovery in the early 1900s, its presence is ubiquitous today.']

['What are some examples of how the photoelectric effect is applied?', 'If you have watched streetlights turn on automatically in response to the setting sun, stopped elevator doors from closing simply by putting your hands between them, or turned on a water faucet by sliding your hands near it, you are familiar with the electric eye, a name given to a group of devices that use the photoelectric effect for detection.']
['What can we learn about photoconductive cells?', 'All these devices rely on photoconductive cells.']
['What are photoconductive cells?', 'These cells are activated when light is absorbed by a semi-conductive material, knocking off a free electron.']
['When an electron knocks off a free electron, what happens?', 'When this happens, an electron void is left behind, which attracts a nearby electron.']
['What happens to the electron?', 'The movement of this electron, and the resultant chain of electron movements, produces a current.']
['What else does this current do?', 'If electron ejection continues, further holes are created, thereby increasing the electrical conductivity of the cell.']
['What happens as the current decreases?', 'This current can turn switches on and off and activate various familiar mechanisms.']
['What is one of the most significant applications of this effect?', 'One such mechanism takes place where you may not expect it.']
['What is it that makes a movie sound so good?', 'Next time you are at the movie theater, pay close attention to the sound coming out of the speakers.']
['How do they emit sound?', 'This sound is actually created using the photoelectric effect!']
['What is on the audiotape?', 'The audiotape in the projector booth is a transparent piece of film of varying width.']
['How is the film used?', 'This film is fed between a photocell and a bright light produced by an exciter lamp.']
['What happens when this light hits the photocell?', 'As the transparent portion of the film varies in width, the amount of light that strikes the photocell varies as well.']
['What does this do?', 'As a result, the current in the photoconductive circuit changes with the width of the filmstrip.']
['Does this create sound?', 'This changing current is converted to a changing frequency, which creates the soundtrack commonly heard in the theater.']
['Is there any other content in this chapter?', 'Although strange to consider, the answer to both questions is yes.']

['What is the most important thing to know about photons?', 'Despite the odd nature of photons, scientists prior to Einstein had long suspected that the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation shared properties with our more macroscopic particles.']
['What is the photoelectric effect?', 'This is no clearer than when considering the photoelectric effect, where photons knock electrons out of a substance.']
['What is the photoelectric effect?', 'While it is strange to think of a massless particle exhibiting momentum, it is now a well-established fact within the scientific community.']
['What is the figure that shows macroscopic evidence of photon momentum?', 'Figure 21.10 shows macroscopic evidence of photon momentum.']
['What is figure 21.10?', 'Figure 21.10 shows a comet with two prominent tails.']
['What are the composition of comet tails?', 'Comet tails are composed of gases and dust evaporated from the body of the comet and ionized gas.']
['What is interesting about the comet tails?', 'What most people do not know about the tails is that they always point away from the Sun rather than trailing behind the comet.']
['What can you tell me about the diagram?', 'This can be seen in the diagram.']
['What are some of the things that are important about photon momentum?', 'The evidence indicates that the dust particles of the comet are forced away from the Sun when photons strike them.']

['How do photons force the particles away?', 'Evidently, photons carry momentum in the direction of their motion away from the Sun, and some of this momentum is transferred to dust particles in collisions.']
['What happens when protons collide?', 'The blue tail is caused by the solar wind, a stream of plasma consisting primarily of protons and electrons evaporating from the corona of the Sun.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is conserved in quantum mechanics, just as it is in relativity and classical physics.']

['What is the Compton Effect?', 'Some of the earliest direct experimental evidence of this came from the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons in substances, a phenomenon discovered by American physicist Arthur H. Compton (1892–1962).']

['When did Compton discover the Compton Effect?', 'Around 1923, Compton observed that X-rays reflecting from materials had decreased energy and correctly interpreted this as being due to the scattering of the X-ray photons by electrons.']
['What is the particle that is involved in this collision?', 'This phenomenon could be handled as a collision between two particles—a photon and an electron at rest in the material.']
['What was the result of the collision?', 'After careful observation, it was found that both energy and momentum were conserved in the collision.']
['What did the article cover?', 'See Figure 21.11.']
['Who won the Nobel Prize for the Compton effect?', 'For the discovery of this conserved scattering, now known as the Compton effect, Arthur Compton was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1929.']
['What was determined by Louis de Broglie?', 'was determined by Louis de Broglie.']
['What is the de Broglie relation?', 'In this equation, called the de Broglie relation, h represents Planck’s constant and λ is the photon wavelength.']
['What is the characteristic of photon momentum?', 'We can see that photon momentum is small, since  $$\\(\\mathbf{p} = h/\\lambda.\\)$$  and h is very small.']
['Why does this matter?', 'It is for this reason that we do not ordinarily observe photon momentum.']
['What is a common observation?', 'Our mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them, except perhaps in cartoons.']

['What is photon momentum?', 'Compton saw the effects of photon momentum because he was observing X-rays, which have a small wavelength and a relatively large momentum, interacting with the lightest of particles, the electron.']
['What do we know about electromagnetic radiation?', 'We have long known that EM radiation is like a wave, capable of interference and diffraction.']
['What can light be modeled as?', 'We now see that light can also be modeled as particles—massless photons of discrete energy and momentum.']
['What is the particle wave duality?', 'We call this twofold nature the particle-wave duality, meaning that EM radiation has properties of both particles and waves.']
['How is this contradictory?', 'This may seem contradictory, since we ordinarily deal with large objects that never act like both waves and particles.']
['What are some examples of particles and waves?', 'An ocean wave, for example, looks nothing like a grain of sand.']

['What is the term for properties of the photon analogous to phenomena we can observe directly, on a macroscopic scale?', 'However, this so-called duality is simply a term for properties of the photon analogous to phenomena we can observe directly, on a macroscopic scale.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'See Figure 21.14.']

['Is there anything else we need to know?', 'If this term seems strange, it is because we do not ordinarily observe details on the quantum level directly, and our observations yield either particle-like or wave-like properties, but never both simultaneously.']

['What is the particle-wave duality?', 'Since we have a particle-wave duality for photons, and since we have seen connections between photons and matter in that both have momentum, it is reasonable to ask whether there is a particle-wave duality for matter as well.']
['Is there such a particle-wave duality for matter as well?', 'The answer, strangely, is yes.']
['What does this mean?', 'The consequences of this are tremendous, as particle-wave duality has been a constant source of scientific wonder during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.']
['What are the atoms?', 'While often taken for granted, our knowledge of the existence and structure of atoms is the result of centuries of contemplation and experimentation.']

['What was the earliest known speculation on the atom?', 'The earliest known speculation on the atom dates back to the fifth century B.C., when Greek philosophers Leucippus and Democritus contemplated whether a substance could be divided without limit into ever smaller pieces.']

['Whose ideas were more refined?', 'Since then, scientists such as John Dalton (1766–1844), Amadeo Avogadro (1776–1856), and Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) helped to discover the properties of that fundamental structure of matter.']

['What scientist helped with the theory of atoms?', 'While much could be written about any number of important scientific philosophers, this section will focus on the role played by Ernest Rutherford (1871–1937).']

['What did Rutherford discover?', 'Though his understanding of our most elemental matter is rooted in the success of countless prior investigations, his surprising discovery about the interior of the atom is most fundamental in explaining so many well-known phenomena.']
['What was the plum pudding model?', 'In the early 1900’s, the plum pudding model was the accepted model of the atom.']

['What did the model suggest?', 'Proposed in 1904 by J. J. Thomson, the model suggested that the atom was a spherical ball of positive charge, with negatively charged electrons scattered evenly throughout.']
['What was the model like?', 'In that model, the positive charges made up the pudding, while the electrons acted as isolated plums.']

['Why was it popular?', 'During its short life, the model could be used to explain why most particles were neutral, although with an unbalanced number of plums, electrically charged atoms could exist.']

['When was this experiment conducted?', 'When Ernest Rutherford began his gold foil experiment in 1909, it is unlikely that anyone would have expected that the plum pudding model would be challenged.']

["What was Rutherford's experiment?", 'However, using a radioactive source, a thin sheet of gold foil, and a phosphorescent screen, Rutherford would uncover something so great that he would later call it “the most incredible event that has ever happened to me in my life”[James, L. K. (1993).']
['Did he win any awards?', 'Nobel Laureates in Chemistry, 1901–1992.']
['Where was it published?', 'Washington, DC: American Chemical Society.]']
["What was Rutherford's experiment?", 'The experiment that Rutherford designed is shown in Figure 22.2.']

['What was the experiment about?', 'As you can see in, a radioactive source was placed in a lead container with a hole in one side to produce a beam of positively charged helium particles, called alpha particles.']
['What was the beam of alpha particles made up of?', 'Then, a thin gold foil sheet was placed in the beam.']
['What did the gold foil do when the high-energy alpha particles passed through it?', 'When the high-energy alpha particles passed through the gold foil, they were scattered.']

['What was observed from the bright spots they produced when they struck the phosphor screen?', 'The scattering was observed from the bright spots they produced when they struck the phosphor screen.']
['What was the plum pudding model?', 'The expectation of the plum pudding model was that the high-energy alpha particles would be scattered only slightly by the presence of the gold sheet.']

['What were the bowling pin analogy?', 'Because the energy of the alpha particles was much higher than those typically associated with atoms, the alpha particles should have passed through the thin foil much like a supersonic bowling ball would crash through a few dozen rows of bowling pins.']
['What was the deflection?', 'Any deflection was expected to be minor, and due primarily to the electrostatic Coulomb force between the alpha particles and the foil’s interior electric charges.']
['What did Rutherford say he discovered in the experiment?', 'However, the true result was nothing of the sort.']

['What were the results of the experiment?', 'While the majority of alpha particles passed through the foil unobstructed, Rutherford and his collaborators Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden found that alpha particles occasionally were scattered to large angles, and some even came back in the direction from which they came!']
['What was the result of Rutherford scattering?', 'The result, called Rutherford scattering, implied that the gold nuclei were actually very small when compared with the size of the gold atom.']

['How did Rutherford determine that?', 'As shown in Figure 22.3, the dense nucleus is surrounded by mostly empty space of the atom, an idea verified by the fact that only 1 in 8,000 particles was scattered backward.']
["What is Rutherford's Experiment?", 'Although the results of the experiment were published by his colleagues in 1909, it took Rutherford two years to convince himself of their meaning.']
['How did Rutherford feel about the discovery?', 'Rutherford later wrote: “It was almost as incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.']
['Why did Rutherford believe this?', 'On consideration, I realized that this scattering backwards ... [meant] ... the greatest part of the mass of the atom was concentrated in a tiny nucleus.”']

["When was Rutherford's analysis published?", 'In 1911, Rutherford published his analysis together with a proposed model of the atom, which was in part based on Geiger’s work from the previous year.']
['What was the model of the nucleus?', 'As a result of the paper, the size of the nucleus was determined to be about  $$\\(10^{-15}\\)$$  m, or 100,000 times smaller than the atom.']
["How did Rutherford's model impact physics?", 'That implies a huge density, on the order of  $$\\(10^{15}\\)$$  g/cm3, much greater than any macroscopic matter.']

['What did Rutherford discover with his experiment?', 'Based on the size and mass of the nucleus revealed by his experiment, as well as the mass of electrons, Rutherford proposed the planetary model of the atom.']
['What is the planetary model of the atom?', 'The planetary model of the atom pictures low-mass electrons orbiting a large-mass nucleus.']
['What other things did Rutherford suggest?', 'The sizes of the electron orbits are large compared with the size of the nucleus, and most of the atom is a vacuum.']
["What did Rutherford's model look like?", 'The model is analogous to how low-mass planets in our solar system orbit the large-mass Sun.']
['What is the force that causes the atom to vibrate?', 'In the atom, the attractive Coulomb force is analogous to gravitation in the planetary system (see Figure 22.4).']
["What is the significance of Max Planck's discovery?", 'In 1900, Max Planck recognized that all energy radiated from a source is emitted by atoms in quantum states.']
['What was the answer to question two?', 'The answer was first found by investigating the spectrum of light or emission spectrum produced when a gas is highly energized.']
['What is the first question?', 'Figure 22.5 shows how to isolate the emission spectrum of one such gas.']
['What is the figure 22.5 about?', 'The gas is placed in the discharge tube at the left, where it is energized to the point at which it begins to radiate energy or emit light.']
['What does this do?', 'The radiated light is channeled by a thin slit and then passed through a diffraction grating, which will separate the light into its constituent wavelengths.']
['What will happen to the separated light?', 'The separated light will then strike the photographic film on the right.']

['What do you want to learn about the atom?', 'To tie the unique signatures of emission spectra to the composition of the atom itself would require clever thinking.']

['Who first stated that limit to knowledge in 1929 as a result of his work on quantum mechanics and the wave characteristics of all particles?', 'It was Werner Heisenberg who first stated that limit to knowledge in 1929 as a result of his work on quantum mechanics and the wave characteristics of all particles (see Figure 22.14).']

['What is the uncertainty associated with?', 'Viewing the electron through the model of wave-particle duality, Heisenberg recognized that, because a wave is not located at one fixed point in space, there is an uncertainty associated with any electron’s position.']

['What is the nucleus?', 'The nucleus itself has spectacular characteristics.']

['What characteristic do nuclei have that causes their decay to emit radiations with energies millions of times greater than atomic energies?', 'For example, certain nuclei are unstable, and their decay emits radiations with energies millions of times greater than atomic energies.']
['What is known about the nucleus?', 'Some of the mysteries of nature, such as why the core of Earth remains molten and how the Sun produces its energy, are explained by nuclear phenomena.']
['Did they discover anything else about the nucleus?', 'The exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus has revealed new fundamental particles, forces, and conservation laws.']

['What is a proton?', 'At this point, you are likely familiar with the neutron and proton, the two fundamental particles that make up the nucleus of an atom.']

['What is the difference between neutron and proton?', 'Both particles have nearly the same mass, although the neutron is about two parts in 1,000 more massive.']

['What is this article about?', 'To more completely characterize nuclei, let us also consider two other important quantities: the atomic number and the mass number.']

['When was this discovered?', 'In 1896, the French physicist Antoine Henri Becquerel (1852–1908) noticed something strange.']

['What was he concerned about?', 'When a uranium-rich mineral called pitchblende was placed on a completely opaque envelope containing a photographic plate, it darkened spots on the photographic plate..']
['What did Becquerel do next?', 'Becquerel reasoned that the pitchblende must emit invisible rays capable of penetrating the opaque material.']

['Did he find out more about this?', 'Stranger still was that no light was shining on the pitchblende, which means that the pitchblende was emitting the invisible rays continuously without having any energy input!']

['What did scientists discover?', 'There is an apparent violation of the law of conservation of energy, one that scientists can now explain using Einstein’s famous equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What were other discoveries?', 'It was soon evident that Becquerel’s rays originate in the nuclei of the atoms and have other unique characteristics.']
['What is the chemical reaction of uranium?', 'To this point, most reactions you have studied have been chemical reactions, which are reactions involving the electrons surrounding the atoms.']
['What do Becquerel’s rays originate from?', 'However, two types of experimental evidence implied that Becquerel’s rays did not originate with electrons, but instead within the nucleus of an atom.']
['What is this material about?', 'First, the radiation is found to be only associated with certain elements, such as uranium.']
['What is the uranium radiation?', 'Whether uranium was in the form of an element or compound was irrelevant to its radiation.']

['What was the second piece of evidence that the radiation cannot be atomic?', 'The huge energy emitted during each event is the second piece of evidence that the radiation cannot be atomic.']

['What is the energy per event of nuclear radiation?', 'Nuclear radiation has energies on the order of 106 eV per event, which is much greater than typical atomic energies that are a few eV, such as those observed in spectra and chemical reactions, and more than ten times as high as the most energetic X-rays.']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle?', 'To answer those questions, it is necessary to look into the structure of the nucleus.']
['What is the structure of the nucleus?', 'Though it is perhaps surprising, you will find that many of the same principles that we observe on a macroscopic level still apply to the nucleus.']
['What is an important fact from the study material?', 'A variety of experiments indicate that a nucleus behaves something like a tightly packed ball of nucleons, as illustrated in Figure 22.17.']
['What are some other important things to know about the nucleus?', 'Those nucleons have large kinetic energies and, thus, move rapidly in very close contact.']
['What can be learned from the information?', 'Nucleons can be separated by a large force, such as in a collision with another nucleus, but strongly resist being pushed closer together.']

['What are the nucleons called?', 'That is what you expect if you pack nucleons so close that there is no empty space between them.']
['Why did they choose this number?', 'After all, the nucleus is very small and its protons, being positive, should exert tremendous repulsive forces on one another.']

['What is the other constant?', 'The answer is that a previously unknown force holds the nucleus together and makes it into a tightly packed ball of nucleons.']
['What is the force called?', 'This force is known as the strong nuclear force.']
['Can we predict the strength of the force?', 'The strong force has such a short range that it quickly fall to zero over a distance of only 10–15 meters.']
['How is the force like glue?', 'However, like glue, it is very strong when the nucleons get close to one another.']
["What is important about the nucleus' shape?", 'The balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces is what allows the nucleus to maintain its spherical shape.']

['What happens when the balance of the nuclear and electromagnetic forces is out of balance?', 'If, for any reason, the electromagnetic force should overcome the nuclear force, components of the nucleus would be projected outward, creating the very radiation that Becquerel discovered!']
['What happens to the nucleus when it breaks apart?', 'Understanding why the nucleus would break apart can be partially explained using Table 22.2.']
['What is the balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force?', 'The balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force is a tenuous one.']

['What is the strength of the strong nuclear force?', 'Recall that the attractive strong nuclear force exists between any two nucleons and acts over a very short range while the weaker repulsive electromagnetic force only acts between protons, although over a larger range.']

['What happens to the nucleus when it is out of balance?', 'Considering the interactions, an imperfect balance between neutrons and protons can result in a nuclear reaction, with the result of regaining equilibrium.']

['What happened in the unstable nucleus?', 'To regain stability, the nucleus needed to undergo a nuclear reaction called alpha (α) decay.']
['What is the act of emitting particles or energy from the nucleus called?', 'Radioactivity refers to the act of emitting particles or energy from the nucleus.']

['What did you find surprising?', 'That those terms share a root with the term radiation should not be too surprising, as they all relate to the transmission of energy.']

['What is the most common type of decay?', 'It is the most common type of decay and causes the nucleus to regain equilibrium between its two competing internal forces.']

['What is the resemblance between alpha decay and beta decay?', 'During alpha decay, the nucleus ejects two protons and two neutrons, allowing the strong nuclear force to regain balance with the repulsive electromagnetic force.']

['What will happen to the original nuclide?', 'By ejecting an alpha particle, the original nuclide decreases in atomic number.']
