['What happens to the Sun when its hydrogen is depleted?', 'Stars like the Sun are stable for billions of years, until a significant fraction of their hydrogen has been depleted.']
['What was the world like when fission was discovered in 1938?', 'The world was in political turmoil when fission was discovered in 1938.']
['What was the significance of this?', 'Compounding the troubles, the possibility of a self-sustained chain reaction was immediately recognized by leading scientists the world over.']
['What was the conceit?', 'The enormous energy known to be in nuclei, but considered inaccessible, now seemed to be available on a large scale.']

['What other important information is included in the material?', 'Within months after the announcement of the discovery of fission, Adolf Hitler banned the export of uranium from newly occupied Czechoslovakia.']
['Why did he ban the export?', 'It seemed that the possible military value of uranium had been recognized in Nazi Germany, and that a serious effort to build a nuclear bomb had begun.']
['Who were the scientists that developed nuclear weapons?', 'Alarmed scientists, many of whom fled Nazi Germany, decided to take action.']
['What was the famous person?', 'None was more famous or revered than Einstein.']

['What was the name of the famous person who helped get the American government to make a serious effort at constructing nuclear weapons as a matter of survival?', 'It was felt that his help was needed to get the American government to make a serious effort at constructing nuclear weapons as a matter of survival.']
['Who wrote the letter?', 'Leo Szilard, a Hungarian physicist who had emigrated to America, took a draft of a letter to Einstein, who, although a pacifist, signed the final version.']
['What was the letter for?', 'The letter was for President Franklin Roosevelt, warning of the German potential to build extremely powerful bombs of a new type.']
['When was the letter sent?', 'It was sent in August of 1939, just before the German invasion of Poland that marked the start of World War II.']
['What happened in 1941?', 'It was not until December 6, 1941, the day before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, that the United States made a massive commitment to building a nuclear bomb.']
['Who was building the bomb?', 'The top secret Manhattan Project was a crash program aimed at beating the Germans.']

['How long was the program?', 'It was carried out in remote locations, such as Los Alamos, New Mexico, whenever possible, and eventually came to cost billions of dollars and employ the efforts of more than 100,000 people.']
['Who was chosen to head the project?', 'J. Robert Oppenheimer (1904–1967), a talented physicist, was chosen to head the project.']

['What did Enrico Fermi and his group accomplish in December 1942?', 'The first major step was made by Enrico Fermi and his group in December 1942, when they completed the first self-sustaining nuclear reactor.']
['What happened after the first atomic pile was built?', 'This first atomic pile, built in a squash court at the University of Chicago, proved that a fission chain reaction was possible.']
['What was the Manhattan Project?', 'Plutonium was recognized as easier to fission with neutrons and, hence, a superior fission material very early in the Manhattan Project.']
['What was learned about the Manhattan Project?', 'Plutonium availability was uncertain, and so a uranium bomb was developed simultaneously.']
['What did the project teach us?', 'Figure 22.32 shows a gun-type bomb, which takes two subcritical uranium masses and shoots them together.']

['What else did you find interesting about the article?', 'To get an appreciable yield, the critical mass must be held together by the explosive charges inside the cannon barrel for a few microseconds.']
['What was the device made of?', 'Since the buildup of the uranium chain reaction is relatively slow, the device to bring the critical mass together can be relatively simple.']
['What is the neutron source used for?', 'Owing to the fact that the rate of spontaneous fission is low, a neutron source is at the center the assembled critical mass.']
['What is the most important thing that happened in this section?', 'Plutonium’s special properties necessitated a more sophisticated critical mass assembly, shown schematically in Figure 22.33.']

['What is a sophisticated critical mass assembly?', 'A spherical mass of plutonium is surrounded by shaped charges (high explosives that focus their blast) that implode the plutonium, crushing it into a smaller volume to form a critical mass.']

['What can be done with an implosion technique?', 'The implosion technique is faster and more effective, because it compresses three-dimensionally rather than one-dimensionally as in the gun-type bomb.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Again, a neutron source is included to initiate the chain reaction.']
['What was the first nuclear weapon built?', 'Owing to its complexity, the plutonium bomb needed to be tested before there could be any attempt to use it.']

['Where did the Trinity test occur?', 'On July 16, 1945, the test named Trinity was conducted in the isolated Alamogordo Desert in New Mexico, about 200 miles south of Los Alamos (see Figure 22.34).']
['What was the result of these tests?', 'A new age had begun.']
['What was the yield of the Trinity device?', 'The yield of the Trinity device was about 10 kilotons (kT), the equivalent of 5,000 of the largest conventional bombs.']

['When did the atomic bomb first drop?', 'Although Germany surrendered on May 7, 1945, Japan had been steadfastly refusing to surrender for many months, resulting large numbers of civilian and military casualties.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Invasion plans by the Allies estimated a million casualties of their own and untold losses of Japanese lives.']
['Did they try to stop the bomb from dropping?', 'The bomb was viewed as a way to end the war.']
['Who had first commissioned the bomb?', 'The first bomb used was a gun-type uranium bomb dropped on Hiroshima on August 6 by the United States.']
['How many people were killed by the bomb?', 'Its yield of about 15 kT destroyed the city and killed an estimated 80,000 people, with 100,000 more being seriously injured.']
['What was the second bomb used for?', 'The second bomb was an implosion-type plutonium bomb dropped on Nagasaki only three days later.']

['How many people did the bomb kill?', 'Its 20-kT yield killed at least 50,000 people, something less than Hiroshima because of the hilly terrain and the fact that it was a few kilometers off target.']
['What was the plan for the bombing of Japan?', 'The Japanese were told that one bomb a week would be dropped until they surrendered unconditionally, which they did on August 14.']
['Did the United States use more than one bomb in the war?', 'In actuality, the United States had only enough plutonium for one more bomb, as yet unassembled.']

['What did scientists do to produce weapons?', 'Knowing that fusion produces several times more energy per kilogram of fuel than fission, some scientists pursued the idea of constructing a fusion bomb.']

['Did the US produce the first fusion bomb?', 'The first such bomb was detonated by the United States several years after the first fission bombs, on October 31, 1952, at Eniwetok Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.']
['What was the yield of the bomb?', 'It had a yield of 10 megatons (MT), about 670 times that of the fission bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.']

['What other countries did this?', 'The Soviet Union followed with a fusion device of its own in August 1953, and a weapons race, beyond the aim of this text to discuss, continued until the end of the Cold War.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Figure 22.35 shows a simple diagram of how a thermonuclear bomb is constructed.']
['What is the difference between a fission bomb and a fusion bomb?', 'A fission bomb is exploded next to fusion fuel in the solid form of lithium deuteride.']

['What happens after the explosion?', 'Before the shock wave blows it apart,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays heat and compress the fuel, and neutrons create tritium through the reaction  $$\\(n +^{6}\\text{L}\\text{i}\\rightarrow^{3}\\text{H} +^{4}\\text{H}\\text{e}\\)$$ .']
['What is the next section?', 'Additional fusion and fission fuels are enclosed in a dense shell of  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$ .']

['What is the shell for?', 'At the same time that the uranium shell reflects the neutrons back into the fuel to enhance its fusion, the fast-moving neutrons cause the plentiful and inexpensive  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$  to fission, part of what allows thermonuclear bombs to be so large.']
['What is the key aspect of this material?', 'Of course, not all applications of nuclear physics are as destructive as the weapons described above.']
['What other applications of physics are used?', 'Hundreds of nuclear fission power plants around the world attest to the fact that controlled fission is both practical and economical.']
['What is the purpose of nuclear power?', 'Given growing concerns over global warming, nuclear power is often seen as a viable alternative to energy derived from fossil fuels.']
['What was the purpose of medical applications?', 'Applications of nuclear physics have become an integral part of modern life.']

['What types of medical applications have they become?', 'From the bone scan that detects one cancer to the radioiodine treatment that cures another, nuclear radiation has diagnostic and therapeutic effects on medicine.']
['What other types of medical imaging techniques do we learn about?', 'A host of medical imaging techniques employ nuclear radiation.']
['What are some of the advantages of using nuclear radiation?', 'First,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  radiation can easily penetrate tissue; hence, it is a useful probe to monitor conditions inside the body.']

['What other benefits does it have?', 'Second, nuclear radiation depends on the nuclide and not on the chemical compound it is in, so that a radioactive nuclide can be put into a compound designed for specific purposes.']
['What is used to create it?', 'When that is done, the compound is said to be tagged.']
['What are some of the uses of tagged compounds?', 'A tagged compound used for medical purposes is called a radiopharmaceutical.']
['What can radiopharmaceuticals be used for?', 'Radiation detectors external to the body can determine the location and concentration of a radiopharmaceutical to yield medically useful information.']
['What are some examples of using this?', 'For example, certain drugs are concentrated in inflamed regions of the body, and their locations can aid diagnosis and treatment as seen in Figure 22.37.']

['What other applications can you think of?', 'Another application utilizes a radiopharmaceutical that the body sends to bone cells, particularly those that are most active, to detect cancerous tumors or healing points.']
['What can be done with the information?', 'Images can then be produced of such bone scans.']
['What other uses can you give me?', 'Clever use of radioisotopes determines the functioning of body organs, such as blood flow, heart muscle activity, and iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.']

['What is an example of a radioactive substance being used in medicine?', 'For instance, a radioactive form of iodine can be used to monitor the thyroid, a radioactive thallium salt can be used to follow the blood stream, and radioactive gallium can be used for cancer imaging.']
['What is one thing that you learned in this section?', 'Once a radioactive compound has been ingested, a device like that shown in Figure 22.38 is used to monitor nuclear activity.']
['What type of device is used to detect a gamma ray?', 'The device, called an Anger camera or gamma camera uses a piece of lead with holes bored through it.']
['What is the second device used?', 'The gamma rays are redirected through the collimator to narrow their beam, and are then interpreted using a device called a scintillator.']
['What does this device do?', 'The computer analysis of detector signals produces an image.']

['What are the drawbacks of this detection method?', 'One of the disadvantages of this detection method is that there is no depth information (i.e., it provides a two-dimensional view of the tumor as opposed to a three-dimensional view), because radiation from any location under that detector produces a signal.']

['What is the most important aspect of Medical Imaging?', 'Single-photon-emission computer tomography (SPECT) used in conjunction with a CT scanner improves on the process carried out by the gamma camera.']
['What is the SPECT?', 'Figure 22.39 shows a patient in a circular array of SPECT detectors that may be stationary or rotated, with detector output used by a computer to construct a detailed image.']
['What type of images are obtained with this technique?', 'The spatial resolution of this technique is poor, but the three-dimensional image created results in a marked improvement in contrast.']
['What kind of image is it?', 'Positron emission tomography (or PET) scans utilize images produced by  $$\\(\\beta^{+}\\)$$  emitters.']
['What is the role of the positron?', 'When the emitted positron β+ encounters an electron, mutual annihilation occurs, producing two γ rays.']

['What do the two rays do?', 'Those  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays have identical 0.511 MeV energies (the energy comes from the destruction of an electron or positron mass) and they move directly away from each other, allowing detectors to determine their point of origin accurately (as shown in Figure 22.40).']

['What else does the PET scan consist of?', 'It requires detectors on opposite sides to simultaneously (i.e., at the same time) detect photons of 0.511 MeV energy and utilizes computer imaging techniques similar to those in SPECT and CT scans.']
['What is the role of PET?', 'PET is used extensively for diagnosing brain disorders.']
['What does it note?', 'It can note decreased metabolism in certain regions that accompany Alzheimer’s disease.']
['What can PET be used to check?', 'PET can also locate regions in the brain that become active when a person carries out specific activities, such as speaking, closing his or her eyes, and so on.']
['What are the biological effects of ionizing radiation?', 'We hear many seemingly contradictory things about the biological effects of ionizing radiation.']
['What are the effects contradictory?', 'It can cause cancer, burns, and hair loss, and yet it is used to treat and even cure cancer.']
['What is the underlying simplicity in nature?', 'Once again, there is an underlying simplicity in nature, even in complicated biological organisms.']

['What is the underlying simplicity of ionizing radiation?', 'All the effects of ionizing radiation on biological tissue can be understood by knowing that ionizing radiation affects molecules within cells, particularly DNA molecules.']
['What else did you find out about the study material?', 'Let us take a brief look at molecules within cells and how cells operate.']

['What else do you find out about cells?', 'Cells have long, double-helical DNA molecules containing chemical patterns called genetic codes that govern the function and processes undertaken by the cells.']
['What happens if the dna is damaged?', 'Damage to DNA consists of breaks in chemical bonds or other changes in the structural features of the DNA chain, leading to changes in the genetic code.']
['How much damage can happen to DNA per cell per day?', 'In human cells, we can have as many as a million individual instances of damage to DNA per cell per day.']

['What is the repair ability of DNA vital for maintaining?', 'The repair ability of DNA is vital for maintaining the integrity of the genetic code and for the normal functioning of the entire organism.']
['What happens to a cell with a damaged ability to repair DNA?', 'A cell with a damaged ability to repair DNA, which could have been induced by ionizing radiation, can do one of the following:']
['What does senescence cause?', 'The cell can go into an irreversible state of dormancy, known as senescence.']
['What is cell death called?', 'The cell can commit suicide, known as programmed cell death.']
['What causes a tumor?', 'The cell can go into unregulated cell division, leading to tumors and cancers.']

['What does the body do to ionizing radiation?', 'Since ionizing radiation damages the DNA, ionizing radiation has its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce, including most types of cancer.']
['Why does ionizing radiation have its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce?', 'Thus, cancer cells are more sensitive to radiation than normal cells and can be killed by it easily.']
['What is the cause of cancer?', 'Cancer is characterized by a malfunction of cell reproduction, and can also be caused by ionizing radiation.']
['How can ionizing radiation cause cancer?', 'There is no contradiction to say that ionizing radiation can be both a cure and a cause.']
['Why is radiotherapy so effective against cancer?', 'Radiotherapy is effective against cancer because cancer cells reproduce rapidly and, consequently, are more sensitive to radiation.']

['To make the dose for cancer cells as high as possible while limiting the dose for normal cells, what is the central problem in radiotherapy?', 'The central problem in radiotherapy is to make the dose for cancer cells as high as possible while limiting the dose for normal cells.']

['What is the ratio of abnormal cells killed to normal cells killed called?', 'The ratio of abnormal cells killed to normal cells killed is called the therapeutic ratio, and all radiotherapy techniques are designed to enhance that ratio.']
['What other techniques are used to enhance that ratio?', 'Radiation can be concentrated in cancerous tissue by a number of techniques.']
['What type of techniques are used for well-defined tumors?', 'One of the most prevalent techniques for well-defined tumors is a geometric technique shown in Figure 22.41.']
['How does the technique work?', 'A narrow beam of radiation is passed through the patient from a variety of directions with a common crossing point in the tumor.']
['What is the advantage of this technique?', 'The technique concentrates the dose in the tumor while spreading it out over a large volume of normal tissue.']
['What are the uses of radiation therapy?', 'Another use of radiation therapy is through radiopharmaceuticals.']
['What are radiopharmaceuticals used for?', 'Cleverly, radiopharmaceuticals are used in cancer therapy by tagging antibodies with radioisotopes.']
['What do those antibodies come from?', 'Those antibodies are extracted from the patient, cultured, loaded with a radioisotope, and then returned to the patient.']
['What happens after returning those antibodies?', 'The antibodies are then concentrated almost entirely in the tissue they developed to fight, thus localizing the radiation in abnormal tissue.']
['What kind of iodine is used to fight thyroid cancer?', 'This method is used with radioactive iodine to fight thyroid cancer.']

['What are the side effects of radiotherapy?', 'While the therapeutic ratio can be quite high for such short-range radiation, there can be a significant dose for organs that eliminate radiopharmaceuticals from the body, such as the liver, kidneys, and bladder.']
['What is the technique limited by?', 'As with most radiotherapy, the technique is limited by the tolerable amount of damage to the normal tissue.']
['What was Radiation Dosage?', 'To quantitatively discuss the biological effects of ionizing radiation, we need a radiation dose unit that is directly related to those effects.']
['What are the effects of radiation on a biological organism?', 'To do define such a unit, it is important to consider both the biological organism and the radiation itself.']
['What is the definition of Radiation dose?', 'Knowing that the amount of ionization is proportional to the amount of deposited energy, we define a radiation dose unit called the rad.']
['What is the Radiation Dosage unit?', 'It 1/100 of a joule of ionizing energy deposited per kilogram of tissue, which is']
['How much dose would an affected tissue receive if it was exposed to a certain amount of radium?', 'and the unaffected tissue would have a zero rad dose.']
['How do you calculate radiation doses?', 'When calculating radiation doses, you divide the energy absorbed by the mass of affected tissue.']
['What else do you need to know about calculating radiation doses?', 'You must specify the affected region, such as the whole body or forearm in addition to giving the numerical dose in rads.']
['What is the significance of 1 rad?', 'Although the energy per kilogram in 1 rad is small, it can still have significant effects.']
['What is another significant factor?', 'Since only a few eV cause ionization, just 0.01 J of ionizing energy can create a huge number of ion pairs and have an effect at the cellular level.']

['What else did you learn about this unit?', 'The effects of ionizing radiation may be directly proportional to the dose in rads, but they also depend on the type of radiation and the type of tissue.']

['What does type of radiation refer to?', 'That is, for a given dose in rads, the effects depend on whether the radiation is  $$\\(\\alpha\\)$$,  $$\\(\\beta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$, X-ray, or some other type of ionizing radiation.']

['What is the relative biological effectiveness (RBE) relating to the amount of biological damage that can occur from a given type of radiation?', 'The relative biological effectiveness (RBE) relates to the amount of biological damage that can occur from a given type of radiation and is given in Table 22.4 for several types of ionizing radiation.']
['What dose units are used?', 'A final dose unit more closely related to the effect of radiation on biological tissue is called the roentgen equivalent man, or rem.']

['What is the rem defined as?', 'A combination of all factors mentioned previously, the roentgen equivalent man is defined to be the dose in rads multiplied by the relative biological effectiveness.']
['What are the large-scale effects of radiation on humans?', 'The large-scale effects of radiation on humans can be divided into two categories: immediate effects and long-term effects.']
['What is an immediate effect characterized as?', 'Table 22.5 gives the immediate effects of whole-body exposures received in less than one day.']
['What is the difference between a long-term effect and a short-term effect?', 'If the radiation exposure is spread out over more time, greater doses are needed to cause the effects listed.']
['How does the dose impact a person?', 'Any dose less than 10 rem is called a low dose, a dose 10 to 100 rem is called a moderate dose, and anything greater than 100 rem is called a high dose.']
['What are the four basic forces of the universe?', 'Despite the apparent complexity within the universe, there remain just four basic forces.']
['What are the four basic forces?', 'These forces are responsible for all interactions known to science: from the very small to the very large to those that we experience in our day-to-day lives.']

['What do the four basic forces describe?', 'These forces describe the movement of galaxies, the chemical reactions in our laboratories, the structure within atomic nuclei, and the cause of radioactive decay.']
['What do they describe?', 'They describe the true cause behind familiar terms like friction and the normal force.']
['Are the four forces known as fundamental?', 'These four basic forces are known as fundamental because they alone are responsible for all observations of forces in nature.']
['What are the four fundamental forces?', 'The four fundamental forces are gravity, electromagnetism, weak nuclear force, and strong nuclear force.']
['What are the forces that are most familiar to us?', 'The gravitational force is most familiar to us because it describes so many of our common observations.']
['What is the gravitational force used for?', 'It explains why a dropped ball falls to the ground and why our planet orbits the Sun.']
['What can matter do for us?', 'It gives us the property of weight and determines much about the motion of objects in our daily lives.']

['How does this force affect our daily lives?', 'Because gravitational force acts between all objects of mass and has the ability to act over large distances, the gravitational force can be used to explain much of what we observe and can even describe the motion of objects on astronomical scales!']

['What are some of the challenges that scientists are facing to fully understand gravitational force?', 'That said, gravity is incredibly weak compared to the other fundamental forces and is the weakest of all of the fundamental forces.']
['How is gravity different than the other forces?', 'Consider this:']
['What is the mass of the Earth needed to hold an iron nail to the ground?', 'The entire mass of Earth is needed to hold an iron nail to the ground.']
['What can be done with this force?', 'Yet with a simple magnet, the force of gravity can be overcome, allowing the nail to accelerate upward through space.']
['What are some of the functions of an electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is responsible for both electrostatic interactions and the magnetic force seen between bar magnets.']
['What is the coulomb force?', 'When focusing on the electrostatic relationship between two charged particles, the electromagnetic force is known as the coulomb force.']

['What is the other function of the electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is an important force in the chemical and biological sciences, as it is responsible for molecular connections like ionic bonding and hydrogen bonding.']

['What is the force behind the common physics forces of friction and the normal force?', 'Additionally, the electromagnetic force is behind the common physics forces of friction and the normal force.']
['What is the relationship between these forces?', 'Like the gravitational force, the electromagnetic force is an inverse square law.']
['Can you tell me what the inverse square law says?', 'However, the electromagnetic force does not exist between any two objects of mass, only those that are charged.']
['What is the force that causes the structure of an atom to change?', 'When considering the structure of an atom, the electromagnetic force is somewhat apparent.']
['What is the force that holds the electrons in place?', 'After all, the electrons are held in place by an attractive force from the nucleus.']
['What is the Coulomb force between the protons?', 'After all, if all protons are positive, it makes sense that the coulomb force between the protons would repel the nucleus apart immediately.']
['What is the neutron force?', 'Scientists theorized that another force must exist within the nucleus to keep it together.']

['Why do they believe that?', 'They further theorized that this nuclear force must be significantly stronger than gravity, which has been observed and measured for centuries, and also stronger than the electromagnetic force, which would cause the protons to want to accelerate away from each other.']
['What is the strong nuclear force?', 'The strong nuclear force is an attractive force that exists between all nucleons.']

['What is the strongest force at short ranges?', 'This force, which acts equally between proton-proton connections, proton-neutron connections, and neutron-neutron connections, is the strongest of all forces at short ranges.']
['What does the diameter of a single proton mean?', 'However, at a distance of 10–13 cm, or the diameter of a single proton, the force dissipates to zero.']
['What is the diameter of a single proton?', 'If the nucleus is large (it has many nucleons), then the distance between each nucleon could be much larger than the diameter of a single proton.']
['What is the weak nuclear force responsible for?', 'The weak nuclear force is responsible for beta decay, as seen in the equation  $$\\[{}_{Z}^{A}X_{N}\\operatorname{~\\rightarrow~}\\']
['What is the equation for beta decay?', '~_{Z + 1}^{A}Y_{N–1}~ + ~e~ + ~v.\\]$$  Recall that beta decay is when a beta particle is ejected from an atom.']
['What is the strong nuclear force?', 'In order to accelerate away from the nucleus, the particle must be acted on by a force.']
['Who was the first to visualize the force?', 'Enrico Fermi was the first to envision this type of force.']
['What else did he understand about the force?', 'While this force is appropriately labeled, it remains stronger than the gravitational force.']
['What is the ionizing radiation?', 'However, its range is even smaller than that of the strong force, as can be seen in Table 23.1.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'The weak nuclear force is more important than it may appear at this time, as will be addressed when we discuss quarks.']

['What was the concept of forces acting over a distance had greatly troubled particle physicists?', 'Just as it troubled Einstein prior to formulating the gravitational field theory, the concept of forces acting over a distance had greatly troubled particle physicists.']

["What was Yukawa's contribution to particle physics?", 'These mysterious interactions were first considered by Hideki Yukawa in 1935 and laid the foundation for much of what we now understand about particle physics.']
['What was Yukawa’s focus?', 'Hideki Yukawa’s focus was on the strong nuclear force and, in particular, its incredibly short range.']
['What was his idea?', 'His idea was a blend of particles, relativity, and quantum mechanics that was applicable to all four forces.']

['What is his model?', 'Yukawa proposed that the nuclear force is actually transmitted by the exchange of particles, called carrier particles, and that what we commonly refer to as the force’s field consists of these carrier particles.']

['What is the particle called that is exchanged between nucleons?', 'Specifically for the strong nuclear force, Yukawa proposed that a previously unknown particle, called a pion, is exchanged between nucleons, transmitting the force between them.']
['What is a particle called a pion?', 'Figure 23.3 illustrates how a pion would carry a force between a proton and a neutron.']

['What does Yukawa’s strong force have to do with it?', 'In Yukawa’s strong force, the carrier particle is assumed to be transmitted at the speed of light and is continually transferred between the two nucleons shown.']
['What other work does Yukawa do?', 'The particle that Yukawa predicted was finally discovered within cosmic rays in 1947.']

['What is the name of the particle that is smaller than a nucleon but larger than an electron?', 'Its name, the pion, stands for pi meson, where meson means medium mass; it’s a medium mass because it is smaller than a nucleon but larger than an electron.']

['What is the name of the field that Yukawa launched?', 'Yukawa launched the field that is now called quantum chromodynamics, and the carrier particles are now called gluons due to their strong binding power.']
['What is the reason for the particle name change?', 'The reason for the change in the particle name will be explained when quarks are discussed later in this section.']
['What is the strongest force with a carrier particle?', 'As you may assume, the strong force is not the only force with a carrier particle.']
['What is the weakest force?', 'Nuclear decay from the weak force also requires a particle transfer.']
['What are the particle particles named?', 'In the weak force are the following three: the weak negative carrier, W–; the weak positive carrier, W+; and the zero charge carrier, Z0.']

['What did Fermi infer?', 'As we will see, Fermi inferred that these particles must carry mass, as the total mass of the products of nuclear decay is slightly larger than the total mass of all reactants after nuclear decay.']
['What is the carrier particle for the electromagnetic force?', 'The carrier particle for the electromagnetic force is, not surprisingly, the photon.']

['What can a photon be used for?', 'After all, just as a lightbulb can emit photons from a charged tungsten filament, the photon can be used to transfer information from one electrically charged particle to another.']
['What is the proposed carrier particle for gravity?', 'Finally, the graviton is the proposed carrier particle for gravity.']
['Is the graviton currently being researched?', 'While it has not yet been found, scientists are currently looking for evidence of its existence (see Boundless Physics: Searching for the Graviton).']
['What do you find interesting about Figure 23.4?', 'Figure 23.4 shows a virtual photon transmitted from one positively charged particle to another.']
['What is a particle called that is not a photon?', 'The transmitted photon is referred to as a virtual particle because it cannot be directly observed while transmitting the force.']
['What is Figure 23.5?', 'Figure 23.5 shows a way of graphing the exchange of a virtual photon between the two positively charged particles.']

['What is a graph of time versus position called?', 'This graph of time versus position is called a Feynman diagram, after the brilliant American physicist Richard Feynman (1918–1988), who developed it.']
['What is the purpose of a Feynman diagram?', 'The Feynman diagram should be read from the bottom up to show the movement of particles over time.']

['What can you tell me about the diagram?', 'In it, you can see that the left proton is propelled leftward from the photon emission, while the right proton feels an impulse to the right when the photon is received.']

['What is the name of the person who developed the Feynman diagram?', 'In addition to the Feynman diagram, Richard Feynman was one of the theorists who developed the field of quantum electrodynamics (QED), which further describes electromagnetic interactions on the submicroscopic scale.']
['Did he receive any awards for this?', 'For this work, he shared the 1965 Nobel Prize with Julian Schwinger and S.I. Tomonaga.']
['What other information about the diagram did you find interesting?', 'A Feynman diagram explaining the strong force interaction hypothesized by Yukawa can be seen in Figure 23.6.']
['What does the diagram show?', 'Here, you can see the change in particle type due to the exchange of the pi meson.']

['What does the relative mass of the listed carrier particles tell us about the four fundamental forces?', 'The relative masses of the listed carrier particles describe something valuable about the four fundamental forces, as can be seen in Table 23.2.']

['How is this determined?', 'W bosons (consisting of  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  bosons) and Z bosons ( $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons), carriers of the weak nuclear force, are nearly 1,000 times more massive than pions, carriers of the strong nuclear force.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'Simultaneously, the distance that the weak nuclear force can be transmitted is approximately  $$\\(\\frac{1}{1,000}\\)$$  times the strong force transmission distance.']

['What is the next topic of discussion?', 'Unlike carrier particles, which have a limited range, the photon is a massless particle that has no limit to the transmission distance of the electromagnetic force.']
['What does this relationship lead scientists to understand?', 'This relationship leads scientists to understand that the yet-unfound graviton is likely massless as well.']
['What is this study material about?', 'Before looking at all the particles that make up our universe, let us first examine some of the machines that create them.']

['What is the fundamental process in creating unknown particles?', 'The fundamental process in creating unknown particles is to accelerate known particles, such as protons or electrons, and direct a beam of them toward a target.']
['What is the target?', 'Collisions with target nuclei provide a wealth of information, such as information obtained by Rutherford in the gold foil experiment.']
['What can be done with accelerators?', 'If the energy of the incoming particles is large enough, new matter can even be created in the collision.']
['How does the mass energy equivalence work?', 'The more energy input or ΔE, the more matter m can be created, according to mass energy equivalence  $$\\(m = \\text{Δ}E/c^{2}\\)$$ .']

['What limits are placed on what can occur by known conservation laws?', 'Limitations are placed on what can occur by known conservation laws, such as conservation of mass-energy, momentum, and charge.']
['What else is limited by known laws?', 'Even more interesting are the unknown limitations provided by nature.']
['What are the unknown limitations?', 'While some expected reactions do occur, others do not, and still other unexpected reactions may appear.']
['What happens when there are unexpected reactions?', 'New laws are revealed, and the vast majority of what we know about particle physics has come from accelerator laboratories.']
['What is most interesting about accelerators?', 'It is the particle physicist’s favorite indoor sport.']
['What was the first accelerator developed?', 'Our earliest model of a particle accelerator comes from the Van de Graaff generator.']
['What was the device used for?', 'The relatively simple device, which you have likely seen in physics demonstrations, can be manipulated to produce potentials as great as 50 million volts.']

['What did it do?', 'While these machines do not have energies large enough to produce new particles, analysis of their accelerated ions was instrumental in exploring several aspects of the nucleus.']
['What happened in 1929?', 'Another equally famous early accelerator is the cyclotron, invented in 1930 by the American physicist, E.O. Lawrence (1901–1958).']
['What was the figure that was used to show the relationship between the atoms?', 'Figure 23.8 is a visual representation with more detail.']
['What is the cyclotron?', 'Cyclotrons use fixed-frequency alternating electric fields to accelerate particles.']
['What does the magnetic field do?', 'The particles spiral outward in a magnetic field, making increasingly larger radius orbits during acceleration.']
['What happens after that?', 'This clever arrangement allows the successive addition of electric potential energy with each loop.']
['What happens when it is fully charged?', 'As a result, greater particle energies are possible than in a Van de Graaff generator.']
['What is a synchrotron?', 'A synchrotron is a modification of the cyclotron in which particles continually travel in a fixed-radius orbit, increasing speed each time.']
['What is a synchrotron used for?', 'Accelerating voltages are synchronized with the particles to accelerate them, hence the name.']
['What can synchrotron be used for?', 'Additionally, magnetic field strength is increased to keep the orbital radius constant as energy increases.']
['What are the major components of synchrotrons?', 'A ring of magnets and accelerating tubes, as shown in Figure 23.9, are the major components of synchrotrons.']
['What is a superconductor used for?', 'High-energy particles require strong magnetic fields to steer them, so superconducting magnets are commonly employed.']

['What other interesting information do you want to know about the synchrotron?', 'Still limited by achievable magnetic field strengths, synchrotrons need to be very large at very high energies since the radius of a high-energy particle’s orbit is very large.']
['What do physicists need to further probe the nucleus?', 'To further probe the nucleus, physicists need accelerators of greater energy and detectors of shorter wavelength.']
['How is this accomplished?', 'To do so requires not only greater funding but greater ingenuity as well.']

['What is the purpose of the beams used at Fermilab and the LHC?', 'Colliding beams used at both the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab; see Figure 23.11) near Chicago and the LHC in Switzerland are designed to reduce energy loss in particle collisions.']
['What is the main function of a stationary particle detector?', 'Typical stationary particle detectors lose a large amount of energy to the recoiling target struck by the accelerating particle.']

['How do colliding beams work?', 'By providing head-on collisions between particles moving in opposite directions, colliding beams make it possible to create particles with momenta and kinetic energies near zero.']
['What happens when the particles of matter combine?', 'This allows for particles of greater energy and mass to be created.']
['What is the schematic representation of this effect?', 'Figure 23.10 is a schematic representation of this effect.']
['What is the main purpose of linear accelerators?', 'In addition to circular accelerators, linear accelerators can be used to reduce energy radiation losses.']

['What is the largest linear accelerator in the world?', 'The Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (now called the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory) in California is home to the largest such accelerator in the world.']
['What did Isaac Newton say about atoms and space?', '“The first principles of the universe are atoms and empty space.']
['What else did he say?', 'Everything else is merely thought to exist…”']

['Is there any information provided about quarks in the article?', '“… Further, the atoms are unlimited in size and number, and they are borne along with the whole universe in a vortex, and thereby generate all composite things—fire, water, air, earth.']
['Does this article go into detail about why all composite things are made of atoms?', 'For even these are conglomerations of given atoms.']
['What is the most important thing to know about atoms?', 'And it because of their solidity that these atoms are impassive and unalterable.”']
["What was Diogenes Laertius' view of fundamental particles?", 'The search for fundamental particles is nothing new.']

['What were the earlier views on fundamental particles?', 'Atomists of the Greek and Indian empires, like Democritus of fifth century B.C., openly wondered about the most finite components of our universe.']

['What was significant about this view?', 'Though dormant for centuries, curiosity about the atomic nature of matter was reinvigorated by Rutherford’s gold foil experiment and the discovery of the nucleus.']

['What were the smallest particles that scientists have observed?', 'By the early 1930s, scientists believed they had fully determined the tiniest constituents of matter—in the form of the proton, neutron, and electron.']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to Py?', 'This would be only partially true.']
['What is the article about?', 'At present, scientists know that there are hundreds of particles not unlike our electron and nucleons, all making up what some have termed the particle zoo.']

['What else did they find in the zoo?', 'While we are confident that the electron remains fundamental, it is surrounded by a plethora of similar sounding terms, like leptons, hadrons, baryons, and mesons.']

['What is the difference between fundamental and non-fundamental particles?', 'Even though not every particle is considered fundamental, they all play a vital role in understanding the intricate structure of our universe.']
['What is the definition of a fundamental particle?', 'A fundamental particle is defined as a particle with no substructure and no finite size.']
['What are the three types of fundamental particles?', 'According to the Standard Model, there are three types of fundamental particles: leptons, quarks, and carrier particles.']

['What are the particles responsible for transmitting fundamental forces between their interacting masses?', 'As you may recall, carrier particles are responsible for transmitting fundamental forces between their interacting masses.']
['What are a group of six particles not bound by the strong nuclear force?', 'Leptons are a group of six particles not bound by the strong nuclear force, of which the electron is one.']

['What are the fundamental building blocks of a group of particles called hadrons?', 'As for quarks, they are the fundamental building blocks of a group of particles called hadrons, a group that includes both the proton and the neutron.']
['What is the major tenet of his theory of geometry?', 'Now for a brief history of quarks.']
['What physicists first proposed quarks?', 'Quarks were first proposed independently by American physicists Murray Gell-Mann and George Zweig in 1963.']
['What were the original 3 quarks proposed?', 'Originally, three quark types—or flavors—were proposed with the names up (u), down (d), and strange (s).']
['What is a fact about this chapter?', 'At first, physicists expected that, with sufficient energy, we should be able to free quarks and observe them directly.']

['How did this theory fail?', 'However, this has not proved possible, as the current understanding is that the force holding quarks together is incredibly great and, much like a spring, increases in magnitude as the quarks are separated.']
['What else is known about quarks?', 'As a result, when large energies are put into collisions, other particles are created—but no quarks emerge.']
['What is known about quarks?', 'With that in mind, there is compelling evidence for the existence of quarks.']

['What is this evidence?', 'By 1967, experiments at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory scattering 20-GeV electrons from protons produced results like Rutherford had obtained for the nucleus nearly 60 years earlier.']

['What was the study about?', 'The SLAC scattering experiments showed unambiguously that there were three point-like (meaning they had sizes considerably smaller than the probe’s wavelength) charges inside the proton as seen in Figure 23.12.']
['What evidence did he suggest?', 'This evidence made all but the most skeptical admit that there was validity to the quark substructure of hadrons.']
['What is the strange quark?', 'The inclusion of the strange quark with Zweig and Gell-Mann’s model concerned physicists.']

['What did he know about the strange quark?', 'While the up and down quarks demonstrated fairly clear symmetry and were present in common fundamental particles like protons and neutrons, the strange quark did not have a counterpart of its own.']
['What was his biggest concern?', 'This thought, coupled with the four known leptons at the time, caused scientists to predict that a fourth quark, yet to be found, also existed.']
['When did physicists discover a particle with this new quark?', 'In 1974, two groups of physicists independently discovered a particle with this new quark, labeled charmed.']
['What did this lead to?', 'This completed the second exotic quark pair, strange (s) and charmed (c).']
['When was the final pair of quarks proposed?', 'A final pair of quarks was proposed when a third pair of leptons was discovered in 1975.']
['What was the final pair of quarks?', 'The existence of the bottom (b) quark and the top (t) quark was verified through experimentation in 1976 and 1995, respectively.']

['Why was it so long between the discovery of the bottom quark and the verification of the top', 'While it may seem odd that so much time would elapse between the original quark discovery in 1967 and the verification of the top quark in 1995, keep in mind that each quark discovered had a progressively larger mass.']
['Why is that?', 'As a result, each new quark has required more energy to discover.']
['What kind of charge do quarks have?', 'One of the most confounding traits of quarks is their electric charge.']

['Why is this?', 'Long assumed to be discrete, and specifically a multiple of the elementary charge of the electron, the electric charge of an individual quark is fractional and thus seems to violate a presumed tenet of particle physics.']

['Are there any other important aspects of the charge?', 'The fractional charge of quarks, which are  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{2}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{1}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$, are the only structures found in nature with a nonintegral number of charge  $$\\(q\\)$$ .']
['Are there any other important aspects of the charges?', 'However, note that despite this odd construction, the fractional value of the quark does not violate the quantum nature of the charge.']

['Does this violate the quantum nature of the charge?', 'After all, free quarks cannot be found in nature, and all quarks are bound into arrangements in which an integer number of charge is constructed.']
['What are some other quarks?', 'Table 23.3 shows the six known quarks, in addition to their antiquark components, as will be discussed later in this section.']

['What is the distinction between flavor and color?', 'While the term flavor is used to differentiate between types of quarks, the concept of color is more analogous to the electric charge in that it is primarily responsible for the force interactions between quarks.']
['What does he say the electrostatic force is responsible for?', 'Note—Take a moment to think about the electrostatic force.']
['What causes attraction and repulsion?', 'It is the electric charge that causes attraction and repulsion.']
['Is that the same as flavor?', 'It is the same case here but with a color charge.']

['What are the three colors available to a quark?', 'The three colors available to a quark are red, green, and blue, with antiquarks having colors of anti-red (or cyan), anti-green (or magenta), and anti-blue (or yellow).']
['What is an example of a question that you found interesting in this material?', 'After all, the quarks are not actually colored with visible light.']
['What is the reason quarks are described as colors?', 'The reason colors are used is because the properties of a quark are analogous to the three primary and secondary colors mentioned above.']
['What is the analogy to light?', 'Just as different colors of light can be combined to create white, different colors of quark may be combined to construct a particle like a proton or neutron.']
['What else did the writer say?', 'In fact, for each hadron, the quarks must combine such that their color sums to white!']
['What does combining different quarks produce?', 'Recall that two up quarks and one down quark construct a proton, as seen in Figure 23.12.']
['What is the sum of the three quarks’ colors?', 'The sum of the three quarks’ colors—red, green, and blue—yields the color white.']
['What is the theory of color interaction within particles called?', 'This theory of color interaction within particles is called quantum chromodynamics, or QCD.']
['What does this theory have to do with?', 'As part of QCD, the strong nuclear force can be explained using color.']
['What do scientists refer to as one of the four fundamental forces?', 'In fact, some scientists refer to the color force, not the strong force, as one of the four fundamental forces.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Figure 23.13 is a Feynman diagram showing the interaction between two quarks by using the transmission of a colored gluon.']
['What is a gluon?', 'Note that the gluon is also considered the charge carrier for the strong nuclear force.']
['What color is the quark flavor?', 'Note that quark flavor may have any color.']
['What color is the down quark in Figure 23.13?', 'For instance, in Figure 23.13, the down quark has a red color and a green color.']
['What is the difference between a quark and a particle?', 'In other words, colors are not specific to a particle quark flavor.']
['What can be revealingly grouped according to what forces they feel between them?', 'Particles can be revealingly grouped according to what forces they feel between them.']
['Are massless particles affected by gravity?', 'All particles (even those that are massless) are affected by gravity since gravity affects the space and time in which particles exist.']

['Are all charged particles affected by the electromagnetic force?', 'All charged particles are affected by the electromagnetic force, as are neutral particles that have an internal distribution of charge (such as the neutron with its magnetic moment).']
['What other types of particles are given special names?', 'Special names are given to particles that feel the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['Are there any other names for these types of particles?', 'Hadrons are particles that feel the strong nuclear force, whereas leptons are particles that do not.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'All particles feel the weak nuclear force.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that hadrons are distinguished by being able to feel both the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['What are the characteristics of hadrons?', 'Leptons and hadrons are distinguished in other ways as well.']
['What is unique about hadrons?', 'Leptons are fundamental particles that have no measurable size, while hadrons are composed of quarks and have a diameter on the order of 10–15 m.']
['What are the characteristics of the two types of particles?', 'Six particles, including the electron and neutrino, make up the list of known leptons.']
['What are some of the characteristics of hadrons?', 'There are hundreds of complex particles in the hadron class, a few of which (including the proton and neutron) are listed in Table 23.4.']
['What were the major scientific discoveries that led to a new understanding of hadrons?', 'There are many more leptons, mesons, and baryons yet to be discovered and measured.']

['What is the purpose of trying to uncover the smallest indivisible things in existence?', 'The purpose of trying to uncover the smallest indivisible things in existence is to explain the world around us through forces and the interactions between particles, galaxies and objects.']
['How do scientists get samples of small particles?', 'This is why a handful of scientists devote their life’s work to smashing together small particles.']
['What is a proton made of?', 'The proton, like all hadrons, is made up of quarks.']
['What kind of quarks are in hadrons?', 'A few examples of hadron quark composition can be seen in Figure 23.14.']
['What is shown in the figure?', 'As shown, each hadron is constructed of multiple quarks.']
['What is the particle called that has four quarks?', 'As mentioned previously, the fractional quark charge in all four hadrons sums to the particle’s integral value.']
['What does this mean?', 'Also, notice that the color composition for each of the four particles adds to white.']
['Are there any other interesting things I should know?', 'Each of the particles shown is constructed of up, down, and their antiquarks.']
['What is most surprising about this information?', 'This is not surprising, as the quarks strange, charmed, top, and bottom are found in only our most exotic particles.']
['What did you learn in your last section?', 'You may have noticed that while the proton and neutron in Figure 23.14 are composed of three quarks, both pions are comprised of only two quarks.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'This refers to a final delineation in particle structure.']
['What are particles with three quarks called?', 'Particles with three quarks are called baryons.']
['What is the term W boson?', 'These are heavy particles that can decay into another baryon.']
['What are particles with only two quarks called?', 'Particles with only two quarks—a-quark–anti-quark pair—are called mesons.']
['What is the term for particles of moderate mass that cannot decay into the more massive baryons?', 'These are particles of moderate mass that cannot decay into the more massive baryons.']
['What are some of the important terms associated with hadrons and leptons?', 'Before continuing, take a moment to view Figure 23.15.']
['What does this figure have to do with hadrons and leptons?', 'In this figure, you can see the strong force reimagined as a color force.']
['What are the particles interacting in this figure?', 'The particles interacting in this figure are the proton and neutron, just as they were in Figure 23.6.']

['What is the reenvisioning of the strong force as an interaction between colored quarks?', 'This reenvisioning of the strong force as an interaction between colored quarks is the critical concept behind quantum chromodynamics.']
['What is the biggest difference between matter and antimatter?', 'Antimatter was first discovered in the form of the positron, the positively charged electron.']
['Who discovered the positron?', 'In 1932, American physicist Carl Anderson discovered the positron in cosmic ray studies.']

['How did he discover it?', 'Through a cloud chamber modified to curve the trajectories of cosmic rays, Anderson noticed that the curves of some particles followed that of a negative charge, while others curved like a positive charge.']
['What was the difference between the positive and negative curves?', 'However, the positive curve showed not the mass of a proton but the mass of an electron.']

['What did he determine the mass of an electron by?', 'This outcome is shown in Figure 23.16 and suggests the existence of a positively charged version of the electron, created by the destruction of solar photons.']
['What is the opposite of matter?', 'Antimatter is considered the opposite of matter.']
['What is the opposite of matter?', 'For most antiparticles, this means that they share the same properties as their original particles with the exception of their charge.']
['What does the exception of their charge mean?', 'This is why the positron can be considered a positive electron while the antiproton is considered a negative proton.']

['How does this compare to neutral particles?', 'The idea of an opposite charge for neutral particles (like the neutron) can be confusing, but it makes sense when considered from the quark perspective.']

['Is the antineutron composed of one anti–up quark and two anti–down quarks?', 'Just as the neutron is composed of one up quark and two down quarks (of charge $$\\(+ \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$and $$\\(- \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively), the antineutron is composed of one anti–up quark and two anti–down quarks (of charge  $$\\(- \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$  and $$\\(+ \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively).']
['What is important about the neutron?', 'While the overall charge of the neutron remains the same, its constituent particles do not!']
['Did you learn anything about antimatter?', 'A word about antiparticles: Like regular particles, antiparticles could function just fine on their own.']
['What else did you learn about antimatter?', 'In fact, a universe made up of antimatter may operate just as our own matter-based universe does.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of the article?', 'However, we do not know fully whether this is the case.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'The reason for this is annihilation.']

['What is the process of destruction that occurs when a particle and its antiparticle interact?', 'Annihilation is the process of destruction that occurs when a particle and its antiparticle interact.']

['What do the particles do when they come together?', 'As soon as two particles (like a positron and an electron) coincide, they convert their masses to energy through the equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$ .']

['What makes it difficult for scientists to study antimatter?', 'This mass-to-energy conversion, which typically results in photon release, happens instantaneously and makes it very difficult for scientists to study antimatter.']
['Can you tell me anything else interesting?', 'That said, scientists have had success creating antimatter through high-energy particle collisions.']
['What kinds of antimatter has been created?', 'Both antineutrons and antiprotons were created through accelerator experiments in 1956, and an anti–hydrogen atom was even created at CERN in 1995!']

['What is the purpose of the annihilation of antiparticles?', 'As referenced in Figure 22.40, the annihilation of antiparticles is currently used in medical studies to determine the location of radioisotopes.']

['What is the current scientific view of the fundamental components and interacting forces of matter?', 'The Standard Model of the atom refers to the current scientific view of the fundamental components and interacting forces of matter.']

['What are the fundamental particles?', 'The Standard Model (Figure 23.17) shows the six quarks that bind to form all hadrons, the six lepton particles already considered fundamental, the four carrier particles (or gauge bosons) that transmit forces between the leptons and quarks, and the recently added Higgs boson (which will be discussed shortly).']
['How many fundamental particles do we have?', 'This totals 17 fundamental particles, combinations of which are responsible for all known matter in our entire universe!']
['Are there any other particles?', 'When adding the antiquarks and antileptons, 31 components make up the Standard Model.']
['What is Figure 23.17?', 'Figure 23.17 shows all particles within the Standard Model of the atom.']
['What is significant about this chart?', 'Not only does this chart divide all known particles by color-coded group, but it also provides information on particle stability.']
['What can you learn from this chart?', 'Note that the color-coding system in this chart is separate from the red, green, and blue color labeling system of quarks.']
['What can you find out about matter from this chart?', 'The first three columns represent the three families of matter.']
['What is Family 1?', 'The first column, considered Family 1, represents particles that make up normal matter, constructing the protons, neutrons, and electrons that make up the common world.']
['What is Family 2?', 'Family 2, represented from the charm quark to the muon neutrino, is comprised of particles that are more massive.']
['What is the difference between family 3 and family 2?', 'The leptons in this group are less stable and more likely to decay.']
['How is this different than Family 2?', 'Family 3, represented by the third column, are more massive still and decay more quickly.']
['How are these different?', 'The order of these families also conveniently represents the order in which these particles were discovered.']
['What is the Standard Model of the Atom?', 'The Standard Model also summarizes the fundamental forces that exist as particles interact.']
['What do the particles interact with?', 'A closer look at the Standard Model, as shown in Figure 23.18, reveals that the arrangement of carrier particles describes these interactions.']
['What is the model of the universe?', 'Each of the shaded areas represents a fundamental force and its constituent particles.']
['What are the forces represented?', 'The red shaded area shows all particles involved in the strong nuclear force, which we now know is due to quantum chromodynamics.']

['which other forces are represented?', 'The blue shaded area corresponds to the electromagnetic force, while the green shaded area corresponds to the weak nuclear force, which affects all quarks and leptons.']
['What happens to the forces?', 'The electromagnetic force and weak nuclear force are considered united by the electroweak force within the Standard Model.']
['Are there any more forces?', 'Also, because definitive evidence of the graviton is yet to be found, it is not included in the Standard Model.']
['What is the smallest mass particle?', 'One interesting feature of the Standard Model shown in Figure 23.18 is that, while the gluon and photon have no mass, the Z and W bosons are very massive.']
['What did Peter Higgs believe?', 'In the 1960s, British physicist Peter Higgs and others speculated that the W and Z bosons were actually just as massless as the gluon and photon.']

['Why did they believe the masses of particles were zero?', 'However, as the W and Z bosons traveled from one particle to another, they were slowed down by the presence of a Higgs field, much like a fish swimming through water.']
['How was the bosons slowed down?', 'The thinking was that the existence of the Higgs field would slow down the bosons, causing them to decrease in energy and thereby transfer this energy to mass.']
['What do they think?', 'Under this theory, all particles pass through the Higgs field, which exists throughout the universe.']
['Why did the gluon and photon not pass through this field?', 'The gluon and photon travel through this field as well but are able to do so unaffected.']
['What is the Higgs Boson?', 'The presence of a force from the Higgs field suggests the existence of its own carrier particle, the Higgs boson.']
['What theorized boson interacts with?', 'This theorized boson interacts with all particles but gluons and photons, transferring force from the Higgs field.']
['What are some of the particles that it interacts with?', 'Particles with large mass (like the top quark) are more likely to receive force from the Higgs boson.']
['What is an example of a particle?', 'While it is difficult to examine a field, it is somewhat simpler to find evidence of its carrier.']
['When did scientists discover the Higgs-like particle?', 'On July 4, 2012, two groups of scientists at the LHC independently confirmed the existence of a Higgs-like particle.']
['How did they do this?', 'By examining trillions of proton–proton collisions at energies of 7 to 8 TeV, LHC scientists were able to determine the constituent particles that created the protons.']

['What was the most significant part of the discovery?', 'In this data, scientists found a particle with similar mass, spin, parity, and interactions with other particles that matched the Higgs boson predicted decades prior.']
['What did CERN say about the discovery?', 'On March 13, 2013, the existence of the Higgs boson was tentatively confirmed by CERN.']

['Did they win any awards?', 'Peter Higgs and Francois Englert received the Nobel Prize in 2013 for the “theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin and mass of subatomic particles.”']
['What is Understanding the Grand Unified Theory about?', 'Present quests to show that the four basic forces are different manifestations of a single unified force that follow a long tradition.']

['What are the four basic forces?', 'In the nineteenth century, the distinct electric and magnetic forces were shown to be intimately connected and are now collectively called the electromagnetic force.']
['What other forces are involved in the theory?', 'More recently, the weak nuclear force was united with the electromagnetic force.']
['What is important about the theory?', 'As shown in Figure 23.19, carrier particles transmit three of the four fundamental forces in very similar ways.']

['Are the basic forces all connected?', 'With these considerations in mind, it is natural to suggest that a theory may be constructed in which the strong nuclear, weak nuclear, and electromagnetic forces are all unified.']
['What is the search for a correct theory linking the forces called?', 'The search for a correct theory linking the forces, called the Grand Unified Theory (GUT), is explored in this section.']
['Who developed the electroweak theory?', 'In the 1960s, the electroweak theory was developed by Steven Weinberg, Sheldon Glashow, and Abdus Salam.']
['What is the electroweak theory?', 'This theory proposed that the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are identical at sufficiently high energies.']
['How are these forces identical?', 'At lower energies, like those in our present-day universe, the two forces remain united but manifest themselves in different ways.']

['What were some of the main consequences of the electroweak theory?', 'One of the main consequences of the electroweak theory was the prediction of three short-range carrier particles, now known as the  $$\\(W^{+},\\)$$ $$\\(W^{-},\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons.']

['What other consequences did it have?', 'Not only were three particles predicted, but the mass of each  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 81 GeV/c2, and that of the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 90 GeV/c2.']

['What was evidence of this theory?', 'In 1983, these carrier particles were observed at CERN with the predicted characteristics, including masses having those predicted values as given in Figure 23.17.']
['Are they the same thing?', 'They are definitely distinct under most circumstances.']
['How are they different?', 'For example, they are carried by different particles and have greatly different strengths.']

['What happens when the conditions are altered?', 'But experiments show that at extremely short distances and at extremely high energies, the strengths of the forces begin to become more similar, as seen in Figure 23.20.']
['What is the most important information?', 'As discussed earlier, the short ranges and large masses of the weak carrier bosons require correspondingly high energies to create them.']

['What else did the article cover?', 'Thus, the energy scale on the horizontal axis of Figure 23.20 also corresponds to shorter and shorter distances (going from left to right), with 100 GeV corresponding to approximately 10−18 m, for example.']
['What is the distance between the two objects?', 'At that distance, the strengths of the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are the same.']
['What was the energy of the system?', 'To test this, energies of about 100 GeV are put into the system.']
['What is the outcome of the reaction?', 'When this occurs, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  carrier particles are created and released.']

['What other information was included?', 'At those and higher energies, the masses of the carrier particles become less and less relevant, and the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson in particular resembles the massless, chargeless photon.']

['What else is mentioned in the article?', 'As further energy is added, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  particles are further transformed into massless carrier particles even more similar to photons and gluons.']

['What is the most important point made in the article Understanding the Grand Unified Theory?', 'The extremely short distances and high energies at which the electroweak force becomes identical with the strong nuclear force are not reachable with any conceivable human-built accelerator.']
['How do scientists use the theory to find a new way to measure energy?', 'At energies of about 1014 GeV (16,000 J per particle), distances of about 10 to 30 m can be probed.']

['How are they testing the theory directly?', 'Such energies are needed to test the theory directly, but these are about 1010 times higher than the maximum energy associated with the LHC, and the distances are about 10 to 12 smaller than any structure we have direct knowledge of.']

['What would be the realm of various GUTs, of which there are many, since there is no constraining evidence at these energies and distances?', 'This would be the realm of various GUTs, of which there are many, since there is no constraining evidence at these energies and distances.']
['How is the theory different from others?', 'Past experience has shown that anytime you probe so many orders of magnitude further, you find the unexpected.']

['What kind of theories result in the same consequences?', 'However, not all theories result in the same consequences.']

['What does it mean that all theories will not result in the same consequences?', 'Much of the science we accept in our everyday lives is based on different models, each with their own strengths and limitations.']
['What is important about strengths and limitations?', 'Although a particular model may have drawbacks, that does not necessarily mean that it should be discounted completely.']
['What is one consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed?', 'One consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed is proton decay.']
['What can you tell me about the hypothesis?', 'Multiple current GUTs hypothesize that the stable proton should actually decay at a lifetime of 1031 years.']

['What time do scientists believe it is?', 'While this time is incredibly large (keep in mind that the age of the universe is less than 14 billion years), scientists at the Super-Kamiokande in Japan have used a 50,000-ton tank of water to search for its existence.']

['What was the purpose of the Super-Kamiokande tank?', 'The decay of a single proton in the Super-Kamiokande tank would be observed by a detector, thereby providing support for the predicting GUT model.']
['How did the experiment go?', 'However, as of 2014, 17 years into the experiment, decay is yet to be found.']
['What does the lack of decay mean?', 'This time span equates to a minimum limit on proton life of  $$\\(5.9\\  \\times \\ 10^{33}\\)$$ years.']
['What would this result mean for the theory?', 'While this result certainly does not support many grand unifying theories, an acceptable model may still exist.']
['What is the relationship between the macroscopic and microscopic worlds?', 'Nature is full of examples where the macroscopic and microscopic worlds intertwine.']

['Is there anything else interesting that you learned from reading?', 'Fusion of nuclei likewise explains the energy of stars.']
['What is the most important thing that you learned about the passage?', 'Today, the patterns in particle physics seem to be explaining the evolution and character of the universe.']
['What is the nature of the universe?', 'And the nature of the universe has implications for unexplored regions of particle physics.']

['What did Edwin Hubble observe in 1929?', 'In 1929, Edwin Hubble observed that all but the closest galaxies surrounding our own had a red shift in their hydrogen spectra that was proportional to their distance from us.']
['What did this discovery mean?', 'Applying the Doppler Effect, Hubble recognized that this meant that all galaxies were receding from our own, with those farther away receding even faster.']
['What did this discovery lead to?', 'Knowing that our place in the universe was no more unique than any other, the implication was clear:']
['What was discovered?', 'The space within the universe itself was expanding.']
['What does expanding mean?', 'Just like pen marks on an expanding balloon, everything in the universe was accelerating away from everything else.']
['What is the big bang?', 'Figure 23.21 shows how the recession of galaxies looks like the remnants of a gigantic explosion, the famous Big Bang.']
['How long ago was the Big Bang?', 'Extrapolating backward in time, the Big Bang would have occurred between 13 and 15 billion years ago, when all matter would have been at a single point.']
['How did that change the way things were?', 'From this, questions instantly arise.']

['What do you know about the Big Bang?', 'Knowing this, let’s move forward from the start of the universe, beginning with the Big Bang, as illustrated in Figure 23.22.']
['What was the next chapter?', 'The Planck Epoch $$\\(\\left( {0\\rightarrow 10^{-43}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['What were the results?', 'As a result, modern cosmology suggests that all four forces would have existed as one force, a hypothetical superforce as suggested by the Theory of Everything.']

['What does the thermodynamic model help explain?', 'As a result, gravity separates, leaving the electroweak and strong nuclear forces together.']

['What is the next chapter?', 'The Inflationary Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{- 36}\\rightarrow 10^{- 32}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['What is the next title of your study material?', 'The Electroweak Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{-32}\\rightarrow 10^{-11}s} \\right)\\)$$']
